PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

PARA.TAB: Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469, 274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:
Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms
Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:
ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms
Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty The Queen of Australia our head of State and as in duty bound will every pray. God save The Queen.

PETITION.TITLE: Consumption Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned,

PETITION.PARA: (i)are alarmed by talk of a consumption (goods and services) tax which we feel would have a devastating effect on the lives of the people on low to middle incomes.
(ii)call on the Senate to express its total opposition to the introduction of a consumption (goods and services) tax.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully call on the Government to withdraw its endorsement from the arms bazaar, AIDEX `91, scheduled to be held in Canberra, 26-28 November, 1991, and to ensure that no government department or company takes part in the aforementioned event.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
The Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:

There is widespread concern and outrage in the international community about the Salvadoran government's treatment of its returning refugee and internally displaced population. Since the signing of the San Jose Agreement on Human Rights by the Salvadoran government and the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front under the mediation of the United Nations, we have been hopeful for an improvement in the Salvadoran government's treatment of its civilian population, particularly those in the repatriate communities and the social movement. Every Article of the Agreement under Section 1. Respect for and Guarantee of Human Rights, has been violated by the Salvadoran government and its armed forces. The international community is aware more than ever before of the systematic intimidation and harassment including capture, torture, rape and murder of members of repatriate communities and the social movement by the Salvadoran armed forces.

We can only conclude that the Salvadoran government's lack of control of its armed forces is indicative of its own lack of real commitment to a negotiated peaceful solution to the civil war. It appears, furthermore, that the Salvadoran government is unwilling to honour Agreements to which it is signatory, including international Conventions on Human Rights, and in doing so places itself above international law.

The international community, including the Australian government, has a common interest in the peaceful resolution to the conflict and the initiation of a genuine free democratic process in El Salvador. We therefore call upon the Australian government to:
(1)Use all diplomatic channels available to urge the Salvadoran government to:

TAB.TAB: (a)respect the rights of returning refugees, internally displaced people's and community organisations,
(b)order the armed forces to comply with the San Jose Agreement.

PARA.TAB: (2)Urge the US Administration to convert all military and associated aid to humanitarian development processes.
(3)Involve itself in direct support for the UN Verification Commission (ONUSAL).
(4)Provide a special fund for Australian non-government organisations working with social movements and repatriate communities in El Salvador.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VALLENTINE

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to present to the Senate a petition which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders as it is not in the correct form.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

Senator VALLENTINE—I present to the Senate the following petition from 10 petitioners requesting the Australian Government to withdraw from AIDEX 91, end support for companies trading in arms represented at AIDEX 91, and cease arms sales to foreign governments:

SPEECH.PARA: AIDEX `91 (The Australian International Defence Equipment Exhibition) will take place in Canberra on November 26-28. It will be the largest arms fair yet held in this region. Currently AIDEX has Australian Government approval and involvement.

Promoting the arms trade is an immoral and short-sighted policy. Trading in arms is a constant provocation to war. Domestic oppression and international aggression are its results. Arms purchases by countries in the Asian-Pacific region divert resources from much needed peaceful development, health, education and social welfare. The Australian Government should not be seeking a short term response to the present economic crisis by involvement in this trade and should embark on a strategy to ensure that arms manufacture is confined to our legitimate defence needs.

We need to heed the lessons of the Gulf War. Without the complicity of legitimate and illicit arms traders this war could not have occurred. Ordinary citizens in Europe and North America were scandalised to find that their respectable corporations were deeply involved in arming Iraq. Australians in the future do not want to be similarly compromised.

At a time when the major powers are reducing their arsenals and their arms trade, it is indefensible for the Australian Government to be expanding its involvement in the promotion, manufacture and export of weapons, arms components and support services.
We call on the Australian Government to:

PARA.TAB: Withdraw from AIDEX `91
End support for companies trading in arms represented at AIDEX `91
Cease arms sales to foreign governments

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CALVERT

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to present to the Senate a petition which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders as it is not in the correct form.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

Senator CALVERT—I present the following petition from 107 petitioners from Southern Cross Homes Incorporated who are disturbed at the use of public funds to produce R-rated films which can only serve further to undermine community standards and behaviour:
Southern Cross Homes Incorporated
Caring for the Aged
A Charitable Activity of the Knights
of the Southern Cross

PARA.TAB: N.S.W. Head Office: Cardinal Gilroy Village,

TAB.TAB: Barcom Street, Merrylands, N.S.W. 2160

SPEECH.PARA: To Senator Paul Calvert
Parliament House
Sydney

PARA.TAB: 23rd Nov. 1991

SPEECH.PARA: Sir,
Like you, we the undersigned, are disturbed at the use of public funds to produce an R-rated film, which can only serve further to undermine community standards of behaviour.
One would have thought that Annie Sprinkle, ex-prostitute and porn actress, would be the last person to speak to us about the meaning of sexuality.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—These sorts of petitions are presented on a non-broadcast day, but I believe that there is a weakness in the system that such petitions are read out virtually in full whereas other petitions are not. It may be becoming a device, though I am not saying that was the case today. Maybe, Mr President, you could look at having this procedure continued with, but with none of the content read to the Senate.
—It is only a summary, but I think Senator Calvert went further than the usual summary. I will investigate the position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPINDLER

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to present to the Senate a petition which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders as it is not in the correct form.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

Senator SPINDLER—I present to the Senate the following petition from 2,065 citizens requesting that the Senate urge the Government to reduce expenditure on defence and use the money saved for the needs of the community and the environment:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia humbly showeth:
That currently Australia's military expenditure is $8,327 million a year, i.e. over $22 million a day:
That the 1989 Environmental Land Package allowed $320 million to be spent on the environment over the next ten years, but that this
is less than the cost of one Anzac frigate (initially $416 million)
or less than half the cost of one submarine ($644 million);
That Project Kangaroo 1989 military exercise cost $230 million in three months, more than two-thirds the sum allotted to the environment for ten years;
That, in the meantime we urgently need more money for

SPEECH.PARA: housing for the homeless,
safer and more efficient public transport,
more hospital staff and beds,
better health services, education, child care, etc.;

PARA.TAB: That while we recognise the need for legitimate spending on defence, we consider that current expenditure and projected development of Australian military capacity far exceeds that required to maintain Australian security;

That we believe a reduction in our military build up would, in fact, contribute to peace and security in our region, and therefore appeal to the Government to reduce expenditure on armaments and use the money thus saved for the needs of the community and the environment.
And we, your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

(ii)the removal of sales tax on all vehicles, including farm vehicles which are not exempt at the moment, and

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —

TAB.TAB: (i)the tax and economic reform package announced by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has been in the public domain for a full week, and

PARA.TAB: (b)calls on the Government, because of its inability to find fault with the tax and economic reform package, to support the package publicly and immediately so that the people of Australia will be left in no doubt whatsoever that it is the only feasible solution to our current economic malaise and should be implemented as soon as possible; and

(c)requests that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) inform the Governor-General that his Government is unable to govern this nation effectively and that, as a result, both Houses of Federal Parliament should be dissolved and a full election should be held as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —
(a)welcomes the decision of the Liberal and National parties to ensure all educational services will not be subject to the goods and services tax;
(b)notes that, as a result of the proposed abolition of seven taxes, including the wholesale sales tax, payroll tax and customs duty, the actual costs of educational services will be reduced; and

(c)welcomes the policy of the Liberal and National parties to provide $3 billion additional spending for education to the year 2000, including increased resources for higher education, TAFE and schools.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —

(a)notes that one of Queensland's major tour bus operators calculates that, with the implementation of the `Fightback' package announced by Dr Hewson, it would save $1,953,000 on the fuel used in its last year's operations, a further $100,000 would be saved by the abolition of the Government's wholesale sales tax on tyres, and there could be a further savings of $125,000 on the Government's wholesale sales tax on spare parts and maintenance; and

(b)congratulates the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and the Liberal and National parties for proposing the abolition of excise on fuel, which will substantially boost the ability of average Australians to travel to tourist destinations in Queensland by motor vehicle.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —

(a)notes that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), after carping about a lack of information on the Opposition's reform proposals over the past 18 months, has failed to acknowledge the Government's total inability to match the depth and breadth of the `Fightback' documentation, refused to accept the opportunity to debate the subject with Dr Hewson in the Parliament, and shown appalling lack of leadership or direction for both Government members of parliament and the people of Australia; and
(b)calls on the Prime Minister to:

TAB.TAB: (i)demonstrate his concern for `the course' the Government has taken which, by his policies over eight years, has brought to this country almost one million unemployed, uncontrolled overseas debt, a falling comparative international standard of living and growing bankruptcies of businesses, industries and farming, and

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —
(a)notes with dismay the intolerable figure of 30 per cent youth unemployment and a total of nearly 1.5 million Australians unable to find the work they seek;

(b)condemns the Government for its passive approach to the unemployment problem and for its callous lack of regard for the needs of the young people in our society who are shouldering a disproportionate burden of the recession that former failed Treasurer (Mr Keating) said we had to have; and

(c)welcomes with relief the visionary policies of the Coalition's `Fightback' package which give hope to youth by spelling out our new initiatives for the unemployed, which will restore job growth, expand education and training programs, and enable earlier access for the unemployed to programs that combine both employment and training.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

I have not yet heard whether they are ready to proceed. As for the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4), I conveyed to the Government this morning that that Bill also had had amendments produced, I think the night before last, that there were still matters being discussed by the shadow Ministry, and that we would not be able to proceed with that at present. TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—It is a fairly complicated program because of various requirements. Certainly the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Bill (No. 2) 1991 has been put on first, hoping that some of these other things can get sorted out. I have no information on that.

—I suggest that the motion be put that we proceed with the program up to the Veterans Affairs' Legislation Amendment bill (No. 2) 1991, and then have another motion to go on after that when we are ready.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA

TALK.START.PARA: —A message has been received from the House of Representatives requesting the concurrence of the Senate in a resolution inviting the President of the United States of America to address both Houses of Parliament. Copies of the message have been circulated in the chamber.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Robert Ray)—by leave—proposed:
(1) That the Senate:

TAB.TAB: (a)invites the President of the United States of America to address the Senate, on 2 January 1992 at a time to be fixed by the President and notified to all Senators;
(b)accepts the invitation of the House of Representatives to meet with that House for that purpose; and
(c)concurs in the provisions of the resolution of the House relating to the conduct of that meeting.

PARA.TAB: (2)That this resolution be communicated to the House of Representatives by message.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have only just received a copy of this motion. I must say that it is not in the form that I was anticipating. I knew that the House of Representatives was inviting Mr Bush to address the House and that the House was inviting the Senate to be present, but I was not aware that the Senate was inviting Mr Bush to address the Senate in the House of Representatives. That approach is unprecedented. The Government has obviously decided that it wants to do it in this form: that it wants the Senate to issue such an invitation. It is not unreasonable for me to say that I would like those on this side of the chamber to have an opportunity to consider what is now being put to us. I would like the matter to be deferred and dealt with later in the day.
—The CIA will be on to you blokes for rejecting Bush's offer.

—Senator Schacht tries to turn this into a joke. It is a serious matter. We welcome President Bush's visit. Members of the House of Representatives have made the decision that they want him to address the Parliament in the House of Representatives. I do not have any problem with that aspect. But the second part, which is the motion that the Government is now seeking us to agree to this morning without notice, does set a precedent in that, as I said, it is seeking us to now invite the President to address the Senate in the House of Representatives. It is an unusual form and it is reasonable that we have time to consider it.

—by leave—I do not rule out a delay and reconsideration later. The Clerk has tried to assist me in this matter. It is for the Parliament to invite the President, not the House of Representatives or the Senate. Both Houses are inviting the President to address a joint session on this occasion. Notwithstanding tradition, Charles I and all the rest of it, on this occasion the sitting will be in the House of Representatives—it is its one turn a century, I suppose—whereas the rest of the joint sittings are always held in the Senate. I understand that clause (a), which states that the Senate invite the President of the United States, is just to replicate what the House of Representatives has done because it needs to be a joint invitation. We have equal powers.
—It should be the President and the Speaker, surely.

—Senator Reid says that the President of the Senate should invite the President of the United States. I am not sure about that technical difficulty. Quite clearly, at least one side of the chamber—maybe both—is suffering from a surfeit of information. I would move that this matter be adjourned and reconsidered at 1 o'clock this day when I will be back on duty.
—The President should be presiding with the Speaker.

—I believe that I will, just as in the last joint sitting here that I chaired the then Speaker, Joan Child, sat to my left. I have been drawn into a debate that I did not want to be drawn into. My advice from the Clerk is that I have to call a meeting of the Senate. The Senate has to decide whether it will then go to the House of Representatives for the meeting.
—I am happy to move that the matter be adjourned until 1 o'clock. Therefore, I move:

PARA.TAB: That the debate be now adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make one point. It seems to me that another point has been overlooked, and that is in the wording. It concerns what Senator Hill was referring to and not what Senator Robert Ray has picked up. The motion says:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)invites the President of the United States of America to address the Senate. . .

My understanding is that the Senate is the Senate when we as senators are sitting in this chamber. We are not the Senate when we are sitting in the House of Representatives. I draw attention to that point. Possibly some change in the wording is necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe it will be a sitting of the Senate in the House of Representatives chamber. However, we are considering whether this matter should be adjourned now.

—Mr President, when this matter is reconsidered at 1 o'clock, could you outline to the Senate specifically your role and give us an assurance that in the discharge of your duties the dignity and position of this Senate will be upheld?
—Yes, I will undertake to make a statement at the same time setting out the full procedural details of what at this stage I expect to happen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting the motion concerning the adjournment of this matter, I noticed—and I have not had the opportunity to raise this with Senator Hill, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate—that yesterday when this matter was discussed in the House of Representatives, Dr Hewson was trying to raise a point. However, he was quite rudely cut off in mid-sentence—this does not happen with your rulings, Mr President—and he was not allowed to proceed with the very serious matter relating to what would happen at the proceedings. According to the House of Representatives rules that have been laid down, which apparently form part of this message, I understand that the only person to speak will be the Speaker of the House of Representatives. Paragraphs 3(a) and 3(b) of the message state:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)the Speaker shall preside at the meeting;
(b)the only proceedings shall be an address by the President . . . after which the Speaker shall forthwith adjourn the House and declare the meeting concluded. . .

Dr Hewson was making the very real point—or was trying to before he was cut off—that in an Australian parliament the Speaker of the House does not have the same sort of status as the Speaker of the House has in the United States. Dr Hewson was proposing that there be a short address of welcome by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and by himself—very short, not a speech. Those are matters which Senator Ray might like to consider between now and 1 o'clock so that the matter can be fully debated and fully considered at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on this motion to adjourn this matter. Mr President, I wonder whether, when you come back to this chamber to provide a report to the Senate on this matter, you could provide the reasons why we are breaking with all previous precedents and have decided for the first time, from my understanding of what Senator Ray said, to join the honourable members in the House of Representatives chamber.
—I said that I would make a full statement. However, it will be the Senate that makes the decision, not me. The Senate, when it adopts a motion, will make the decision.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures on the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991, together with the submissions and transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures was formed to investigate the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991, which had already attracted almost total community condemnation. This legislation seeks to ban political advertising on the electronic media during Federal, State and local government elections and by-elections, which we discovered could mean as much as a 16-week ban in a given year. This legislation seeks to introduce transparent electoral funding through disclosure of political donations as long as that protected species—and I refer to the unions—still seemed to roam free. This legislation would cut to the quick that most major element of democracy—freedom of speech. This legislation would discriminate against the print handicapped, the rural community and our migrant population.

PARA.TAB: Despite all but seven of over 100 written submissions, and all but four witnesses, opposing the Bill, the majority report refused to take heed of the damage the political agenda would cause. I would go further to say that a number of witnesses were pressured—harangued by some, one would argue: for example, the Law Council of Australia—

TALK.START.PARA: —Intimidated.

—Some witnesses were intimidated in the line of questioning. Hansard shows that a number of the witnesses were treated with perhaps little respect. With the aid of selective and out of context quoting of the evidence, we have the majority members of the Committee, the Labor members, painting a distorted picture of community acceptance that the amended Bill allays most of the human rights complaints against a ban on political advertising. That is absolutely untrue. The report creates an impression that the Committee heard evidence to substantiate the necessity of such a ban to halt Federal political corruption. That is absolutely untrue. No such evidence was forthcoming and no instances of Federal political corruption were presented to the Committee. Instead, what we did uncover was that countries with a political ad ban had widespread and deeply embedded political campaign corruption.

PARA.TAB: The report is a reflection only of the Australian Labor Party's agenda on this subject. It is a transparent effort to wipe out electronic political advertising because the Government is so on the nose with the community, and so in debt from the last campaign, that there are simply no funds to pay for an electronic campaign at the next election.

Interestingly—and I think this shows the hypocrisy of the move—statistics before the Committee revealed that the Labor Party, far from actually considering electronic media advertising unnecessary, had increased its spending in this area significantly in the last Federal election campaign while other parties had spent less than they usually did or somewhere about the same.

This has been a totally hypocritical exercise from beginning to end. This is again evident in the majority report's lack of resolve to tackle full, fair and equitable disclosure. Full disclosure of political donations to the Labor members of the Committee meant disclosure which kept union donations to the ALP still hidden and which protected Government donations to politically active third parties. It meant disclosure as long as the union movement and therefore the ALP retained their quite significant taxation advantages. It meant disclosure as long as the indirect electoral funding advantage of the incumbent governments through staffing, government advertising and use of equipment remained protected. So what are we left with now?

TALK.START.PARA: —A good report.

—I can assure Senator Aulich that that is only in the eyes of the beholder. The report erroneously still recommends a ban on paid political advertising on the electronic media during campaigns. We are told that free time donated by the television and radio networks is to take its place. That free time was condemned by Minister Beazley on 9 May in his second reading speech on this very Bill. I quote Minister Beazley:

SPEECH.PARA: Free time would unfairly advantage the major political and incumbent parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will agree with that.

—I am glad Senator Ray agrees with me. We have a select committee recommending that very course. I agree with it also, Senator Ray: this is free time which the networks will have to pay for while, unjustly, direct mail companies, advertising agencies and the print media will find themselves the recipients of a revenue bonanza in the face of the ban on paid political electronic advertising. Free time and talking heads do not remove the free speech concerns of the Human Rights Commissioner or those put forward by Australia's top constitutional lawyers—that problem remains.

PARA.TAB: As Deputy Chairman of the Committee, I have, with Senator Kemp, produced a dissenting report—in what was a limited time frame at the end—which to some degree redresses the balance of the majority report. I bring to the Senate's attention that the recommendations in the majority report are not a true reflection of the evidence before the Committee but a sad reflection of the Government using the political process to resolve its own party political problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak very briefly on the report of the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures as a member of the Committee.
—You predetermined your ideas. You wasted your time.

—My views have not been predetermined. They were never predetermined. To a large extent my views were influenced by what was said on this Committee and by some of the questions, for example, that Democrat Senator Cheryl Kernot raised. She raised a number of questions, as a third party force in a sense, which made me think about the whole question of how this potential Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill affects all parties and independents running for the Senate and the House of Representatives.

PARA.TAB: The issue at hand is whether or not speech is free if one needs to pay $50,000 for a 30-second advertisement on Sydney prime time television. It is not free if political parties have to spend something like $16m to put their case before the electorate in a few weeks leading up to an election. Free speech is not free if, for example, the forest industries—as laudable as their viewpoints may be—can spend a million dollars on television before an election campaign, when their opponents, the conservation interests, can spend only about $28,000 on radio mainly because they cannot afford television.

One does not have free speech if the people who can buy the most advertising and who can buy the most effective advertising agencies are going to dominate the agenda leading up to election day. That is not free speech and yet Senator Parer says that my views were predetermined before I sat on that Committee. My views were affected by the evidence that came before us and particularly the evidence that updated the costs of running electronic media campaigns during an election. It worried me even more when we came out of it.

My views were also affected by what I saw in the United States and by my continuing links with United States senators and members of the House of Representatives. I know that every week the average incumbent senator in the United States has to raise $10,000 in order to run what is considered to be a moderate campaign for his or her election. In the United States Congress, the senators and House of Representatives members are most concerned about who they have to meet and what dinners they have to speak at in order to raise enough money to be competitive.

We know what has happened in the United States: 25 per cent of the eligible voters voted for Ronald Reagan to be President and 50 per cent of the eligible voters did not bother to vote in the presidential election campaign. That figure has been consistent in the last four American elections. Why? Because they know that their Congress has been bought. They know that money talks in the American political system.

Australia was going down that track; $30m-odd was spent on the last election campaign. Where does the money come from? It comes from people who want to buy influence. Obviously, they have not been able to do that with the Labor Party; but the danger is always there. I admit that in certain areas around Australia money has bought influence with all political parties. We now have a choice to make as a parliament. We are going to say, `Enough is enough. Those with money will not buy this Parliament and they will not buy the State parliaments around Australia'. Honourable senators can rest assured that if we do not make a decision in the next year or so about cutting the costs of Federal and State election campaigns we will make all political parties vulnerable to the persuasion of those people with money who want to stand over those parties and subtly gain influence—not only at a party level but also at an individual level.

If those opposite want to come into this Parliament and say they have been bought and they want to live with the fact that they have been bought, then they should disregard this report and vote against any Bill to control the dramatic escalation of election costs in this country. Someone said to me—and it came through in the submission of the Liberal Party to this Committee—that there is no political corruption in Australia; it is not significant.

We have had a royal commission in Tasmania where the then Premier of the State handled $10,000 and got his teenage son to count the $10,000 that had been given to the Premier by a political donor. In the same State, evidence was given before that royal commission that money which was gained through the silver ingoting of waste products from television and newspapers was put into football socks, translated into cash and then given to people in order to buy political favours.

In Western Australia we have had allegations that undue influence was brought to bear on governments by people with money. That is the other side of the political coin. I am not playing political favourites in this place. In Queensland we have had a situation where systematic corruption of the police and the political system has been proved in court and by Drummond. We have had situations in New South Wales where both political parties have agreed that political corruption has been systematic and has been sufficient to distort the political process.

What other proof do we need that political corruption is sitting on the doorstep of most Australian parliaments? The temptation for political parties to allow themselves to be influenced by those with money—the influence peddlers and influence buyers—is there in front of us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the unions.

—I am talking about political corruption. Right throughout the hearings, all we heard from the people representing the Liberal Party on this Committee was, `What about the unions?'. The unions have annual reports. All of their members know what money is given to political parties because it is there in black and white in the reports. The Labor Party tables its reports publicly in every State. So the affiliation dues and donations from the union movement are tabled publicly. In all the time that I have been in politics—and that is from the age of 20; I am 46 now—I have never been in a Labor Party State council that has excluded the press from any information like that.

PARA.TAB: Let me refer to a couple of other issues. Why did the Liberal Party send only Senator Parer to appear before our Committee. Senator Parer is a politician. Presumably, he does not raise the funds for his party. He does not run his party's campaigns. He does not know where the money trail goes—in other words, who are the donors and so on—

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't underestimate him.

—I am following the theory. When Senator Parer came before us we asked the question, `Where is your national director? Why isn't he here?'. We asked, `Where is your treasurer who raises the money?'. Senator Parer said, `Oh, you didn't ask them'.

PARA.TAB: The simple fact is that this Committee wrote to all political parties and said, `Send along the people who know about political fund-raising, about running campaigns'. And what did the Liberal Party send us? It sent us Senator Parer on his own. It seems to me that, as a committee, we were not going to get the information unless we talked to the people who knew. So as a committee, we then said, `Would you send along the National Director of the Liberal Party so that we can ask him questions about the way his Party raises money, how it hides donations, how it is in fact influenced by the giving of money'.

I wanted to ask a number of specific questions about how the Liberal Party paid for the massive campaigns. I wanted to ask about how it paid for the mid-term campaigns. Honourable senators will remember the incentivisation campaign. How did the Liberal Party pay for that? Where did the money come from? I wanted to ask some questions about how certain business organisations pay $100,000 or more a year for people to work in the offices of Andrew Peacock and other Liberal leaders. In other words, private companies paid the salaries of these people and then assigned them to the offices of important people in the Liberal Party.

I asked the question, `How do shareholders in public companies tolerate a situation in which, without letting them know, money is given in such a way to the Liberal Party?'. If I were a shareholder in those companies, I would want to know why that had happened. Who was there to tell us? It was only Senator Parer. It seems to me that this whole situation is not being taken seriously if only Senator Parer turns up to give his views when asked about the way in which the Liberal Party runs campaigns.

It appears from the Liberal Party statements that by putting bans on political advertising, this Government is going to distort the picture of what happens elsewhere in the world, that somehow or other we are one-out and unusual in wanting to do that. The members of the Liberal Party who were on this Committee and some others, including Senator Parer, who knows but says nothing about it, are aware that of the 19 major countries that we surveyed, only five are like Australia where it is basically a case of winner take all, spend what you like on political campaigns and money starts to count. Of the 19 countries surveyed, 14 have bans of some sort or another on electronic and, particularly, television advertising prior to election day.

So political parties do not have a right to go out and buy votes. Rich private interests groups do not have the right to back political parties in a search for influence. That is not a right of free speech—that is bought speech. Honourable senators can make up their minds whether in the years to come they want parliaments to be bought or whether they will support the concept of free speech—that is, the right of all citizens and all interests groups to be represented in this Parliament.

The Liberal Party was very self-conscious about this whole exercise. It was self-conscious about the fact that we were calling for public submissions. We know that the Liberal Party wrote to every interest group in the country trying to tell them what a terrible Bill this would be. The Liberal Party wrote to every vulnerable interest group which did not know anything about the Bill and distorted the picture. The Liberal Party even helped to write the letters that were sent to us. We saw letters from various interest groups, welfare groups and other organisations that looked as if they had been written by the one person. Because of the flawed logic in those letters, I can only assume the wording came from Senator Parer. When I looked at the letters I thought, `This is extraordinary. They all seem to read the same way'.

I was interested to hear the views of, for example, Garry Morgan. I was interested to hear the views of Rod Cameron from ANOP. I was interested to hear the views of people who have been involved in the political system and who have not been necessarily either duped or have an axe to grind. I looked at those views and said, `Yes, let us examine it'.

I am prepared to look at some of the views that have been expressed by Senator Kernot. I think some of the suggestions she made in the minority report are positive and will give us a better Bill in the long run. This is one of the major reasons that I think there was real value in this Committee. We called together people. We focused the nation's attention on this matter. What is more, we had open and public hearings at which people could be questioned about their views. The Committee did not just receive letters that had been written by people presumably like Senator Parer on behalf of a political party. At least we had the opportunity to listen to people tell us under oath what really goes on in their organisations.

So I support the concept of the Bill. This Parliament sooner or later has to make a decision about the question of reducing the escalation of expenditure on political campaigns so that people can never say about us, `This is the best Parliament that money can buy'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. We are considering a motion that the Senate take note of a report. Is that motion in order in view of the fact that the report is not available to honourable senators and, as I understand it, copies have not even been printed?
—Here is a printed copy.
—They are certainly not available. I have sought to obtain a copy.
—The situation is that the Senate gave leave for the motion to be moved. Under those circumstances, it is therefore a decision of the Senate itself.

—As can be seen from the debate so far, it was quite an experience to serve on such a volatile committee as the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures. Committee members held passionately opposed views which, in the case of Senators Kemp and Schacht, I would categorise as two immovable forces. I do not know what stage has to be reached before something has to give.

PARA.TAB: I think in many instances the views can be summarised as pro-and anti-unionism, with human rights being dragged along at the rear. I think it is fair comment to say that some witnesses would be entitled to believe that they had been subjected to some over-rigorous questioning. In the case of the last witness, Mr Sherry from Queensland, I personally believe that the word `intimidation' could be appropriately used.

Nevertheless, in between the overt political brawling, which I do not think did the Committee any justice, we did hear evidence from expert witnesses. I found a lot of that evidence to be informative and compelling. My views were not pre-determined. These witnesses are practitioners in the field. They gave evidence which was informative as well as subjective.

I think I should make the point that this report is a report on a piece of legislation. We will have an opportunity if and when we see the legislation next week to speak in the second reading debate about the issues which predictably have been raised so far. So I am not going to canvass all of those arguments at this stage.

I want to make a couple of points that I have raised in my own dissenting report. These are key points for the Australian Democrats, who believe that the great majority of political electronic advertising, borne out by the evidence, is emotive, manipulative and usually seeks to appeal to the lowest common denominator. It does little to address the issues; in fact, evidence was given that it debases the political process. Having said that, in my view the report does not address adequately the issue of what will happen when money previously spent on electronic advertising is rechannelled into other forms of direct marketing. I think that was an important point. We have seen that happen and used successfully, and I personally believe that voters will have a threshold to that approach but that that threshold has not yet been reached.

My second general point is that a great deal of questioning time was devoted by the two Opposition members on the Committee to the issue of tax advantages to the ALP via the union movement, particularly in the matter of tax deductibility of donations. I think it is fair to say that the Committee's view, expressed in paragraph 5.12, that this was not directly relevant to the inquiry is not supported by me. I think that that issue quite clearly dealt with campaign funding and third party expenditure. The body of evidence quoted in the report to illustrate this issue is sparse and does not reflect the amount of time devoted to and evidence heard on this issue. I do not share the passion of Opposition members on that issue, but I do not think that the report adequately reflects the amount of time that we as a Committee spent discussing it.

I have made a couple of recommendations of my own based on the evidence I have heard. I think it is very important that electors have a right to receive basic factual information. That is why I made my first recommendation in my own minority report. I have talked about a public register of lobby groups as well. I have talked of addressing the equalising of public funding arrangements for the Senate and the House of Representatives —not by increasing the Senate vote but perhaps by looking at the opportunity of treating the lot as a pool to be halved. I cannot subscribe to the view that what we as senators do is less onerous or less important than what is done by members of the House of Representatives as shown by the value of public funding for each vote.

I have also raised the issue of compensation to radio and television for free time which is allocated under the Committee's recommendations. I do not accept the Committee's conclusion, or the conclusion arrived at in the Opposition's dissenting report, on the matter of truth in advertising. It is always difficult to pursue such a concept, but I do not believe it is impossible. There is a distinction between trade and commerce in products and in ideas. I listened carefully to the evidence and I give notice that I intend to pursue the matter.

Despite the volatility of the Committee, I learned a lot about chairmanship techniques. I think that this will be an important report and I will probably be glad to have had the experience of having been a member of the Committee. I support the motion that the Senate take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some brief remarks on this important report by the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures. The matter that concerns me most relates to the principles that seem to be selectively applied by some of the honourable senators opposite, particularly by Senator Schacht, who was Chairman of the Committee and put his name to the report.

PARA.TAB: Having been in the Senate for only a year or so, I have on many occasions witnessed Senator Schacht, in adjournment speeches and matters relating to motions on Third World countries and other nations, speaking with great principle and passion on political freedoms and human rights in countries such as South Africa, Myanmar, Cambodia and China, to name those that immediately spring to mind. Senator Schacht has rallied for the advancement of human rights and political freedoms in those nations.

Therefore, it is a matter of some concern when somebody such as Senator Schacht, who professes to care about matters such as political freedom and human rights, puts his name to a report that in one fell swoop would reduce the level of political freedom and human rights in Australia in a way that has not even been contemplated by this Parliament in decades. This can only lead one to believe that people who would advocate such a ban as contained in this report have a problem with their principles. I think that they can only be referred to as hypocrites.

It is important that, as Senator Schacht has put his name to this report, whenever these matters of political freedoms in nations such as South Africa, Myanmar, Cambodia and China come up for debate relating to the sorts of issues that the people in Tiananmen Square died for only three years ago, he should be reminded continually by me and by my colleagues of his selective application of principles to matters of political freedom.

To turn to a separate point, I believe that the proposal to have free time allocated at the rate of some 17 minutes a day on commercial media outlets and on the ABC—under which the Government, although opposed to advertising on the ABC, is forcing that body to advertise political parties for 17 minutes a day—is again a matter of pure hypocrisy. In relation to the tabling of this report and as we move towards this piece of stupid legislation, I believe it is important that the Australian people fully understand the hypocrisy of Labor senators. I call on the Australian people to reject this report, to reject the legislation that we will see before this chamber and to support the minority report to which my colleagues Senators Kemp and Olsen have put their names.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not intend to speak in this debate. In tabling in Parliament a report on legislation, the usual practice is that there is no debate, because it is known that that debate will take place during speeches on the second reading motion. But, as Senator Olsen moved that the report be noted, we now have a motion before the Senate which has enabled this debate to take place. I would have thought there would have been plenty of opportunity to debate these matters on the second reading motion and for people to express their views forcibly on a very contentious and controversial issue.

PARA.TAB: However, now that we have this matter before us in this form, I as Chairman of the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures will take this opportunity to speak. I had prepared a 10-page tabling speech, which would take close to half an hour to read to the Senate. However, I do not intend to read it, but seek leave of the Senate to have the tabling speech incorporated.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is in it? Why not pass it around so that we can see it?
—I did not know exactly what those opposite were going to do.
—You knew that we wanted to speak.
—I did not know what those opposite intended to do until it actually happened. I seek leave to have the tabling speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find that interesting. We have heard a lot of debate here about free speech.
—You knew. You are entitled to say it, but you should observe the normal courtesies.

—I would have thought that the normal courtesy would be for Senator Kemp to have told me, as Chairman of the Committee, that he was not going to go through the normal procedure but was going to seek leave to move a motion, which is not the normal practice during debate on a select committee report on legislation coming back to the chamber. So be it; I will make a few remarks about the report.

PARA.TAB: First of all, I want to place on record my appreciation—and I think this would be on behalf of the whole Committee—to the members of the Secretariat of the Committee for their very hard work during the existence of this Select Committee. They are Rosemary Laing, Secretary; John O'Keefe, Principal Research Officer; Yvonne Marsh, Senior Research Officer; and Rachael Kelly, Executive Assistant. It was not easy being a part of the Secretariat of this Committee in view of the quite clear differences of opinion amongst its members. I believe that the members of the Secretariat discharged their duties with absolute impartiality in providing assistance to all members of the Committee no matter what their views and not only assisting me in drafting the Chairman's report, but also assisting other members in drafting their minority reports.

I want to deal with a couple of issues which have come up in remarks made by Opposition speakers. I will wait until the debate on the motion for the second reading of the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991 to go into greater detail on the report. I will try to limit my remarks certainly to less than the half an hour I am entitled to because other speakers have spoken for much less than half an hour.

First of all, there is the issue of disclosure of union donations and tax deductibility. Senator Kernot is correct in saying that there was extensive questioning. I suppose it is because, as Chairman, I allowed endless questions to be asked of any witnesses about this issue. I think that was the correct procedure to take.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not how others see it.

—There was never any limit—particularly on Senator Kemp—to revisit this issue with any witness. What I am particularly interested to note about the minority report from Opposition members is that if they were so concerned that union members do not have an opportunity to express a view through plebiscite—which is expressed in their minority report—about whether they want part of their membership fees paid as an affiliation fee to the Australian Labor Party or part of the union moneys paid to the Labor Party as a donation, why do they not recommend, if they are fair dinkum, that there should be a plebiscite of all shareholders before any donation is made from any public or private company in Australia? There is not a word about that in the report.

PARA.TAB: Already, under the Industrial Relations Act, the union movement has to publish an annual report declaring the affiliation fees it pays to an organisations such as the ALP, including donations. There is no such requirement—and I think it is a deficiency in the Companies Act—on companies, public or private, to provide the same disclosure. There is not a word about that in the minority report from the Opposition members, despite their expressions about decent public disclosure. They want to leave it silent; they want to protect their mates. They do not want their mates, as company directors, to be exposed to the shareholders for how much money they may give to political parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not compulsory to own shares just to get a job. There is no `no ticket, no job' in the share market.

—I will come to Senator Campbell in a moment, and his amazing remarks about human rights. First of all, I want to deal with the procedures of the Committee. Senator Kernot made remarks about a witness—the last witness, I think it was—Mr Sherry, who may have been intimidated. I want to make it clear that I think that those remarks were addressed to me, as Chairman. I do not in any way resile from what I said to Mr Sherry and I do not resile in any way from what I said to Mr Morgan. Both of those witnesses knowingly used the privileges of Parliament to give evidence accusing individual citizens of Australia of illegal, corrupt practices that, if proven in a court, would mean that people would suffer a sentence.

PARA.TAB: What I did, first of all in Mr Morgan's case, was say to him that he had made extremely serious allegations under privilege against another person; they were so serious that he should go directly to the Director of Public Prosecutions and give the information. I believe that was correct. We also made sure that the person named had an opportunity to respond.

When Mr Sherry gave evidence he mentioned many names of trade unionists and others in Queensland. Again, I said to him right at the end of the hour that we were given by the Senate, because the Senate was sitting, and I stressed this point to him, that his strong accusations of intimidation—clearly criminal offences—against individuals under privilege would have much greater credibility if he went to the appropriate authorities with his information. I still urge Mr Sherry to do so. Under cross-examination earlier he had indicated that despite all these threats of intimidation he had made no effort to go to the Cooke inquiry in Queensland with his information and he had made no effort to go to the Fitzgerald inquiry or anybody else. Our Committee was the first opportunity he took.

Under the terms of reference of our Select Committee much of his evidence probably could have been ruled ineligible. I was quite willing to let him have his say, I did not interrupt, but right at the end—we gave everybody 10 minutes to ask questions and I had the last three minutes because some people had taken more than their 10 minutes—I made that comment to him. I believe it was only reasonable considering the extraordinary allegations made against other citizens whom we have now written to. Some of them have replied and some will have to come back through the Standing Committee of Privileges, I suspect, to put their side and respond to Mr Sherry's allegations.

I want to come to the question of free speech and human rights which has been raised by some Opposition members. Senator Campbell made the point that I am a hypocrite because I am interested in human rights in a number of countries and am not interested in human rights in this Bill. It is true, and I do not deny the fact, that I have been to a number of countries privately and on parliamentary delegations—overwhelmingly privately—and raised issues of human rights.

I have to say to Senator Campbell that his remarks are particularly offensive not to me but to the people I have spoken to in those countries. I will give him one example. In February 1989 in Rangoon I sat down with 20 students from the Rangoon university and had a private discussion about human rights in that country. I asked whether any of the students around the table had suffered imprisonment and torture. For the next hour I listened to every one of those people, ranging between 15 and 25 years of age, give horrifying accounts of how they had been treated, abused and tortured by the regime.

If I had said to them, `Would you like to have a democracy in this country—human rights? For a three-week election campaign period you would not be able to have paid election advertisements on television, but you would have the right to freedom of religion, the right to free assembly, the right to free speech and the right to free trade unions?', I know what they would have said. The people raising this issue in Australia, such as Senator Campbell, do not know what human rights are all about. He is not interested. I will be very interested to hear in the future his commitment on these sorts of places, making the sorts of statements that offend these sorts of ordinary people who have been butchered.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you wear it on one sleeve, you have to wear it on the other sleeve as well.
—I have a stronger commitment than Senator Campbell will ever have to human rights. I have been to these places.
—Oh!

—Has Senator Campbell made a speech in this place on human rights? Is he a member of the Parliamentary Amnesty International Group? How many embassies has he protested to? I suspect not one. Senator Campbell is a fraud on this issue.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! I believe the term `fraud' is unparliamentary. Would Senator Schacht withdraw the remark?

TALK.START.PARA: —If it is unparliamentary, I withdraw. There was no absolute evidence given to the Committee, even by the witnesses who were friendly to the Opposition's viewpoint, that there is an absolute free speech requirement under the UN convention. Professor Alston, a most virulent critic of the Bill, admitted that it is all qualified; the argument is about the qualification. Mr Burdekin, the Human Rights Commissioner, also accepted that there are qualifications. The qualifications are written into the UN human rights convention. The qualifications include public order and public morals.

PARA.TAB: Members of the Opposition who were serving on the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies—the 0055 committee—want to ban certain messages between consenting adults over the telephone because it may affront their moral position. That is an infringement of free speech. I accept that that is a legitimate debate; I may or may not agree with it. Members of the Opposition want to affect free speech in that area, and they have got a select committee established to do it.

The evidence was overwhelmingly before the Committee—even the protagonists brought along to defend the Opposition's position admitted this—that free speech is not a pure position; it is qualified for good order and public morals in the community. I argue that the good order of Australia, public order, means trying to eliminate as much corruption as possible or to stop it from taking place. The witnesses, even those favouring the Opposition's position, agreed that that was not an unreasonable objective of the Parliament. They may disagree with the particular proposal.

Senator Campbell is implying that free speech is at risk in human rights terms. We received some interesting evidence from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. We wrote to the human rights section of the Department and asked, `Have you ever taken up any cases under the UN human rights convention against any number of western European countries who have bans on political advertising, putting that it is a breach of political rights, of human rights, an infringement of free speech within the terms of the UN convention?'. It simply said, `No, we never have because it is not an infringement of human rights and political free speech'. That is the legal position of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. It is in the evidence given and set out in the report.

I asked Professor Alston whether, with his great concern on this issue, he had ever arranged for issues to be taken up in the European Parliament or in the UN or with the parliaments of western Europe where all of these bans apply? These countries are set out in the appendix at the back of the report. He said no. I asked Mr Burdekin, the Human Rights Commissioner, whether he had taken up these matters. He said that he had not. In every country of western Europe there is some form of limitation on electronic advertising. No-one in western Europe or in the Human Rights Commission is complaining that this is an infringement of free speech.

It is an absolute furphy for Senator Campbell to claim that this is the equivalent of the killing of people in South Africa or Burma or China or Cambodia. Senator Campbell should go to the killing fields in Cambodia, actually stand in the Tuol Sleng interrogation centre and see the 10,000 photos of people, including Australians, who were butchered by Pol Pot. He should say to them that the three-week limitation on electronic advertising is the equivalent of this massacre. It is absurd. It is an obscenity to make that point. It is an obscenity on the victims of genocide in Cambodia that Senator Campbell, who could not find it on a map if we gave him a 10-day start, compares those two situations.

The recommendations we have made are overwhelmingly the best balance between the issues of free speech, access and corruption. We have recommended that the ban apply in the election period, that free time be made available during the election period to the political parties and that it be in a talking head format so that it is not distorted, so that it is proper political information. In the non-election period, people can put on advertisements as normal, in any way that they see fit. Third party groups such as the timber industry still have plenty of opportunities to put their case.

Finally, I refer to disclosure. I was interested to read the minority report from the Liberal Party members. Despite their attack on the majority report, there is no specific recommendation on what they would do. From reading their report, I do not know whether they actually support the new disclosure provision.

TALK.START.PARA: —It doesn't go far enough. We say that.

—If it does not go far enough, why did the minority report not detail what Senator Kemp thinks would go far enough? There is nothing. There is not one recommendation in the minority report about what we should do. All it is is a bucket of bile over the majority report. That is all it is—a bucket of slop the Opposition has tipped over to try to smear everything. In the end, it shows that there is now every chance that the Opposition will not vote even for the disclosure provision. If it were, it would be moving an amendment. There is no recommendation anywhere.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition hopes that this Bill is defeated in its entirety so that the existing system will continue. The Opposition believes that, on balance, it will advantage it in raising money for future election campaigns without disclosure. That is what it is all about. The Opposition hopes that one way or the other this Bill, or any of the amendments, in whatever form—with amendments perhaps from the Democrats or the Government—will fail completely. The Opposition is not fair dinkum about dealing with the issue of corruption and possible corruption in the political process in Australia.

It has never been the position of the Liberal Party or the National Party to deal with corruption. They do not want to deal with it; they want to forget all about it so that for any future election they can collect the buckets of money, the carpetbags full of money, without disclosure, to pay for their campaign. The Opposition has been doing it for 90 years; it wants to do it for another 90 years. Fortunately, the Australian people have woken up and are demanding political disclosure. They have seen the political process being corrupted by big buckets of money being donated to all political parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Burkie.

—I said all political parties. The public wants it changed. In the end, I think the public will support the Committee's proposal as the best balanced way to achieve the objective of reducing the potential for corruption in the political process in Australia. I commend the report to the Senate and to the Parliament.
—I ask that Senator Schacht table the document from which he quoted.
—I seek leave to table the document.
—Senator Schacht sought leave to table a document before. Leave was refused by the Senate. Is this the same document?
—I think Senator Harradine asked that Senator Schacht table the document from which he was quoting.

—Pursuant to standing order 168, I ask that the document quoted from by Senator Schacht be tabled. I believe that it is the same document Senator Schacht sought to have incorporated into Hansard. I wish to have the document tabled so that I can read it. I may not agree with it, of course, but it adds to the information that is available to the Senate, and I see no objection to that.

—In the normal course of events, if Senator Schacht wished to table a speech he should have, in courtesy, circulated it to other members of the Senate. Senator Schacht did not do that. We do not know what is in that particular document; we do not have a clue because he did not have the courtesy to show it to people, even those who may have had just an interest in this matter. Given that, and the lack of courtesy of Senator Schacht, I do not think that this document should be incorporated in Hansard or tabled until we have had a chance to see it.
—It is ironic that the passionate defenders of free speech do not want this document to be available for people to read it. It just exposes the sham. I support Senator Harradine's request.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the report of the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures, which is before the Senate. I join with Senator Schacht in thanking the members of the Committee secretariat for their great help during the many weeks in which the Committee operated. In particular, I should like to thank Rosemary Laing, John O'Keefe, Yvonne Marsh and Rachael Kelly for their work.

PARA.TAB: As has been very clear from the debate to this stage, it was a very difficult Committee. I suspect that few other examples could be brought to mind where there was such a bitterly divided Committee; where there were so many concerns expressed, often publicly, about the procedures that were adopted by the Committee. It put an enormous strain on such people as Rosemary Laing to make sure that all of us felt that we were properly catered for and to steer that difficult line between the various groups on the Committee.

I should like to express, certainly on my own behalf, and I am sure I speak with the strong support of Senator Olsen, our great thanks to Rosemary Laing for the work that she did and to note that her job was, I suspect, particularly difficult on this Committee.

Various matters have been raised by speakers on this report. At this stage, I wish to limit my remarks to a few comments to pick up some of the thoughts that have been expressed and to add a few of my own. It is clear that the Committee was very divided. There were great concerns about particular aspects of the way the Committee operated. Senator Kernot drew our attention to one incident which occurred in the Committee. That was the intimidation of a Mr Sherry, who was the final witness. It is my view also that there was an attempt to intimate Mr Sherry. That was a great pity because, although people may or may not agree with the views put by Mr Sherry, he was entitled to a fair hearing. I do not believe that he had that fair hearing.

It is worth noting that, when Mr Sherry came before the Committee, he probably spoke to us—after the comments by the Chairman—for about half an hour. The meeting was then deferred and leave of the Senate was sought for the Committee to sit between 5 p.m. and 6 p.m. on that day. Mr Sherry had raised a number of matters. The Chairman arrived late for the Committee hearing. The Committee did not start, in fact, until 5.10 p.m. Therefore, there was a very obvious ploy to strictly limit the ability to question Mr Sherry. It was limited because of the lateness of arrival of the Chairman. That is worth putting on the record because it demonstrates the way Senator Schacht tends to operate.

Then we came to the end of the hearing. Senator Schacht, who had adopted a very loose interpretation of the starting time of the Committee, suddenly decided to have a very strict interpretation of its finishing time and launched into a vitriolic abuse of Mr Sherry. I do not plan to go through that, but people who wish to read Hansard and look at the Chairman's final statement can see the vitriolic abuse which Senator Schacht launched against Mr Sherry.

Mr Sherry may have been under the impression that that was the view of the Committee. There was no time for other members of the Committee to comment. I believe that Senator Kernot wanted to make a comment. I wished to make a comment. But, whilst Senator Schacht had been loose on the starting time, boy, was he tough on that finishing time. He said, `This meeting is now finished. No further comments can be allowed'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Schacht has had his chance to speak; I will have mine. In future, I would advise anyone who is asked to sit on a committee with Senator Schacht as its Chairman to seek very close assurances on how such a committee will be conducted.

PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht drew our attention to the fact that he wrote, presumably in the name of the Committee, to two witnesses afterwards urging them to take particular action. I cannot recall Senator Schacht's seeking leave of the Committee to write to Mr Morgan. I cannot recall his seeking leave of the Committee to write to Mr Sherry. I suspect that he wrote as Chairman of that Committee.

So I would say to Senator Schacht that there are many worries about the way this Committee was conducted. Not the least is the report which is now before this Parliament. In the year and a half for which I have been a member of this chamber, I have sat on a number of committees, the members of which have had fairly vigorously opposing views. Reports have been produced which to my mind have fairly canvassed the evidence that has been put.

I agree with Senator Kernot that the majority report which has now been presented to this Parliament does not fairly canvass all the evidence which has been put before the Committee. I think that is appalling. I do not say that the majority members are not entitled to reach their own conclusions. On balance, undoubtedly the recommendations that they have been prepared to bring down would also have been included. But those people who did not agree with the majority report were at least entitled to see the evidence, which they believed was important and which was put before the Committee, properly canvassed. In my view that did not happen.

Senator Schacht showed something of a glass jaw in relation to the comments by Senator Campbell on the human rights issue. We got a long speech from Senator Schacht about his great record on human rights. I say to Senator Schacht, who has walked out of the chamber—he will presumably have a chance to read all of this in Hansard—that it is very easy to walk around the world and lecture all these other countries on their human rights.

The real test of one's commitment to human rights is how one reacts when one is put to the test; how one reacts when the interests of the Labor Party have to be weighed against wider human rights interests. I say `wider human rights interests' because this was the information that was brought before the Committee by the Human Rights Commissioner, which indicated that the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill was in serious breach of a UN convention on human rights.

What did this great man, this great advocate of human rights, do when he was faced, probably for the first time in his life, with a choice between accepting Labor Party interests and promoting the human rights interests of the wider community? There are no prizes for guessing how Senator Schacht came down. The answer is: when put to the test, Senator Schacht came down on the side of the interests of the ALP.

I do not believe that the Bill which this report deals with has been brought before this Parliament in order to solve the problems of political corruption which have been apparent before at least a number of royal commissions and inquiries in various States. I do not believe that this Bill effectively addresses that. I believe that there are three main reasons why this Bill has been brought before the Parliament.

The first reason is that the Labor Party has been faced, and is being faced, with a massive public relations problem resulting from WA Inc. This Bill was born in the climate of the early exposures of WA Inc. This has been brought before the Parliament to attempt to fool the public that the Labor Party is concerned about effectively tackling political corruption in this country. The second reason that this Bill came before the Parliament and the way it is worded—I believe this is clear from the evidence before the Committee—is that it is trying to entrench a major Labor Party advantage as we go towards the next election. There is no doubt that political advertising is the most effective method of getting one's messages across, whatever people may think of the actual ads themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —What nonsense!

—It is. As Secretary of the Labor Party, Senator McMullan spent more money on political advertising than on any other form of election campaigning. So, by his own decisions and activities, he indicates that political advertising is the most effective form of getting a message across to the public. He has done it for years including when he was Labor Party Secretary.

PARA.TAB: The Labor Party is petrified that the political ads which will be run in the next election will be very effective in recalling to the public at large these disgraceful broken promises that the Labor Party has made year after year. It will bring to attention those famous films of four men in a boat as they go out to Laurie Connell's yacht. Those are the things that the Labor Party is petrified of being recalled to the public.

The third reason that this Bill has been brought before this Parliament is that the Labor Party—because of its disgraceful performance, loss of support in the community and the fact that its rich mates are no longer rich—is going to be strapped for funds. It is going to be strapped for funds in a big way. It is also an attempt to limit possible funding advantages that a Hewson-led Liberal Party might have as it sweeps towards victory in the next election. In my view, this is not concerned with human rights; it is not particularly concerned with corruption, although in some aspects it may help and in some aspects it may hinder. It is concerned about entrenching Labor Party advantages to the detriment of other parties.

The next point I wish to make is the general logic on which this Bill is built. No evidence was given before the Committee that, in some way, banning political advertising would in any way limit election spending. Senator Kernot raised the point—and I agree with her—that it is likely that if political parties are limited in their rights to advertise on TV, they will divert funding into other areas. The only people who objected to this view before the Committee were the Labor Party witnesses. It defies logic and belief that money will not be diverted into such other areas as direct mail, newspaper advertising and so forth. The Labor Party decided to take this mighty step. Yet was there any evidence produced before the Committee which could have actually shown that, in all these other countries where TV advertising is, in some way, restricted in election periods, corruption is any less and election spending is not growing at the high rates that we have seen in Australia? Was there any evidence produced to the Committee?

TALK.START.PARA: —You did not produce any.

—It is the logic on which this Bill is built, Senator Schacht. Two countries which interest me, France and Japan, have restrictions on political ads in the election period. Both countries have been racked in the last 12 months or so by major funding scandals. So the very flimsy logic on which this Bill is built falls over. No essential or effective evidence was produced which shows the contrary case. There are some very big issues which this Senate and the public will now have to address as a result of the recommendations which the majority report has brought down. The key groups that are going to have to effectively address this are, in fact, not the major political parties. I believe that, as Senator Ray confirmed, the major political parties, or at least the Labor Party, have in this report attempted to look after themselves. It is okay for the Democrats, the Labor Party and indeed, by extension, the Liberal Party to advertise in election periods now. It is okay for us. Certainly, it will be very restricted. It is okay for us to do it and basically do it free. That is a major advantage then.
