PARA.TAB: A third party, such as the AMA, the Australian Conservation Foundation or any small political group which feels it must bring a pressing message to the public arena on TV, cannot afford TV, but it can certainly afford radio ads, but these will be wiped out. They will be excluded by this Bill from bringing their views to the public arena in this critical election period. That is what is going to happen. They will be excluded.
As we ponder the impact of this Bill and the consequences for our political system, I

SPEECH.PARA: wonder whether Senator Kernot can go out to all those interest groups with which her Party has close links and say to them, `We fixed ourselves up. We have our free time on TV in the election period, but I am sorry, you have not got your free time. You cannot place ads even on radio'. That is what this Bill says as it now stands. Senator Kernot, whether she likes it or not, is now in the eye of the storm.

PARA.TAB: If the major parties believe that they can so strictly inhibit the rights of all of these other smaller groups in this disgraceful, cynical Bill, I suggest that there will be a howl of outrage from the wider community, and so there should be. I shall be trying hopefully to promote it because it is a disgraceful abuse of our rights in this country to say that every other group but the major political parties cannot run ads on radio and TV during the critical weeks of democracy, the election period.

My final comment is that, as we looked at the evidence put before the Committee, it became very clear that there were other very expensive forms of electioneering. Putting ads in major daily newspapers is very expensive. Perhaps even one of the most expensive forms of electioneering is direct mail. There are a lot of very expensive areas in which one can campaign during election periods. The Labor Party has geared itself up. We have all received another laser printer. I did not ask for another laser printer, but Senator Bolkus has written off and given us all another laser printer. So the Labor Party is gearing itself up to run the mother of all direct mail campaigns in the next election period.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can't you use it? The Liberal Party will tell you how to use it, don't worry.

—That is what you are doing, Senator Schacht. It is very obvious. But it is not at the expense of the Labor Party's own fundraising efforts; it is at the expense of the taxpayer and by courtesy of the taxpayer. That is what the Labor Party is doing, and it is blatantly obvious. This is why this Bill is such a cynical exercise, in my view.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I believe that the debate on this, as we have already seen this morning, will become very vigorous. Many issues will be canvassed. My concluding comment is that the majority report that has been brought down by Senator Schacht does not reflect the evidence that was brought before the Committee in a fair and balanced way. It is going to be our work in the coming weeks to get out and explain to people the real facts of this disgraceful Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I claim to have been misrepresented. I certainly accept the fact that, in debate, things should be robust and that honourable senators have to take as much as they dish out, but I take exception to one inference in Senator Kemp's remarks that I deliberately planned to come late to a meeting between the hours of 5 and 6 o'clock to restrict the time of Mr Sherry in giving evidence. I have just checked my diary. The reason I was late is that I was chairing a private meeting of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade—I am Chairman of that Committee—with, ironically, two members of the ANC constitutional committee, Mr Zola Skwiyiya and Professor Dular Omar. They were in Australia to seek legal advice from all sorts of people, including, I suspect, members of the Opposition, about how to draft a democratic constitution for a non-racial democratic South Africa and a commitment to a bill of rights. That was the reason. I concluded the meeting as early as I could to get to the Select Committee meeting. I apologise that—
—Why didn't you advise us to start?

—I did say that I was late because I was at a previous meeting, but Senator Kemp did not hear that. That was the reason I was late. I also wish to explain that when I arrived to chair that scheduled one-hour meeting of the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures, I said that every member of the Committee would have 10 minutes to ask questions because we were limited to time. As it turned out, because I was late, I was the one person who did not take 10 minutes; I had only two minutes right at the end. So I did not limit any of the other members of the Committee in asking questions. I was the only one who was limited because I was late, and I have explained the reasons for that. I must say that, from listening to Mr Zola Skwiyiya and Professor Dulah Omar speak on human rights, it certainly would be instructive if some of those opposite had a discussion with them about human rights in South Africa. They would then understand the real issues.

—I want to make just a few remarks in relation to the report of the Senate Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures, its tabling this morning and the motion moved by Senator Alston that the Senate take note of it. The first point I want to make is a very simple one and bears repeating because, as I understand the position of members of the Labor Party on this matter, they do not understand it and so it has to be repeated until they finally do.

PARA.TAB: The point I want to make is this: members of the Labor Party cannot clean up the conduct of elections by taking away or killing the most essential element of those elections. It is a bit like throwing the baby out with the bath water. It is absolutely essential for the proper conduct of elections that we have what is sometimes called a free exchange of information, but that would more properly be described as an unrestricted exchange of information. That is the very basis of an election. It is on that basis that those who have the capacity to vote decide who they want to vote for. The whole system does not work if we cannot have an unrestricted exchange of views at election time.

We have Government senators saying, `We will fix up this corruption', about which they seem to know so much. They are saying, `We'll fix that up. We'll restrict the exchange of views at election time'. There is no way they can describe the proposal they are putting forward as anything other than that. It will mean that my Party, as a major party, the Australian Democrats, as a major party, and the Labor Party will be able to put their views. They will nonetheless be restricted in the amount of time they use, but they will get some time. Let us not pretend we will have unrestricted access to putting our views; it will be restricted.

Let us also not pretend that it is free time. It is only free to us; we do not have to pay. The community and other advertisers will pay in the end and it will all flow through to their products. Let us not kid ourselves that Labor has found some magic way to get free time. It is the old story of no such thing as a free lunch. The simple point is: what if there is a major party issue that I feel differently about from the majority of my Party and I want to put out one radio advertisement during election time to say to people, `Look, as a senator for South Australia, I do not agree with that'?

I will give honourable senators an example. Despite having promised that it would not introduce one and despite, its having been introduced, having promised that it would not increase it, the Labor Party decided to double the sales tax on wine. As it happens, my State produces nearly 60 per cent of Australia's wine.

TALK.START.PARA: —And good wine at that.

—And, as Senator Olsen quite rightly says, very good wine it is. I was not happy to support my Party's view that the sales tax on wine should be supported. It is not worth going into the reasons why my Party chose to support it nor the reasons why I would not, partly because I think that is obvious; my State produces 60 per cent of the wine and we were going to be disadvantaged far more than any other State.

PARA.TAB: What if that happened just before an election? Under this legislation I would not be able to tell the electors of South Australia that I was prepared to stand up for their position. That is absolutely outrageous. So the big voices get a say but the little voices do not.

One of the growing concerns about Australian politics today is the power of the major parties—the power of the registered and organised political parties. More and more we are seeing a swing towards what one might call fringe groups, because there is a perception that the major parties are not representing the wide variety of views of the community. In response to that, we are seeing more and more independents being elected to Parliament.

So what are some members of parliament doing? They are getting together in some sort of backdoor system to lock out would-be independents from being able to use electronic advertising at election time. They could not come at a more disgraceful act. How will the independents get a say?

When a party holds the power, I can understand that it perhaps wants to keep it, but this is definitely not the right way to go about it. If a party wants the proper conduct of elections, it has to have an unrestricted exchange of views. The independents have to be allowed to have their say. Individuals who come from the major parties have to have a say to the extent that it is different from what the majority might think. If a party in power does not do this, it is a farce. It is just pretending that there is a free exchange of views when there is not.

Senator Aulich came into the chamber and made some comments about corruption without going slightly pink in the face, which I was somewhat amazed at. Nonetheless, he made the mistake that the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) made—a mistake, I might say, that was laughed at by the Human Rights Commission. He said, `This advertising on the radio and television is not free; it is paid for'. I have already established that the so-called `free time' on television is not free time. These people in the gallery will be paying for it by paying higher prices for the products that are advertised on television. Surely he does not think that the television stations will pay for it out of the goodness of their hearts, does he? Hell no! All Australians will be paying more.

Anyway, the point I want to make is that the word `free' in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights is not understood by anyone other than Senator Aulich and Senator Bolkus to mean `that which is not paid for'. I doubt whether even Senator Schacht would be so stupid as to go along with that notion. He has a long record of understanding human rights and he must understand that that is not what `free' means in that covenant. He knows it full well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know exactly what it means.

—Good. I note that Senator Schacht says that he knows what it means. I also note that he is not coming out to support Senator Bolkus and Senator Aulich, who clearly do not know what it means and who run around this country pretending that `free' means that which is not paid for. It does not mean that; it means unrestricted. So if I want to put a different view to yours, Mr Acting Deputy President, or if a member of the public in the gallery wants to place one advertisement to suggest that people should vote for me, Senator Olsen or Senator Schacht, they should be able to do so. Their views should not be restricted in any way. So `free speech' does not mean speech which is not bought.

PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht and Senator Kemp interjecting—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! Senator Schacht and Senator Kemp can continue discussions outside if they wish.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I have had to speak over Senator Schacht before, and he will not stop me now. Free speech is not that which is not paid for; it is unrestricted speech. An unrestricted exchange of views is essential to the proper conduct of elections. Without that, we do not have the lifeblood of an election, the proper exchange of unrestricted views, so that people can understand who wants to do what should they be elected to parliament.

PARA.TAB: The other point I want to make relates to the Government's emphasis on the costs, this enormous cost. We speak in millions of dollars; our campaigns are so expensive.

TALK.START.PARA: —Eighteen million dollars.

—Senator Schacht offers me a figure of $18m for the last election. If that is the case and there are about 10 million voters, that represents $1.80 a head. The information I have is that at the last election more like $30m was spent on advertising. I regard that as pretty cheap, too. There are 10 million voters.

—Order! There are too many interjections from both sides of the Chamber. Senator Kemp, Senator Olsen and Senator Schacht, if you want to have another committee meeting, you can have it later. I want to hear what Senator Vanstone has to say.

—If we do a rough calculation—I admit it is a very rough calculation—and take Senator Schacht's figure of $18m, add another 50 per cent or so and bump up the cost to $30m, with 10 million electors it would mean a cost of $3 per elector to be informed on the issues. I do not call that expensive. I am amazed that we get away with it so cheaply—absolutely amazed. Let us suppose that we were to go in for something which Senator Schacht might prefer, even more than this alleged free time. If we said to the Australian Electoral Commission, `Look, we, the Liberal Party, will give you a leaflet, the Democrats will give you a leaflet and the Labor Party will give you a leaflet, could you distribute one of each of these leaflets? They will not have any propaganda in them; you will check that the content is all right.'—the thought police will be out and they will check that it is okay—`Will you send them out to each elector?', it is London to a brick on that the Electoral Commission could not do that for $3 a head. It definitely could not do that for $3 a head. It could not adequately convey the views.

PARA.TAB: Of course, it is not simply a question of being able to advertise so that a view can be put. I am well aware of the fact that some of the advertisements, especially those run by the Australian Labor Party at the last election, do not have much in the way of substantive comment about politics. But they do—and this is important—raise the issues. If the Labor Party wants to run, as it did in the last election, some overly schmalzy environmental advertisement, pretending it would be the friend of the environment—it has been caught out now on pretending to be the friend of the environment—and if it wants to suggest that somehow the advertisement tells the public something about the Labor Party, I say it should be able to do so. I say so for two reasons. Firstly—

TALK.START.PARA: —They shouldn't be allowed to lie.

—No, the Labor Party should not be allowed to lie on matters of fact, I quite agree. But if it wants to show a schmalzy advertisement with beautiful pictures of some of the fantastic environmental sites that perhaps should be protected, good luck to it. I say that for two reasons.

PARA.TAB: First, the running of that advertisement will only raise the issue in the public's mind. The fact that the Labor Party runs that advertisement is a good thing. It encourages debate. Some people will say, `What a load of rubbish; Labor will never do that'. Of course, in hindsight, people know full well how much value there was in a Labor Party commitment to look after the environment. It has been caught out on that. At least the running of that advertisement with the limited information that it might have included did generate some discussion about what the Federal Parliament should be doing about the environment. It gave me the opportunity to put my views when the matter was raised. It would have given the Australian Democrats the opportunity to make some response to it.

Secondly, advertisements are important not only because of their substantive content—they should not be criticised for the lack thereof—but also because they play another role. This unrestricted exchange of information that I say we should have generates discussion. That is what advertisements should do at election time. I do not regard $1.80 a head, or $3 a head, as expensive at all. Sure, I will never see $30m. I will probably never have $1m or $500,000. But for the nation to spend $18m at an election—$1.80 a head—to inform people of the various views and to generate debate strikes me as being cheap, very inexpensive.

TALK.START.PARA: —But do they really inform?

—I do not know where Senator Kernot has been during the past few minutes. I have just made the point that the importance of advertisements is not based solely on their substantive content. I have acknowledged that—in fact, I selected one example—

—Senator Kernot has had her go; she should give me mine. I selected an advertisement that I regarded as lacking in substantive content. I am sure I could come up with a list of many more than one. No doubt Senator Kernot has a little list in her drawer of a few advertisements that she thinks lack substantive content. She must have been chatting in the corner when I was speaking because she missed the point I made: the advertisements that do not necessarily have substantive content in them at least play another important role. They generate debate. They raise the issues. They make it so that when Senator Kernot, Senator Schacht or I go to a public meeting, that issue is raised. When an issue is raised with parliamentarians because non-substantive advertisements have been run, it gives them the opportunity to raise the detail of those issues that the parties might want to raise.

PARA.TAB: The points I have made thus far, Mr Acting Deputy President, are these. We cannot clean up the conduct of elections by taking away the most essential element of them: an unrestricted exchange of information and generation of debate. I should not need to go past that point. As it appears that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, and some members of your Party do not understand that, it bears repeating.

I further made the point that $1.80 a head—let me exaggerate it, make it $3 a head—to engage in this exercise, to inform the community of the choices and to generate debate on those choices is something I regard as an inexpensive exercise—very cheap. If we are not prepared to spend that on deciding who will run this show, what are we prepared to spend?

Perhaps we should have spent a little more and we would not be in the mess in which we are now with your Party in government, Mr Acting Deputy President. My Party should have spent more. We should not have let Australia go down the plughole by electing the people opposite—

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order! I am trying to be absolutely fair in this debate, to have no views at all from the chair. But we do have interjections flying across the chamber between senators who do not have the floor. Senator Vanstone, and no-one else, has the floor.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a surprise to me to find that; but, Mr Acting Deputy President, I am pleased for your intervention.

PARA.TAB: The third point I made is that moving to such a system of free time for the registered parties is simply a grab of power by the big boys and girls, locking out the independents, locking out the would-be smaller parties. In hindsight I see that the Australian Democrats started off running as some independents. Perhaps they would not be here now if we had locked them out of some advertising earlier on. For them, as part of a small party, to have any hand in squashing the voices of people smaller than themselves is a disgrace—an absolute disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —That won't wash.

—If the Democrats are saying that that will not wash, let them go around to some of the smaller groups. Let the Democrats tell those smaller parties, `You're okay, Jack and Jill; you're from a registered party, but you will not be able to put your views'. Let the Australian Democrats come with me to tell some independent who does not like any of the registered parties, some independent who wants to stand on his own, that if he is not in a registered party, he should not have a say.
—They will get free time as well as the others.
—Well and good. Let us come to that. I now turn to the point of corruption. Perhaps I have not understood that interjection. Is Senator Kernot telling me that anyone who wants to place—
—Senator Kernot has had her shot. She has interjected and I am giving her the opportunity now to clarify her interjection.
—You're asking; you're getting an answer.

—If Senator Lees does not mind, I would like to get the question out first. Is Senator Kernot telling me that anyone who wants to run advertisements will be able to do so? Is that what she is saying? She should just nod yes or no. It should be simple. She cannot answer it simply, can she? There is a technicality in the proposal that will lock out some people. That is why Senator Kernot cannot answer yes or no. It is not a yes or no answer. It cannot be done.

PARA.TAB: I will move on to the question of corruption, which, Mr Acting Deputy President, you say that your Party knows so much about. In your speech, you indicated that you have full knowledge of the level of corruption and you implied that there was some relationship between corruption and the need of the parties to have money to advertise. Perhaps, Mr Acting Deputy President, you have some special knowledge of that which I do not have. I myself do not have any knowledge of that. What I do know about corruption is this: it takes two to tango. Corruption is a function, in part, of people who want to seek influence, meeting with other people who are prepared to sell it. That is what it is. It is not just a function of money needed to advertise; it is a function of people who want to buy influence and cheapskates who are prepared to sell it when they can.

Removing the opportunity for the parties to advertise as they will, and for independents, et cetera, to advertise as they will, will not get rid of those people in the community with an amount of wealth who seek to buy influence. They will still be there and they will be looking for other ways to advertise. I suggest, Mr Acting Deputy President, that if it is the case, as you seem to allege it is, that there are people in politics who will sell that influence—and you say that they will sell it to get advertising money—then they will sell that influence to get some other benefit, either for their party or for a personal benefit.

So removing the opportunity for individuals and parties to advertise as they choose does not get rid of those who want to seek influence and does not get rid of those who are prepared to sell it. That is the fundamental question that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, need to answer about corruption before your Party suggests limiting people's rights to speak as they will during an election, the most important time to have unrestricted speech. I noticed Senator Faulkner, whose intellectual capacity sometimes astounds, on the other side of the chamber say, `People can put their view at another time'. Great! It will be a real help to members of the public who want to vote if I have put my view about something six months before an election. That will be a great help for people who want to know what I think, who will have to go back and look through what I might have said, or some advertisement I might have placed, some time ago. That is an extraordinary proposition to put forward.

The last substantive point I want to make in relation to this matter is about the dollars needed to win a campaign. Not only will restricting advertising during election time not get rid of corruption, not only does it limit the right of unrestricted exchange of information between those who want to stand and those who are thinking about supporting people, but also it will not get rid of the perceived need of the major parties for large funds. Do I think for one minute that when the people opposite finally do what they have been prevaricating about for the last three months—and that is get rid of old Bob and put in Mr Keating—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—Those opposite are thinking about finally getting rid of Mr Hawke, our most illustrious Prime Minister. It was a poor performance by the Labor Party in the last couple of weeks in relation to the very visionary proposals put forward by my Party as to how to get this country out of the mess that it is in. The total silence by those opposite, their total incapacity to answer, tells us only that it will not be long before they do what most of them have wanted to do for a long time—but they just do not have the guts—and that is get rid of a Prime Minister who has had his time and put in a man who is absolutely determined to have the job and who is going to get the job, either before Christmas or after Christmas.

PARA.TAB: When Mr Keating finally gets there—Senator Schacht is working very hard to see that this happens; Senator Button would like to see this change; I forget where Senator Faulkner is; Senator Childs, who is in the Left, is still hoping the Prime Minister can hang on—do those opposite think for one minute that he will sit back on his thumbs and say, `Oh, well, we will just have a bit of free time and that is the only thing I will do to get my message across'? Do we honestly think that?

TALK.START.PARA: —There is an issue of relevance here. You are highly irrelevant.

—If Senator Schacht had had his mouth shut and his ears open for a period of time greater than 10 seconds during my speech, he would have understood the points that have been made. If he would like to open his ears now and `fermez la bouche', he will hear the point that I am coming to. If he does not want to do that, I do not see why he can claim irrelevance if he is not listening.
—I am just pleading relevance. Read the report.

—If Senator Schacht would like to button up for a minute, he will get the relevance. He has had his chance and the more he interrupts the more I will go on until that clock over there says `thirty minutes'. I have some points to make and I am going to make them. If Senator Schacht wants to keep delaying me, that is fine. I return to the point I was making—
—Order! Senator Schacht, enough is enough. You have had enough interjections. Senator Vanstone can make her own speeches.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I just asked Senator Vanstone to be relevant to the report. Senator Vanstone has been stretching our patience on this side of the House by the irrelevance of her remarks because they are not relating to the report that was tabled.

—On the point of order: if Senator Schacht, as I have indicated to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, wants to sit down and button up for a minute and let me get through this point, he will see its relevance. As I understand it, this is common behaviour for Senator Schacht on committees. If he does not like what someone is saying, he says it is not relevant; he tries to shut them up. He cannot do that in here.
—There is no point of order. Senator Vanstone is quite free to develop her argument as she sees fit. I presume she will be relevant.

—The message is coming through that my voice is getting a bit loud into the microphone. I thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President, because it has to be loud to go over the interjections that have been allowed until you quite properly intervened. I do not mind speaking loudly; I am just sorry that it offends the ears of some others. I have to get to that volume in order to get my point out. The question I was asking was: when the people on the other side finally get rid of the Prime Minister they now have and put in Mr Keating—which I regard as an inevitable course of action, certainly one I have said that Senator Schacht and Senator Button are very keen to see happen—do we imagine that Mr Keating as Prime Minister will simply say, `Look, we have to go to the election and we can have this free time and we will leave it at that'? Do we imagine that Mr Keating will do that? I certainly do not.

PARA.TAB: I pick up the point that Senator Kernot made. Buckets and buckets of money will be poured into direct mail. Senator Olsen made a point about telemarketing and letterboxing. So the desire to seek power and retain it is not at all eradicated by this proposal. The funds that have thus far been used for electronic advertising will be used in some other way to get the message across from the various parties. That is all that will happen, so there is no big change.

Finally, Mr Acting Deputy President, when I started speaking you were not in the chair. When I planned my speech, I planned to make these remarks last. They are remarks in relation to a speech that you have made and I give you fair notice of that lest you wish to get out of the chair, put someone else in it and interject as you choose. They are not, in my view, offensive remarks. If you want some advice from me, you do not need to do that, but I am giving notice that if you want to nod to the Deputy President I would be happy to hold on for a second and talk about something else while you do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is fine, Senator. I would never interject because that is disorderly.

—Thank you. In relation to your remarks, I find it incredible that a member of a committee can come in here and say, `We asked the major parties about their fundraising and how they run elections and they sent along Senator Parer; they would not send the people who knew'. Either Senator Aulich was somewhere else when the Liberal Party Federal Director gave evidence to this Committee or his mind was somewhere else.
—He was there.

—Senator Olsen tells me that Senator Aulich was in fact there. I am amazed that, having been at a committee hearing at which the Liberal Party Federal Director was present and questions having been asked of him, Senator Aulich should come into this chamber and try to give the impression to other honourable senators, members of the gallery and the press gallery that the Liberal Party Federal Director—who does know how the Liberal Party raises its money, does know where it is spent and does know quite a lot, more than anybody else, about how we campaign—did not give evidence and did not answer questions put by Senator Aulich. It can only reflect on the honourable senator that he made those remarks this morning.

PARA.TAB: The second point in relation to Senator Aulich's contribution this morning—I offer this advice to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate), who is at the table, because he looks bemused about what has been happening while he has been away, apart from the constant interjections from Senator Schacht—is that he implied, if he did not say specifically, that the Liberal Party wrote the letters for interest groups to put forward to the Committee. All that does is confirm for me that Senator Aulich's attitude to interest groups and to single electors is exactly the same as that of the majority of his Party—namely, that they are stupid people.

How stupid does anyone think interest groups have to be? Does one think that they are going to come along to the Liberal Party and say, `We are so stupid, we cannot write our own letters'? It is an insulting remark to make that not only would the Liberal Party do this but also interest groups would be so incapable of writing their own letters that they would go along with that. I support the motion moved by Senator Olsen that the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commence my remarks on the report of the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures, as a number of other contributors to this debate have, by thanking those who worked in the Committee secretariat for their good work. As others have said, it was a very difficult task for the Committee Secretary and the other members of the secretariat staff, although I think that the great majority of honourable senators were very cooperative in their approach.

PARA.TAB: That goes for Senator Olsen who, although I disagreed with many of the contributions he made, put his viewpoint forcefully and I believe within the Standing Orders. I did not always agree with what Senator Kernot put forward, but she worked in a very cooperative fashion. The other members that I served with were my colleagues the Government senators: yourself, Mr Acting Deputy President, and of course the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Schacht. However, the one dishonourable exception to this is Senator Kemp who, throughout his contributions to the Committee, behaved in a disgraceful and abominable fashion. It was an absolute disgrace.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Senator Faulkner, I am listening very carefully to what you are saying. I consider `disgraceful' and `abominable' to be appropriate words for this chamber, but `dishonourable' is a word that I think you could probably withdraw. You could say `exception' but not `dishonourable exception'.

TALK.START.PARA: —If it is unparliamentary, I withdraw it.
—Unconditionally withdraw.
—If it is unparliamentary, I withdraw it.
—I have said it is unparliamentary.

—Senator Kemp's role was one of disruption throughout the time that this Committee met. For him to come into this chamber today and attack the Chairman of the Committee is nothing short of rewriting history, because Senator Schacht had to deal with Senator Kemp's difficult behaviour. At all times throughout the hearings of this Committee Senator Kemp made life as difficult for the Chairman, as difficult for the other members of the Committee and as difficult for the witnesses as he possibly could. I want to congratulate the Chairman for his tolerance throughout the Committee hearings—although, to be mildly critical of Senator Schacht, I thought that he was too tolerant at times. But he was dealing obviously with a very difficult situation.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the witness Mr Sherry, I did not believe that Mr Sherry should have come before the Committee. I voted against his appearance when it was originally proposed and I voted against his appearing again when it was suggested that he come back. But Senator Schacht, for which he is well known, was very tolerant in his approach and allowed that witness to appear, to slander and libel people under parliamentary privilege and to make a contribution completely outside the terms of reference of the Committee.

I have mentioned Senator Kemp's role on the Committee. Frankly, I thought his behaviour was maniacal and obsessional. His specific interest was in attacking the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the trade union movement in general, with the odd—very odd in his case—broadside at Senator Bolkus, such as we saw this morning when he raised the issue of honourable senators being given a laser printer for their offices. When he mentioned that, I was reminded of something I read in the Sydney Morning Herald on 23 November. I read an article on page 7 entitled `Coalition kicks off 4-month soft sell'. This article was about the four-month soft sell of the coalition's GST package and it states:
Faced with a cynical electorate, the Opposition has abandoned the traditional slick and expensive television and radio advertising campaign—

SPEECH.PARA: I wonder why; probably because the coalition thinks that it would not work—
for a concerted grass roots push involving plenty of personal communication.
But here in the last paragraph of this article is the sting in the tail; here is the misuse of the public purse. I wonder whether Senator Kemp is going to defend this:

PARA.TAB: The estimated more than $1 million cost of printing the pamphlets will be borne by the Coalition—

SPEECH.PARA: which I bet it tried to get out of—

but Australians will pay for the postage. While Liberal organisations in some electorates plan to letter box the material, most of the massive distribution will be paid out of the mail allowances of Federal Coalition MPs.

What hypocrites those opposite are. Throughout the period that this Select Committee met, the Government's Bill came under close examination from all members of the Committee. It became clear that, regardless of the irrelevancies that were brought forward by the Opposition, not one substantial criticism could be made. There is a continuing fraud being perpetrated by the Opposition about disclosure. It claims to believe in `full, fair and equitable disclosure' but, of course, it does not believe in disclosure at all and it is going to fight tooth and nail to stop political donations in this country being disclosed. The Opposition will use any excuse and any device to try to ensure that.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition members of the Committee tried to insinuate that people who donate to political campaigns in this country have been intimidated, but they did not produce one skerrick of evidence. These no-hopers could not produce one example throughout the sittings of this Committee to sustain that argument. These no-talent people on the other side of the chamber could not come up with a single example. During the processes of the Committee I questioned the Federal directors of all the major political parties and many other witnesses about this very matter. There is not an example in Australian politics; no example has ever been produced.

I suppose it is fair to say to Senator Parer that at least he made an effort. He came up with a case, apparently from Andrew Peacock's first election campaign in 1966, and claimed that the ACTU or Laurie Carmichael —I think it was Laurie Carmichael, who was not employed by the ACTU at that time—had been guilty of standing over some unknown business. He could not produce any more information. What a flimsy performance; what a pathetic effort from the honourable senator and his colleagues. In fact, I congratulate the Liberal Party on what it did in fronting to the Committee with Senator Parer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

—I am glad the honourable senator asked that question. The Liberal Party fronted to the Committee with Senator Parer. When I asked questions during the Committee hearing about funding, fund raising, donations and all of the crucial issues, of course Senator Parer could not answer them. I do not blame him for that; of course he could not answer them because it was a matter for the Liberal Party secretariat—the Liberal Party machine. It was trying to hide this information all the way down the line. Senator Parer did not know, and eventually we had to extract from the Liberal Party a commitment to send along Mr Andrew Robb, who is the Federal Director of the Liberal Party, so that we could get down to tintacks on some of the crucial issues the Committee faced. I know the role that you played, Mr Acting Deputy President, in insisting upon that process.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Labor Party started absolutely up front with the National Secretary of the Party, Mr Bob Hogg, and its fund raiser, Mr Gary Gray. They were the first witnesses off the blocks. They came along and answered all the questions they were asked. In fact, Mr Hogg came back to the Committee on two other occasions. But the Liberal Party tried to sweep everything under the carpet. It brought along Senator Parer, who as shadow Minister had responsibility for the Bill. It was fair enough for him to come in that capacity, but there was no effort to bring along anyone from the Liberal Party organisation who could answer the nitty gritty questions this Committee wanted to ask.

I am aware that commitments have been made to try to keep this debate within some constraints, given that we will have a full second reading debate at a later stage. However, I might say that that does not seem to apply to Senator Vanstone, who frothed at the mouth for about half an hour and spoke the greatest load of hogwash that I have ever heard in this chamber. I do not know what she had for breakfast, but it certainly had an emetic effect upon her. She talked about what would happen to her if she were running in a pre-selection campaign and how she could not run an advertisement if it took a different perspective from what the Liberal Party was suggesting at the time. If I were Senator Vanstone, I would not be running an advertisement for anything, whether I agreed with the Liberal Party or not. If it was as good as the effort she put up on the consumption tax, with her little pamphlet and all of the little diagrams—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right. It was not much of a job. She sabotaged her own Party. If she actually disagreed with a party policy, I really do think—
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I ask whether the remarks being made by Senator Faulkner are relevant to the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill.

PARA.TAB: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It really raises the same issue as Senator Schacht raised: this seems to be totally irrelevant to the report of the Senate Select Committee.

—Order! I must insist that, when I am listening to a point of order from any senator in this place, that senator is heard in silence. I do not need assistance from anyone on either side of the chamber. Senator Parer has raised the question of whether or not Senator Faulkner is being relevant. There has been some fairly wide latitude given today to a number of speakers with regard to this Bill. It is a very broad, wide-reaching Bill. Therefore, I cannot uphold the point of order because Senator Faulkner is traversing areas that are within the ambit of the Bill.

—Senator Vanstone wasted 30 minutes, and I can assure the Senate that I do not intend to waste any more than 30 seconds on Senator Vanstone. All the hard evidence that came before the Committee could be described as being in support of the general thrust of the report we have tabled today—and those opposite know it. It is quite clear that the costs of political campaigning in this country are changing the nature of the political process. It is also quite clear from the evidence the Committee received that the substantial costs of political campaigning are in electronic advertising: $15m was spent on broadcast advertising in the last Federal election campaign.

PARA.TAB: In order to deal with those escalating costs and with the fact that the sleaze factor is becoming more common in Australian politics, this Government has a responsibility to act, and act now, to contain costs and remove the influence of money from the Australian political process. I believe this Bill does that. I believe the report of the Select Committee helps the Government to deal with some minor problems that have been identified by interest groups. It puts some different views before the Senate and it proposes some significant changes to the legislation that I believe will improve it and make it acceptable to the vast majority of ordinary Australians.

I believe that the fundamental task of this Government—and it should be the fundamental task of all Australian parliamentarians—is to remove the sleaze factor from Australian politics and to deal with the possibility of corruption in the political process. I believe the Bill and the report of the Committee are of great assistance in achieving that goal.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I claim to have been misrepresented by Senator Faulkner. During the massive diatribe by Senator Faulkner—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order! If it is a personal explanation it can be only that; it cannot be a comment on anyone else's speech. You must explain where you were personally misrepresented.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner said, among other things, that my sole purpose in being on the task force was to interrupt and cause problems for the Chairman. The point I wish to make is that that is absolutely not true. My task was—as it is the task of every person on a committee—to make sure that the Committee was conducted fairly and equitably toward all honourable senators on the Committee and to ensure that witnesses were given a fair chance to answer questions put to them by honourable senators. I believe a reading of the Hansard will demonstrate the accuracy of what I say. The Committee did have problems with the Chairman, and Senator Faulkner was right to draw our attention to that. The Chairman seemed to believe it was his role to harangue witnesses—

—Order! Senator Kemp, I specifically said to you before you spoke that you are making a personal explanation. That means you discuss ways in which you were misrepresented. You cannot comment on the speeches of other people or any misrepresentation that might relate to them. That is not your business. Have you finished your personal explanation?

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek your guidance. I am seeking to explain why I do not believe that, as Senator Faulkner said, my sole task was to interrupt and cause problems for the Committee Chairman. I am seeking to explain that.

—I rise on a point of order. I was here during Senator Faulkner's speech. I do not believe that he said Senator Kemp went on to the Committee with the sole task of disrupting it. He said that once Senator Kemp was on the Committee his performance was such and such—

—Senator Schacht, it is an interesting point of order, but it is irrelevant. Except by leave of the Senate, you cannot explain the points that were made in Senator Faulkner's speech. Therefore, I call Senator Kemp and ask whether he has finished his personal explanation.
—I think that point of order shows exactly the problems we had on the Committee.

—I would like to speak very briefly on the report from the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures, in response to some statements made by other speakers. What the Senate Select Committee looked at was a Bill that was introduced by Senator Bolkus to ban all political advertising on 365 days of the year by all political parties and all interest groups. Tacked on the end were a couple of clauses relating to disclosure.

PARA.TAB: What is very clear from this report is that the majority report makes a sham of the committee system, and this is not the first time. It is apparent that Labor members on the Committee went there with a predetermined conclusion. When I interjected in the debate earlier, Senator Robert Ray said yes, he agreed, and made the point. This Parliament has dragged in witness after witness at great expense to the taxpayers of Australia—and what for? What did they achieve? The conclusion by the Labor members on the Committee was predetermined. It was a sham, and it raises questions about the whole committee system, a system that is supposedly bipartisan. It is not the first time it has happened. I will not go into the other one, but the classic related to Sydney Airport.

During your own contribution to this debate, Mr Acting Deputy President, you asked why I appeared on behalf of the Liberal Party. The Select Committee was looking at a Bill that was before the Parliament. I know that it is hard for Labor members and senators to understand the difference between the Liberal Party and the Labor Party. I made clear in my submission why I was there. In contrast to the Labor Party, the organisational wing of the Liberal Party does not claim the right to dictate policy to the parliamentary party. The Liberal Party believes that parliamentary representatives should be accountable to their constituents, not to a small cadre of union officials and party activists. That is what we had on that Committee—party activists; just look at them, because that is all they were. I think the position should be clarified. Also a remark made by you, Mr Acting Deputy President, intimated that Mr Hogg—

TALK.START.PARA: —Does Senator Schacht have to babble on in this way? He has had his chance but never stops. He is just like a lorikeet over there. Incidentally, he claims to be the great champion of freedom in other places. We hear him in here every day talking about Myanmar, South Africa and so on, but what happened when a witness appeared before the Committee who was scared out of his brain when giving the evidence he did? Senator Schacht intimidated him in a way that Senator Schacht himself would have been disgusted at had it occurred in another country. It was an absolute disgrace.

PARA.TAB: The young man who gave evidence was frightened. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Veterans' Affairs: Work Bans

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on a matter of public interest which I think will concern all honourable senators and certainly will concern the public. Several weeks ago, staff at the Department of Veterans' Affairs National Computer Centre in Sydney placed bans on the use of computer facilities as a protest against proposed staff arrangements following the decision to privatise the National Computer Centre. The Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, in this place, in answer to a question I asked of him, said that the work bans were deplorable and that the action of the Public Sector Union was not responsible action in the circumstances.

PARA.TAB: The Government took the union to the Industrial Relations Commission on a number of occasions and had the bans declared illegal, and still they remained in place despite repeated attempts to dislodge them. These are the staff who, in a submission in March last year, said that one of the penalties of commercialisation of these computer facilities would be the loss of `a loyal and dedicated staff who understand what the Department and its clients need'. The actions of the Public Sector Union throughout this whole dispute show a total lack of understanding of the needs of the veterans community, a total lack of concern for those health service providers who look after the veterans, and, I now find, a total lack of concern for the taxpayers of Australia, many of whom are in difficult financial circumstances, as we all know.

I have criticised the Government for not being prepared to take strong enough action against this union. The people involved could well have been stood down. They could well have lost their pay for not doing the work for which they were employed. Those work bans went on for far too long, as a result of the Government's inaction and its failure to take the union head on, as it deserves to be. Single mothers, whom the Government professes to be concerned about, were going without pay while they continued to look after our veterans on their daily visits to their homes.

However, I want to take the matter further. The Department then placed advertisements in the daily newspapers advising veterans that their pensions would continue to be paid despite the continuing work bans, although many of the allowances were not paid. Those advertisements, of course, were an extra cost to revenue and a cost to the taxpayer. But, beyond that, we now find that the taxpayer has been funding the campaign. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter which was sent by Mr Robert Morrison of the Public Sector Union Delegates Committee in Brisbane to the Secretary of the Proserpine Returned Services League Club.

SPEECH.PARA: Public Sector Union DVA Sub-Branch Delegates Committee (SDC)
Dear Secretary

PARA.TAB: You may be aware that Public Sector Union members in the Department of Veterans Affairs are currently taking action as a result of the Federal Government's decision to privatise the Department's National Computer Centre. All PSU actions to date have been directed at the Department and the PSU is making every effort to minimise the impact of these actions on clients, but the Government's privatisation moves will have a serious impact on DVA staff and clients alike.

In July the Government announced its decision to privatise the operations of the National Computer Centre. Bids from public sector agencies were rejected and two private companies were asked to make "best and final offers" in line with the Government's stated aim of promoting the Australian information technology industry. Yet according to newspaper reports one of these firms is now merging with a multi-national company.

There is also significant community concern over the security of client information, highlighted in the "4 Corners" report of 21 October 1991. The privatisation means that client's personal and medical details will be put into unknown, unaccountable hands of an organisation whose main motivation is profit. This decision is of grave concern to the PSU generally in that Government functions, particularly records, should remain the sole responsibility of the Government and be carried out in the public sector. The significant issues are security of data, privacy provisions, enforcement of contractual penalties and protection against financial devastation. Effectively the decision to privatise the Computer Centre is the PRIVATISATION OF PENSIONS.

This issue is just one aspect of the Government's dismantling of the Department of Veterans Affairs. The transfer of Repatriation hospitals to State control, the proposal to move the Treatment Accounts area to the Health Insurance Commission, and rumours regarding the Social Security take over of Veteran's Pension payments show the general trend to wind down services to veterans. The PSU is also concerned by membership job losses in this time of rising unemployment. It is because of the likely loss of nearly 100 jobs in the National Computer Centre, without any real recompense for workers, that our members have been forced to put bans on computer systems.

Letters of support have been received from the general public and from some veteran's organisations (who suggested that we write to you), but more support is needed. Please discuss the issues outlined in this letter with your members and with other veterans organisations. Any letters of support would be greatly appreciated. Also make your views known to your Federal member of parliament, the Prime Minister and the Minister for Veterans Affairs.
If you have any questions or concerns about this matter, please contact Robert Morrison on (07) 223 8316 or Jenny Thompson on (07) 223 8319.

SPEECH.PARA: Yours faithfully
R. Morrison
for PSU Delegates Committee

TALK.START.PARA: —The delegate, Mr Robert Morrison, said in that letter that the delegates wanted support from veterans, from their members and from other veterans organisations. They wanted that support to be by way of public statements, by lobbying Federal members, by lobbying the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and by lobbying the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys). That letter gave the names and phone numbers of two union members—Robert Morrison on (07) 223 8316 and Jenny Thompson on (07) 223 8319.

PARA.TAB: Obviously, those telephones were going to be used during departmental time. We wonder whether the letter was prepared during departmental time. Certainly the introduction and signature on each letter were handwritten. To make matters worse, the envelope is a departmental envelope. It has on it `Commonwealth Department of Veterans' Affairs, GPO Box 651, Brisbane, Queensland, 4001', and, as honourable senators can see, postage was paid by the taxpayer.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a rip-off, Senator.

—I am glad the Leader of the Government acknowledges it is a rip-off. I call on the Government to investigate this matter. I understand that it took place not only in Brisbane; it was more widespread than that. I clearly see from the Minister's statement that he does not consider it acceptable for the Public Sector Union to use departmental resources, including telephones, postage and stationery, together with staff time, for union activities. I ask the Minister: will he see that an investigation into this issue is carried out immediately? PARA.TAB: I am sure that the veterans of this country and their carers, as well as the taxpayers of Australia, will be appalled to know that this group, which has been responsible for the hardship to them resulting from the work bans, was at the same time stealing from the Commonwealth to further its activities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PARA.TAB: This Bill proposes amendments to the Excise Tariff Act 1921 to incorporate into that Act 2 Excise Tariff Proposals already tabled in Parliament.

The first Proposal relates to an increase in excise duty for naturally occurring liquefied petroleum gas, or LPG and the second relates to a decrease in excise duty for gasoline for use in aircraft, or Avgas.

SPEECH.PARA: LPG

PARA.TAB: Clause 4 of the Bill will increase the excise rate for LPG for the period 1 April 1991 to 1 July 1991 from $5.78 per kilolitre to $35.94 per kilolitre.

The amount of excise duty payable on naturally occurring LPG is adjusted in April and October each year in accordance with this Government's and the previous Government's long standing policy of calculating the excise duty on the basis of 60% of the amount by which the realised price for naturally occurring LPG exceeds $147 per tonne. The realised price is calculated as a weighted average of the prices received from exports and local sale of LPG during, in this case, the six month period from 1 September 1990 until 28 February 1991.
The increase in the excise rate effected by Clause 4 reflects the higher export prices obtained for LPG during the relevant six month period as a result of the Iraq/Kuwait conflict.

It is noted that as from 1 July this year the excise on LPG has been replaced by a resource rent tax, under the Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Act 1991 which amended the Petroleum Rent Tax Assessment Act 1987. Transitional arrangements in that Act provide that excise collected since 1 July 1990 on naturally occurring LPG is offset against the producer's tax liability under the resource rent tax legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: AVGAS

PARA.TAB: Clause 3 of the Bill will decrease the excise duty on Avgas with effect from 1 July 1991, by reducing the rate of excise from 27.395 cents per litre to 27.074 cents per litre. The decrease is due to the withdrawal of the Civil Aviation Authority's rescue and firefighting service from capital city secondary airports.

When the Civil Aviation Authority was established on 1 July 1988, the Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriation) Act provided for the payment to the Authority of that portion of the revenue from Avgas excise which had historically been attributed to the functions transferred to the CAA.

Subsequently, the general aviation representative associations advised the authority that they no longer required the rescue and fire fighting service (RFFS) at capital city secondary airports. The capital city secondary airports are Archerfield in Brisbane, Bankstown in Sydney, Essendon and Moorabbin in Melbourne, Parafield in Adelaide and Jandakot in Perth.
Accordingly, the Civil Aviation Authority Board decided to remove the service from those airports from 1 July 1991.

The CAA's decision to withdraw its rescue and firefighting services from the 6 secondary airports followed a comprehensive review of existing rescue and firefighting services arrangements which involved input from the aviation industry, local authorities, metropolitan fire brigades and the Federal Airports Corporation.
In view of the removal of the service the Board requested that the rate of Avgas excise which had been calculated as an offset against the cost of providing the service be similarly reduced.

SPEECH.PARA: FINANCIAL IMPACT STATEMENT
A)Liquefied Petroleum Gas

PARA.TAB: The increase in the excise rate for naturally occurring LPG is estimated to result in an increase of $9.4 million in excise receipts for the three months commencing on 1 April 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: B)Gasoline for use in Aircraft

PARA.TAB: Nil; the reduction in the rate of excise and customs duty on gasoline for use in aircraft will reduce the Commonwealth revenue by approximately $340,000 for l991-1992. Money appropriated to the Civil Aviation Authority will reduce by that amount so therefore there will be no net financial impact.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present its Explanatory Memorandum.

SPEECH.PARA: CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL
Mr President

PARA.TAB: The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991, which is now before the chamber, contains a number of amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1987. Some of these amendments have previously been introduced as Customs tariff proposals.
Sections three and four of the Bill are operative on and from the twelfth of March 1991 and contain administrative amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1987.

Section three contains a change to section 14 of the principal act to ensure that "free" is a rate of duty for the purposes of section 19 of the principal Act, which was amended by the Customs Tariff Amendment Act 1991.

Section four defines the developing country rate of duty for certain goods presently covered by quota arrangements which end in 1993. This is necessary to implement new preference arrangements for the republic of Korea, Hong Kong, Taiwan province and Singapore in respect of these goods. These preference arrangements have effect from the first of July 1992 and correct tariff changes contained in the Customs Tariff Amendment Act 1991.

Section 13 amends paragraph 10(1)(b) of the Customs Tariff Amendment Act 1991 by inserting a reference to the first of July 1992. This amendment takes effect on the twelfth of March this year and ensures the correct implementation of phasing rates of duty announced in the Government's Industry Statement.

Schedule one provides a duty free rate for pre-tanned bovine and equine leather. This corrects an anomaly introduced at the time of conversion to the harmonized tariff and operates on and from the first of January 1988.

Schedule two provides a free rate of duty for parts of wheelchairs. This results from a government decision on the Industry Commission's report on "aids and appliances for people with disabilities". Minor amendments are also made to two subheadings of chapter 90 following printing errors in the Customs Tariff Amendment Act 1991. This schedule operates on and from the first of January 1991.

Schedule three is operative on and from the twelfth of March 1991. It implements phasing rates of duty for certain goods of 2204 and 2205, in accordance with the Government's Industry Statement. For technical reasons, these changes were not able to be implemented by the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1991. Minor administrative changes are made to two subheadings of chapter 63 and to subitems 11a and 21v in schedule 5.

Schedule four which is operative on and from the tenth of April 1991 contains a new additional note to chapter 20. This note defines orange juice to include products of oranges, regardless of methods of derivation. This amendment restores the intended rates of assistance for orange juice, following representations from the local citrus industry.

Schedule five is operative on and from the first of July 1991. It contains administrative amendments to subheadings in chapters 7 and 17. Rates of duty for Canada are inserted in two subheadings of chapter 20. These amendments correct administrative oversights in the Customs Tariff Amendment Act 1991.

The rate of duty on aviation gasoline has been reduced by 0.321 cents per litre. This results from a decision by the Civil Aviation Authority to withdraw its rescue and firefighting service from capital city secondary airports. Part of the customs duty collected on aviation gasoline was regarded as an offset against the cost of providing this service.
Minor amendments are made to note 1 and subnote 2(b) to chapter 43 to conform with changes to the harmonized nomenclature.

Schedule five also implements measures to facilitate Australia's partial accession to the 1950 UNESCO agreement, more commonly known as the Florence Agreement. The changes introduce free rates of duty for educational, scientific and cultural material.

Schedule six which is operative on and from the first of October 1991 accords Czechoslovakia developing country status, as announced by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce on the fourteenth of August. The Government has also accorded this status to Namibia.

Schedule seven is operative on and from the first of January 1992. It includes changes to various section and chapter notes, headings and interpretative rules in the harmonized nomenclature. Australia is a signatory to the Customs Co-operation Council Convention and under article 16 is obliged to implement periodic changes to the harmonized system.
Some of the changes are substantial and the following consequential amendments have been introduced:
A new subheading of heading 2106 has been created to maintain protective rates of duty for certain food preparations which have been reclassified;
Subheading 2818.10 Has been split to maintain protective rates for artificial Corundum, not chemically defined; and

Additional note 2 to chapter 61, additional note 1 to chapter 62 and the additional note to chapter 95 have been omitted. The substance of these notes has been incorporated in other notes or headings of schedule 3.
Other changes are of an administrative nature only and have no effect on classification or duty rates.
Schedule eight will have effect on and from fourteen days after this Bill receives Royal assent, and contains the following changes:

Denatured ethyl alcohol is amended by removing the revenue component from the current duty rate. Excise duty applies only to potable spirits for human consumption. Denatured ethyl alcohol, or methylated spirits, is free from excise duty when produced in Australia. The inclusion of an excise equivalent duty in the customs tariff is therefore an anomaly, as only the protective element of the customs duty should be applicable.

The amendment of this item will correct this anomaly and together with associated administrative changes to the excise regulations will streamline the import regime applicable to methylated spirits; and
Other minor administrative changes which are consequential to amendments contained in previous Customs Tariff Amendment Acts.

SPEECH.PARA: Financial Impact

PARA.TAB: Tariff changes to implement the terms of the Florence Agreement will involve a revenue loss of approximately $28 million in 1991/92, $30 million in 1992/93 and $32 million in 1993/94.
Customs duty forgone through the reduction of the duty rate for aviation gasoline is expected to be approximately $35,000 per annum.

The inclusion of Czechoslovakia in the list of developing countries is expected to result in a revenue loss of around $1.7 million per annum. The inclusion of Namibia will result in a loss of around $7,000 per annum.
The initiative to reduce the duty rate for parts of wheelchairs is expected to cost less than $100,000 per annum.
Other changes contained in this Bill will have only minor revenue implications.
Details of the amendments contained in this Bill have been included in an explanatory memorandum which has been circulated for the information of Honourable Senators.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Speaking for the Opposition on these two Bills, I note that the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1991 increases the duty payable on LPG from 1 April 1991 to 1 July 1991 in accordance with the proclaimed formula which increases the duty from $5.75 per kilolitre to $35.94 per kilolitre. That was basically as a consequence of the increase in prices through the Gulf War. But from 1 July 1991, which is now past, it is replaced by the resource rent tax under the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Amendment Act 1991, so there will be no requirement for any future Bill of this nature to contain such a provision.

PARA.TAB: The second part deals with a reduction in excise on aviation gasoline to compensate for the fact that firefighting provisions at secondary airports around Australia have been withdrawn. That has led to a huge decrease of 0.321c per litre from 27.395c per litre to 27.074c per litre. As a purchaser of avgas, I welcome the move, but I must say that it is so small as to not send me into paroxysms of ecstasy.

In one sense, the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill is a routine tariff Bill which comes before the chamber quite regularly, amending rates of duty; but in this case it also includes some policy issues and extends developing nation status for some new countries. The Bill, after some definitions and dates for operation of certain sections, defines the developing country rate of duty for certain goods which are presently covered by quota arrangements which end in 1993. There are some corrections in accordance with the harmonised tariff and there are some corrections of anomalies created by the introduction of the harmonised tariff. A free rate of duty is declared for parts of wheelchairs. Orange juice has been redefined to include products of oranges, regardless of methods of derivation, to restore the intended rate of assistance to the Australian industry.

The important policy change introduced is to facilitate Australia's partial accession to the 1950 UNESCO agreement—the so-called Florence Agreement. This allows free rates of duty for educational, scientific and cultural material. Developing country status is conferred on Czechoslovakia and Namibia. The Opposition does not oppose that, but I think it is more than time for Australia to look at the concessions it gives on tariffs to developing nations. Some of those nations now arguably have a higher standard of living—or will very soon have a higher standard of living—than Australia has. The only thing in defence of the present policy is that with falling levels of tariff protection, the concessions granted to developing nations obviously become fewer year by year. Finally, the revenue component is removed from the current duty rate on the revenue collected on denatured ethyl alcohol.

In the few moments I have left I will make some observations on tariffs. My position on this is very clear. I came into the Senate nearly 14 years ago and in my maiden speech I talked about the dangers of a very high tariff regime. I have not changed my basic position. Obviously, over the years experience has tended to give me a slightly different view on some details, but the basic principle that I had when I came in years ago was that tariff protection really is something that should be eliminated but, from a practical point of view, if that cannot be attained, it should be kept at the very lowest level.

When I came into the Senate the average industry rate was about 30 per cent. It is interesting to note that some of the few people here now on both sides who were in the Parliament at that time have become arch proponents of a low tariff regime, but at the time it was not a very popular position to adopt. The evils of it were quite obvious: poor productivity, poor management, strong unions and very, very low productivity in Australia. That was because, when there were any problems at all, a manufacturer would simply ask for increased tariff protection and it would be granted. We even went past tariff protection and got to the absurd stage of having quotas, which further distorted the markets.

I am pleased that there has been a reduction in tariffs, but it is not a simple matter that can be thought about in black-and-white terms so we can say either that we will have no tariffs or that we will have a lot of them. There are very significant consequences in reducing tariff regimes. They have to be thought through and alternative strategies have to be put in place to compensate for those changes. I think the Government is doing that.

My great concern with what is happening at present is that the matter of balance is not being addressed. General Australian industry tariff protection—and I am pleased to see that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, is in the chair for this, and can correct me if I am wrong—with the exception of two groups, is around 7 per cent—yes, the Minister confirms that. And that is a great reduction on what it was before.

To return to the question of balance, two industry groups are excluded: the textile, clothing and footwear group, and the motor industry group. Both of those have had very effective lobbies, irrespective of the politics of the government of the day.
I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later hour this day.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! In accordance with the undertaking I gave earlier, I will now set out for the Senate the procedural implications of the proposed resolution for a joint meeting of the two Houses to be addressed by President Bush.

PARA.TAB: In doing so I make it clear that it is a matter for decision by the Senate whether this meeting takes place and the form it takes. The proposed joint meeting can occur only if agreed to by the Senate by resolution.
I will now set out the effect of the parts of the provisions of the resolution proposed by the Government.

Paragraph (1)(a) of the resolution would invite the President of the United States to address the Senate at the proposed time. The reason for this provision is that it is proposed that this occasion be a formal meeting of the Senate. A person other than a senator cannot address the Senate except by express invitation of the Senate. This paragraph would also fix the time for the proposed meeting in the same way as the Senate fixes the times of its normal meetings.

Paragraph (1)(b) of the resolution accepts the invitation of the House of Representatives to meet with that House in the House of Representatives chamber. It is for the Senate to determine the place, as well as the time, of its meetings. The effect of this paragraph is that the Senate would hold a formal meeting in the House of Representatives chamber at the invitation of that House. The situation at the meeting would be that the two Houses would be holding formal meetings simultaneously in the same place, so that President Bush would be addressing a formal meeting of the two Houses together.

Paragraph (1)(c) of the resolution would have the effect that the Senate would adopt for itself the rules proposed by the House of Representatives for the joint meeting. This is necessary because, as the meeting would be a formal meeting of each House, it is necessary to provide some rules for the meeting. The rules proposed by the House are contained in paragraph (3) of the resolution of the House, and are as follows:

INTERJECT.PARA: (a)the Speaker would preside at the meeting—

and I would like to make it clear that it is proposed that I be seated on the dais next to the Speaker during the meeting, as occurred with the former Speaker when she attended the last joint meeting here in the Senate—
(b)the only proceedings at the meeting would be an address by the President of the United States—
it is proposed that the Speaker briefly introduce President Bush, and after President Bush's address the meeting would be automatically adjourned—
(c)the procedures of the House would apply to the meeting so far as they are applicable. . .

It is necessary to make this provision to avoid any difficulty arising from any inconsistency between the procedures of the two Houses; it should not be necessary to apply any procedures because of paragraph (b).

PARA.TAB: If this resolution is passed the Senate will assemble, at the time provided, in the House of Representatives chamber, for the formal meeting of the Senate at that time and place.

The procedure proposed by the resolution is entirely new, because neither House has a practice of allowing persons other than members to address it, and neither House has procedures for joint meetings for this purpose. I stress again that it is a matter for the Senate to decide whether this new procedure is to be adopted on this occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I am speaking to the resumption of the debate on the original motion put by Senator Robert Ray. I may have already spoken on it, but presumably I can speak again.
—You are tired, Senator.

—I am not tired at all. The problem, regrettably, is that the Government did not extend us the courtesy of showing us the proposed resolution that it was going to put forthwith in this chamber. The usual procedure is that notice is given and we have a chance to consider the content. In this instance, no doubt because of the time constraints, the Government wanted to put it immediately. We would simply have appreciated an opportunity to peruse it and consider it.

PARA.TAB: As you have said in your statement, Mr President, what is proposed here is entirely new. Neither House has procedures for joint meetings. If we are to take a step which may well have consequences down the track, I would have thought we would have been extended the courtesy of an opportunity to consider the detail. Anyway, the Government, after we raised the matter, has given us several hours to do so.

The first point that I want to make is that, as I understand it, this matter has come about because of the courtesy that was extended to Prime Minister Hawke to address a joint sitting of the US Congress. The Prime Minister accepted the invitation and addressed the joint sitting. In accordance with the usual practice in the United States, that sitting is in the House of Representatives. The Prime Minister was desirous of extending a similar courtesy, on behalf of the Parliament of Australia, to the President of the United States.

As we understand it, this is very much a one-off situation. It is not the normal practice in this country. We have adopted the practice of giving a foreign dignitary who is here as a guest of government the opportunity to address parliamentarians elsewhere in the building—usually at a ceremonial dinner in the Great Hall. The distinction has been drawn here because we are repaying a courtesy that was extended by the United States Congress.

We are addressing this matter very much on the basis that it is not intended to set any precedent. We understand that to be the case and that is the way we have been looking at it. This occasion should not be confused with a joint sitting of the chambers—we understand the situation that is prescribed under the law in this country in this respect—which is very rare and which has nothing to do with what is proposed on this occasion.

I am pleased, Mr President, that in the statement that you have just put before us, you have, in fact, used the language `proposed joint meeting of the Houses' so that that confusion will not be drawn.
