Unfortunately, the language of `joint sitting' has been used by others and that has confused the issue and raised questions of precedents of joint sittings, where they took place and the format for those sittings under Australian law. That is not relevant, as I understand it, in this instance. It is not a joint sitting of the chambers; it is proposed that a unique joint meeting of both Houses will be called.

In this unusual circumstance, the next question is, I guess, `Which is the more appropriate chamber for such a joint meeting to be held?'. However, because such a meeting is unprecedented, there is little we can turn to in that regard. As I said, we are repaying a courtesy that took place in the United States lower House. I hesitate to refer to a previous joint sitting, because I think it is probably unhelpful to do so, but the one in 1974 in this Parliament was in the House of Representatives. Openings are held in the Senate and the Monarch or the Monarch's representative attends under the terms of the Constitution. The House of Representatives is invited to attend our chamber and is addressed by the Monarch or the Monarch's representative.

Even though it is inappropriate to look to precedents, there does not seem to be a clear message in similar examples as to what is the more appropriate measure. In this instance, the invitation was to be in the House of Representatives. So, in those terms, we believe that a precedent will definitely not be created if, in the future, another government desires to repay a courtesy that might be extended to an Australian Prime Minister.

Whilst I understand and I appreciate the reasons for this being held in the chamber, I think it does create some little difficulty for the future in that I am not sure that other foreign dignitaries will understand or readily accept the argument that I have just put as to why the US President should be uniquely excepted from our normal practice. It is a situation that we are, nevertheless, prepared to accept and to deal with as it might occur in the future.

Mr President, we have on that basis had a look at the words of the motion that the Government has put before us today. The words `joint meeting' seem to us to be appropriate to what is being sought. We accept what you say, that if it is to be a joint meeting it also requires an invitation of the Senate. This is something that we have not addressed because the words of that motion were put before us only this morning.

I stress that we do not see it creating any precedent as to which is the more appropriate chamber for such exercises or for the way in which we should repay courtesies or offer courtesy to foreign dignitaries. Therefore, taking into account all of the circumstances, we are prepared to accept the motion that is before the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats have some major concerns that follow on from a lot of what Senator Hill has been saying. I will deal firstly with the issue of precedent. It will be very difficult in the future to say to other foreign dignitaries, other foreign heads of state, `No, you do not rate quite that highly'. I wonder how much of a precedent we really are setting. I would like the Government to tell the Senate where the line will be drawn in the future.

PARA.TAB: I am well aware that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) addressed the American Congress when he visited the United States. However, this was by no means a unique occurrence. This courtesy is extended by the United States federal parliament to numerous foreign dignitaries. That is its practice; that is its procedure. But we will be setting an entirely new procedure for our Parliament. The opinion of the Australian Democrats is that it is far more appropriate that the joint meeting be held in the Great Hall, as has been the practice in the past.

Another concern of the Democrats is the timing of the meeting and, therefore, the enormous cost that will be involved. My second question to the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) relates to the provision of full estimates of cost, including the cost of travel. I imagine that honourable senators would not need staff but there certainly would be a travel cost for all honourable senators and probably for some spouses. There would certainly be a cost in running Parliament House in terms of attendants, security staff, catering staff, et cetera. I would like, within a week or so, to be given an estimate of the cost so that the Australian Democrats can look further at it. Even before receiving such an estimate, I suggest that it probably will be a fairly large sum. At a time when government is cutting costs everywhere and anywhere, there would be far better ways in which that money could be spent.

Finally, I want to refer to something that the President said in introducing this debate. He said that it is up to us to ask whether there has already been an exchange of letters and undertakings inviting the President of the United States of America to the joint meeting, or at least some understanding that he will be invited. If that has occurred, it will be very difficult for us to pull out now. It will be very difficult for the Senate if the House of Representatives has passed a motion and it is understood that a joint meeting will take place. If some indication has already been given, it will be extremely difficult for us to do anything now but to sit here and nod.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! As I understand it, the invitation is in this motion. If this motion is not passed, there will not be an invitation.
—That is not answering the question. The question was: were letters exchanged?
—What I said was that the invitation is in this motion. So there has been no invitation yet and there will not be one unless this motion is passed. That is the way I understand it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the National Party of Australia, I support the words of the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) welcoming the visit of President Bush to Australia and to the Australian Parliament to address both Houses. The National Party supports the invitation to the President of the United States of America to address both Houses of Parliament. It is pleasing that the visit to Australia could be rescheduled for January after the President's November visit was postponed. President Bush is most welcome. It is hoped that he will go home with a better knowledge of what is happening in rural Australia and how his subsidy program is affecting the farmers of Australia.

—in reply—If honourable senators wish to oppose this motion, I would indicate that I do not propose to have a division during the lunchtime sitting. This could probably be done immediately after Question Time. However, I do not anticipate that occurring.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill has complained about the short notice. That is a matter for regret. I might explain that as I was not on chamber duty this morning until five minutes to 10, he probably saw the motion at the same time I did. I will pass on his remarks about communications. I think the urgency of the matter was, as he has surmised, that if there were to be amendments or otherwise, it would be preferred, given the long planning processes involved, to get them to the House of Representatives and back today while that House is still sitting.

In terms of the point made by Senator Lees about the question of precedent, we did not worry about that during the wartime session in the 1940s when General Macarthur sat in the House of Representatives next to the Speaker. Maybe that is one of the reasons that President Bush and his country are special in this instance. I do not think anyone else around the world will regard it as a poor precedent that President Bush has been invited to address the joint sittings.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a joint meeting.

—Yes. I recognise that it is an extraordinary privilege that we extend. It is more extraordinary from our point of view than it would be from the Americans' point of view because it is something that occurs not every day but with some regularity in their country.

PARA.TAB: I have been asked about the cost of reconvening parliament. This has been done on numerous occasions. If honourable senators want to raise the question of cost, they should have a look at what the Macklin motion has cost in terms of reconvening parliament over the last four or five years. I will be quite happy to compare those costs with the cost of this joint meeting. These things do cost, though, and one must make a judgment as to whether it is worth the cost.

President Bush obviously has had some problems with timing and most of that is related to his relationship with Congress. He had to cancel his previous trip and I assume that the timing of this trip is due to the fact that Congress certainly will not be meeting at that time. Questions about costs should be formally put on notice so that the relevant Ministers can give an accurate answer. I suggest that the questions should probably be directed to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, which can then collate answers from other departments.
We have been asked whether an invitation has been issued.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, you were not asked that. You were asked whether letters were exchanged.

—I do not need the honourable senator's help. In these finer diplomatic matters, it is usually neither of those things—an invitation has not been issued and letters have not been exchanged. What tends to happen is that this matter is raised at an ambassadorial level with the appropriate White House officer, that Australians are thinking of—
—No letters were exchanged?
—Not that I know of, Senator. I cannot be absolutely—
—But you are going to find out?
—I am not going to find out, Senator. The President has taken that matter on board and I am sure, knowing how tolerant he is of idiotic questions, that he will respond over time to that point.

PARA.TAB: I was trying to explain that there would be some knowledge in Washington of this proposal at this stage, because the way it is done in diplomatic circles is that these matters are raised at an unofficial level to test a potential reaction. So whilst there is no official invitation and I doubt that there has been what the honourable senator calls an exchange of letters, certainly from an ambassadorial level to a certain level in the White House, when the itinerary was being discussed the proposal of a joint meeting of the House of Representatives and the Senate to hear President Bush would have been washed through the system to find out whether they also thought that was a good idea.
These things are usually done on a semi-official level. I know that Foreign Affairs and Defence do these sorts of things every day.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it cannot help to refer to it as an idiotic question. What Senator Walters had asked is quite a correct matter to pursue.

—I am sorry. The honourable senator is right in saying that the subject matter is not idiotic—I withdraw that. But the constant harping on the point when it has been taken up lacks just a bit of delicacy. It is a constant and repeated behaviour pattern from that particular senator.
—Mr President, I take a point of order. I will not be spoken to like that by Senator Ray.
—The honourable senator is speaking to me like that.
—I did not speak to the Minister like that. I take great exception to his referring to me in that way and I would like him to withdraw.

—Mr President, I will withdraw. But I do not think, in the normal circumstances, anything I said was of that nature. As the honourable senator has raised this matter, I will rephrase what I said: the constant interjecting by Senator Walters is unparliamentary and is a disgrace to this place. I will leave it at that.

PARA.TAB: I would now like to be a little more gracious and thank the Opposition—the Liberal and National parties—the Australian Democrats and others for their support on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —He does not have the numbers; that is his problem.

—I will acknowledge that remark just to indicate for history exactly how silly it is. I think a visit by the United States President is very important in an historical context. It is very important to be bipartisan. It is very important, as Senator Boswell has said, that people be able to make the substantive points that they want to make in terms of reinforcing a relationship with the United States but fearlessly raising issues where we have strong disagreements.

PARA.TAB: This particular visit provides a unique opportunity to do that. The fact that we will get a very large turn-up right in the middle of the holiday season, right in the middle of the test cricket season, will definitely prove that the relationship between our countries is a very strong and viable one.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply to the question that I was asked by Senator Walters, as I understand it, if this motion is passed, an invitation from the two Houses will be passed through the Ambassador to the United States President and it will be extended in a letter signed by me and the Speaker. No such letter has been written so far.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL 1991CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 2) 1991

TALK.START.PARA: —To resume from where we were 22 minutes ago, I was talking about the lack of balance in the Government's tariff policy which excluded two groups—the textile, clothing and footwear group and the motor group. It is not my intention to take up the time of the Senate by engaging in a lengthy discussion about tariff policy, but the Parliament has not addressed this vitally important matter. I think it reflects on the Government's management of business that we are dealing with a Bill of this nature, which does provide a legitimate vehicle for senators to express their views on a matter of great importance to Australian industry, within the constraints of a lunchtime debate.

PARA.TAB: I would like to return to the point I was making about the imbalance between these two groups and the rest of Australian industry. This imbalance exists purely because of the effect of the lobby groups which represent both industries. It is very hard to determine the level of tariff protection that applies today in the textile, clothing and footwear group but estimates range between 80 to 150 per cent. For the motor industry it is said to be somewhere around 50 to 60 per cent. Again, I say it is hard to set precise figures. But one thing we can be absolutely certain of is that it is a magnitude beyond the tariff protection that general industry enjoys which, as I said before, is about 7 per cent.

It is important that we look at the consequences of this because everyone needs to wear clothes and everyone needs to wear shoes. The poorest families have to buy clothing and footwear. The effect of the tariff regime means that those families—in fact all of us—have to pay at least twice what we should pay for that clothing. Similarly, in the motor industry, we are paying twice the price that we would pay on the open market.

The other side of it is to look at what benefits we get from this regime. I was browsing recently through the Australian Farm Journal, a journal which I would not put at the highest levels of scholarship in Australia. I doubt that it has the sort of editorial board that most scientific journals would have to review articles before they are published. But the author of an interesting article on protectionism points out that, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures for 1988-89, the textile, clothing and footwear sector comprised 2,311 establishments employing 73,300 people, paid $1.3 billion in wages and generated sales worth about $4.9 billion. The article also points out that, in the same year, Australia exported less than $80m worth of clothing and footwear but imported goods worth $1.1 billion.

In contrast, the farm groups had 125,708 farms in the country, employing about 372,000 people, and their gross value of production was $22.8 billion, and they exported a staggering $16 billion worth of product. The point of relevance here is that the farm sector enjoys little or no tariff protection at all. That leads me to the next point I want to comment on.

There is a great deal of food imported into this country. Most of the stuff, with the possible exception of caviar and French champagne, can be made from Australian sources. The level of importation now runs at in excess of $2.2 billion. It is a huge input. I started expressing concern about this publicly a couple of years back and had a number of press releases, statements and articles published on the nature and extent of the importation of food into Australia. It has since been picked up by others.

In Queensland, one of the large papers ran a campaign to save the pineapple. It was targeted at the importation of pineapples from other Pacific countries which was undercutting the Australian product on the shelves. That was quite a worthy campaign. The trouble with it was that it got off the rails. It failed to look at what was being offered. The problem really is a marketing problem.

Australian food and agricultural producers are pretty efficient. The good ones are very good. The weakness in the whole chain comes with the marketing. The existence of statutory boards, orderly marketing systems and the rest of it have led to monopoly situations which, not in all cases but in a large number of cases, simply are not competitive and do not stay with the market. In the pineapple industry the problem is that the company that does most of the packing and presentation of the product has not moved with the times. In one case it is doing a very good job. It has introduced a new line in fruit juices which is right up to world standards. The quality of the product, the packaging and the presentation of it are absolutely first class, but that is done under a different brand name.

I went out and bought some tinned pineapple last weekend, just out of curiosity, knowing I was going to make this speech. The tins I bought off the supermarket shelf were actually rusty. The labelling is the same as when I was a kid, except that it now has a bar code on it. The presentation of the food is simply not competitive. That general comment can be applied to most Australian food producers. The presentation and marketing is bad. It is not competitive.

When I am going around Asian areas I always go into the supermarkets, and I go into the supermarkets in the most expensive stores because that is where one is going to get imported food. It has been my experience in Tokyo, Manila and other capital cities in Asia that it is very rare to find Australian food on supermarket shelves. One will find a great amount of American food, one will find European food from all countries, and one will find New Zealand food.

New Zealand is very actively marketing into an area which is in our own backyard. Part of that problem, I think, comes from the fact that some of the larger Australian food processors are overseas owned and the owners put marketing restrictions on where the Australian companies can sell. I emphasise the point that if Australia is to counter the flood of imports, it is not necessarily a matter of calling for tariff protection. The first thing to do is to make sure that we have a competitive product coming out of our own sources before we make any complaints.

Senator Hill said something a few minutes ago, by way of interjection, about New Zealand. I do not know any more dishonest country with respect to overseas marketing than New Zealand. I will give the Senate an example.I was contacted a while ago by probably the best producer of oysters, with respect to high quality oysters, in this country. He told me the story of how he had an order from New Zealand for frozen oysters. He supplied 100 dozen oysters to New Zealand. They were frozen; they were opened on a half shell. The day before they arrived in New Zealand, the New Zealand Government, despite the CER agreement, changed the regulation to ban them. The oysters could not be sold in New Zealand.

Last night, the principal of the same company told me that he was at an oyster tasting in Sydney, and being served there—by way of comparison—were New Zealand oysters in precisely the same format as those in which his oysters had been rejected in New Zealand a couple of weeks earlier. If we are going down the path of zero tariff protection, particularly when we have agreements with countries such as New Zealand, in the CER, it is very important that we stand up to them and stop changes to regulations which operate against our interests.

At the end of the day, the final point on zero tariffs is that it does not matter how efficient we are within this country, we will always have a wage inequity. We will always have the case where we pay, in today's figures, a minimum of about $8 an hour. There are other countries in the region that pay about 80 cents an hour or 80 cents a day. That wage balance is something that has always got to be considered.

The biggest issue in the whole of the tariff argument relates to the inefficiencies within the country itself—the problems on the wharfs, the huge problems in transport, the delay over the third runway at Sydney and all the rest of it. It is estimated that inefficiencies that are correctable within Australia add at least $50 billion to the cost of production, the cost of industrial activity in this country. That is the primary target for the Government.

More important than proceeding down the path of tariff reduction is to clean up the inefficiencies within Australia, which can be done. If you go down the path of reducing tariff protection without cleaning up those inefficiencies, you are really taking the life raft away from Australian industry before the passengers of the life raft have reached the shore. We must attend to those reforms within Australian industry and then we must proceed down the path of reducing the tariffs so that Australian industry is competitive and can sell to the markets of the world in the way we have to, to survive, and the way we can if we get efficiencies within this country. I give my support to these two Bills.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I find myself having to dissociate myself from some of Senator MacGibbon's remarks. I would not like it to go on record that the Opposition agreed with the remarks, particularly about the Golden Circle pineapple company.
—I never mentioned it.

—If Senator MacGibbon says that he never mentioned the Golden Circle brand and that it was not antiquated and the tins were not rusty, I completely withdraw those remarks. I accept Senator MacGibbon's word.
—I never mentioned the company name.
—As there is only one company in Australia that produces pineapple, by association he must be referring to that company.

PARA.TAB: The Golden Circle pineapple company in Queensland employs many people—1,300, I think. It is a growers organisation that takes fruit from 500 or 600 growers. I believe its product is absolutely A-grade. It is produced by the most modern technology in the world. It has 75 per cent of the market, and its sales are not reduced because the product is inadequate in any way. The Golden Circle product is one of the best products in Australia and is marketed in the most professional way. The problem that it faces is that much of the imported product has very heavy subsidies on it and is subsidised in a number of ways other than by direct subsidies. I put those facts on the record because, as I said earlier, I certainly would not want Senator MacGibbon's views to be considered as the views of the Opposition in the Senate overall.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions. I shall not referee the brawl between the coalition parties over these matters. It is well known that they have ideological differences over tariff protection. That is the main reason why Senator Boswell does not have a shadow portfolio. He is entitled to put his Party's views about protection, I guess. I do not think there is any specific point I was asked to respond to by any of the speakers. I wish the Bills a speedy passage.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Debate resumed from 7 November, on motion by Senator Collins:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —In handling this Bill on behalf of the Opposition, I indicate at the outset that the Opposition will accept this legislation, which amends the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988 in three principal areas. First, the legislation changes the name of the principal Act to the Financial Transaction Reports Act and the name of the Cash Transaction Reports Agency to the Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre, or AUSTRAC. Secondly, the legislation defines the time at which a person bringing currency into or out of Australia must make a report to a Customs officer. Thirdly, and significantly, the legislation provides for the reporting and analysis of international telegraphic transfer data.

PARA.TAB: To deal briefly with the amendments which change the Agency's name and that of the principal Act, as I said earlier, the Opposition supports this change. The change reflects reality in that the majority of the transactions involved are in fact non-cash transactions.

The second main area of amendment is introduced in clause 7. This clause amends section 15 of the Act, which presently requires a person importing or exporting more than $5,000 in currency to make a report in a prescribed form to a Customs officer. The question has arisen as to exactly when such a report must be made. It was held in a recent South Australian Supreme Court case, Schultz v. Taylor, that a report could still be filed during a Customs baggage search upon a Customs officer discovering the currency. These amendments will make it clear that where currency is being brought into Australia, the relevant time for making the report is when the person arrives at the baggage inspection counter. Where currency is being taken out of Australia, the relevant time is when the person arrives at the passport examination area.

The third area in which this Bill amends the principal Act is in relation to the reporting of international funds transfer instructions. The reporting requirement in relation to cash transfers into and out of Australia applies to hard currency—coin and paper money—and not to telegraphic transfers. The obligation is on the person doing the transfer to report it.

Clause 9 inserts a new division 3 into the Act to deal with reports of international funds transfer instructions. Cash dealers in Australia will be required to report such instructions within 14 days of sending or receiving them, as the case may be.

As is the case with the legislation currently in force, provision will be made to protect cash dealers from suits arising from any action they have taken under the reporting requirements. Officers of the agency will have powers to inspect the reporting systems of cash dealers and it will be an offence to fail to comply with the reporting requirements. Cash dealers who conduct a large volume of transactions by telex and whose systems are not computerised are exempted from reporting requirements until their systems are computerised.

We in the Opposition welcome these amendments. It has become apparent that there are huge losses to taxation revenue resulting from the inability to monitor international telegraphic transfers of funds. Until 1 July 1990, a system of tax screening arrangement and foreign currency controls monitored, to some extent, the movement of funds into and out of Australia. In March 1991 the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration tabled a report dealing with international profit shifting arrangements. Evidence given to that Committee suggested that annual tax revenue losses as a result of the absence of a proper system for detecting tax evasion through profit shifting may be in the order of $100m to $250m. The absence of a proper system for monitoring international transactions also gives rise to $10m in lost Customs revenue and further revenue losses of $30m through the laundering of the proceeds of crime.

The Committee's recommendation, which this Bill implements, was that a system of monitoring international telegraphic transfers be put in place and administered by the Cash Transaction Reports Agency. They are the main aspects of this Bill, which, as I said, the coalition welcomes and supports.

While we are dealing with this legislation, I want to raise some aspects of the principal Act which are for me a cause of concern. Inconvenience and difficulties are being caused by the requirements under the Act with regard to the identification points system for many pensioners seeking to open new bank accounts because they do not readily hold sufficient of the documents or the items on the check list to obtain the requisite 100 points and can only obtain them at considerable expense which, as pensioners, they can ill afford.

I bring to the Senate one example of a constituent who recently raised this issue with me. He is an elderly service pensioner who recently tried to open a savings account with a branch of the Westpac Bank in Adelaide because he already had a defence service home loan with that branch of that bank.

The nearest branch of the Commonwealth Bank, where he currently holds his normal account, now requires him to undertake two separate bus journeys to that bank and is charging what he regards as an exorbitant amount to transfer his mortgage payments from that Commonwealth Bank account to the Westpac Bank branch where his housing loan is being held. For that reason he wished to open a new account at that Westpac Bank branch.

This particular pensioner does not hold a current driver's licence, a birth certificate, or a credit card; nor does he have a telephone service. Therefore, he was unable to obtain the 100 points required to open a new bank account, despite the fact that he has had a housing loan with that bank for the past six years, a loan that is approved by the Government.

Neither the Department of Veterans' Affairs nor the Department of Social Security was able—or they claimed they were unable—to provide a letter of reference of the kind which the bank required for him to gain the requisite points to open this account. Of course, for him as a pensioner to obtain a birth certificate costing $20 was something which he could ill afford.

Whilst indicating that the Opposition supports the amendment to the Act, I ask the Minister to indicate in his response what consideration the Government may be prepared to give to people such as this pensioner who find themselves in circumstances where they are unable to obtain requisite points under the legislation to open a new bank account. Some special consideration needs to be given to people who find themselves in that position.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the last matter raised by Senator Chapman is being looked at by a committee that is advising the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy). I understand that committee includes external representatives from industry, et cetera. The matter has already been taken up at that level and it is being examined. I have not been informed that we have a solution as yet, but no doubt that committee will be looking at that. I think that is the only point that needs to be addressed.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Debate resumed from 13 November, on motion by Senator Cook:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Primary Industry Councils Bill 1991 sets a framework for the establishment of a primary industry council. This Bill proposes to establish a grains industry council and a mechanism by which industry councils may be established for particular primary industries in the future. This legislation, by which councils may be established for particular primary industries, differs from that proposed by the Government in the Primary Industries (Industry Councils) Bill 1991, which was introduced into the House of Representatives earlier this year. In the Primary Industries (Industry Councils) Bill 1991, clause 6 provided for the establishment of a primary industries council by regulation, whereas the Bill we are debating today provides for establishment by inclusion of specific provisions in this Bill.

PARA.TAB: The reason given by the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) in his second reading speech on the Australian Wool Industry Council Bill 1991 for the discharge of the Primary Industries (Industry Councils) Bill 1991 was Opposition concerns about legislation by regulation. I am sure honourable senators will recall that, in a media release of 18 June 1991, my colleague in the other chamber the honourable member for Murray, Mr Bruce Lloyd, outlined the coalition's objections to the Primary Industries (Industry Councils) Bill 1991, which were that various industry councils would be formed by regulation rather than by legislation through Parliament. In that press release Mr Lloyd referred to these issues and the concerns that had been expressed by the National Farmers Federation, the Cattle Council of Australia, the Grains Council of Australia and the Dairy Industry Council. That matter is now addressed by this Bill.

The main object of the Primary Industry Councils Bill 1991 is to provide for the establishment of industry councils to facilitate industry involvement in the policy formulation process. The functions of industry councils are contained in clause 7 and include: to keep under review, and report to the Minister on, the strategic direction of the relevant primary industry; to inquire into, and report on, matters affecting the relevant primary industry which the council thinks require investigation or action; to inquire into, and report to the Minister on, matters affecting the relevant primary industry referred to the council by the Minister; to convene industry review conferences; and to consult with other bodies as it sees fit.

The schedule to the Primary Industry Councils Bill provides for the establishment of a Grains Industry Council. The Grains Industry Council will comprise, in addition to the chairperson, 17 members. These will include the President of the Grains Council of Australia, three members appointed on the nomination of the Grains Council of Australia, a member appointed on the nomination of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Chairperson of the Australian Wheat Board, and a government member.

This is an important piece of legislation. The legislation itself will have to be looked at and reviewed, particularly aspects that may at a later stage impact on the dairy industry, to take account of the concerns of that industry as well. We are glad to note that this legislation picks up the concerns that were raised earlier in the year. The coalition supports the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleague Senator Tambling has covered most of the aspects of the Primary Industry Councils Bill. I would like to

SPEECH.PARA: comment briefly on the makeup of the proposed Grains Industry Council. I believe that the grain industry is represented well enough without having to set up a special industry council. However, the Government has made its decision after receiving representations from some of the industry bodies around the country, although those so-called peak bodies do not necessarily represent totally the views of growers at all times, or even some of the time.

PARA.TAB: However, this Industry Council is to be set up, and it may have a place in Australia at present because of the difficult situation that the grain industry is going through. The makeup of the Council represents a reasonable spread of the grains industry; but three members are to be appointed on the nomination of the Grains Council of Australia and I wonder how many grain growers the Grains Council of Australia really represents. Another member will be the Chairman of the Conference of Chairmen of the Australian Bulk Grain Handling Authorities. They represent all growers because they are all shareholders, but others mentioned in the schedule to the Bill do not totally represent their growers.

I note in paragraph (k) under `Constitution of the Council' that there is to be a member appointed on the nomination of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), in the second reading speech, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The interests of employees in the policies affecting all sectors of the grains industry will be reflected through a member nominated by the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

I will agree with that sort of approach when the ACTU welcomes a member from the grain growing industry onto its Council, but I do not think we will have that reciprocal arrangement for some time to come.

PARA.TAB: I have not got much time to extend my argument on that, but I presume that we will debate this matter at another time, when another government is in power. Until then I support the legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, will be absent from the chamber today. Senator Cook is overseas on Government business. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Cook in relation to his portfolio should be directed to me. Questions in relation to those portfolios he represents should be directed to Senator Collins.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer the Minister to the leaked minutes of a meeting of the Caucus economic and industrial relations committee held on 13 November at which a Reserve Bank board member, Professor Bob Gregory, said that under the accord real wages for full time employees have been falling, wages at the top and bottom ends of the scale are growing but wages in the middle income range are `disappearing'. Why has this Government discriminated so severely against middle Australia and cut its living standards, and why has it so blatantly favoured the rich and powerful?

—That question contains more empty rhetoric than substance. The fact of the matter is—because the Opposition's so-called package is in the eye of the storm a bit at the moment—in one part, the document attacks the Government because real unit labour costs have fallen during the period of this Government and, in another part, it promises that they will continue to fall under a coalition government, if a coalition government is elected.
—What are you rabbiting on about?
—I can answer questions without any assistance from Senator Alston, Mr President.
—People will share in productivity growth in our program, as you know.

—Senator Baume has interjected again that people will share in productivity growth under the Opposition's program. The Opposition has attacked us for the last eight years on the question of productivity. What is the productivity figure for the last eight years? According to the OECD, there was 0.9 per cent productivity growth throughout most of that period and high employment growth. What is the productivity figure in the Opposition's document for the high road? It is 0.8 per cent for the 1990s.

PARA.TAB: Why does not Senator Baume read his own document instead of coming in here asking these silly questions based on false assumptions. If he read his documents occasionally, and saw that they do not support these assumptions, he would have more intellectual status to ask this sort of silly question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note that Senator Button in his response referred to my question as a silly question based on false assumptions. Therefore, I ask him: what are the false assumptions on which the Reserve Bank board member, Professor Bob Gregory, said that wages in the middle income range are disappearing? In that context, and in the context of the fact that lower income earners are being decimated by the loss of their jobs in the recession that we had to have, I ask the Minister once again: why has this Government so blatantly favoured the rich and powerful and savagely discriminated against middle Australia, and what does he intend to do to correct this mess?
—The silly assumptions exist in the question, because the silly assumptions are that wages in—
—By Bob Gregory?
—No. I have accused Senator Alston before of approaching every question with an open mouth.
—It didn't get a laugh last time.

—I know, but I am going to keep on doing it because it is true. The fact of the matter is that Senator Baume asked me a question about wages and then talked about falling standards for middle income earners in Australia. There are a lot of things which go to the question of household disposable incomes beyond wages. That is why it is a silly question.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport. Is the Minister aware of speculation that the National Rail Freight Corporation is to appoint a senior officer of the New South Wales State Rail Authority as its chief executive officer, namely, Mr Graham? Is it the case that the officer in question is insisting that he will accept the appointment only on the basis that the headquarters of the National Rail Freight Corporation is based in Sydney where he lives? Is the Minister aware that the Booz Allen Hamilton report into the establishment of the National Rail Freight Corporation said that the decision on the siting of the administrative headquarters of the National Rail Freight Corporation should be made on commercial grounds alone and, on that basis, Adelaide would clearly be the preferred site? Can the Minister assure the Senate that the board members of the National Rail Freight Corporation, in appointing the chief executive officer, are aware of their fiduciary responsibility to appoint the best person, irrespective of that person's previous employment and association with a rail organisation like the New South Wales State Rail Authority which, over decades, has cost taxpayers through its losses hundreds of millions of dollars? Would the Minister agree that it would be more appropriate to appoint a chief executive officer from a rail authority that has demonstrated its capacity to run on a commercially viable basis, or some appropriate person from outside the rail industry?

—I thank Senator Schacht for his entirely detached and objective question. I am sure he does not have an axe to grind, coming from South Australia. The Minister for Land Transport, Mr Bob Brown, has provided me with the following advice: the board of the National Rail Corporation will be meeting in Sydney tomorrow, that is, Friday, 29 November. The board will be considering, among other things, the appointment of its chief executive and the location of the headquarters.I have also been advised that the NRC has been established under the Companies Code at arm's length from government. I have also been advised that all of the decisions made by the board of the NRC will be in accordance with its strict commercial charter.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Does he support the statement of Treasurer Kerin in the leaked confidential letter of Tuesday, 26 November, to the chairman of the Caucus committee on economic and industrial relations? It read:

QUESTION.PARA: My preference would be not to provide any sales tax exemptions for inputs to services such as road freight. . . providing a sales tax exemption would send mixed signals to the industry at a time when road user charges for heavy vehicles are being developed . . . I would prefer to maintain the present WST treatment of the heavy vehicle road transport industry.
What is the cost burden on Australian business—particularly exporters—and people living in remote and regional Australia, of refusing to make sales tax on road freight refundable?

TALK.START.PARA: —I was asked a question about this by Senator Short yesterday and I said I would get him an answer from the Treasurer. I am not in a position to provide Senator Tambling with those sorts of figures at the present time but I am in a position to provide him with some information.

PARA.TAB: First of all, it is a central principle of the wholesale sales tax system that the service sector is not subject to sales tax on its output. It generally bears sales tax on those of its inputs which are taxable. That has been the position of the service sector all along, and the Opposition upheld this principle in all its years in office, since the introduction of sales tax in 1935.As Senator Tambling pointed out, the road freight industry is an important part of the services sector and should bear sales tax on its inputs for that reason.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rail, sea and air?

—I said that it is part of the services sector. I suppose the Opposition will claim that the proposed GST will refund tax paid on all business inputs. The Opposition has specifically said that it intends to exempt from the GST input tax from some important industries: residential rents and construction, other building construction, financial services, gambling and lotteries—service industries. The present sales tax collected on road freight inputs has been estimated by the Department of Transport and Communications —this is as close as I can get to Senator Tambling's request for a figure—to be between 2 per cent and 4.5 per cent of operating costs in those industries.
—It's 6 per cent!
—I said it was 4.5 per cent.
—I am correcting you—it's 6 per cent.
—I was asked to give an answer and I am doing so. If Senator Boswell hangs around long enough, one day he may get the opportunity to answer a question. I do not think it will be for a long time.
—You won't be here, anyway.

—It is the only way those opposite can get rid of me—it was my decision. The Opposition has omitted a factor in its proposed indirect tax treatment of road freight. The direct road user charges were negotiated between the Commonwealth and the States at the July special conference. That has been a matter of some comment. It represents a shortfall of some $900m from the Opposition's proposed fuel taxation arrangements. Senator Tambling asked me for specific amounts of the cost. I cannot translate those percentage figures into amounts. I will try to get that done for him.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has acknowledged that the cost burden, in his estimation, is between 4 per cent and 2.5 per cent of the operating costs and the significance that that has to people living in rural and remote areas. The Minister also referred to the question Senator Short asked yesterday with respect to the Caucus paper which canvassed that it may be desirable to gradually remove sales tax exemptions on the other freight transport modes of rail, sea and air. Does the Government rule out any changes in these areas in the forthcoming Budget?

—I correct Senator Tambling on one point he made in his supplementary question when he said that the burden was between 4 per cent and 2.5 per cent. It is between 2 per cent and 4.5 per cent. It might be desirable to move an input cost to these industries, but it comes at some cost to general revenue and other taxpayers. When the Opposition thought it had a scheme which may have this effect, it miscued by $900m in its calculations—just $900m. I am not in a position to make any projections about next year's Budget. At the appropriate time, the Government will make a decision about all of these issues.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the response to my question on Tuesday, 12 November. The response states that a relief vessel loaded with supplies would be allowed into Dubrovnik in the next couple of days. Did the relief vessel arrive safely in Dubrovnik? Who is responsible for the distribution of relief supplies when they arrive in Dubrovnik to ensure that they do not fall into the hands of the Yugoslavian army forces? Have there been any further reports of Australians caught up in the conflict in Zagreb and Dubrovnik?

—The relief vessel that Senator Jones is referring to is the Rhodos, which was chartered by the International Committee of the Red Cross. According to the ICRC, the Rhodos arrived in Dubrovnik on 21 November, carrying food and blankets. It also brought in eight Red Cross delegates, including several nurses and a sanitary engineer, who is working on restoring water supplies.

PARA.TAB: A second Red Cross relief ship has now arrived in Dubrovnik. The Dimarathos, carrying approximately 250 tonnes of relief goods, including food, blankets, clothes and medicines, reached Dubrovnik on 25 November. With the arrival of this ship, the Red Cross considers that the food and medical supply situation in Dubrovnik is no longer desperate. As well as the ICRC, other national and external relief organisations have successfully organised relief shipments to Dubrovnik.

The Red Cross is responsible for the distribution of the supplies brought into Dubrovnik by its two relief ships. The Red Cross relief delegate responsible for distribution will oversee the unloading and warehousing of the supplies. The local Red Cross organisation will then help organise the actual distribution of supplies to those in need. The ICRC relief delegate will closely monitor all stages of this process.

Up-to-date information on the welfare of Australian citizens in Zagreb and Dubrovnik is obviously very difficult to obtain, despite the Embassy's considerable efforts over a long period to maintain contact with Australians. Telephone communications between Belgrade and the Adriatic coast have not been possible for many weeks, although the Embassy in Rome has, in quite a number of cases, been able to make contact.

There were originally 10 Australians registered in Dubrovnik, but the latest advice the Embassy in Rome received, when it tried to contact them, was that they were no longer at the numbers called. We have had only one inquiry regarding an Australian citizen there. We learnt on 25 November that she was well and on her way back to Australia.

At the time the conflict erupted, there were about 180 Australians registered in Zagreb. This figure is unlikely now to be accurate as some will have left and others may have gone there from parts of Croatia affected by the fighting. Communications between Zagreb and Belgrade are also extremely difficult. It is impossible to be precise about this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade seen reports that Indonesian soldiers executed up to 80 people on 15 November, three days after the Santa Cruz cemetery massacre; that troops shot dead 10 people on 17 November and a further seven people, including a one-year-old boy, on 18 November? Has the Minister also seen reported comments that a witness to the 15 November shootings will give evidence only to a United Nations investigative delegation if his safety can be guaranteed? Does the Minister believe that these allegations will also be investigated by the committee set up by the Indonesian Government? If so, as this is an Indonesian Government committee of inquiry, will witnesses give evidence?

—I am aware of the various reports containing allegations of further killings. It remains the case that we have no evidence from any source to support or substantiate those reports. Officers from our Embassy in Jakarta have been sent to East Timor to investigate further the allegations in question. To date, they too have obtained no evidence in support.

PARA.TAB: As to the question of investigations of these reports by the national investigation commission, I hope that these reports will be investigated by that body and that all relevant witnesses will be given a chance to give evidence to it. Our Ambassador in Jakarta has made it clear to the Indonesian authorities that we believe that these allegations of further killings should be properly and fully investigated.

The Prime Minister, our Ambassador in Jakarta and I have already called on the Indonesian Government in various ways to conduct a full and credible inquiry that will lead to a publicly accessible report and, of course, the punishment of any wrongdoers. We see the establishment of that national commission as being a positive first step in that direction. In this regard, I am encouraged by the reported remarks of the head of the commission, Judge Djaelani, that the commission is hoping to view foreign videos of the 12 November killings, will look into foreign and local press reports, will seek to question eyewitnesses and will go anywhere in Indonesia, if necessary, to gather information. We will have to wait and see whether those undertakings, commitments and processes are satisfactory.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. Are any of the police on duty at the AIDEX exhibition being financed by the organisers of the exhibition, due to budgetary constraints on the Federal Police? Has the level of police involvement at the exhibition meant that there are not enough police available for other duties in Canberra, leaving residents susceptible to increased levels of crime?

—Senator Bruce Childs, who has taken a very long and active interest in the promotion of peace activities in Australia over many years, has been approached by, I think, one of those involved in the protest demonstrations with these allegations. He did give me some little notice that he might ask this particular question.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that this allegation, that the police are being paid for by the organisers of the AIDEX exhibition, is complete and utter nonsense. It has no foundation whatsoever. It is, I believe, part of the rumour-mongering and black propaganda that is being put around by the demonstrators and protesters in relation to this particular incident outside the NATEX Centre. I certainly exclude Senator Childs, whose concern in these matters is well-attested. He, quite rightly, has sought proper information from me in this chamber as to that particular allegation, which I completely refute. It is quite erroneous.

The Australian Federal Police in the Australian Capital Territory are being paid for by the citizens of the Territory through their contributions to the Australian Capital Territory Government in order to keep the public peace in the Territory. The police role is a public one. It is twofold. It is to protect the protesters in their right to demonstrate peacefully and lawfully on a matter about which they feel extremely strongly—and they are certainly entitled to demonstrate peacefully and lawfully. The police also have a duty to ensure that those who wish to have lawful access to the site are enabled to do so. Those who are involved in the exhibition are entitled, have a right, to go about their business without unlawful hindrance. It is in relation to the clash that has occurred between the demonstrators and the police that Senator Childs and others have expressed concern.

Some of the allegations that have been made, sometimes in the context of giving notice of motion by some senators in this place about police violence against the demonstrators, seem to be grossly prejudging an issue which is properly in the domain of the Commonwealth Ombudsman if proper, substantiated allegations and complaints are made to him. It is very unfortunate that honourable senators have given an impression that the violence has emanated from the police in this clash.

On my last information some 28 police had suffered severe enough injuries to be required to attend hospital. There have been nine cases of broken limbs, including broken arms, of the police. So the impression being given of one-sided assault, wielding batons and boots and inflicting extreme violence on demonstrators, as it has been put by some senators in this place, is completely and utterly wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of the demonstrators have been injured, too!

—Yes. As far as I know, one demonstrator has been required to attend hospital. The fact is that instances have been reported of avocado seeds studded with nails being thrown at the police; condoms filled with urine thrown at the police; an attempt, according to the Electricity Authority, to electrify the fence; and some demonstrators smearing themselves with faeces.
—That was to protect them from the sun.

—I do not know whether that gives a level 15 protection, but I can tell Senator Vallentine that I will not be trying it at Bondi. I need also to say in answer to Senator Childs's very proper question that, whilst patrol strengths in the Capital Territory have been marginally reduced and deployed to AIDEX, this reduction has been offset by redeploying community policing patrols on to 12-hour shifts. This is in line with a police practice of 20 years regarding emergencies which require significant police resources. At this stage the level of resources is adequate to respond to requests from the ACT community for police assistance.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations to the leaked Labor Party documents. Is he aware that they show that under the accord real wages for full time employees have been falling; that the work force is segregated in the documents into two categories—`good jobs', such as doctors, lawyers, et cetera and `bad jobs', such as labourers, et cetera; that all the accord has done for males is to halt the 40 per cent decline in male so-called bad jobs; and that, due to more young jobless staying on at school, the unemployment problem is now moving into the older 20 to 24 years age group? Does the Minister agree with the Caucus categories of `good jobs' and `bad jobs' which distinguishes jobs in such elitist terms? What is the Hawke Government planning to do to fix up the unemployment mess, given this documentation of the accord's failure?
—I have not seen this document but let me say that—
—It was tabled yesterday; it is a Caucus minute.

—I have not read it; I am sorry. I have other things to do besides reading copies of stolen documents which Opposition senators want to throw on the table. The revelation that real wages have been falling is one of the most phenomenal bombshells that have ever been dropped in the Senate by the lot opposite. Everybody knows that. The Opposition's own document attacks the Government for that. The Opposition in its own document then goes on to point out that real wages will continue to fall; that productivity will be very poor under the scenario predicted by Dr Hewson in the model; and that we will have an even worse situation.
—That is our worst case.

—No, the high road—page 342; we have all studied it. Productivity over the period from 1991-92 is shown as 0.8 per cent. Through the 1980s, according to OECD figures, Australia's productivity was 0.09—
—That is the worst case scenario.
—No, it is the high road. The Opposition's low road is 0.4 per cent; its base case is 0.43 per cent.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections. Senator Chapman asked the question.
—I am not getting an answer, though, Mr President.

—Senator Chapman does not get an answer because all his friends come in psyched up like people who have been to a Billy Graham crusade but they have not read the document. The Opposition's document—study it carefully—does not support the assumptions made throughout the paper. It does not support the assumptions made, so let us be clear about that.

PARA.TAB: Real wages have fallen. If Senator Chapman says that the classification into `good jobs' and `bad jobs' is elitist and not a pleasant classification, I have no trouble in agreeing with him about that. Doctors' jobs have always been good jobs in this country. Doctors' jobs have always been good jobs under any government and will, presumably, continue to be so, and better under a Liberal government, if the Liberal Party ever gets into office, because doctors will get a much bigger slice of the taxpayers' money. I do not personally agree with the categorisation but that is an observation which is not important.

The other part of the question was about more people staying at school. It is true that more people are staying at school. We regard that as an important achievement of this Government because when we came into office the participation rates in higher school education for this country were amongst the lowest in the OECD. The participation rates in post-secondary education were amongst the lowest in the OECD when we came into government. That was after eight years of the Liberal Party having a go at it. Now that has all changed, and we do not make any apologies for that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the controversial and deplorable practice of driftnet fishing. Has the Minister seen recent media reports suggesting that Japan has agreed to ban the practice of driftnet fishing? Can the Minister explain to the Senate Australia's role in this issue? What part does Australia play?

—I hope all honourable senators have seen the press reports because this does represent a very fundamental, dramatic and welcome breakthrough. Australia warmly welcomes the announcement made by Japan a few days ago that it will cease all high seas driftnet fishing by the end of 1992. This is a major step towards the global moratorium Australia has been trying to achieve for some time. The Japanese Government has announced that its driftnet fishing fleet will be cut back by 50 per cent before July 1992 through a reduction in the number of vessels, the length of their nets and the areas of operation. Japan will implement a complete global moratorium on the practice by 31 December 1992.

PARA.TAB: Australia has continued to press for a global ban on driftnet fishing in the lead-up to this year's United Nations General Assembly debate on the issue. Since the 1989 resolution in the General Assembly on driftnet fishing, No. 44/225, major scientific reviews have taken place. These have vindicated the concerns of the international community about the impact of that fishing technique on fishery resources and marine wildlife. There is now widespread agreement that driftnetting on the high seas should cease.

In concert with other concerned nations, we will press for the Japanese action to be matched by the other major driftnet fishing nations that continue to operate on the high seas, such as Korea and Taiwan. We are especially concerned about the continued presence of a large fleet of Taiwanese driftnet vessels that are fishing in the Indian Ocean. Driftnet fishing there may threaten the recovery of the very severely depleted southern bluefin tuna and have serious impacts on other marine resources, including albacore tuna, marine mammals, turtles and sea birds.

The good news is that the Japanese announcement sets the scene for agreement on a resolution at this year's General Assembly to achieve an end at last to the wasteful, indiscriminate and very destructive practice of driftnet fishing on the high seas.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer the Minister to Tuesday's report in the Sydney Morning Herald that his own Department is recommending a clampdown on double dipping and lump sums along the lines advocated by the coalition. Did the Minister approve the submission? Does he still stand by his recent comments on these matters to ASFA, when he said that double dipping had to stop and that he would push to limit the size of lump sums? Does he still stand by his comments last year that the coalition's plans to raise the preservation age to 60 years had merit? In view of his obvious inability to persuade the Government to take these necessary steps, now that the coalition has bitten the bullet on all these issues, will he support the coalition's proposals in these areas? If not, why not?

—Mr President, as you will recall, a question was asked of me by Senator Durack on a similar matter yesterday. I explained then that superannuation is not within my portfolio and I therefore do not answer questions about it at Question Time.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I have here—I am sure I do not need to wave them around—quotations from Senator Richardson, who has grandstanded around the nation on these very issues, at times even going so far as to say, `Perhaps I should not be speaking in this area, but I have to'.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. I realise that Senator Alston does not know anything about taking points of order, but I want to draw to your attention that he was supposed to be asking a supplementary question, and there was not one.
—On the point of order, Mr President: I have not yet asked the question, so I do not see how Senator McMullan can possibly come to that conclusion.
—Order! Senator Alston, will you ask your supplementary question.

—Is it not a fact that the Minister's area of responsibility is concerned with age pensions and that the concept of double dipping has a dramatic effect on the ability of people to access age pensions, either prematurely or in circumstances when they should not get them at all, that therefore he has a direct responsibility for involvement in these areas, and that that is why he has been pontificating on the subject? If that is not the reason, why has he opened his mouth in the first place?

—I think I can confirm that there are many superannuants who receive part pensions. It has been the case for some time and no doubt it will be the case for some time to come. The responsibility for superannuation in this Government does not lie with me, however. It resides in Treasury, and that has always been the case.

PARA.TAB: I have been called upon on a number of occasions to represent the Government at a whole range of different dinners and to make speeches, so I comment on things from time to time. In any event, when speaking outside one's area of ministerial responsibility—which happens all the time if one does talkback radio or whatever else—one is always asked questions about everybody else's portfolio. I do not need to answer every question on every portfolio as I might do on a radio program. I thought this was Question Time, not John Laws.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. Can the Minister advise what effect deregulation has had on the interstate aviation industry?

—The Government deregulated the interstate aviation industry in October 1990. As a result of that deregulation, restrictions over the type and number of aircraft that could be imported into Australia were lifted and air fares became a matter for the industry and not for the Independent Airfares Committee. Beyond the maintenance of safety standards and the provision of traffic management, the Federal Government has no role to play in interstate air services. Expansion in the capacity of the domestic aviation sector is now strictly a matter for the commercial judgment of the operators themselves. The success or failure of individual operators will also depend on their ability to operate successfully in a deregulated market.

PARA.TAB: The big winners from this new system have been Australian travellers. There are now thousands of different air fares and air fare and accommodation packages available to the public that have never been made available before. Deep discounts of up to 70 per cent are currently being offered on many of Australia's major routes. The airlines carried a record 15.4 million passengers to the year ending September. I therefore completely fail to understand the statement that has been made in the Opposition's document—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Fightback program.

—As Senator Hill is so preoccupied with quoting from Fightback!, I will refer to a statement on page 10, chapter 1, verse 4 of the document, where Dr Hewson has painted a ridiculous picture of even cheaper air fares under what he calls the partial deregulation that the Government has achieved in the current system. According to Dr Hewson, the Opposition will allow both Qantas, our international carrier, and Air New Zealand to operate on domestic routes in Australia which will offer cheaper air fares. This is pure fantasyland. The Opposition is clearly very sensitive about what the document is called. In my view, the document should have been called `Fantasia' instead of Fightback!. Perhaps the Opposition could have timed it with the release of the Walt Disney video that has just come out: `You've seen the movie; now read the book'.

PARA.TAB: Looking at the air fares that are being offered on routes such as Sydney-Perth return, for example, I am quite happy to state that nobody could possibly get cheaper air fares under any circumstances than are currently being offered in Australia. I am perfectly happy to stick my neck out one jot further and reiterate comments I have made before by saying that the extent of the deep discounting that is currently going on in Australia cannot continue forever when airlines are offering seats at less than the total cost of providing them. It is simply not prudent commercial practice to continue to do that for any length of time.

It is simply impossible to offer cheaper air fares than are currently being offered in Australia. The only result from international operators dumping seats on the Australian domestic market will be the absolute prevention of the emergence of any new Australian domestic carriers and the placing of enormous, and I think unsustainable, pressure on the existing ones.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Social Security aware of reports by rural producers who have contacted Department of Social Security officers in south-east Queensland that the officers were unaware of the announced changes to bring forward assistance to rural people from 1 January to 1 December? Is he also aware that the Brisbane DSS policy unit, the Toowoomba DSS and Warwick DSS were unable to supply any details on how the assistance could be implemented? Does the Minister agree that the assistance package will provide little help and cost the Government very little if the Department cannot sort out its administrative systems and provide producers with information on how they can apply for assistance? Will the Minister act immediately to ensure that his Department and its officers are able to properly administer the scheme in an efficient and effective manner? Otherwise, does this mean that the much publicised announcement to bring forward the assistance program was only a propaganda exercise designed to hoodwink struggling rural producers?

—One of the difficulties is that the legislation has to get through the Senate. I think that it will be debated tonight. When it is debated tonight, and on the assumption that we get it through, all our offices will be faxed with all the details tomorrow morning.

PARA.TAB: On other occasions when I have sought to give prior notice of legislation that had not yet been passed by the Senate, the Opposition has criticised me roundly. All I can do is notify the Department that some changes are under way and give an indication of what I think they will be, but I have to wait until after they are through the Parliament before I can give the 300 offices around Australia the details. If Senator Bjelke-Petersen will help me get the legislation through tonight—and I know that she is the sort of person who will—I will make sure that the information gets out tomorrow morning.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Now that Cabinet has approved the introduction of resource security legislation via the Forest Conservation and Development Bill, can the Minister advise whether the Government has received any commitment for investment under the terms of the legislation? In particular, is there a firm commitment to invest in a pulp mill in Tasmania? Further, what is the value of investment involved in any such commitment? How many jobs will be created by any such investment for which a firm commitment has been given? Finally, will any form of Commonwealth financial assistance, subsidy or concessions be provided to any of these projects? How many jobs will be created by any such investment? If so, what will be the cost to the taxpayer?

—The proposed resource security legislation arises from an undertaking given in the March economic statement to introduce forest conservation and development legislation to better protect Australia's native forests and to facilitate much needed value adding investment in the forest industries. The legislation is about providing a transparent and predictable environment for industry.

PARA.TAB: Having regard to the history of this industry in Tasmania, no industry could make commitments without the passage of that legislation. It would be very silly to do so because the investments contemplated are huge. Without some understanding of the provision of security of the raw material resource, I believe that it would be silly for any industry to make commitments of that kind. It is now up to the industry to assess the commercial opportunities available. I am hopeful and confident that Australia will be benefiting from world class value-added investments before the end of this decade.

In a sense, the second and third parts of Senator Vallentine's question are not relevant, having regard to what I have just said. There are no special subsidies or other forms of incentives offered to pulp mills, for example, over and above other industries. Of course, it is anticipated that a pulp mill would be a highly successful export earner and a profitable business in its own right. This Government is not in favour of offering particular subsidies to any industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will it be possible for investment in softwood plantation resource processing to be counted towards meeting the $100m threshold for resource security? If so, will export woodchipping of native forests be permitted as an ancillary activity under such resource security agreements? What, if any, limitations on such export of native forest woodchips will be imposed?

—Native forest woodchips are exported under agreements between the producer and the State government, which in this case is largely Tasmania. The producers are granted export licences by the Commonwealth Government. I am not sure that there is any contemplation of developing any softwood woodchip industry. Whether softwood plantations would be taken into account in the $100m limit referred to in Senator Vallentine's question may be irrelevant, but I will seek to obtain an answer on that point from the appropriate Minister and let her know.

—The Minister for Administrative Services will be aware that the Department of Administrative Services Expo 91 was officially opened in Sydney yesterday and closes on Friday. Would the Minister explain to the Senate why the Department of Administrative Services sees fit to lease space for this program at Darling Harbour? What was the cost and how many departmental personnel were in attendance? How does the Minister justify, during the worst recession in living memory, spending taxpayers' money on such gimmicks as a tropical Hawaiian hut, with DAS personnel dressed in Hawaiian outfits handing out free fruit juices and Smarties; a life-sized mannequin greeting visitors and shaking hands with them; a practice shooting gallery of Australian Protective Services where shooting skills can be tested by visitors; leading Australian figures who have nothing to do with the operations of the Department being flown in to address the program; wall to wall Comcars in attendance outside the Expo; and, perhaps to take the cake, a Comcar competition, the prizes for which include a bottle of port devalued by being autographed by the Prime Minister, a desk set, a Comcar watch, golf tees, a Comcar car shield and a Comcar travel voucher?

—I thank Senator Parer. I have sat here for a couple of days now and, I must admit, witnessed a performance which has been matched only by ringside wrestling. I ask the other side to be quiet while I answer this question.

PARA.TAB: I do know of the Expo. In fact, I was there yesterday and had the pleasure of opening it. I must say that, in the context of opening it, I made a couple of points both in respect of Administrative Services as a department and how it has developed over recent years and in respect of the understanding of the Department as embodied in the principles and plans of the Opposition's package which was announced last week.

The basic point about the Department of Administrative Services over the last three years is that it has transformed enormously as a department. It has transformed in such a way, and will continue to transform, that as from July 1993, 85 per cent of its functions will be available for competition on the open market. The Department of Administrative Services will not have the tie over other departments that it has had in the past.

Gearing up to that, obviously in terms of maintaining a client base, the Department of Administrative Services has to promote itself. It does so in a way that matches the private sector and will continue to do so in such a way. We are in the business of making this Department competitive and making it operate commercially and on the best practices available in the private sector.

If Senator Parer wants to focus his little mind on little gimmicks that may be used in promotion, so he may. But when he assesses the performance of the Department of Administrative Services he should look at the way that the Department has transformed over the last four years. We are talking about a department that has become more and more competitive and has, over recent years, reduced the level of its cost on the Budget by $260m per annum.

As these reforms continue those reductions will increase to approximately $350m per annum. They are massive cost reductions imposed on a department and achieved through a process of reform of that department. We are also talking about a total restructuring of this department which over the past four years has meant a reduction in staffing levels from 18,600 to somewhere in the vicinity of 14,000.
