In making an assessment of the Department of Administrative Services, those opposite should keep those things in mind. The Department is transforming. It is becoming competitive. It has to do so to survive. In that process of change, there will be a few problems. No-one is running away from the fact that change brings problems and Administrative Services is facing up to those problems.

I tell those opposite that the Department will continue to market itself and to promote itself. At the end of the day it is in the business of maintaining business. By maintaining business, the cost of that Department on government revenue is commensurately decreased. Let us compare this approach with the approach that is embodied in the Opposition's documents.

TALK.START.PARA: —We didn't ask that.
—I do not care what the Opposition asked. There is a criticism implied in this question—

—Those opposite can throw as much as they like, but we will give them a lot back over a long time. The Opposition's proposals are embodied in a document prepared by Elmer Fudd's brother—

PARA.TAB: Yesterday Administrative Services was in the business of promoting itself. The Opposition's promotion was one that was best geared to a US baseball game.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order: the answer has to be relevant to the question that was asked. The question asked was what was the cost, how many public servants were involved and to whom was Expo 91 directed. The Minister has answered the third part. The parts that remain are: what was the cost and how many public servants were involved.
—Mr President, there is no point of order.
—Order! Senator Bolkus can speak to a point of order.

—Order! There is no point of order.
—On the question of costs, I will ascertain what they were. In that process I will also give Senator Parer a fairly big brief on the values of promotion, what it costs and what the benefits are.

—I ask the Minister for Defence: how many police personnel were involved in any way in the Australian International Defence Exhibition? How many armed forces personnel are involved in any way in AIDEX? What is the total commitment to AIDEX of human resources from other government departments or agencies? PARA.TAB: Senator Bell asked me how many armed forces personnel were involved. I assume that he means inside the AIDEX exhibition. I will find out that information for him, but they would not number very many. I was then asked how many human resources from other government departments were involved. Again, I do not know. It is a privately run exhibition. Senator Bell would have to contact each department. I suspect there are none, but Senator Bell would have to ask that question of all of the other Ministers to get the answer. The answer to the question on the resources involved is the same.

As to the total budgeted cost of government involvement: of course, I do not know that as I control the defence side only, and that figure is $66,000. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. My inspiration for directing the question towards Senator Ray was a photograph that I saw of him as a supporter of this exhibition. I thought that, as a supporter, Senator Ray would have a reason for doing that and a knowledge of how much government involvement there was. I ask again: if there is not an open-ended budget, what is the finite end of the budget for government support?

—Have you been there?

—I have not been there, and I have not counted the police there; nor is it my responsibility to know how much other government expenditure will be involved at a private exhibition. I have never sought to know and it is not my responsibility to know. Eventually the Minister for Finance would know. If Senator Bell wants to know and if he has any idea of whether any other government agencies were involved, he should ask those agencies.

PARA.TAB: Let me say one final thing. We have had two questions on AIDEX today. It is true to say that as a public relations exercise the demonstrations have not been terribly successful. TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. PARA.TAB: Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 September 1991, Senator Calvert asked me as Minister for Administrative Services a question about fire services. I now have an answer to that question and I seek leave to incorporate that answer in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

1. The Department of Administrative Services (DAS) is implementing a progressive restructure of the fire protection maintenance contracts to allow more frequent market testing and facilitate the entry of new service providers.
This follows the previous approach adopted in 1988 when six contract packages, covering all Commonwealth fire protection requirements in the ACT, were awarded on an open tender basis.

Most of the successful contractors were traditional manufacturing based companies who effectively serviced their own equipment. This has ensured efficient and reliable servicing of fire protection equipment in the ACT.
The 1988 contracts were let for a period of three years with a further three year option. However, after consulting clients, DAS decided to call fresh tenders after the first three years.

Rather than invite open tenders for all contracts at the one time and for the same periods, DAS considered that, for the following reasons, existing contracts should be broken up into smaller packages, the letting of contracts should be staggered and a mixture of select and open tendering should be used:

ANSWER.PARA: (a)the client's requirement for a particular level of service and a preference for a service provider with proven performance;
(b)obtaining the most cost effective delivery of the service;
(c)the importance and sensitivity of the facility;

(d)the role of the supplier of older equipment still in service, including the provision of technical information and spare parts which are often not available other than from the manufacturer of that older equipment. The ability to source replacement parts for equipment can extend its useful life and hence defer the capital cost of replacement;
(e)the need to regularly test the market for new entrants in servicing fire protection equipment in order to gain any savings in more effective and efficient industry practices; and
(f)the desirability of providing regular opportunities for new entrants while minimising unnecessary disruption to the industry.

PARA.TAB: Once the new staggered system has been put in place DAS plans to use open tendering for most, if not all, contracts in future. This will be increasingly practicable as older fire protection equipment is replaced by new facilities. The present preference, in some cases, to use the manufacturer of the equipment to also service that equipment would therefore no longer necessarily apply.

With regard to contractors being recognised by Standards Australia DAS advises that Standards Australia accredits an organisation's quality system rather than the amount of work it has the capacity to carry out.

2. DAS advises that all five companies are registered as separate entities. Four share common directors and are listed by the Australian Securities Commission as having the same ultimate holding company.

The companies were selected because they have an established record of satisfactory service, they are the manufacturer of significant items of installed equipment and are able to ensure adequate support and have satisfied the tenants of buildings that they can comply with their security requirements.

3. DAS advises that careful analysis of each offer is undertaken and comparisons made with market rates for similar work. Preliminary evaluation of all tenders received to date indicates a significant reduction in the costs will be achieved under the new contracts.
It should also be recognised that price is not the sole determinant. A low price tender which cannot deliver the required level or type of service should not necessarily succeed.

4. As indicated earlier the Commonwealth already held contracts with suppliers for fire protection services which could have been extended until 1994; however fresh tenders were invited. This allowed the scope of work to be refined, the prices offered to be reviewed and, for some contracts, new suppliers to enter the market.

The decision to call some open tenders and some select tenders will allow an orderly transition within the industry. New contractors wishing to enter the market will be able to demonstrate their competence progressively and existing contractors will have time to adjust to new market conditions.
For those tenders which have closed the evaluation shows no significant difference between those received as select tenders and those received from open tender.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Alston on 28 November 1991 relating to superannuation.

SPEECH.PARA: The answer given by Senator Richardson today was a follow-up to a question asked yesterday in my absence about where Senator Richardson stood in relation to a number of matters which are directly within his area of responsibility. I find it extraordinary that today he should yet again squib at answering that vital question. Not only does the question relate to matters about which he has spoken publicly and at length, but the first part of my question asked him directly whether he had authorised the submission to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation which contains a number of matters squarely within his own area of responsibility. It is a submission submitted by his own Department. One would have thought that it has to have had his approval.

PARA.TAB: The submission contains a number of matters that bear directly on the question of double dipping and the questions of restricting access to age pensions, which, as we know, have been rising exponentially in recent years and are now costing the taxpayer almost $10 billion a year, in addition to the amount that is spent on veterans' service pensions, which I think is another $5 billion. Double dipping is therefore a critical issue and, for once in a very long career of political expediency, Senator Richardson on other occasions has had the courage to stand up and take a national interest view. That is why he has been going to places like the National Conference of the Association of Superannuation Funds at Southport a few weeks back where there were 780 delegates, which is a world record for the industry, so I am told. Who should be there in all his glory but the Minister for Social Security. Was he there on behalf of a colleague? Absolutely not. He was there in his own right as Minister for Social Security and he had no hesitation in giving the conference the benefit of his advice in a whole range of areas.

The conference review note, which records what the Minister had to say at the conference, says that he was talking about things that were not Government policy, but the 800 delegates were left in no doubt that the Government wants to see investment funds flowing into value-added industries. The Minister stressed that he was enunciating a personal point of view. So not only was he going there representing himself alone but also he was quite prepared to speak out on these areas. My information is that he told those present at the conference that the natives in Canberra were restless and it would only be a matter of time before the Government moved to introduce investment controls, unless he did something about it. The fact of the matter is that he got a very poor reception—

TALK.START.PARA: —They applauded for ages. I couldn't get off the stage.
—It must have been a recorded message played by one of his staff—
—How many people did you get running to the casino to listen to you? Not one!
—There were about 700 people there when I was there. If those opposite look at Barry Dunstan's report the following day, they will see the stormy reception which the Minister got.
—What!

—The Minister did not even bother to read the Australian Financial Review. Barry Dunstan happens to be the pre-eminent commentator on superannuation in this country. I am appalled that the Minister does not even read those sorts of comments. That day Senator Richardson blathered on about the complexities of the industry and accused the industry of constructing incomprehensible jargon which, of course, is another way of saying that he did not have a clue what they were talking about. That criticism, according to AAP, drew a very quick response from the President of the Association, who said that complex rules imposed by the Government were to blame. So there is no doubt that Senator Richardson regarded himself as perfectly capable of talking on anything that was vaguely relevant to his area of responsibility. A report on 31 October in the Australian states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Senator Richardson, said yesterday he would push for legislation to limit the size of lump-sum superannuation payments to stop "double dipping" by retirees.

PARA.TAB: Senator Richardson said the government policy of giving preferential tax treatment to retirees who invested their superannuation instead of spending their lump sums had had only a "minimal" effect.
He said the superannuation rules would have to be changed, "if not to prohibit, then at least substantially limit" lump-sum payments.
Senator Richardson said his strategy to end double dipping was not government policy but it was a "goal" he had set himself.

SPEECH.PARA: It is curious indeed that it should find itself in his own Department's submission to that Committee only a matter of a couple of weeks later. We have the Canberra Times reporting:

The practice of using lump-sum superannuation pay-outs for a holiday—or to pay off a house—then "double dipping" into the public purse for an aged pension had to stop, the Minister for Social Security, Graham Richardson, said yesterday.

There is no suggestion that he was somehow there on behalf of the Treasurer. So why is it that the Minister is not prepared to come clean today? What is it that precludes him from being able to tell us where things stand? I do not think one has to be too smart to know the answer to that. The fact is that he has either been rolled in Cabinet or the Government is still dragging its feet and has been overtaken by events, the major one of which, of course, is the release of our Fightback document which simply bites the bullets.

PARA.TAB: We have had all these wonderful speeches in all these areas. It must be more than 12 months ago that Senator Richardson got himself a big page one headline saying the Government was going to extend fringe benefits cards to all the aged pensioners over a certain age irrespective of their income. I think he might have said that it would be up to a limit of $50,000. What have we had ever since? The very clever strategy in all this is that he was hoping to get a few cheap headlines on the way through and then trot it out in the Budget prior to the next election. Of course, once again, he has been overtaken by events.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is rubbish. Anyway, I will demonstrate that in a second.

—I very much look forward to it. On the one hand, we have the Minister out there for once prepared to show some glimmer of understanding of the national interest, recognising that there might just be a few people who will not like the idea of putting limitations on lump sums, or who might not like the idea of raising the preservation age—and indeed they do not. On the other hand, when I floated this idea 12 months ago and said that it would be our policy, the Minister actually said it had a bit going for it, until of course he was jumped on from a great height by the then Treasurer, Mr Keating. What was Mr Keating's reason for not embracing this sensible concept? It was too difficult politically and industrially. In other words, Bill Kelty would not wear it. It was nothing to do with rationality.
—Is he in the Cabinet?
—No, this was the honourable member for Blaxland. At that time he had some pre-eminence in the Party.
—Who is the honourable member for Blaxland again?
—I do not know. He is another one of those racehorses—

PARA.TAB: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not running for leader of the Labor Party.
—Neither am I.
—I know he is not but his horse is and he is still in the stables.
—You went round the track six times.

—Well, I got here. One might say this is not a great place to end up but we are both in it, for better or worse. I look forward to seeing those opposite enjoying it for many years to come—no doubt from this side in the near future. The interesting thing is that Senator Richardson has been spending most of his waking moments in recent months trying to back this horse from Blaxland, which is still in the stables and does not show any great inclination towards going for a gallop, let alone getting close to the winning post.
—I think it was lame.

—The Government should probably take a few of them out and shoot them but I suppose it will not do that. The Government will probably hang around and wait until George Bush comes out here and use it as a pretext for a special Caucus meeting. But before that happens, Senator Richardson will go to ground. Indeed, the White Paper that is supposed to have surfaced many days ago—

PARA.TAB: Senator Robert Ray interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure Senator Ray is not familiar with the White Paper on simplification of superannuation. Mr Kerin only saw the need for it when he got such a very poor reception to his announcement about the superannuation guarantee levy. He very quickly thought that he had better try to salvage it by promising a White Paper. My information is that it has already gone to Cabinet and been approved. But now, of course, in the wake of our announcements in these areas, it is all back to square one. Indeed, even the Evatt Foundation recognises that most of our initiatives have trumped the Government comprehensively. The Government will need to go back and rework its White Paper. That, of course, is the great tragedy of those who seek, for once in their expedient lives, to espouse some sort of political morality because it has to deliver the goods.

PARA.TAB: Senator Richardson has talked about these things up and down the nation and one would have thought the very least he could have done was to deliver. If he could not get it through Cabinet, we understand that, but at least he should have been prepared to remain on the public record. He has had two chances in the last two days to say that double dipping still must stop; that the preservation age still must be raised; and that there are a number of other initiatives one can take to stop double dipping like putting a ceiling on lump sums. He is on the record as being in favour of all these things but suddenly he is not prepared to endorse them. I simply say, `We have been, why won't you?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some weeks ago I did deliver a speech to the conference to which Senator Alston referred and, because the speech was largely on superannuation, naturally enough the speech was cleared with the office of the Treasurer (Mr Kerin). In fact, the Treasurer's office wrote parts of it. I am not going to be jumped on from a great height by any Treasurer about it because it came out of his office.
—But you didn't say that you were there on his behalf, did you?

—I did not say I was there on his behalf. Because I had been invited to address the conference, and I accepted, I then asked the Treasurer—naturally enough, because it is his area of responsibility—`What would you like me to say?'. He told me and so I said it.
—But you didn't tell the audience that you were somehow limited.
—I do not think that I needed to. I find this quite strange.
—You spoke in your own right.

—Often when I am making speeches in my own right I clear them with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), with the Treasurer and with a whole host of people because one ought to do that. That is the proper way to run government. I offered perhaps one or two comments during the 30 or 35 minute speech: one was on double dipping and the other was on investment and value-adding. I do not resile from that. It is simply not my responsibility to answer questions on those subjects here.

PARA.TAB: If one looks at the portfolio, it is obvious that superannuation has some crossover. That is why I regularly consult with the Treasurer on the question and that is why he will consult with me over the course of the next year as we develop our response to the Budget decision on the superannuation guarantee levy with employers and unions. I will be in constant contact with him over it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is all about restricting access to the age pension.

—But it is also true that the age pension system has an important overlap with the tax system. What we do with taxation between now and 1995 will be very important, but that does not mean I answer questions on the taxation system here and I will not be. It obviously has a relationship with the CES because we jointly administer JSA and Newstart with it, but I will not be answering questions on what the CES does for the same reasons. It is absolutely ridiculous to suggest that I am under some obligation to comment on all of that.

PARA.TAB: As I said earlier, it is also true that during normal ministerial duties, speeches and question times around the country Ministers get asked about everything. I even get the odd question on defence. All that Ministers can do is follow the Government line and if they do not know what it is then simply say so. That is why, over the course of five years as a Minister, it has not been a worry for me and it is not a worry now.

Senator Alston referred to the question of the extension of fringe benefits. He obviously does not understand where that is up to at all. So I suppose I should explain. It is not a matter of grabbing cheap headlines; nor is it a matter of the Government's intent not being serious. We shall be doing it. I went to a meeting with the States some time back. The only State to be critical of me, oddly enough, was New South Wales, which is a bit of a shock. The States overwhelmingly carried a resolution which I had suggested. I might say they have since changed their minds at a meeting with the Premier and come back with a proposal which is much more in line with what the Commonwealth would have wanted; one I did not think I would have been able to get through at that meeting with the welfare Ministers. Again, I am delighted with that.

The extension of fringe benefits had nothing to do with age. Senator Alston said it affected those over a certain age but that is not true. It was an extension to all of those who are on a part pension; whereas at the moment there is an income limit of $103 or $104 a week. Senator Alston is wrong on all counts on that. I expect that an announcement on that will be made, as I have been saying for the last six months, around March or April next year, and we will proceed to do it. I am happy to answer questions on that because that is directly within the portfolio and I am the one handling the job. However, when it comes to what happens with superannuation over the course of the next 12 months as the Government's decisions announced in the Budget are negotiated with employers and employees, it will be the responsibility of the Treasurer to answer questions on that. I would have it no other way.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Future of the Naval Communication Station at North West Cape, Western Australia

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on the future of the naval communication station at North West Cape in Western Australia, and to move to take note of the statements and three related documents.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to inform the Senate that the Australian and United States governments have now agreed on new arrangements concerning the future of the joint Australia-United States naval communication station at North West Cape in Western Australia. Mr Acting Deputy President, you might recall that on 12 March 1990 the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) announced that the United States had agreed to discuss an Australian proposal to take over and operate the station as an Australian defence facility, instead of as a joint defence facility.

PARA.TAB: I am able to announce today that the US Secretary of Defense, Mr Dick Cheney, and I have recently endorsed the elements of a seven-year phased transition plan that will result in the station becoming an Australian naval communication station. I table my exchange of letters with Mr Cheney. The changes will shortly be reflected in amendments to our formal agreement with the United States governing the station. We will achieve this through an exchange of diplomatic notes between my colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, and the US Ambassador, His Excellency Mr Melvin Sembler.

Originally established as a US naval communication station in 1963, North West Cape has functioned as a joint defence facility since 1974. Its primary purpose is to communicate with submerged submarines. The transition period during which the station will become an Australian naval communication station will be marked by three important changes at the station which I will now outline.

First, there will be considerably enhanced Australian participation in station management and operations. A Royal Australian Navy officer will be appointed as commanding officer in 1992 and will be responsible for managing the station. Australia's leading role will be even more apparent because there will be few, if any, US Navy personnel at the station after 1993; most will have left before then. The US Navy will continue to be actively engaged at the station, which will remain a joint facility during the transition. It will have access to three of the four very low frequency channels used for communicating with submerged submarines, will contribute to operating costs, and assist with logistics support, capital upgrades and technical expertise.

In a second major change, it has been agreed that a civilian contractor will be selected after free and open competition to operate the station. Contractor operations will be introduced as soon as possible after 1992. The US Navy has confirmed a need to minimise its manpower at the station by then.

Third, until now Australia's contribution to station operating costs has been limited to the salaries and allowances of the Royal Australian Navy and Australian Protective Service personnel working there. Under the new arrangements, the cost of operating the station will be shared by Australia and the United States on the basis of user pays principles, both during and after the transition. In broad terms, Australia's share will be about 25 per cent of the total VLF costs. The actual amount will depend on the terms of the contract to be signed with the civilian operator and other factors. I must say, however, that total operating costs and staffing levels are expected to be significantly lower than they are at present.

These benefits are also an excellent example of what the Government hopes to achieve under the defence commercial support program. Under this program, the Government will transfer defence support activities to the private sector, where this is practical and cost effective. The introduction of a civilian operator at North West Cape reflects my determination to pursue this policy vigorously.

There has been some speculation about what it might cost Australia to take over the station. I am pleased to be able to inform the Senate that the United States Government has advised us that it will seek no compensation for the buildings and other structures at the station while it continues to have access to the station.

Mr Acting Deputy President, the Cold War may be over but, as the Gulf war earlier this year showed, the need for defence has far from disappeared. We need to remain prepared to deter and, if necessary, to deal with a range of other contingencies in support of peace and international stability.

In keeping with our original proposal, the new arrangements at North West Cape include a guarantee that the United States will continue to have access to the station after it becomes an Australian facility, with the United States continuing to share the operating costs on user pays principles. We welcome the continuing US access to the station, which will help support the US presence in the Asia-Pacific region. It is a very practical demonstration of the US commitment, a commitment that is also recognised and appreciated by our regional neighbours.

The new arrangements also advance other Australian interests. In particular, they reinforce the significant improvements this Government has made in enhancing Australia's self-reliant defence posture. The station's capability for communicating with submerged submarines throughout and beyond our area of strategic interest is unique in our region. It contributes significantly to the security of our own submarine operations and the safety of their crews. We use that capability extensively. It will become even more important to us as the six new Collins class submarines begin to enter service with the Royal Australian Navy in the next few years. In short, the new arrangements show that Australia is itself willing to take the responsibility for ensuring that this essential element of our submarine capability is maintained. This is defence self-reliance in its maturity.

I would like to pay tribute to the people of Exmouth for their fine contribution to the morale and welfare of the thousands of service men and women who have worked at the station in the years since it was commissioned.Theirs has been a noteworthy contribution to our defence relationship with the United States and in support of the Royal Australian Navy. There is no clearer indication of the warmth and generosity of the people of Exmouth than the considerable number of US and Australian service personnel who have sought to return to the station for second and even third postings.

I know that there is some apprehension in Exmouth about the changes to be made at the station. In response to these concerns, I have arranged for the Deputy Chief of the Naval Staff personally to brief the people of Exmouth and station employees on the changes I have just outlined. The briefing team will include a US Navy representative from the United States. A similar briefing has been arranged for the Western Australian Government in Perth because of the many implications the changes will have for State Government operations in the town.

Some time ago I agreed to the establishment of a consultative forum under the chairmanship of Mr Tom Stephens, MLC, to look at the future needs and development prospects of the town of Exmouth. While these are still early days, it is important to point out that the Australian and United States governments both remain committed to the fullest possible consultation with the station work force and with other interested parties in Exmouth concerning the detail of the changes to be phased in over the next seven years.

Times have changed considerably since the station and the town grew up together. But they also present new opportunities, and I would like to encourage the people of Exmouth and those who work at the station to use those opportunities to build for the positive future of the town. The changes I have described will ensure that the station—and hence Exmouth itself—has a solid and enduring foundation for the years ahead. Today's announcement provides a firm basis for all concerned to be confident about the future and to plan accordingly.

Many points of detail still need to be worked out in discussions between the Royal Australian Navy and United States Navy. Nevertheless, the changes I have outlined represent a major departure from the arrangements that were put in place almost 30 years ago and, with few amendments, have shaped the management and operation of the station since. Indeed, the new arrangements are a landmark in building Australia's defence self-reliance and a measure of the maturity of our relationship with the United States.

Secretary Cheney has welcomed the new arrangements as testimony to the flexibility in our relationship, which enables it to adapt to changing circumstances as mutual security needs require. This flexibility has made our alliance an enduring, and welcome, feature of the security environment in the Asia-Pacific region.

In March 1990 the Prime Minister spoke about burden-sharing. He described the Australian proposal for changes at the station as a constructive contribution to our alliance with the United States, which would support our shared interests in the peaceful development of the Asia-Pacific region. Today we have seen that initiative rewarded. The changes that have resulted ensure that the station will continue to operate in ways that best serve Australia's interests and those of our US partner.
I commend this outcome to all Australians. I table the statement and I move:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) has just delivered is a very important one. It deals with an important aspect of our defence, and for that reason it deserves great attention from the Senate. The Opposition agrees entirely with that part of Senator Ray's statement in which he emphasises the importance of the North West Cape Harold E. Holt communications station, as it is named. It has performed a very important role, not only in the defence of Australia but also during the Cold War in the defence of the Western alliance interests throughout that period. We agree entirely with the comments to the effect that, simply because the Cold War is over, there is no reason why we should relax as far as our defence needs are concerned. It has a continuing role, including use by our ally the United States, and, in regard to our defence, it is important in relation to the operation of our submarines. That has established it as a very important defence facility.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition has no disagreement whatever with those observations made by the Minister for Defence in the statement, nor do we as an Opposition oppose the changeover of control of the station from a joint to an Australian facility. The question whether it is necessary to make that transition at this time is another matter. That will be the subject of some discussion by me this afternoon. I wish to make it perfectly clear that we are not opposing the idea of this station becoming an Australian defence facility. I dare say that many Australians, who perhaps do not place the same importance on the United States alliance as we do, will welcome that change.

The timing of the change has created a number of problems, which is what I want to concentrate on now. I want to deal with the problem of the so-called seven-year phasing of the change; I shall deal with the problems of payment and expense involved in the exercise; and I shall then deal with the serious problem that has been created for the Exmouth community as a result of the change.

It is important to look at how the genesis of this change from a joint facility to an Australian facility arose. As the statement points out, on 12 March 1990—a somewhat significant date because it was in the middle of the last election campaign—the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) visited Western Australia where several seats were being hard fought and were greatly at stake for the Government. Mr Hawke there announced with a great flourish that the United States had agreed to discuss an Australian proposal to take over and operate the station as an Australian defence facility.

I do not think anyone would be given any prizes for assessing the political basis of this whole exercise at that time. Events that occurred subsequent to 12 March 1990 add force to that argument. Having made this great flourish in the middle of the election campaign in Western Australia, the Government was duly re-elected, and then for months and months nothing seemed to be happening. Nothing was being said about the serious financial consequences of the proposal. Figures were freely quoted at the time of some $30m in extra costs for our defence budget, yet there seemed to be no concern on the part of the Government about resolving the issues which it had created.

It was not until the end of 1990 that there were any ministerial discussions about this question. It was then stated that at the Ausmin talks which were held towards the end of 1990 an agreement had been arrived at for a seven-year phased transition. From the perspective of the people most concerned in the area, this matter having been raised in the election campaign giving rise to doubts and concerns, every effort appeared to be made by the Government to allay those concerns. I again raised the matter with Senator Robert Ray in the Estimates hearing in April of this year. We were then told that officials were to conduct discussions about the seven-year transition proposal. All this led to the view that there would not be an immediate withdrawal of American personnel from the base and that the whole exercise would be done in a staged and sensible way. However, within a week or two of those hearings, the United States commander of the base, on his return from a visit to Washington, announced that the Americans would all be withdrawing within two years.

It is interesting that when the matter was then raised with Ministers, including Minister Bilney in the other place who had something to say about the matter, the statement as to American bases was being played down as a United States Navy view. Senator Robert Ray said in the Senate on 28 May this year:

SPEECH.PARA: If in fact the US Government adopts the Navy's view and decides to pull out all of its officers and ranks out of the base in October 1993 instead of over the seven-year period outlined after talks between Secretary Cheney and me, we would have to look at that timetable again.

Therefore, even as recently as 28 May this year, the urgency of the matter was being played down by both Ministers, because Minister Bilney said the same thing in answer to a question in the other place. It was said that it was a US Navy view. There was nothing further from the truth because clearly it was the United States Government's view. Indeed, the United States Government seized on the offer by the Australian Government to rid itself of major costs in the operation of this facility as part of its general drawdown of forces around the world. Clearly, the Americans seized on this offer by the Prime Minister, made out of the blue in the last election campaign, as a way of assisting them in reducing their defence costs around the world.

PARA.TAB: What surprised me was that this Government did not in the first place assess the significance of what was being said by the Prime Minister; or indeed the significance of the timetable that would be imposed by the United States Government. Certainly the Australian Government was still trying to play down the matter as recently as the end of May this year. The dogs had been barking for ages that the US Government was about to take steps of this kind, and indeed has now done so very rapidly since 28 May this year.

Following those statements here in the Senate at the end of May this year, negotiations were quickly brought into play in Washington at official level. Indeed, when I visited Washington in the middle of September this year I was told that the agreement had all been stitched up. Things were moving extremely rapidly at a time when we and the people of Exmouth were being led to believe that there would be no worries and that it would all fall into place in the seven-year transition period.
The fact is that the withdrawal by the United States personnel from this base will be even more sudden than the Government has led us to believe right up until now. The Minister's statement says:

SPEECH.PARA: An R.A.N. officer will be appointed as commanding officer in 1992,—
I think that is October 1992—
and will be responsible for managing the station.
That is less than a year away now. It continues:
Australia's leading role will be even more apparent because there will be few, if any, US Navy personnel at the station after 1993, and most will have left before then.

It is quite clear that, far from being a seven-year withdrawal, the withdrawal will be even sooner, quicker and more extensive than was suggested by the US commander in May this year when he was talking about a two-year period. It is very disappointing, to say the least, that this whole exercise has been managed in this way by this Government and this Minister. It seems to me that there has been a real failure in diplomacy on the part of this Government in this matter.

PARA.TAB: There are further worrying aspects. Now that we know that the withdrawal will take place in 1992, and will be well and truly completed in 1993, there is clearly a very major question as to whether Australia will be able effectively to manage the station from the time it actually takes over. Funnily enough, there will not be a change of name from a joint facility to an Australian facility in October 1992 when we appoint the Australian commander. That name change will not occur within the seven-year period. Goodness knows why it will not occur in 1992 because by then an Australian naval officer will be the commander of the base and, as the Minister has just told us, there will be a civilian contractor put in to run it.

There must be a very serious question as to whether the contractor will have sufficiently trained personnel to take over the running of the base within that timetable. The Minister has set out a timetable at the end of his speech which does not throw much more light on the matter. It is perfectly obvious that that will be a problem.

Nor is there any further light shed on this by the letters that have been tabled. The schedule that I have just referred to, the `Outline for the phased transition of Navcomsta Harold E. Holt from a joint defence facility to an Australian defence facility', says that from October 1992 to October 1993 there will be the following:
appointment of a RAN Commanding Officer. . .
award of contract for civilian operator, and start of contractor build-up as remaining USN personnel withdraw. . .
start of an Australian contribution to Station operating costs once the civilian operator is engaged.

SPEECH.PARA: Less than two years from now, the whole transition will virtually be in place.

PARA.TAB: The reference in the statement by the Minister to the seven-year transition is only a sop. He and his United States counterpart agreed on a seven-year transition when they first talked about this about a year ago, that has now clearly changed and a quite different transition period of two years has been agreed on. I do not know why the Minister just does not accept the reality of that in this statement and stop trying to make out that it is, in effect, a seven-year transition period.

I add in passing that the Opposition certainly is not criticising the decision to appoint a contractor to run the base. That is entirely in line with the view that we have adopted for some time in regard to the Government's own force structure statement in May and the development of our own policy. That is a sensible thing to do, but we are concerned about whether it will be possible to choose the contractor and for him to be able to get his work force together in time. It will need a specially trained work force of many people and that will present a real practicable problem.

Next, there seems to be some doubt about payment. This has loomed large in previous discussions about whether Australia would be required to make any payments to the United States for the use of the equipment. Under this arrangement Australia will be required to start paying for its share of the operations of the base—about one-quarter, I gather—and the United States will continue to pay for the other three-quarters during this period of seven years. Presumably that will pertain as long as the United States remains a partner beyond the seven years—and we expect and hope that that will be the case—but if the United States decided that it did not want to continue that arrangement beyond seven years we, as a nation, will be faced with bearing the total cost of this operation because we need it for communications with our own submarines.

In his statement Senator Ray says that the United States will seek no compensation for buildings and other structures at the station while it continues to have access to the station. The question of what is referred to as residual value will not arise until the United States ceases to be interested in the base. As I said, the letter from Senator Ray to Mr Cheney says that the issue of residual value need not be addressed while the United States continues to have access to the station.

Nevertheless, there is the question of whether or not the United States would seek to remove vital equipment if that occurred. That seems to be left entirely in the air. The question of compensation would only arise, according to Senator Ray's letter to Mr Cheney, in relation to the residual value of buildings, structures and improvements to the station funded by the United States Government—and, of course, the United States has built it all—and not removed upon termination of the agreement. We could be left in queer street as far as this agreement is concerned.All I am saying is that this agreement certainly does not seem to deal with that very important question that could arise down the track. I am sorry that the statement does not seem to clarify that in a better way.
Finally, I want to say something about the position of the Exmouth community. The statement by the Minister is a masterpiece of understatement in relation to the Exmouth community. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I know there is some apprehension in Exmouth about the changes to be made at the station.

I have news for the Minister. There is a great degree of anxiety among the community at Exmouth as a result of the way this Government has carried on since 12 March 1990. The community has been building up a head of steam; there is a real head of steam there now. When the community learns of this statement, as it probably will later today, there will be a great deal of anxiety indeed. I think it is just as well that Senator Ray is sending the Deputy Chief of the Navy to Exmouth tomorrow to talk to people. I know that there have been previous discussions with people in Exmouth, but nothing has been resolved by the Government, and it will have to be.

PARA.TAB: This withdrawal will have a severe impact on the local community. As the statement shows, there are 400 United States uniformed personnel, most of whom will be gone within the next 12 to 18 months—certainly before the two years are up. Those people were occupying nearly 200 houses in the town and their departure will leave this property vacant. What will happen to it? What effect will this have on property values in Exmouth? There is great concern about that.

The Government has a major obligation to the Exmouth community and, indeed, so does the United States Government. The United States Government has had a major benefit from the use of the station, and will continue to benefit from its use. Both governments have an obligation to the people of Exmouth. Certainly, the Government should ensure that many of the people who have been working there—the 160 civil personnel working on the base who live in Exmouth—are given every opportunity to participate in the running of the base when it is commercialised.

The Government will need to address the problem of housing in the town. It will also have to face up to the question of what is going to be done for the future of Exmouth. The Minister mentioned that he has set up a consultative forum to consider these matters, chaired by a local member of the Western Australian Legislative Council. He does not tell us where the forum has got to or what it has been doing. It will have to be activated. The Western Australian Government will also have to be brought into this in relation to what other jobs can be created in this area. The United States personnel have magnificent facilities on the base which will become vacant, and the question arises of the future of those facilities. Perhaps they could be made available for tourist developments of one kind or another in the region. There is a build-up of tourism in that region, and that is obviously one of the most likely ways to create more jobs in Exmouth to replace the many jobs that will be lost as a result of this proposal.

In conclusion, in my view this is a very disappointing statement. It may be, as the statement says, an advance in Australia's defence self-reliance, and we have no objection to that. In point of fact, it is a sorry story of ineptness by this Government and the failure of its uninspired diplomacy with the United States. It was caught totally flat-footed; it was hoist with its own petard. For political purposes, this whole thing was activated by the Prime Minister, and then virtually buried for some considerable time. The United States has taken up the offer suddenly and with a vengeance. The Government has had to come into line with a timetable that was presented as a seven-year timetable and is now less than two years. It is a sorry performance on the part of the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address briefly the ministerial statement on the future of the North West Cape. The statement sets out arrangements for transferring control of the North West Cape naval communications station from the United States to Australia over a seven-year period, ending in October 1998.

PARA.TAB: The statement contains several major provisions. First, the Royal Australian Navy will take command of the station next year. Secondly, station operations will be taken over by a civilian contractor shortly thereafter, culminating in a near or total withdrawal of United States Navy personnel by October 1993. An Australian contribution to station operating costs will commence then. Thirdly, a five-year period of joint operation will commence thereafter, with a transfer of control taking place at the end of that period. The United States Navy will have guaranteed access to the station during and after the seven-year transitional period. Finally, Australia will be liable for the residual value of buildings and equipment if United States access ends after Australian control commences.

Honourable senators will remember that the North West Cape takeover was announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during last year's election campaign, with a clear intention of wooing the preferences of Australian Democrats and Greens voters in Western Australia. This vote-buying exercise was a direct response to a campaign run by parts of the Western Australian peace movement called Take Back the Cape, which called for the base to be taken over for the exclusive use of the Australian Defence Force.

However, this takeover plan contains one crucial difference: it allows for continued guaranteed access to the station by the United States Navy for its communications needs. This would include communications to naval forces engaged in such repugnant and inhumane military operations as the Gulf war. It seems likely that United States access will be provided irrespective of the Australian Government's opinion of the legitimacy of the operation in question. There will probably continue to be a gaping hole in Australian control and sovereignty. In other words, this statement makes very little difference to the role of the North West Cape. The real changes are in cost sharing and administration arrangements. On this score, the Democrats note that there will be no payment of the residual capital costs of the station for as long as the United States has access. We wonder whether the implication is that we will be up for a lot of costs at the end of that period.

We also note that an Australian contribution to operating costs will begin during 1993. It is interesting that during the seven-year transition period the United States will retain access to three of the four channels for submarine communications, as it does now. This suggests that North West Cape will continue to serve the United States to a much greater degree than it will serve Australian interests, and any cost-sharing arrangement must clearly reflect this arrangement.

There is also an uncomfortable suggestion in this statement that the transfer is actually being designed to suit the United States timetable for reducing numbers of personnel deployed to overseas bases. The October 1992 deadline for appointing an Australian commander and letting the civilian operations contract is specifically designed to meet this schedule.

The Democrats have one major concern about this arrangement, which goes to the heart of our defence policy. We believe that the case for a continued operation by Australia of a submarine fleet in the light of changing regional circumstances and Australia's comfortable strategic position is highly questionable. There are many other security priorities which should take precedence over running the existing fleet and spending more than $5 billion on the new Collins class vessels.

Without a submarine fleet there would be no need for submarine communications facilities. It follows that the expenditures associated with this takeover are a waste of taxpayers' funds. Ultimately, the question is whether we need North West Cape at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are several points in the ministerial statement that need to be challenged. The Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) refers to the history of the base. It is worth remembering that originally the United States began discussions with the Menzies Government in 1960, at a time when Australia's motivation was to get the United States base here so as to make it worth its while to defend this country if Australia were ever attacked again. In 1980, Professor Des Ball referred to it as a suitable piece of real estate.

PARA.TAB: In the 1960s the Labor Party had the guts to question the need for this base, but power seems to have corroded its principles, despite the involvement of the base in an offensive nuclear war-fighting option, and the Government has never acknowledged secondary functions through the involvement of the United States National Security Agency. We can only guess at those or get information from the United States under its Freedom of Information Act, which is worth a lot more than ours.

For some years the base has ceased to communicate with US SSBNs as the Trident submarines communicate through the VLF station at Jim Creek in the State of Washington on the US mainland. So it has served only as a backup facility for some time, but as a backup facility, of course, it still retains some importance to the United States Navy. That is why the United States Government is now prepared to allow Australia to run the base, and we apparently want it to communicate with the new RAN submarines operating off the West Coast.

This decision once again leads me to question the need for these expensive submarines, because it is the extra cost of running this huge facility at North West Cape which is the sort of item that gets left out of the accounts for the submarine project. We will have to bear all of those costs, but they are not accounted for.

Submarines are designed to combat high level threats, and we have been repeatedly told that there are no high level threats to Australia. We do need more patrol boats and smaller vessels to combat low level security threats such as illegal fishing, illegal immigration, drug running, and so on. We do not need these submarines, which will cost taxpayers some $5 1/2 billion plus the extra cost of running North West Cape, which is never included in the accounting.

The statement still does not make clear how the United States will be using the facility in future or whether it will still be utilised by the National Security Agency through its naval branch. Other paragraphs in the statement are also highly contentious. The Minister referred to the end of the Cold War but then went on to justify a continued high level of military expenditure. He also referred to the continued presence of the United States in the Asia-Pacific region, which he welcomes but I do not.

I have repeatedly stated that we should be taking advantage of the end of the Cold War to promote non-military forms of conflict resolution, not to further escalate a conventional arms race in the neighbourhood. The global policeman role of the United States referred to by the Minister seems to infer that the East-West conflict is being replaced by a North-South conflict, with Australia taking sides with the industrialised nations, continuing to maintain its dominant role in the world economy at the expense of poorer countries, especially in our region.

Virtually every country in the Asia-Pacific region is a friend or ally of the Western alliance, with the exception of China, Vietnam and North Korea, none of which could possibly pose a threat to Australian security. It is well known that, if the United States were to vacate the facility, it could easily relocate somewhere else, as it contemplated doing some 30 years ago when it considered other sites in the western Pacific.

So now we are to continue being saddled with this somewhat ancient facility, which the United States Navy does not really need except as a backup facility, and which the Royal Australian Navy does not really need either, I would suggest. As Senator Durack pointed out, the United States Government does not bother to consult with the Australian Government on withdrawal timetables. Australia again is unassertive and ill-informed and just lets the United States walk all over us. Is this why we are now breaking new ground in inviting President Bush to address a joint sitting of the Australian Parliament? This is not an Australian tradition; it is an American tradition. Did George suggest this to Bob in one of his infamous phone calls? Regardless of where the suggestion came from, it is another example of Australia following the US lead.

I strongly disapprove ofall this precedent entails, especially in terms of costs to Australian taxpayers for not only the million dollar special sitting of parliament but also the gigantic security costs involving the 200-person entourage travelling with the President. They are very smart in the United States. It is the same thing—they get the kudos and we pay. With the North West Cape we will continue its upkeep for their convenience but at our expense.

It is a bit like the Gulf war, really, out of which the United States managed actually to make money. That is, if the other countries that went into bat with it, such as Germany and Japan, cough up as promised, the United States will make $13 billion out of that slaughtering operation. In the estimation of some people, the United States will get a lot of credit points for that too, but not in mine.

I have repeatedly stated that we should be taking advantage of the end of the Cold War to promote non-military forms of conflict resolution. That is not what we are doing by elevating our own military preparedness, as some people would like to call it, by going in for high-tech, offensive capabilities like these submarines which, as I said, we do not need.

There is very little mention of real costs in this statement except to say that costs will be shared in the post-transition period on a user-pay basis. Where are the figures? The Minister gives us no figures whatsoever in this statement. What kinds of charges will be laid and for what kinds of uses? None of that is mentioned.
Neither does the Minister deal with the costs of updating the facility. I should like to remind him of the article by Herschel Hurst in the Pacific Defence Reporter of May 1990, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Meanwhile, it is accepted in Canberra that considerable updating of equipment—
at North West Cape—

will be necessary in the next five or ten years. And that will cost a lot of money. However, strategists say the money will have to be found if Australia is to continue with the policy of defence self-reliance.

The Minister does not even mention that. The technology there is old. This is a facility that has been there for a very long time. It needs upgrading. There is no mention of the ongoing running costs or the costs of upgrading the facility. I therefore await with some interest the figures, not only for the running costs so that we can talk to a couple of submarines at any one time, but also the extra cost for Australian taxpayers of updating the facility. The Government has a responsibility to come clean and give us the figures.

PARA.TAB: As far as the people of Exmouth are concerned, they have had time over the years to make the transition from being a US military town, as it was from 1963 to 1974—that is what it was established for, a United States military town—to the so-called joint facility status from then until now, and later on it will be an Australian Navy town.

However, there are two other very important aspects to life in Exmouth. Local businesses would do better to concentrate on non-military opportunities to ensure a good quality of life for people who live in Exmouth and for people to visit. I mention the burgeoning fishing industry and the Cape Range National Park. Both fishing and tourism are two very important industries of which the people of Exmouth can be proud.

I should hope that they will be able to see their way clear not to be quite so concerned about losing some of the US influence. For goodness sake, this is meant to be Australia, not an outpost of the United States Navy. They should be glad that it is returning to Australian hands but they do need decent consideration by this Government. As Senator Durack has pointed out, that is not forthcoming. The timetable has been set from outside, imposed by the Americans. It is the same old story. The people of Exmouth deserve better than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Durack said in his excellent review of the document, this is an important statement before the Senate this afternoon. The Opposition supports the general intent of the document, but we are certainly very concerned about the shortage of details within it. It is very short on anything that we can get our teeth into, such as the actual costs which are involved. We ought to know those costs at the outset. Unlike the wanderings of the two speakers before me, I believe that we cannot have a defence force that does not cost money. If we want a decent defence force, we have to be prepared to pay for it.

PARA.TAB: Submarines are part of the Australian defence capability and we have to be able to talk to them and control them. The only way we can talk to a submarine and maintain communications is through the very long wavelengths that are propagated out of the VLF transmission station. This is what North West Cape is all about. It is a naval communications station; it is a high frequency station. We have many HF stations around the world and around the country, but North West Cape is the only one in this part of the world that is also a VLF station. It is the only way that we can talk to a submerged submarine.

If we are going to put a lot of money into the submarines as combat weapons, we have to maximise their survivability. One of the ways to do that is by keeping them well below the surface of the water. We cannot transmit down to a submerged submarine other than through the very long wavelength transmissions from these sorts of stations.

I have been to North West Cape many times. It is a very impressive place to visit. There are a number of high towers—some of them probably go up to about 1,000 feet, from memory. It has a very big aerial farm with heavy cables between the towers. The transmission facility itself precedes the electronic era with respect to the transmitting equipment. It is all done with huge glass valves like the old radio sets were in the thirties, forties and fifties. That is done because there is not a more modern substitute for them.

The reason that we would like to know the cost estimates is that very high costs, quite apart from the manpower costs, are involved in maintaining this station. The aerials, for example, have to come down quite regularly—I think about every 12 months. A number of them are replaced quite frequently. We are looking at very big costs there because miles and miles of heavy gauge copper and aluminium cables are involved.

North West Cape is no longer of prime importance to the United States. At the height of the Cold War and deterrence, nuclear submarines with ICBMs were deployed around the world and targeted against Soviet Russia. With improving technology and the latest marks of Tridents with their longer range, it is possible for the Americans to keep those submarines closer to the mainland of the United States in the Pacific and to communicate with them from mainland VLF stations. Nevertheless, it is important to maintain a backup facility; it is important to the United States from that point of view. But it is also crucially important to us. We simply have no other way of communicating with submarines. We should remember that not only Australian submarines in the Indian Ocean, but also Australian submarines in the South Pacific can be contacted through North West Cape if that is their theatre of operations.

As Senator Durack said, it is true that we got into this by accident. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) thought he was going to lose the election. Of course, it is a matter of fact that he did poll fewer votes for the Labor Party than the Liberal and National parties did. But owing to the successful rorting of the boundaries in New South Wales some years ago, the Labor Party ended up with a small majority. The point was that the Labor Party was very worried about the outcome through the election campaign in 1990. Mr Beazley and Mr Hawke decided to buy a few votes in Western Australia. They said, `We will buy this. We will take this station over from the United States'.

Nevertheless, there has been a better outcome to it than we might have expected given the precipitate nature of the decision. We welcome the fact that it will move under Australian control. It seems, thanks principally to the generosity of the United States, that it is going to work out on favourable grounds for Australia in so far as there will not be a charge made for those facilities while the Americans, if the text is correct, have access to the facilities. So even when the transition period is over and the Americans retain access, even if they are not actually using it, I presume that there will not be a charge to Australia for the capital costs of the facilities there.

The point that I would like to make in relation to the document tabled by Senator Ray is to do with the interesting statement that this is `defence self-reliance in its maturity'. I have a very high regard for Senator Ray. He is one of the most honest of the Labor Ministers in so far as he does not seek to fudge issues; but he is certainly fudging in a very big way there. In no sense is this defence self-reliance in its maturity. It is a step along the path to self-reliance, and we support that. But one of the great canards that the Labor Party markets about its defence policy is that somehow or other since it has come to power Australian defence has become self-reliant.

We have to spend only a few minutes looking at the capabilities of the Australian defence forces; we only have to spend a few micro-seconds looking at the sustainability of the Australian defence forces. In other words, how long could the Australian defence forces fight if there was a defence emergency? If we look at their missile stocks, ammunition stocks, fuel stocks and equipment stocks we realise that the sustainability of the Australian defence forces is measured in terms of days; not weeks, months or years as it should be. The Labor Party maintains this deception that somehow or other we have achieved maturity in defence self-reliance. That sentence in the statement is really quite wrong.

Finally, looking ahead to the future, I think that Australia should be carefully looking at alternative transmitter technology. As I said earlier, this transmitting station precedes the electronic age. It may be possible to come up with newer types of transmissions. I do not believe that we will get away with the need to have VLF signals to communicate with submarines in the foreseeable future. But I think it is possible that an alternative transmitter technology could arise either in the form of ground stations or airborne transmission. If that could come about, it may be that the costs of operation in the longer term will diminish for us. The facts of the matter are that for the foreseeable future we will be having submarines within our defence armament, and the necessity to communicate with them at all times and under all conditions is one of the crucial requirements for the defence forces.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a Senator for Western Australia, I feel that there have been two aspects of the future of the naval communications base at Exmouth that have been of great concern in the anticipation of the statement that Senator Ray has put down today. Like Senator MacGibbon and Senator Durack, I find that it is very light-on on detail.

PARA.TAB: The first of the concerns that I have is the future of the town and the people of Exmouth. This is a community, of course, that has grown around the base and taken a vigorous life of its own. It is also a community that has for too long suffered uncertainty as to its future and a serious lack of communication from this Labor Government.

My colleague Senator Durack, as shadow Minister for defence, has visited Exmouth and talked with the members of its community in great detail about the transitional details that are needed to be put in place. I wonder whether the Minister for Defence has done likewise. The people of Exmouth really feel as though they have been neglected because the Minister for Defence has not taken some official consultative process earlier and in much more detail than he has currently displayed.

It is more than 18 months since the Prime Minister announced that the Royal Australian Navy would be taking over from the US Navy at a time of anxiety for an isolated but significant community of 2,700 people. Yet both Federal and State Labor governments have seemingly forgotten until now that the Shire of Exmouth exists. The people of Exmouth have not been getting a fair deal from Labor at the State level. Their State Labor member of the Legislative Assembly promised them a marina, which was shelved once the extent of WA Inc losses started to bite. As a result of this recent uncertainty and disappointment, no fewer than 20 per cent of privately owned dwellings were on the market and Exmouth was about to experience its first mortgagee sale.

We are now told that a briefing will be given tomorrow by Admiral Taylor to the people of Exmouth and that he will be talking with the new consultative forum. I hope this will result in some practical assistance, as the Minister's tribute to Exmouth, though shared by the coalition, is not enough on its own. The people of Exmouth really deserve some proper attention by this Government. I am disappointed that it did not happen a long time ago. While it is good that they are getting this briefing tomorrow, it is a shame that they have not been kept informed on an ongoing basis about the detail of what their lives will hold in Exmouth in the future.

While the Minister may refer to a seven-year transition, the fact remains that after 1993 Australia will be in effective control of the base, the US navy personnel will be gone, and there will simply be far fewer service personnel. Certainly Exmouth will enjoy some advantage with the possible contracting of work to civilians, but with 1993 looming closer there may be a need for other assistance.

I must emphasise that Exmouth is not like some of the mining towns in the north of Western Australia that were not designed to continue beyond the life of a mine. This is a very different set of circumstances. This is a town where people have made a permanent commitment and it is a town with a future beyond the servicing of a defence facility. Exmouth is ideally placed to serve as a centre for marine tourism. We now have a marine park covering the Ningaloo Reef, and Exmouth is the obvious base for those Australians who will be visiting one of the State's latest attractions. Transitional assistance in the form of roads and community infrastructure will not be a mere palliative but an investment in the future of the north. I certainly hope the people of Exmouth get this type of assistance.

This brings me to my second concern, which is the defence needs of Australia. We may well understand that the dramatic lessening of superpower rivalry diminishes the need of the United States to maintain as many defence facilities, but this development does not mean that Australia does not need a continuing naval communications facility at Exmouth. We may not need to worry any more about the activity of the Soviet Navy, but we have an abiding need to maintain our own preparedness, especially with regard to the Indian Ocean. India has developed a powerful navy with considerable potential for strategic outreach. We cannot afford to ignore the possibility that future governments of India may be influenced more strongly by hardline Hindu nationalism. This may not happen, but it is one good reason why we need to continue effective surveillance after the United States has withdrawn.

As a Liberal, I also believe that Australia should retain close defence cooperation as part of ANZUS and what I might term the Western alliance of democratic nations that no longer confront the Soviet Union but must at times cooperate against regional tyrants and international law breakers, of whom Saddam Hussein was a prime example. Simply, the continuation of the naval communications centre is far from obsolete or irrelevant. I am pleased to hear that the base will continue, but the transitional stage is certainly my concern.

Exmouth has played an essential role as a service town in the ultimate defence of Australia through more than 25 years of sometimes dangerous international developments. In earlier days it has been subject to the attentions of what could be called the Loony Left of Australia. We have heard one of the loony Loony Left speak today in Senator Vallentine. It is very disturbing that she has taken the attitude she has, particularly to an area in her own State.

It is a shame that the Loony Left of Australian politics has detested our alliance with the world's most powerful democracy and that it cannot grasp the fundamental truth that effective intelligence, far from imperilling the security of Australia, is the best guarantee of maintaining peace. The alliance has also resulted in Australia obtaining facilities built by our ally at minimal cost to ourselves. In 1974, protesters travelled to Exmouth in order to stage a noisy protest at the base. The police were busy ensuring that the angry townspeople of Exmouth did not overreact to the absolute idiocy of that protest and that it was not successful. But it certainly would have weakened our defence and destroyed the townspeople's livelihoods if the protesters had been able to get a firm grip at that stage in 1974.

We owe it to the people of Exmouth to ease the transition from a military service economy and we owe it to Australia to ensure that effective naval intelligence remains. I hope the Government makes every effort possible to ensure that that transition is smooth and with minimum disruption.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy), I present the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the social and fiduciary duties and obligations of company directors. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: NOVEMBER 1991
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT OF THE SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS ON "THE SOCIAL AND FIDUCIARY DUTIES AND OBLIGATIONS OF COMPANY DIRECTORS
Background to Committee's Report

In accordance with a resolution of the Senate on 26 May 1988, the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs ("the Committee") conducted an inquiry into the social and fiduciary duties and obligations of company directors.

2.The Committee received 33 written submissions and conducted public hearings in Sydney, Canberra and Melbourne during February and March 1989. Submissions were made by a wide range of parties including business, accounting, directors' and shareholders' associations, the Australian Stock Exchange, the National Companies and Securities Commission, and a number of prominent company officers and academics. The Government gratefully acknowledges the contribution of these individuals and groups to the Committee's report.
3.The Government further notes that the Committee focused its inquiry on the following broad areas:

PARA.TAB: qualifications of directors;
multiplicity of directorships;
role of directors and composition of the board, including board committees (especially audit committees);
the nature of directors' existing duties and responsibilities, the standards required, to whom the duties and responsibilities are owed and whether they should be widened; and
the enforcement of the law in so far as it concerns directors.

SPEECH.PARA: 4.The Committee's report was tabled in the Senate on 22 November 1989.

5.The Government would like to thank the Committee for its contribution to the development of company law. It welcomes the Committee's recommendations as an important step in ensuring that the reputation of the Australian corporate sector is restored to a level which meets community and commercial expectations, both in Australia and abroad.
The new national scheme for corporate regulation

6.On 14 July 1989, the Parliament enacted the Corporations Act 1989. In June 1990, the Government concluded heads of agreement with the States and the Northern Territory concerning the administration in Australia of the law relating to corporations and securities.
