The heads of agreement led to the commencement on 1 January 1991 of a new national scheme for the regulation of the law in Australia concerning corporations and the securities markets.
The Government's corporate law reform program

7.Following the commencement of the new scheme, the Government has commenced a major program of reform in companies and securities law. The Parliament has already enacted the Corporations Legislation Amendment Act 1991 which, among other things, made substantial changes to the law concerning the consolidation of company accounts and insider trading, the latter being in response to the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs entitled "Fair Shares for All: Insider Trading in Australia".

8.A second Bill effects reforms in stock exchange settlement procedures, implements the outcome of a review of the Australian Company Number provisions and makes technical changes to the fundraising provisions. A third Bill implements the Government's decisions announced in July on redemptions from unlisted property trusts.

9.The Government plans to expose a fourth reform Bill early next year, with a view to introduction in the Autumn 1992 Sittings. This will be a major reform Bill, and will deal with significant reform proposals concerning corporate insolvency, loans to directors, executive remuneration, further developments in stock exchange settlement procedures and the legislation outlined below in response to the Report by the Senate Standing Committee.
The Government's overall approach to directors' duties
10.The Government considers that the law relating to the duties and obligations of company directors is one of central importance, affecting as it

does the interests of shareholders, directors, creditors, employees and the general community. The Government is also concerned, however, to ensure that the Corporations Law does not unnecessarily burden the vast majority of company directors who are honest and competent. To this end, and consistent with the Committee's recommendations, the Government proposes a model for reform which takes into account, and builds upon, measures taken by the commercial community to enhance the competence and compliance by company directors with their social and fiduciary duties.
Note on terminology

11.References made by the Committee to provisions of the "Companies Act" have been amended throughout this statement to refer to the corresponding provisions of the new Corporations Law. Similarly, references by the Committee to the Company Directors Association of Australia and the Institute of Directors in Australia have been taken as references to their successor body, The Australian Institute of Company Directors, following their amalgamation subsequent to the tabling of the Committee's report.
12.The following paragraphs of this statement address in turn each of the Committee's recommendations.
Recommendations 1 and 2
A.Recommendation 1
13.An objective duty of care for directors be provided in the companies legislation.
B.Recommendation 2

14.A `business judgment rule' be introduced into Australian company law. It should include an obligation on directors to inform themselves of matters relevant to the administration of the company. They should be required to exercise an active discretion in the relevant matter, or alternatively, to show a reasonable degree of care in the circumstances.

15.The Government supports the notion of an objective duty of care and the prescription of requirements relevant to that duty. The Government proposes to achieve this directly, rather than through the introduction of a "business judgment rule".

16.The business judgement rule, which is a common law doctrine used in the United States, offers directors protection from civil action provided they act in good faith, without a conflict of interest, take reasonable steps to obtain information and act with a reasonable degree of care and diligence.

17.The Committee indicated that in its opinion the enactment of a business judgment rule would encourage the making of informed business judgments, stimulate innovation and risk taking, and limit judicial intrusiveness in private sector decision making. The Companies and Securities Law Review Committee ("CSLRC") has, since the tabling of the Senate Committee's report, also recommended the enactment of a business judgment rule.

18.The Government notes that the business judgment rule is one of a number of rules concerning directors' duties developed by the United States courts. The Government notes that Australian company law already confers a general discretion on the courts to relieve an officer of civil liability arising out of a breach of duty, negligence or trust. The Government is not at this stage convinced that it is appropriate to introduce in isolation this one aspect of American jurisprudence into the Australian law on director's duties.

19.Nevertheless, the Government notes that a number of recent court decisions have imposed significant personal liability upon directors whom the court considered were not sufficiently careful or diligent: Hussein v Good (1990) 8 ACLC 390; Heide Pty Ltd v Lester (1990) 8 ACLC 958; Statewide Tobacco Services v Morley (1990) 8 ACLC 827; Commonwealth Bank of Australia v Freidrich (1991) 9 ACLC 946. It acknowledges that these decisions may have created concerns in the minds of some directors about the relationship between honest, informed risk-taking and their personal liability for a breach of their duty of care and diligence to the company.

20.The Government agrees with the Senate Committee and the CSLRC that the law should not discourage directors who engage in honest, informed risk-taking, and to this end must provide such directors with the clearest guidance. However, the Government considers that there are alternative approaches, to be preferred to the enactment of a business judgment rule, which can provide additional guidance to directors as to what is expected of them, while making it clear that honest, informed risk-taking will not attract a civil or criminal sanction.

21.The Government considers that this additional guidance may best be provided by amending subsection 232(4) of the Corporations Law to clarify the standard of care and diligence required of company directors.

22.Subsection 232(4) currently provides that an officer of a corporation shall at all times exercise a reasonable degree of care and diligence in the exercise of his or her powers and the discharge of his or her duties. The Committee said that the extent of the duty of care owed by a director pursuant to subsection 232(4) is measured by reference to the particular director's knowledge and experience. It concluded that the duty of care established by subsection 232(4) was measured by a subjective standard, and that this standard was too low. The Committee recommended that subsection 232(4) be amended to require an objective standard of care, but did not propose a particular standard.

23.The Government considers that, since the tabling of the Committee's report in 1989, the courts, in their assessment of what is reasonable, have tended to raise the standard of care and diligence required of directors. It notes observations of Tadgell J in Commonwealth Bank of Australia v Friedrich, supra, at p.956:

"As the complexity of commerce has gradually intensified . . . the community has of necessity come to expect more than formerly from directors . . . In response, the parliament and the courts have found it necessary in legislation and litigation to refer to the demands made on directors in more exacting terms.
Tadgell J also said that:

"To speak of a director of ordinary, reasonable or average competence or prudence, or indeed of an ordinary reasonable or average director, is to give no very useful description, whereas a person seeking properly to perform the duties of a director of a particular company can be identified by reference to more specific criteria of which ordinariness, reasonableness and averageness are, or may be, merely ingredients." (Commonwealth Bank of Australia v Friedrich, supra, at p.955)

24.In order to provide the guidance and clarity mentioned above, and in an attempt to provide a more "useful description" of what is required of company officers, the Government proposes that subsection 232(4) be amended to reinforce that the duty of care is an objective one, requiring a company officer to exercise the degree of care and diligence that a reasonable person would exercise. The Government also proposes that the amended provision identify a series of factors relevant to the exercise of the appropriate standard of care and diligence. The intention is that the courts would have regard to these matters in their consideration of whether an officer had contravened the objective duty of care and diligence established by subsection 232(4) as amended.
25.The Government proposes that those matters include considerations such as the extent to which the officer:

PARA.TAB: (a)acquired information and made enquiry concerning the company's affairs (including attending relevant meetings);
(b)exercised an active discretion in the matter at issue;
(c)ensured that, where appropriate, the company established systems:

TAB.TAB: (i)to ensure that persons who prepared reports or opinions relied upon by officers of the company (including the officer concerned) were honest, reliable and merited confidence in relation to the report or opinion;
(ii)to ensure and monitor compliance with the law (and the company's constituent documents) by the company and its officers;
(iii)to ensure that those who took part in the management of the company's affairs were not subject to a disabling conflict of interest or duty;

(iv)to ensure that decisions taken by persons whom the board had appointed as the company's agent or to whom it had given a power of attorney (including the managing director or any other person who had the capacity to bind the company) were monitored; and

PARA.TAB: (d)complied with any such systems established by the company.

SPEECH.PARA: 26.The Government considers that this reform will provide directors with the guidance they require to avoid incurring personal liability, thus removing the need for a business judgment rule.
Recommendation 3
27.Directors be required to attend board meetings unless there is a reasonable excuse for non-attendance.

28.The Government supports this recommendation. No one could dispute the Committee's central contention that directors should, whenever possible, attend Board meetings. It would not seem appropriate, however, to impose a sanction in respect of a single failure to attend a meeting. Further, the question of how many meetings the Board convened might be just as important as how many were attended by a particular director. More generally, the Government does not understand the Committee to be singling out attendance at meetings to the exclusion of other indicia of care and diligence.

29. The Government considers that frequency of attendance at Board meetings could usefully be expressly set out in the legislation as one factor relevant to the question whether the overall pattern of behaviour of the director constituted a sufficient exercise of care and diligence. It is therefore proposed to specify attendance at meetings as a matter to which the court may have regard in its consideration of whether the director has breached the duty of care and diligence (see paragraph 25 above).

30.The Government also considers that the members of a public company are entitled to know whether their directors have attended board meetings. It therefore proposes to require the directors of a public company to include in the company's annual report to its members a note indicating the number of board meetings convened that year and the number of meetings attended by each person who was a director of the company at any time during that year.
Recommendation 4
31.The companies legislation be amended to provide for, and specifically limit, the extent to which company officers may rely on others.

32.The issue here is when, in the circumstances of a particular company, it is appropriate for company officers to delegate to other persons, committees or organizations, and rely on reports or opinions prepared by them.

33.Whilst the Government accepts the Committee's recommendation in principle, it is difficult to provide for these matters in precise detail, given the great diversity of companies and their operations, and the need to avoid creating inflexibility in the way in which the managements of companies respond to changing commercial needs.

34.The Government considers that, as with the question of attendance at meetings, the question of the extent to which officers delegated their powers and relied on others in making key decisions should be identified as a factor to be taken into account in deciding whether the officer has fallen short of the required duty of care to the company (see paragraph 25 above). This will enable a court to consider whether an officer has delegated in an irresponsible manner and, if so, the extent to which that irresponsibility may have caused loss to the company.
Recommendation 5
35.The companies legislation be amended to set out requirements which must be met for exoneration of directors from what would otherwise be breaches of their fiduciary duties.

36.The Committee referred to the general rule of fiduciary law that a beneficiary may forgive acts of a fiduciary which are in breach of the fiduciary's duty to the beneficiary. As an extension of this principle the Committee noted that a company in general meeting may generally ratify an action taken by a director for an improper purpose. The Committee considered that the object of fiduciary law is not to prohibit conduct but to compel disclosure, so that the company may consider whether to consent to the director undertaking a course of action that would otherwise involve a breach of the director's duty to the company. The present law, however, allows the general requirement of disclosure to a general meeting to be displaced by the company's articles of association. Further, there are suggestions that a director might vote as a shareholder to approve his or her own actions.

37.The Committee focused on three categories of breach of fiduciary duty: misuse of corporate assets, transactions with the company involving a conflict of interest, and the taking up for personal gain of business opportunities which ought to be taken up by the company. The Committee said that:

"It is difficult to formulate a general rule for disclosure and consent to activities which would otherwise be breaches of fiduciary duty. For some questions the involvement of shareholders is clearly warranted, while for others it would render decision making unnecessarily cumbersome. Different consent regimes may be appropriate for the various fiduciary rules".

38.Since the tabling of the Committee's report, the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee ("CSAC"), established under the Australian Securities Commission Act 1989 to provide expert advice to the Attorney-General in relation to the law concerning corporations, has addressed the issue of loans to directors and related topics. A report by CSAC, entitled "Reform of the Law Governing Corporate Financial Transactions", recommends the enactment of a disclosure and consent regime in relation to breaches of duty involving misuse of corporate assets and transactions with the company involving a conflict of interest.
39.The Government proposes to include in the planned exposure draft Bill provisions addressing the matters considered by CSAC.

40.The most important single area concerning the exoneration of directors identified by the Senate Standing Committee and which is not addressed in detail in the CSAC report is the area of corporate opportunity. Given the specific and major reforms recommended by CSAC in the other areas mentioned by the Senate Standing Committee, the Government intends to monitor experience with CSAC's proposals before asking CSAC to develop complementary proposals in the area of corporate opportunity.
Recommendation 6
41.The companies legislation be amended to permit all creditors to share equally in sums recovered from directors.

42.The Government understands this recommendation to be directed at the situation where a liquidator's lack of standing under section 592 of the Corporations Law to sue directors for debts incurred by the company can lead to one or more creditors securing an advantage over others.

43.It notes that this proposal resulted from the Committee's endorsement of one aspect of a wide-ranging reform concerning the personal liability of company directors on the winding up of an insolvent company proposed by the Australian Law Reform Commission in its "General Insolvency Inquiry".

44.The Commission noted that there can be cases where only individual creditors, and not the liquidator, can sue a director who allowed a company to engage in insolvent trading. As the Commission noted, this can result in a multiplicity of actions or a situation where the relevant director's assets are exhausted in meeting the claims of some only of the creditors involved. It would be more equitable to allow the liquidator to sue on behalf of the company, so that the proceeds of the action could be distributed among creditors more generally.
45.The proposed exposure draft Bill will include provisions which address the Commission's recommendations.
Recommendation 7
46.Criminal liability under companies legislation not apply in the absence of criminality.
47.The Government has considered this recommendation in conjunction with recommendations 22 and 23, which provide:

PARA.TAB: Subsection 232(4) of the Corporations Law be amended so that criminal liability under that section only applies where conduct is genuinely criminal in nature.

Civil penalties be provided in the Corporations Law for breaches where no criminality is involved, and, in appropriate circumstances, people suffering loss as a result of a breach be enabled to bring a claim for damages in the proceedings taken to recover the penalty.

SPEECH.PARA: 48.The Government accepts these recommendations.
49.The Committee considered that criminal liability under section 232 of the Corporations Law should be confined to conduct involving fraud or dishonesty.

50.Section 232 of the Corporations Law contains the principal provisions relating to directors' duties. The duties set out in the section reflect common law fiduciary duties of a director. The law generally regards breach of fiduciary duty, in the absence of any dishonest intent, as a civil matter.
51.The Committee said that:

"The criminal law is a necessary means of enforcing proper behaviour. Where offences are genuinely criminal in nature, criminal sanctions are appropriate. They are only appropriate in those circumstances.

Where a breach of the law does not involve criminality, a civil penalty may be appropriate. Proof of the breach would have to be established on the civil onus (that is, on the balance of probabilities) and there would be no stigma of criminal conviction attaching to the director. In appropriate circumstances, people who suffered loss as a result of the breach could simultaneously bring a claim for damages in the proceedings taken to recover the penalty.

52.Subsection 232(2) provides that an officer of a corporation shall at all times act honestly in the exercise of his or her office. Offences against subsection 232(2) committed with any fraudulent intent are punishable by a $20,000 fine or imprisonment for 5 years, or both. Where there is no such intent the maximum penalty is a $5,000 fine without an imprisonment option.

53.Subsection 232(4) provides that an officer shall exercise a reasonable degree of care and diligence (punishable by a $5,000 fine with no imprisonment option). Subsections 232(5) and (6) provide that an officer may not make improper use of information or his or her position as an officer (punishable by a $20,000 fine or 5 years imprisonment, or both).
54.A person may not take part in the management of a company during the five years following conviction for an offence against section 232.

55.The Government agrees with the Committee that a mere failure to comply with a fiduciary duty should not attract a criminal sanction. It notes that a company officer may contravene section 232, and thus be subject to criminal sanction, without having committed any fraud against the company, its members or its creditors. Further, because section 232 attracts the criminal law standard of proof, the regulatory authorities cannot succeed in any action under the section against a director for breach of duty unless they are able to establish the elements of the breach beyond reasonable doubt. To a certain extent, this could inhibit recovery action where a breach, though not committed with any dishonest intent, has caused significant loss to the company.

56.In the light of these factors, and in response to the Committee's recommendations, the Government proposes to amend section 232 with the intention of confining the criminal liability of directors to conduct involving a dishonest intent. Civil penalties will be introduced into the Corporations Law in relation to breaches of section 232 falling short of dishonest intent.

57.Specifically, the Government proposes to amend section 232 to make civil penalties available in relation to each of subsections 232(2), (4), (5) and (6) as they presently stand. The trial of a matter involving a civil penalty will adopt the civil rules of evidence, practice and procedure, and standard of proof. Proof of contravention of a civil matter will not result in a conviction or a criminal record. On proof of a contravention of any of subsections 232(2), (4), (5) and (6), the court will be able to make an order that the defendant be disqualified from taking part in the management of a corporation and impose a pecuniary penalty, such as those available under the Trade Practices Act 1974, the Customs Act 1901, and the Taxation Administration Act 1953.

58.Criminal penalties (in the form of a fine and/or a term of imprisonment) will be retained in relation to a contravention of subsection 232(2), (4), (5) or (6) which is committed with a dishonest intent. The inclusion of subsection (4) in this list responds specifically to recommendation 22 by the Committee, though it is perhaps difficult to envisage a situation where dishonest activity would properly be characterised as a breach of a duty of care and diligence.

59.The corporation will be empowered to seek compensation in respect of a breach of subsection 232(2), (4), (5) or (6); irrespective of whether or not the person had been convicted of an offence or made subject to a civil penalty order in relation to those provisions. On finding proved either an offence or a civil penalty contravention, the court will be empowered to impose, in addition to a criminal or civil penalty respectively, an order for compensation to the corporation involved. These propositions reflect existing subsections 232(7) and (8). It will be for the Australian Securities Commission to use the enhanced options available to it in a way that best advances the interests of shareholders.

60.Subsection 318(1) of the Corporations Law provides that a director of a company commits an offence if he or she fails to take all reasonable steps to comply with, or to secure compliance with, certain provisions of Part 3.6 of the Corporations Law concerning a company's obligation to prepare financial statements. Although section 318(1) is not mentioned in the Committee's report, the Government notes that the sentencing options on a conviction for an offence against subs.318(1) are similar to those currently available under subs.232(2) (ie, they vary according to the presence or absence of fraud). It is therefore proposed, in relation to section 318, to introduce a civil penalties option such as that proposed in relation to section 232.

61.As for the level of penalty, the Attorney-General's Department is undertaking a general review of penalties under the Corporations Law. That review will include consideration of the civil and criminal penalties which should apply in relation to contraventions of section 232 as amended. Pending completion of that review, however, the Government is concerned to demonstrate clearly the seriousness with which it regards directors' duties. The Government accordingly proposes that the maximum monetary penalty for breach of section 232 should be set at $200,000 and there should be an additional penalty available, where the breach involves a dishonest intent, of imprisonment for up to 5 years. The formula $200,000 and/or 5 years imprisonment matches the recently amended penalty set out in the Corporations Law in respect of insider trading offences.
Recommendation 8
62.The companies legislation be amended to make it clear that the interests of a company's employees may be taken into account by directors in administering the company.

63.It is well-established in law that a company's directors may act in the best interests of employees whenever that is consistent with the best interests of the company as a whole. Clearly, a coincidence of such interests will be the usual situation. The question is whether a legislative provision is appropriate to further advance the interests of employees. The Australian Securities Commission and the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee have each expressed concern about the potential for the general provision proposed by the Committee to impact adversely on the directors' overriding duty to act in the best interests of the company. The Law Council of Australia considers that such a provision would not change the law, and is therefore unnecessary, and that an amendment which did change the law in this area would be contrary to sound policy. Given these concerns, the Government does not propose to legislate in the terms proposed by the Committee. In the Government's view, the interests of employees upon a winding-up (the issue which seems to have been of particular concern to the Senate Committee) would be better addressed directly, by providing special priorities for employees upon a winding-up. The Government proposes, in this regard, to give to employees the same special legislative priority in a winding-up in respect of unpaid employer superannuation contributions as is already accorded to unpaid back-wages.
Recommendation 9
64.Matters such as the interests of consumers, or environmental protection, be dealt with not in the companies legislation but in legislation aimed specifically at those matters.

65.The Government accepts this recommendation. It has already proposed that measures taken by an officer to ensure compliance by the company with the general law be specified as a matter relevant to whether the officer has exercised an appropriate standard of care and diligence (see para. 25 above). Nevertheless, the Government considers that the Corporations Law is not an appropriate vehicle for the enforcement of legislation relating to matters such as the interests of consumers and the environment. Legislation relating to those matters will usually be cast in a manner that affects all legal persons, not merely bodies corporate.
Recommendation 10

66.The NCSC and the ASC proceed to consult as necessary, in particular with shareholder groups and others involved in the securities industry, in order to develop a proposal to eliminate unfair practices relating to small shareholders in renouncable rights issues.

67.The Government shares the Committee's concerns that the terms upon which renouncable rights issues are made available can disadvantage the interests of the holders of small parcels, particularly in relation to the marketability of options and the timeliness of the information made available to shareholders concerning their rights under the issue. In this regard, the Australian Securities Commission has indicated that it is currently consulting with the Australian Stock Exchange about this issue.
Recommendations 11, 12 and 13
A.Recommendation 11
68.(i)The establishment of an audit committee be made a requirement for public listing of a company;

TAB.TAB: (ii)The chairperson and a majority, or all, of the members of the audit committee be non-executive directors;
(iii)The audit committee be required to meet regularly and report to the board;
(iv)The audit committee have direct access to the company's auditors (internal and external) and senior managers, and the ability to consult independent experts where necessary; and
(v)As a high but lesser priority, similar requirements be introduced for larger non-listed companies.

SPEECH.PARA: B.Recommendation 12
69.Audit committees have the following functions:

TAB.TAB: (i)reviewing financial information to ensure its accuracy and timeliness and the inclusion of all appropriate disclosures;
(ii)ensuring the existence and effective operation of accounting and financial controls;
(iii)overseeing the audit of the company, including nominating the auditors, approving the scope of the audit and examining the results;
(iv)providing a link between the auditors and the board;
(v)any other functions allocated to it by the company, provided that the extra functions do not compromise its ability to perform the tasks set out in paragraphs (i)—(iv) above.

SPEECH.PARA: C.Recommendation 13

70.Smaller unlisted companies be encouraged to set up audit committees, or, in the absence of an audit committee, have auditors present at board meetings which approve financial statements prior to their distribution to shareholders.

71.The establishment of audit committees as proposed by the Committee has the potential to enhance the quality of financial information about Australian companies and alleviate concern relating to the difficulty of maintaining a proper balance between the wishes of company management and the interests of shareholders and creditors.

72.The Government notes that the Working Group on Corporate Practices and Conduct has recommended that each public company establish an audit committee with a majority of non-executive directors. The Working Group included a number of major peak business and professional organisations, including the Australian Institute of Company Directors, the Australian Stock Exchange Ltd, the Law Council of Australia (Business Law Section) and the Business Council of Australia. The report of the Group accordingly offers the opportunity for industry to develop practices concerning the use and establishment of audit committees, especially in the light of the relative lack of experience in the use of audit committees in Australia. The Government proposes to monitor the impact of the Working Group's recommendations before giving consideration to a legislative approach.
Recommendations 14, 15 and 18
A.Recommendation 14
73.The Australian Institute of Company Directors:

TAB.TAB: (a)make an assessment of the courses and programs dealing with the duties and responsibilities of company directors;

PARA.TAB: (b)following this assessment, compile an index which sets out information such as the courses available and the cost, duration and location of the courses;
(c)update the index at regular intervals; and
(d)distribute the index freely amongst company directors.

SPEECH.PARA: B.Recommendation 15
74.The Australian Institute of Company Directors encourage company directors to participate in the available courses and programs.
C.Recommendation 18
75.Company directors' and professional associations, such as The Australian Institute of Company Directors, take steps to develop and promote a code of ethics for company directors.
76.The Government notes that these are matters for The Australian Institute of Company Directors and supports these recommendations.

77.The Government understands that the Institute has undertaken an assessment of the courses and programs available concerning the duties and responsibilities of company directors. It further understands that, as a consequence of that assessment, the Institute is currently developing a range of courses directed towards improving the general level of skills and awareness of the Australian company director. An increase in the availability of such training opportunities should be welcomed as it will contribute to a better understanding of, and compliance with, proper standards of corporate behaviour.

78.The Government notes that The Australian Institute of Company Directors has commenced work on the development of a code of ethics for company directors and expects the Institute's work to add to the foundations in this area provided by the Report of the Working Group on Corporate Practices and Conduct.
Recommendation 16
79.The board of a public company state in the company's annual report the particular skills and expertise that each director brings to the company.

80.The Government accepts the principle of matching the skills and expertise of prospective directors with the demands of the offices they seek. It notes that the Corporations Law already provides at section 307 that the directors' report of a public company that is not a wholly-owned subsidiary of another company must include particulars of the directors' qualifications, experience and special responsibilities (if any).
Recommendation 17
81.A public company include in its annual report a statement of the particular skills and expertise that it considers desirable to be represented on its board.

82.There is nothing in the current law to prevent directors offering their views on such matters to the shareholders. However, where the directors see no need to address this issue, a legislative requirement to address it may result in little useful additional information being made available. It would also be a difficult requirement to enforce, as its content would depend on the nature of the company involved and the subjective question of what skills were needed for that company at a particular time.

83.The Government does not therefore propose to introduce a statutory obligation to implement this recommendation. However, consistent with its firm view that directors should keep the company's members well informed on all matters associated with their management of the company's affairs, the Government is not opposed to the inclusion of such information in the directors' annual report.
Recommendation 19

84.The National Companies and Securities Commission, the Australian Securities Commission and the Corporations and Securities Panel receive the funding necessary for them to be as active, effective and vigilant as possible.

85.The Government is providing ample funding for the effective operation of the Australian Securities Commission and the Corporations and Securities Panel. It is the firm intention of the Government to restore investor confidence and rehabilitate our international reputation. To achieve this, the Government provided over $111 million in the 1990/91 budget and $118 million in the 1991/92 budget for the Australian Securities Commission and associated agencies involved in the enforcement of corporate regulation. In total, the Government proposes to provide an extra $210 million for corporate regulation over the first 4 years of the national scheme, an increase of about 60% over the funding of the co-operative scheme in its final full year of operation.
Recommendation 20
86.That the law be amended to make a director personally liable for complicity where he or she intentionally or recklessly assists in or encourages an act which constitutes an offence by a company.

87.The Government notes that the High Court has decided that, in general criminal law, complicity extends to conduct in which a person intentionally assists in or encourages the commission of an offence. The High Court has, however, expressly rejected the extension of complicity in the general criminal law to conduct in which a person recklessly assists in or encourages the commission of an offence.

88.The Government does not consider that it would be desirable to legislate to establish in relation to offences committed by a corporation what would in effect be an exception to the general criminal law concerning complicity. Further, implementation of the recommendation in relation to all offences which may be committed by a corporation may require special State and Territory legislation.

89.The Commonwealth has established a committee comprising The Right Honourable Sir Harry Gibbs GCMG AC KBE, The Honourable Justice R.S. Watson and Mr A.C.C. Menzies AM OBE to conduct a Review of Commonwealth Criminal Laws. The Review Committee, in its Interim Report concerning the Principles of Criminal Responsibility, has considered and recommended against the enactment of legislation to extend complicity to include recklessness. The Government accepts the Review Committee's conclusion that this issue is one that is best left to the application of existing principles by the courts.
Recommendation 21
90.(i)The appropriate mix of individual and corporate liability for corporate misconduct be referred to a body such as the Australian Law Reform Commission for detailed investigation and report;

TAB.TAB: (ii)the matter be investigated and researched in close consultation with all persons and community groups who are willing and able to contribute; and
(iii)the aim of such a review be to develop a theoretical basis to guide the future drafting of legislation and prosecution guidelines.

SPEECH.PARA: 91.The Committee noted evidence that, while present laws affecting corporations provide for both individual and corporate liability in certain situations, there does not appear to be a well-balanced mix. The Committee said:

"Where there is a practice of prosecuting corporations rather than individuals, no matter what the circumstances, there is a risk that people within the company who ought be held liable will never be called to account for their actions . . . No proper thought is given to the best means of preventing future misconduct.
The way corporations are prosecuted and punished provides little incentive for them to use their internal disciplinary systems to sheet home individual accountability.

92.The Government accepts that there is a need to investigate whether there are more appropriate regimes for the distribution of individual and corporate liability for corporate misconduct. As the Committee acknowledges, the issue is a complex one, requiring expert input.
93.The Government therefore proposes to invite the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee to examine and report to the Attorney-General on alternative sentencing regimes for corporations.
Recommendations 22 and 23
A.Recommendation 22
94.Subsection 232(4) of the Corporations Law be amended so that criminal liability under that section only applies where conduct is genuinely criminal in nature.
B.Recommendation 23

95.Civil penalties be provided in the Corporations Law for breaches where no criminality is involved, and, in appropriate circumstances, people suffering loss as a result of a breach be enabled to bring a claim for damages in the proceedings taken to recover the penalty.
96.The Government accepts these recommendations.
97.The legislation proposed to implement these recommendations is outlined in the response to recommendation 7 at paragraphs 46—61 above.
Recommendation 24
98.A system of on-the-spot fines for minor offences, such as the Victorian PERIN system, be introduced into the administration of company law.

99.The penalty notice provisions of the Corporations Law already address a wide range of offences concerning the failure to keep certain registers or lodge documents with the Australian Securities Commission. Compliance with a penalty notice, by paying the prescribed penalty and remedying the breach, precludes the initiation of criminal proceedings in relation to the breach and is not to be taken as an admission by the person of any liability in connection with the offence.

100.The Government proposes to extend the availability of penalty notices to all offences not involving imprisonment and having a maximum fine not exceeding the default penalty, currently set at $500 in the case of natural persons and $2500 in the case of bodies corporate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —I read this document with some interest because the obligations of a director to a company, and ultimately its creditors, are quite substantial obligations in law and they attach to them quite substantial financial obligations. The existing corporations law provides that where directors have breached their duties and failed their obligations they can be made liable, and there are very good reasons why this is so.

PARA.TAB: For example, one of the provisions—and I will discuss it in more detail a little later—is contained in section 592 of the Corporations Act. It states that, where a company incurs a debt at a time when it is incapable of meeting its debts, the directors can be made liable to the creditors. That is an example of how the law places upon a director a particular obligation to ensure that directors cannot use the corporate veil to rip off creditors and shareholders for their own benefit. Very clearly, it is important that the law place some particular obligations upon directors.

The questions that have to be asked, though, are what obligation should be placed on directors and how far should those obligations go? I do not intend to discuss every one of the recommendations made by the Committee, nor every one of the Government's responses, but there are a number that we need to look at in some particular depth.

I start with the Government's response to recommendation No. 2. This recommendation was effectively that the current subjective duty of care be replaced with an objective duty of care. That is very important because there have been a number of cases where the courts, for one reason or another, have had to consider what is a director's duty of care and how diligent they must be.

When this report was first tabled, Senator Hill said something which I believe is quite accurate. He said that currently we had what appeared to be an objective test but which had been watered down by the courts so that they now looked to a certain degree to the director's particular level of expertise. That is not satisfactory from a creditor's point of view because the creditor enters into a transaction with the company.

It may be fair and reasonable from a shareholder's point of view because that person chooses to invest in a company, in part, because of the experience and expertise of the directors. However, a creditor or a person who enters into a financial transaction with a company does so on the basis that that person is engaged in business, not investment. It is dubious whether this subjective test, this test that looks at the directors' previous levels of experience, is satisfactory from the viewpoint of protecting the creditor. There have been a number of cases in regard to this; for example, Statewide Tobacco Services Ltd v. Morley where the director took very little part—in fact, the head note says that he took no effective part—in the management of the company. In that particular case the company traded whilst insolvent. The director tried to raise a defence that he could not be sued because he had no direct dealings with the day to day management of the company.

I do not believe that it would be reasonable to allow the law to continue in the fashion that it has. I note that the Government has proposed a number of matters which should be included as factors of which a court should bear some consideration in scrutinising the diligence and degree of care exercised by a director. I suppose the difficult point is that not every director is responsible for all the actions of the company. The provision of the law at the moment is designed to place a fairly stringent obligation upon directors to encourage them to become involved at least in the good supervision of the operations of the company.

We do get problems where a company is very large—for example, a publicly listed company—and it is perhaps very difficult for a director to oversee every individual transaction. At the same time there is a lot of public money at stake by way of shares in the company and also by way of money that the company might owe to its creditors at any given time. It is appropriate that directors at least take some steps to properly supervise the operations of the company. I believe that is very important.

One of the other matters that the Government believes should be a factor when considering whether a director has exercised due care and attention or due diligence is the number of meetings of the board of directors which a director has attended. I agree with the Government's proposition that it is not appropriate to impose a sanction just because a director fails to attend one particular meeting. Whether attendance at meetings of boards of directors is necessarily a good indicator of whether the director has discharged his obligations well is an arguable point. One would certainly like to see some attendance. There is a very good argument that directors can be busy people and they can do work outside of board meetings. A reliance on attendance at meetings of the board of directors in itself misses the point that we would expect directors, especially those of smaller companies, to exercise more care and attention, more scrutiny of the operations of the company, than merely attending the meetings of the board of that company.

In recommendation 5 there is also some discussion of, shall we say, the exoneration of the directors from breaches of their fiduciary duties. What is proposed here is some sort of consent mechanism by which the shareholders of a company can exonerate directors from breaches of their fiduciary duties. That may be acceptable if the company is solvent at the time and remains solvent. However, one must remember that where a company is solvent at the time a director is exonerated from breach of care or breach of duty and shortly thereafter the company ends up in liquidation or receivership, that is a completely different matter.

The company in which the shareholders may be the same persons as the directors may well have waived the right to reclaim a substantial sum of money from those directors and in so doing the position of the creditors may have been compromised. If the Government proposes to follow this line, it should be made very clear that, where the exoneration of the directors occurs, at least within the relation back period in the event of insolvency—which is six months prior to the first available act of bankruptcy—that exoneration is automatically void. That at least protects the creditors of the company to some extent from the directors misusing their position and then putting on their shareholders' hats and saying, `We will excuse ourselves from the fact that we did not do the right thing'. That would be unsatisfactory. In the relation back period, if not a period of two years back from the date of the commencement of the winding up, such transactions should be void.

I want to address most of my comments specifically to recommendation 6. This recommendation is critically important with regard to an insolvent company. It really only relates to insolvent companies and it is critically important in the administration of such companies. The recommendation is that where a director has incurred a liability under section 592 of the Corporations Act, that liability is not to the creditor who has suffered the loss, but to all of the creditors equally. Section 592 of the Corporations Act provides that if a company incurs a debt and at that time the company is unable to pay all its debts as and when they fall due, the director can be sued by the person to whom the debt is owed and the money recovered from the director.

It is interesting to note that this provision arises out of the common law of fraud. It arose out of the fact that directors were using the company veil to defraud creditors by incurring a liability in a company which had no ability to pay. The essence of section 592 of the Corporations Act is the debt that was owed to the creditor in question.

I do not believe that it is appropriate that any right to recover from that director should be shared amongst all of the creditors of the company because all have not necessarily been defrauded. It would be very difficult to prove amongst a whole range of creditors that some may have been defrauded and others may not have been before the company became unable to pay its debts as and when they fell due. It is very clear that if the company is unable to meet its debts and it incurs further credit—at least, if the directors know and in certain other circumstances—the directors should certainly be liable to those other creditors.

The belief contained in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on The Social and Fiduciary Duties and Obligations of Company Directors and in particular in the Government's response is that by somehow changing this law, the number of recoveries from directors who trade a company recklessly will be increased. I do not necessarily agree. At the moment there is a real possibility and a real incentive to sue those directors.

If one is a creditor in that circumstance and one sues the director, one knows that it is possible to get one's money back. There are many companies which are insolvent where this has occurred and where there is no money in the company to carry out the action to sue the director. It is ludicrous to expect that a liquidator will put his own money on the line to run the case. That will just not occur.

In all of those companies where the directors have cleaned out all the assets of the company and there is nothing but a bare shell, we will find that there will be no recovery at all because there is no money available for the liquidator to carry out an action. I believe that in focusing on the right to share in the recovery, instead of focusing on the nature of the action which arises—which is an action which arises out of fraud—the Government has missed the point.

I believe that recommendation 6 should not be complied with. I believe that the Government is failing in properly supervising the operations of companies and properly protecting creditors in allowing this particular recommendation to go through. I say that with due respect to all those on the Committee, such as my good friend Senator Cooney who is sitting on the other side of the chamber and who participated in those deliberations. In reality I believe that it will just not work.

I should finally address a number of general comments about the duty of directors. Public expectations have been so raised that perhaps we now have more stringent expectations of directors than we may have had in the past. If that is the case, so be it. The Government has chosen that particular course of action. What is of concern to me is that there are particular incorporated bodies that are above the corporations law and above the recommendations contained in the Government's response, and there are particular organisations where members or creditors do not get the same protection that is contained in the corporations law. I refer, of course, to the privileged position of union directors, the less stringent accounting standards that are expected of unions, the less stringent observance of good audit practice and, quite simply, the less stringent duty of care that is required of a union leader compared with what is required of a company director.

We have had numerous cases where union leaders have taken their mates to the brothel and run up the bill. I know it is shocking, Mr Acting Deputy President; I am shocked by it all as well. All those on this side of the chamber are shocked by it, and I am sure Senator Cooney and many good unionists on the other side will be shocked by it as well. We have found cases of union leaders taking their mates to the brothel and charging it up to the union credit card, and somehow this seems to get through.

I am advancing a very simple proposition, based not on ideology but on a principle of fairness and equity. That proposition is simply this: a union official who exercises power on behalf of the union should bear the same duty of care that one expects of a company director. It does not matter whether it is the trade unionists' money or the shareholders' money, it is all money that has been put in by people in good faith and therefore it should be subject to the same duty of care.

There must be one law for all throughout Australia, not one law for some whom the Government likes and another more stringent rule for others whom the Government dislikes for some particular ideological reason. That is not acceptable. We must have the same accounting standards for unions that we have for companies. We must have the same expectations of union leaders as we have of shareholders and companies. In fact, there is a very good ground to say that we should expect a higher standard of care and a higher degree of diligence and propriety from union leaders than we expect of companies. The point about a company is that free choice is involved in becoming a shareholder of a company. People are not required, on the whole, to become shareholders of companies. However, people are frequently required to become members of a union. That act of compulsion is perhaps the strongest argument one can advance for expecting that a union leader will meet the same standards of care, the same standards of propriety, that the public has come to expect of company directors.

In conclusion, I welcome some of the provisions of the Government's response. There are some areas where I am dissatisfied. I hope the Government will extend to unions and unionists the same protection that is now being afforded to shareholders and creditors of companies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased with the Government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on company directors' duties. I listened with some interest to Senator O'Chee, and I think he got off the point a little towards the end, when he was talking about the duty of unionists in this context. My reading of the Industrial Relations Act must be different from Senator O'Chee's because set out in the Industrial Relations Act are provisions, very similar to the ones set out in the corporate legislation, that require union officials in one case and company directors in other cases to obey very similar duties. For example, I remember a person in a particular union who had to surrender his position for five years because of an offence relating to a ballot, and I think in respect of only 20 ballot papers. I do not approve of that, but it is quite clear that the provisions of the Industrial Relations Act are very similar to the duties cast upon directors under corporate legislation.

PARA.TAB: Senator O'Chee perhaps should be more precise in his evidence when he says that there are cases where a union leader has gone off to a brothel with a credit card and entertained his friends. Any allegations that are to be made in this chamber should be backed up with evidence. Earlier this week I rose in this place and defended the reputation of Mr Packer. I do not think it matters where people come from. If this chamber is going to be used to denigrate a person or a group, if that is how people think the proceedings in the chamber should be conducted, that should be done only with cogent evidence, otherwise we are taking an unfair advantage of our fellow citizens. We are not special people; we are people elected from the community of which we remain a part, and we should never let our sense of fairness be overborne by any position we hold in this place.

I will go through the Government's responses. The Government has looked tentatively and, in my view, properly and exhaustively at each recommendation and it has made a proper response. I express my gratitude to the Attorney-General, Mr Duffy, for doing that. As an illustration of the next point I want to make, I refer not only to this Committee but also to the Select Committee on Animal Welfare, on which you served so splendidly, Mr Acting Deputy President. Much of the effect committees have is in respect of the investigations or the inquiries they carry out and the submissions they hear, and the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare, of which you were such an illustrious member, is a great illustration of that. A great deal of reform came from that Committee, not from specific recommendations we made—I was also a member of that Committee—but from the fact that we were meeting different people and interest groups and that they did something about the matters we were dealing with.

The work of the Senate and the Senate committees does create a climate where change can take place. I am not suggesting that the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs brought about a change in the attitude of the courts, but it did help create a climate that led to the change that has been indicated by court decisions since the Committee's report in November 1989. On page 5 of the Government's response those cases are set out. I simply point out that, just as the Select Committee on Animal Welfare has helped to create a climate, this Committee inquiring into directors' duties has added limited, but nevertheless important, force to achieving change in the corporate world.

The Government will legislate in respect of some of our recommendations. Senator O'Chee said that the Government was to legislate in respect of recommendation 6 and was to adopt the recommendation the Committee had made. It is not my reading of the Government's response to recommendation 6 that it is going to do that, but it certainly expressed a sympathetic understanding of our point. From what appears there, I did not take it that the Government was actually going to adopt that recommendation in the terms that we suggested.
The other thing that the Government has done is in response to recommendation 7 where the Committee recommended:

SPEECH.PARA: Crime liability under companies legislation not apply in the absence of criminality.

The Government has accepted that. In respect of one particular matter under section 232—which I know concerned many people in the company area and, indeed, outside it—the Government proposes going to civil penalties. That was recommended by the Committee and I am glad to see the Government taking up the suggestion to apply civil penalties, rather than criminal ones, to situations where officers of companies fall short of their civil duty. It is quite unfair that any sort of criminal penalty be attached to an act which really is not criminal in the sense that we understand it. A civil penalty does not besmirch a person's reputation but, nevertheless, it ensures that the provisions in the Act requiring people to act in a particular way are complied with.

PARA.TAB: Although these are matters in respect of which the Government cannot legislate, it has expressed its support for the recommendations made by the Committee. For example, recommendations 14, 15 and 18 really went to the issue of professional bodies, relevant to company directors and others in companies, developing a code of ethics. One of the central features of the report was that ethics be looked at as a means of reform in the corporate area. The Government cannot, of course, legislate for a change in ethics, but it has expressed sympathy for steps to be taken for that to be done. The Committee's recommendation 20 stated:

SPEECH.PARA: That the law be amended to make a director personally liable for complicity where he or she intentionally or recklessly assists in or encourages an act which constitutes an offence by a company.

The Government has said that it will adopt that recommendation, leaving out the word `recklessly'. On reading that recommendation, I must confess that the Government is right in leaving out the word `recklessly'. This shows not only that governments can change their minds when they make responses to reports but also that the makers of reports can change their minds in response to the Government's answer.

PARA.TAB: I close by simply referring generally to the report. In my view, this was a very good and substantial report. Looking down the list of members of the Committee, one can see why. Senator O'Chee was critical of aspects of the Committee's report, but when one looks at the membership of the Committee, I suggest that he re-read the report and the response and decide whether he cannot agree with both. On the Committee, besides myself, there was Senator Richard Alston, the Deputy Chairman, who is a very eminent jurist; Senator Bob Collins, now a very good Minister; and Senator Pat Giles who, as a senator in this chamber, is overlooked in terms of the ability she displays. I admire greatly Senator Giles's mind and the skill and energy with which she goes about her work. Indeed, I think she is typical of many members of this chamber who are not in the limelight but who nevertheless contribute mightily.

Other members on the Committee were Senator Robert Hill, the Deputy Chairman until 22 March 1989 and now the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate; Senator Janet Powell, who went on to become Leader of the Australian Democrats; Senator Chris Schacht; and, finally, but by no means least, former Senator John Stone. Despite having Senator O'Chee in his place, the fact that former Senator John Stone is no longer here is a loss to this chamber, particularly in the economic debates that go on here. It is a shame that his career was unfortunately cut short.

As Chairman of the Committee, I again thank the Government for its response; for the way it has analysed the matters put forward by the Committee; and for the way it has gone about accepting what the Committee has said in so many instances and in at least one instance correcting, in my view properly, the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion that the Senate take note of the Government's response and I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), I present the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on United Nations peacekeeping and Australia. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation One

PARA.TAB: The Committee stresses that the Australian Government should give a high priority in its foreign policy objectives to seeking improvement of the United Nations machinery for peacekeeping. The Committee recommends that as far as possible, Australia should coordinate its efforts towards this end with other likeminded countries, particularly those in its immediate neighbourhood. The permanent appointment of an Australian officer to the United Nations Secretary-General's Military Planning Staff should be actively and vigorously pursued. (2.65)

SPEECH.PARA: Response

PARA.TAB: Agree with some qualifications.

SPEECH.PARA: Comment

PARA.TAB: The Australian Government has over the past three years given high priority to efforts to improve the UN's peacekeeping machinery. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade set out Australia's policy on this in his address to the 44th session of the UN General Assembly in 1989. Subsequently the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, particularly members of the Australian mission to the United Nations in New York, have continued to press for such improvement in deliberations on this issue in the General Assembly and in the Special Committee on Peacekeeping. The Government has not had all the success it would have liked, but it and others have certainly succeeded in focusing international attention on the need for action to address this problem. The Government will continue to do so, and its efforts at wider reform in the UN complement the proposals Australia has made concerning improvements to the UN's administration of peacekeeping.

The Government takes practical steps to co-ordinate efforts on this matter with other likeminded countries, especially countries such as Canada. It does this for example through joint Canadian/Australian/New Zealand (CANZ) statements during the regular sessions of the General Assembly. Links with other members of the region on peacekeeping issues, while increasing, are not as well developed. These nations may well come to share Australia's strong commitment to the reform of the UN's peacekeeping machinery, particularly as their involvement in UN peacekeeping operations increases, and when those operations take place in the region—as will now happen with the proposed UN Transitional Authority in Cambodia (UNTAC). Greater Japanese involvement in peacekeeping will also assist this process.

Contact with Australia's neighbours on peacekeeping has thus increased in recent years. The Department of Defence sent a team to Singapore in 1991 for discussion on operational aspects of peacekeeping. It may be possible to develop similar links with Japan, Singapore, Indonesia, Malaysia and Fiji as these countries have taken a close interest in peacekeeping. The Government is also looking at strengthened co-operation with New Zealand on peacekeeping issues.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has been represented at three key seminars on peacekeeping in the region during 1991. The Government is giving consideration to Australia hosting an international Peacekeeping Seminar in 1992-93, which will further focus regional attention on these matters. Funding for this will be sought in the 1992-3 Budget.

PARA.TAB: Continued efforts have been made by officials from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Department of Defence to have an Australian officer appointed to the United Nations Secretary-General's Military Planning Staff. Those five positions are filled on the basis of contracts being offered to military personnel from the principal troop contributing countries—a degree of geographic rotation is involved in the selection of these personnel. Australia's turn will come, but our interests in having personnel in those positions have to be assessed by the Secretary-General on an equitable basis against the interests of many other UN members. Meanwhile the Government has arranged this year two short-term secondments of ADF officers to the UNSG's Military Adviser's staff and we are advised that this has been of great assistance to the Military Adviser.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation Two

PARA.TAB: The Committee recommends that if, following consideration of all the factors in Recommendation 18 of this Report, Australia is to commit forces to a peacekeeping operation in Cambodia, steps should be taken at the most senior levels and every avenue pursued, to put to the United Nations Secretariat Australia's case for command of the operation. (2.66).

SPEECH.PARA: Response

PARA.TAB: Agree.

SPEECH.PARA: Comment

PARA.TAB: The Australian Government has already taken the steps recommended to put to the UN Secretariat Australia's case to provide the Commander of the military component of UNTAC. Senior Secretariat staff, from the Secretary-General down, are well aware of Australia's interest in this position, as are relevant senior officials in the Permanent Five members of the Security Council. The decision on this matter is one for the Secretary-General who then seeks the agreement of the Security Council to the proposed nominee. The Australian Government fully respects the UN Secretary-General's right and competence in this matter. It is also important to note that the UN Secretary-General's Special Representative for Cambodia (who is still to be appointed) will have overall responsibility for UNTAC.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation Three

PARA.TAB: The Committee recommends that a more comprehensive picture of the total financial cost of any Australian contributions to peacekeeping be readily available to Government, to the Parliament and to the Australian people. (3.5).

SPEECH.PARA: Response

PARA.TAB: Agree.

SPEECH.PARA: Comment

PARA.TAB: This Government has worked with a strong sense of commitment to make cost and efficiency assessments of international organisations, including UN peacekeeping operations. The Government fully agrees, therefore, on the need for the total financial cost of operations to be given to the Australian Government, Parliament and people. However, the budgetary process for UN peacekeeping operations explains why accurate costings are sometimes difficult to obtain. When the UN Security Council accepts the Secretary-General's proposals for a peacekeeping operation, it then commissions a detailed operational plan for the operation. Once that plan is approved the UN's Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budget Questions (ACABQ) considers the plan and recommends its budget to the Fifth Committee of the General Assembly. The Assembly then approves the proposed budget and each UN member is obliged to pay its assessed contribution to the total cost of the operation. (Australia's current share is 1.57%.) This represents the total UN budget for the operation. Some reimbursement to troop contributing countries can be made from this budget, and if there is a surplus in the budget (as happened with UNTAG) moneys can be returned pro-rata to member states. However reimbursements are always lagged (partly because there are invariably delays in member states contributing their share to the financing costs for UN peacekeeping operations). Thus member states have to work on their assessed contribution, plus the additional initial cost of any commitment they might make, in determining their total financial obligation to the cost of a UN PKO.

Within the Department of Defence, a new Defence Financial Management Information System is being introduced progressively which will allow Programs to capture expenditure electronically and will provide a wider range of expenditure recording and reporting.

The Department's objective is to refine further costing systems to move towards a more reliable means of cost identification and attribution. However, information recording systems are not sufficiently flexible at this time to provide the total costs of many activities. While Defence can identify the direct costs associated with a specific activity, it is not as straightforward to identify the indirect costs, nor the costs borne by one Program for another Program. In an attempt to overcome this problem in relation to personnel costs, overhead rates have been determined for preliminary cost analysis and cost recovery purposes.

With regard to costs associated with peacekeeping, the main requirement to provide a more comprehensive picture is to identify the additional costs of mounting the operation and to deduct from those additional costs the amounts which can be claimed, and agreed, for reimbursement by the UN. Systems will be implemented to record and report those additional costs and reimbursement on a regular basis.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation Four

PARA.TAB: The Committee recommends that a small, permanent secretariat or task force be established as a matter of priority to oversight the many and varied aspects of peacekeeping in the evolving international order. The staffing should remain flexible so that adjustments can be made, depending on the level of activity in the external environment. Representatives from various departments and agencies affected should be seconded to the unit as required. The basic role of the unit should be pro-active, not reactive. Its starting point should be a clear identification of Australia's interests in peacekeeping, both generally, and as specific cases arise. The reference list in Recommendation Eighteen indicates the range of factors which the unit could monitor, co-ordinate and oversight. The secretariat would also be the appropriate body to oversight implementation of other recommendations of this Report. (3.16)

SPEECH.PARA: Response

PARA.TAB: Arrangements other than those proposed are in place to implement elements of this recommendation.

SPEECH.PARA: Comment

PARA.TAB: Although peacekeeping has some priority in Australia's foreign and defence policies, contributing to UN peacekeeping operations is not a specific objective isolated from other multilateral objectives. Against this background and constrained by the absence of readily available resources the Government intends to maintain its existing arrangements, and, regarding the oversight of Australian involvement in peacekeeping, to use more extensively the Inter-Departmental Committee process to address questions of co-ordination. This enables greater organisational and resource flexibility. The Government considers it is a more appropriate arrangement which directly addresses the issues concerned.

In elaborating this last point it makes most sense for the ADF to maintain responsibility for the administration of Australian military personnel in UN peacekeeping operations, rather than give part of this responsibility to a Secretariat, thus creating an additional bureaucratic layer.

The Government will, however, keep this issue under review, and take a flexible approach to the deployment of resources as necessitated by the level of Australian involvement in UN peacekeeping operations, and requests from the UN for such involvement. The Government will give careful attention to the points raised in the Report and to this Recommendation in devising the best administrative structures for Australian involvement in UNTAC. The Government may also need to look at the issue again if Australian NGOs become involved directly in UN peacekeeping operations.

Consistent with the above, Australia does not have either the Defence Force structure or indeed other resources, to move to a pro-active position on UN peacekeeping beyond the Government's current policy. This is in fact partially recognised in Recommendation 16 of the Report. Australia takes a different view from Canada and the Nordic countries on this issue. Those countries give peacekeeping a much greater priority than Australia, and their Force Structures are designed to accommodate extensive peacekeeping activity. The Government will continue with its policy of assessing peacekeeping opportunities and possible Australian involvement as they arise within the framework of our present Force Structure.
Further oversight of the implementation of the recommendations in this Report will be the responsibility of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation Five

PARA.TAB: The Committee recommends that on-the-ground assessment by Australian personnel of the security situation in the country of a proposed United Nations Peacekeeping operation be instituted as standard procedure for any peacekeeping operation before the commitment of Australian forces.

SPEECH.PARA: Response

PARA.TAB: Agree in part.

SPEECH.PARA: Comment

PARA.TAB: In consideration of any proposal for the deployment of ADF units on operational service, the Government gives careful regard to the risks which personnel would face. Information is drawn from a variety of sources, including Australian diplomatic missions in the area concerned, to provide Government with a comprehensive assessment which is independent of the United Nations' appreciation.

The political circumstances in a country where a UN peacekeeping operation is proposed are often unconducive to the deployment of an Australian on-the-ground assessment team unless it operates as part of a UN Survey Mission. In cases involving the possible contribution of larger ADF contingents to a peacekeeping operation, Australian officers have been included in the preliminary UN missions to the area concerned. Reports by Australian officers who participate in UN surveys are included in the overall assessment presented for Government consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation Six

PARA.TAB: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government ensure the precondition for Australia contributing to a United Nations Peacekeeping force is that all parties are committed to a comprehensive settlement and to the relevant United Nations Security Council and General Assembly Resolutions and United Nations peacekeeping operational plans. (3.25)

SPEECH.PARA: Response

PARA.TAB: Agree.

SPEECH.PARA: Comment

PARA.TAB: It is standard Australian Government policy that all parties to a dispute should agree to a comprehensive settlement and relevant UN resolution before Australia contributes personnel to a UN peacekeeping operation in support of the settlement of the dispute. (Enforcement action, taken under Chapter 7 of the UN Charter, is a separate issue and obviously in that case agreement of all the parties is unlikely). This is also standard operating procedure for the UN Secretary-General, and has been a crucial element in the negotiation of the comprehensive political settlement in Cambodia. In some cases, such as the deployment of MINURSO, strenuous diplomatic efforts are necessary to ensure continued commitment on behalf of the parties involved.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation Seven

PARA.TAB: The Committee recommends that Australia's role in peacekeeping, both military and civilian, be given greater acknowledgment by Government and be more actively publicised. In particular, awards such as the Australian Service Medal should be arranged as soon as possible after the return of an Australian peacekeeping contingent at appropriate public and well-publicised occasions. Consideration should also be given to striking a special medal in certain instances.

SPEECH.PARA: Response

PARA.TAB: Agree in part.

SPEECH.PARA: Comment

PARA.TAB: It is agreed that Australia's role in peacekeeping operations be given greater acknowledgment and be more actively publicised. Headquarters ADF is attempting to ensure that awards given for participation in peacekeeping operations be made as soon as practicable after the return of the contingent. Awards of Service Medals to members returning from the Persian Gulf after Operation DAMASK and the contingent from Operation HABITAT were made immediately upon return to Australia. The awards were made by either the Prime Minister, the Minister for Defence or the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel.

The striking of `special medals' in certain instances would have to be considered in the light of the circumstances pertaining to the operation. However, such circumstances would need to be extremely compelling to add yet another series of awards within the Australian Honours System. It was envisaged that the Australian Service Medal would be awarded for all peacekeeping operations undertaken since the inception of the Australian Honours System.
