Individual operations are identified by a specific clasp. The Government will bear in mind the need to give appropriate recognition to Australian civilians serving in UN peacekeeping operations.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation Eight

PARA.TAB: The Committee recommends that the Official Historian at the Australian War Memorial be commissioned to write a full history of Australian participation in peacekeeping and that it be distributed widely, as one means of maintaining public awareness of the importance of the principles of peacekeeping.

SPEECH.PARA: Response

PARA.TAB: Agree in principle.

SPEECH.PARA: Comment

PARA.TAB: There is clearly considerable advantage in enhancing community awareness of the value of peacekeeping. The question is to find the most appropriate means. The Government already publicises its peacekeeping efforts through press releases when our contributions are announced, coverage of forces while deployed on peacekeeping (as occurred during our UNTAG deployment in Namibia), and further coverage when our peacekeeping forces return.

We have no difficulty with the concept of a history of our involvement in UN peacekeeping. The UN has published its own record of peacekeeping, The Blue Helmets, in which Australia's contributions are recorded. The Australian Defence Force Academy's recently published Australia and Peacekeeping (edited by Hugh Smith; Canberra: Australian Defence Studies Centre, 1990) provides a publicly available source on Australia's role in peacekeeping. One practical difficulty in undertaking a separate official history, however, is determining the parameters of such a history. Peacekeeping is often a continuing activity; there is sometimes no end-point, as is the case with wars, which would allow a discrete record of events to be compiled.
Nevertheless, the Government is exploring with the Official Historian the options for preparing such histories.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation Nine

PARA.TAB: The Committee recommends that a comprehensive review of conditions of service be undertaken to establish mechanisms for both military and civilian personnel, to ensure that consistent and fair conditions of service apply to all Australian participants in peacekeeping. The determination of these conditions of service should be both quick and transparent, and subject to regular re-evaluation.

SPEECH.PARA: Response

PARA.TAB: Agree.

SPEECH.PARA: Comment

PARA.TAB: The Government has agreed that the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, in conjunction with the Minister for Industrial Relations, bring forward for Cabinet consideration, a submission outlining a draft framework for setting conditions of service for ADF personnel serving overseas on deployments such as United Nations peacekeeping missions.

Discussions between the ADF and the Department of Industrial Relations are underway regarding the framework for conditions of service. The aim is to establish an objective and equitable framework for conditions of service for overseas deployments.

The conditions of service for civilian personnel from the Australian Public Service involved in United Nations peacekeeping activities in the future will be coordinated by the Department of Industrial Relations consulting with employing agencies.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation Ten

PARA.TAB: The Committee recommends that steps be taken to implement the following specific suggestions to assist in the welfare of the families of service personnel involved in future peacekeeping operations:
a welfare officer should be appointed in those cases where a whole unit is sent on a peacekeeping mission;
in the case of individuals from different units sent on peacekeeping missions, a key person from the spouse's unit (e.g. the adjutant) should be identified as

SPEECH.PARA: having the responsibility for keeping contact with the family. Spouses should also be put in contact with each other;

PARA.TAB: spouses should be briefed before the deployment and informed of people to contact in case of need; and
spouses should be kept regularly informed of the security situation where the peacekeeping operation is taking place.
The Committee considers that this assistance should also be made available to the next-of-kin of unmarried personnel.

SPEECH.PARA: Response

PARA.TAB: Agree.

SPEECH.PARA: Comment

PARA.TAB: This Recommendation represents the bare minimum of support desirable for any deployment and reflects standard procedures already in place. The provision and structure of welfare support to families and next-of-kin of members deployed is a single Service responsibility. It will vary depending on circumstance. The aim is to provide a comprehensive, accessible, timely and responsive service of a high standard in peace and war.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation Eleven

PARA.TAB: The Committee recommends that additional emphasis be given to negotiation and conflict resolution skills in the pre-posting training provided to those embarking on peacekeeping operations. Ideally, the training should go beyond theoretical presentations, should be practical in emphasis and should, as much as possible, take into account the cultural context in which the peacekeepers will be operating.

SPEECH.PARA: Response

PARA.TAB: Agree.

SPEECH.PARA: Comment

PARA.TAB: The ADF is planning to include a two-day module on negotiation and conflict resolution skills during the pre-deployment training for future Australian UN peacekeeping contingents.

The training module has been developed in conjunction with a specialist consultant, and the fifth UNIIMOG contingent received its training in September 1990. However, validation of the training was not possible, as this contingent did not subsequently deploy.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation Twelve

PARA.TAB: The Committee commends the pioneering role of the Australian Federal Police in including women in its peacekeeping contingent in Cyprus, and recommends that action be taken to ensure that women have equal opportunity to participate in future Australian contributions to peacekeeping operations.

SPEECH.PARA: Response

PARA.TAB: Agree.

SPEECH.PARA: Comment

PARA.TAB: The Government is also proud of the AFP in including women in the Australian UNFICYP contingent, in accordance with the Government's policies on Equal Employment Opportunity. This practice will be continued by future Australian contingents in accordance with operational requirements. Female members of the ADF have recently participated in Operations DAMASK and HABITAT and were also present in Australian contingents to the Multinational Force and Observers, Sinai in the mid-1980s. The progressive introduction of women into new areas and occupations within the Defence Force will ensure that opportunities to participate in peacekeeping operations will increase for female ADF members. It should also be mentioned that Australian female Electoral Commission officers participated in the election supervision aspects of UNTAG's operation in Namibia.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation Thirteen

PARA.TAB: The Committee recommends that steps be taken to amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, or any other relevant regulatory change be made, to give the Australian Electoral Commission the function of providing assistance in the form of the secondment of personnel, or the supply or loan of materiel to a foreign government or to an international organisation in connection with the preparation for or the conduct of an overseas election or referendum as approved by the Australian Government. This function should be reflected in the organisational structure of the Commission. (5.33)

SPEECH.PARA: Response

PARA.TAB: Agree.

SPEECH.PARA: Comment

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade is pursuing this Recommendation with the Minister for Administrative Services. Clearly as the scope and nature of UN peacekeeping and related operations grows and changes and the preparation for and supervision of elections become a higher priority for the UN, Australia should be in a position to respond appropriately. The change recommended will enable that.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation Fourteen

PARA.TAB: The Committee recommends that, in the event of a mixed Australian military/civilian contribution to any operation in Cambodia, careful attention be given to establishing appropriate mechanisms to maximise effective co-ordination. Those mechanisms should extend to civilian Non-Governmental Organisations (NGOs), whose activities are complementary but not part of the peacekeeping operation. The need to ensure security for Australian personnel is a specific requirement that will have to be addressed. The responsibility for ensuring that adequate mechanisms for effective co-ordination are in place for any particular peacekeeping operation should lie with the small permanent peacekeeping secretariat proposed in Recommendation four.(5.61)

SPEECH.PARA: Response

PARA.TAB: Agree.

SPEECH.PARA: Comment

PARA.TAB: The Government will establish appropriate co-ordination mechanisms in the event that there is a mixed civilian/military Australian contribution to UNTAC, as it will be important to maximise the co-operation and the effectiveness of the Australian role in UNTAC. Appropriate procedures will be developed with relevant NGOs, and informal arrangements will be discussed on issues such as the security of Australian personnel who are not part of UNTAC's military contingent. Co-ordination of these arrangements will be the responsibility of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation Fifteen

PARA.TAB: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government take the initiative to explore with countries of the region the idea of greater regional cooperation, at various levels, in developing a capacity to respond to UN peacekeeping requests speedily and efficiently. The emphasis should be on giving a new focus to the links which already exist under on-going defence and foreign policy programs.

SPEECH.PARA: Response

PARA.TAB: Agree.

SPEECH.PARA: Comment

PARA.TAB: As is explained in the Government policy information paper, The Defence of Australia 1987, and in the statement on Regional Security by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade in 1989, Australia has a clear interest in fostering regional defence and security co-operation with countries of our region. Peacekeeping represents a common regional interest. Fiji, Malaysia, Indonesia and New Zealand together with Australia have longstanding records of contribution to UN operations while several other South-East Asian nations have become contributors to UN operations in recent years.

There is scope to share Australia's expertise with regional nations through the defence cooperation activities as has already been done with Singapore during early 1991. Australia and New Zealand co-operated in the provision of the Field Engineering Unit for the UN peacekeeping operations in Namibia and have continued to exchange views on further possibilities for such joint action, particularly in relation to the proposed UN operation in Cambodia. Japan's intention to adopt legislation which will permit Japan to contribute military personnel to UN peacekeeping operations will also open up possibilities for enhanced regional co-operation on peacekeeping issues.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation Sixteen

PARA.TAB: The Committee recommends that Australian contributions to international peacekeeping be explicitly included in the objectives of the Australian Defence Force, and in particular be recognised as one positive element in regional security. Provision should be made for adequate resources to implement Recommendation Fifteen of this Report. The contribution of Australian peacekeeping contingents to a particular peacekeeping operation should:
be assessed on a case by case basis, (taking into account the factors indicated in Recommendation Eighteen);
utilise existing capabilities; and
play no role in determining force structure.

SPEECH.PARA: Response

PARA.TAB: Agree in part.

SPEECH.PARA: Comment

PARA.TAB: The objectives of the Australian Defence Force are spelt out in the Defence of Australia 1987. The fundamental objectives are:
maintaining and developing capabilities for the independent defence of Australia and its interests;
promoting strategic stability and security in our region;

as a member of the Western strategic community working for a reduction in the level of tension between the superpowers and limiting the spread of influences in our region inimical to Western interests.

Above all, the Government believes that Australia's forces should continue to be structured around the most important goal: the defence of Australia. While it would not be appropriate to inscribe peacekeeping as a separate and fourth fundamental objective, it is an important objective insofar as it promotes these objectives, and especially that of regional stability.

Moreover, the Government recognises that forces structured for the self-reliant defence of Australia are also able to be employed in pursuit of wider national goals; the Defence of Australia 1987 explicitly mentions peacekeeping in this regard. The Minister for Defence recently reaffirmed this view in his 30 May 1991 statement to Parliament on `Defence Into The Twenty First Century':

"As the Gulf War showed, from a self-reliant defence force structured for the defence of this nation, Australia can make a contribution to operations further afield in support of friend and allies, and activities sanctioned by the United Nations. Today's decisions will ensure that Australia continues to have the capacity to contribute to wider global and regional security.
The Government agrees that adequate resources should be made available to implement Recommendation Fifteen of the Report.

In respect of the Committee's view on the case-by-case review of particular peacekeeping operations, the Government generally agrees with the three criteria above, with some amendment of the first (taking account of the comments on Recommendation Eighteen below).

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation Seventeen

PARA.TAB: The Committee recommends that the role of the reserves in peacekeeping tasks be comprehensively addressed by current force structure reviews, including ways and means (such as legislation guaranteeing employment) of eliminating obstacles to greater use of reserves for such tasks. The management of peacekeeping operations, including allocation of responsibilities between the Defence Department, Headquarters Australian Defence Force and the individual services, is one particular aspect that should be included in the review.

SPEECH.PARA: Response

PARA.TAB: Agree in part.

SPEECH.PARA: Comment

PARA.TAB: The Government supports the greater use of Reserves for peacekeeping tasks.

Peacekeeping was not addressed by the recently-completed Force Structure Review. The Government does not regard peacekeeping as a force structure determinant, and so it would have been inappropriate to have made peacekeeping part of this process.

However, concurrently with the Minister for Defence's 30 May 1991 statement on restructuring of the ADF, Senator Ray announced the establishment of a new two-star appointment within HQADF, Assistant Chief of the Defence Force—Reserves (ACRES), who will be responsible for management of ADF Reserve Forces. As part of his mission, ACRES is to eliminate obstacles to greater use of Reserves on peacekeeping tasks.

SPEECH.PARA: An Army Working Party Report on Protection of Civilian Interests of Reservists When Called Out, which is due for imminent release, will be of assistance.

PARA.TAB: Concerning the management of peacekeeping operations, we believe that co-ordination and liaison between the relevant areas of the Defence Department and the ADF is quite satisfactory. At this stage the Government sees no need for a review of current arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation Eighteen

PARA.TAB: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government develop a comprehensive reference list of factors that should be taken into account in formulating policy advice on participation by Australia in future peacekeeping operations. At a minimum, the reference list should include a clear statement of
the objectives of the peacekeeping operations itself;
how durable the political settlement underpinning the peacekeeping operation is likely to be (including the extent of agreement and support for the settlement amongst the principal parties);
Australia's objectives if it were to participate (including whether the same objectives could be achieved by other means);
the priority of these objectives in Australia's overall foreign policy (including the relative importance of the United Nations in the overall policy) and in Australia's overall defence policy;
the benefit that Australia might derive from participation (including commercial benefits);
evaluation of the different kinds of contribution Australia might make (military, police, electoral commission etc);
evaluation of the need and prospects for Australians in command positions (and a strategy for achieving a command position in those cases where it is assessed as desirable);
the costs of participation (including level of risk and financial costs);
any penalty, direct or indirect, that might be paid by not participating;
an acceptable time-frame for the commitment (including an indication of the kind of circumstances which would lead to a withdrawal of any Australian contingent); and

the adequacy of planning and preparation undertaken by the United Nations Secretariat (including the negotiation of satisfactory status of forces agreements and contingency plans for the use of force). (7.14)

SPEECH.PARA: Response

PARA.TAB: Agree in part.

SPEECH.PARA: Comment

PARA.TAB: The Government welcomes the Committee's check list of items to be considered in deciding on Australian participation in UN peacekeeping operations. Many of the factors listed have formed part of the Government's decision making process for some time. It is important to recall, however, that in such operations the request (either formal or informal) from the UN Secretary-General for a particular contribution to an operation also forms an important part of the decision making process. The request received is sometimes the result of prior negotiation with UN Secretariat officials. It is also important to note that decisions on the command of an operation are for the UN Secretary-General and then the Security Council. Australia should not expect to command more that its fair share of such operations and in that context its record of participation is an important factor. Finally there may be no certainty about some of the factors listed (time frame for the operation, conclusion of a status of forces agreement, etc) prior to a decision on participation being taken by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation Nineteen

PARA.TAB: The Committee recommends that a summary statement of the factors in Recommendation eighteen as they relate to a proposed, specific peacekeeping operation be publicised widely in the Australian community before a final decision on participation in that particular operation is taken. (7.16)

SPEECH.PARA: Response

PARA.TAB: Reject.

SPEECH.PARA: Comment

PARA.TAB: The Government would be happy to circulate a summary statement on Australian participation in a particular UN operation, once that decision is taken, but not necessarily before the decision is taken. The Government will of course welcome views from Parliament and the public on matters related to Australian participation in UN peacekeeping operations, but the final decision is one that the Government itself must take. In some cases there is insufficient time for an extensive consultation process as envisaged in this recommendation before a decision has to be taken. In other cases the Government may well decide that it should play a leadership role and decide on the issue in advance of wide community debate. Parliament nevertheless provides the forum where the Government must account for its decisions and those on participation in UN peacekeeping operations can be documented along the lines proposed in Recommendation Eighteen.

SPEECH.PARA: NOVEMBER 1991
Senator Graham Maguire
Chair
Senate Standing Committee on
Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Graham

PARA.TAB: I set out in the attachment to this letter the Australian Government's response to the Report of your Committee on "United Nations Peacekeeping and Australia".

SPEECH.PARA: In doing so I wish to make a number of general points on behalf of the Government.

PARA.TAB: First, the Government finds the Report a helpful document which will serve to focus public attention more clearly on an important element in Australian foreign and defence relations. I am pleased to record that the Government can accept in large part almost all of your recommendations.

Second, the Committee underrates the complexity of the task facing the UN Secretariat in maintaining multiple peacekeeping operations. This has been accentuated by the growth in UN peacekeeping activity in the last three years. From 1978 to 1988 no new UN peacekeeping operations were launched. But from 1988 to the present nine new UN peacekeeping operations have been launched—without a significant appreciable increase in UN resources to administer those operations. The Secretariat often has to work to very tight timetables under considerable multilateral political pressure to achieve the tasks set for it. I think there was insufficient recognition given in the Report to just how difficult it can be, at times, in balancing the interests not just of thirty or more troop contributing countries, but more importantly, the expectations of the protagonists to the conflict. The performance of the UN Secretariat so far in 1991 in mounting five new peacekeeping operations has thus been praiseworthy, given the time and resource pressures with which the Secretariat had to contend.

Third, the inclusion in the Report of the views of some named witnesses on the alleged shortcomings of the UN administration of peacekeeping operations has produced a lack of balance on that issue. Such balance could have come from inclusion in the Report of the remarks of other witnesses, such as the officer from the Electoral Commission who was highly complimentary about the UN's administration of the election associated with UNTAG. The negative views quoted in the Report on the UN's administration of peacekeeping do not reflect the considered position of the Australian Government. The Government has a wider appreciation of the political complexities surrounding the administration of UN peacekeeping operations than some individual witnesses and fully recognises and appreciates why, on occasion, these matters may not proceed quite according to plan.

The Government also recognises that UN peacekeeping operations, relying as they do on contributions from many countries, create unique command and management challenges. It is important to recall that the efficiency of these operations depends on national units operating coherently within the command structure established by the UN.
In this context the Committee might also have benefited from testimony from some senior UN Secretariat officials whose views might have been evaluated against those of some of your other witnesses.

Fourth, the Report tends to downplay the complex diplomatic negotiations involved in pursuing Australia's interests in possible participation in UN peacekeeping operations. Merely stating our wishes and our expectation will not necessarily achieve our objective. Our diplomats and other officials have a firm sense of the diplomatic subtleties and nuances necessary for Australia to secure its peacekeeping objectives.

Fifth, the Report states that Australia has participated in the majority of UN peacekeeping operations. This is true, and as a contributor to peacekeeping, Australia's record is good and our reputation stands high. But in personnel terms we are not in the front rank of nations who have consistently participated in peacekeeping operations.

The Report makes reference to twenty-three peacekeeping operations launched by the UN since its inception. Australia has directly contributed personnel to ten of these operations but has also temporarily loaned personnel to three other peacekeeping operations and provided observers in support roles for a further four operations.

Since the release of the Report the UN has launched four new operations in Angola (UNAVEM II), El Salvador (ONUSAL), Western Sahara (MINURSO) and the Advance Mission in Cambodia (UNAMIC) Australia is contributing personnel to MINURSO and UNAMIC. To date Australia has participated to varying degrees in nineteen of the UN's twenty-seven operations.

In terms of personnel, over the years only one in approximately every 250 United Nations peacekeepers has been an Australian. According to United Nations figures available to us at 31 August 1991, (which excludes personnel assigned to MINURSO) there were 33 Australian peacekeepers out of a total of 10,838. Of 54 countries contributing personnel, Australia ranked equal twentieth with India. In 1989 Australia's contribution looked more impressive with 309 personnel attached to UNTAG in Namibia. However, as the Report notes, so did the contributions of eight other countries contributing personnel to UNTAG. Nevertheless with 45 Australian personnel now serving in MINURSO and 40 to serve with UNAMIC, and a significant Australian contribution planned for the UN Transitional Authority in Cambodia (UNTAC), our participation rate will considerably improve.

I should note however that numbers alone are not a measure of the value of a particular contribution: in this case, quantity does not equal quality. While Australia's contribution in numerical terms has been small, we enjoy a high reputation in the UN peacekeeping community for professionalism and competence. If Australia has achieved a standing in peacekeeping higher than our participation rate suggests, it is because of the aforementioned professionalism and competence of our personnel when they participate in UN peacekeeping operations, and also because of the particularly significant role Australia played in UNTAG. Our willingness to play a major role in the Cambodian settlement should also help significantly in lifting our profile in international peacekeeping.

Finally, I would point out that the Government faces resource constraints in contributing to peacekeeping operations and in administering them. For this reason in particular the Government is not proposing any major administrative changes or Defence Force Structure changes. I assure the Committee, however, that the Government is well seized of the importance of peacekeeping in our overall multilateral objectives, and will maintain a capacity to respond flexibly in order to pursue our objectives in this area.
I thank you and members of your Committee for this helpful Report.

SPEECH.PARA: Yours sincerely
GARETH EVANS

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I broadly welcome the Government's response to this important report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on United Nations peacekeeping and Australia. This parliamentary report, which has been unanimously adopted, addressed for the first time—at least in a comprehensive way—Australia's role in contributing to the United Nations peacekeeping activities. These activities, of course, have increased extraordinarily since 1988. Currently, in expenditure terms alone, they amount to more than the costs in administration and all the other programs of the United Nations put together. It is necessary that we address how we as a nation can achieve our own foreign policy and other national goals, be good international citizens and contribute to peacekeeping in the various ways in which they now occur.

PARA.TAB: We saw the United Nations taking more than peacekeeping action so successfully in the Gulf earlier this year. I think it has been announced today that the United Nations is to bring a peacekeeping force to Yugoslavia to participate in the conflict between the Serbian and Croatian forces. There are also peacekeeping forces in the western Sahara, in Kuwait itself now and in a number of other regions. One of the most successful of these involved the activities in Namibia. In what was really a transition arrangement, a UN force made possible the self-determination of the Namibian people in the election of their own government. The activity that is on the agenda the most and which has just begun is the peacekeeping contingent in Cambodia in which Australia will play a very significant role. It is with all of these recent and current activities in mind that the Senate Committee brought down this very substantial report to which the Government is now responding.

The response sets out the Government's position on each of our Committee recommendations. It is clear and is set out in a format which this Parliament welcomes. There were 19 recommendations in the report and they are responded to one by one. All but one have met with a very positive response from the Government. In that one—which I will come to in a few minutes—where the Government rejects the words of recommendation 19, I believe there has been a misunderstanding. I will therefore speak from the cross benches, as it were, in explaining my understanding of the Government's reasons for coming to that conclusion.

Broadly speaking, I understand the Government's response and I believe it is welcomed. I will read the first of the six points which the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, makes in his covering letter to this response. He states:

SPEECH.PARA: First, the Government finds the Report a helpful document which will serve to focus public attention more clearly on an important element in Australian foreign and defence relations. I am pleased to record that the Government can accept in large part almost all of your recommendations.

The second and third points in the letter are a clarification by the Minister and the Government of the complexity of the United Nations administration of peacekeeping forces. In our report, we include the evidence of some witnesses to our inquiry who made criticisms of the United Nations administration. I believe the Minister is very fair in the way in which he says that, as we did not have access to some of the United Nations senior administrators, there is an unintended, but perhaps perceived, bias because we have given some undue weight to these criticisms in the Committee report.

PARA.TAB: I wish to put clearly on the record the fact that I have confidence in the Secretary-General, Perez de Cuellar, and his senior officers—in particular, his special adviser on political affairs who is responsible for peacekeeping forces, Mr Marrack Goulding, with whom I have met on several occasions this year. I have full confidence in Mr Goulding and in the way in which, not only with good intentions but also through very capable and skilful decisions, he and other senior officers in the UN have prepared advice for the Security Council and the General Assembly and seen the implementation of peacekeeping forces.

This is a point that the Minister is making as well: in the complexity of the arrangements that will be made, we ought not read, out of perspective, some of the individual statements that stand alone in our Senate Committee report. So I, as one of those who contributed to the writing of the original report, also want to underline the Minister's redress or reassurance.

I believe there is substance in our reference to the need to improve the UN administration when we say that there were not enough resources. There are not enough resources in the UN administration to cope with the now nine peacekeeping initiatives that have been undertaken in the last three years. There was a period of about 15 or 20 years when there were hardly any peacekeeping initiatives; but there has been a plethora in recent times. I think the point ought to be taken that the objective of having procedures in the commissioning of peacekeeping forces ought to be followed and that there ought to be more resources and militarily experienced officers within the Secretariat, including experienced Australian military officers who come with full maturity to the peacekeeping purposes of the UN. By strengthening the administration of the United Nations in peacekeeping, even those deficiencies that some individuals brought to our attention in our inquiry would be all the more avoidable.

I also recognise that we ought not down play the complex diplomatic negotiations involved—whether by a government of a nation or the UN itself—in determining the arrangements for peacekeeping. I also acknowledge the fifth and sixth points made in the covering letter of the Minister, which say that we should not exaggerate Australia's contribution to peacekeeping over the whole life of the United Nations.

We have contributed to 19 of the 26 or 27 peacekeeping activities of the United Nations. But we are in fact in equal twentieth position amongst the nations of the world in terms of the numbers of personnel that Australia has contributed. I certainly do not wish there to be any misunderstanding; we have said that we have made a significant contribution to the peacekeeping forces qualitatively, professionally and strategically. The Minister's clarification that we are not able to claim that we are amongst the most active nations in the world in contributing numbers to the peacekeeping activities of the United Nations is not unwelcome. Of course, there will be an increase in the present planning with regard to the peacekeeping force in Cambodia.

I wish to refer, in the minute or so I have left, to three or four of the Government's responses. My time is very brief so I will not be able to say all that I would have wished. Recommendation 4 calls for a small permanent secretariat or task force to be established within the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade which would co-ordinate Australia's preparedness for peacekeeping. The Minister responds by indicating confirmation of the arrangements already in place.

However, he adds on page 7 of the response that the Government will keep this matter under review and will give careful attention to the points that have been raised legitimately in the Senate report. In particular, the Government will look at the arrangements, possibly for a secretariat, in the event of Australian NGOs becoming involved more fully. Recommendation 6 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government ensure the precondition for Australia contributing to a United Nations peacekeeping force is that all parties are committed to a comprehensive settlement and to the relevant United Nations Security Council and General Assembly Resolutions and United Nations peacekeeping operational plans.

That is a clear recommendation by the Committee and the Government agrees with it. We understood that this was standard government procedure in Australia and, indeed, standard United Nations procedure, but we do not want to be in any way complacent about this precondition. We do not want to be misinterpreted as being so much in favour of pointing to the way in which Australia could live up to the potential of contributing to peacekeeping operations that we are seen as being gung ho and overlooking some of these important preconditions.

PARA.TAB: Recommendation 13 talks of the need to amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act. That in itself is a recognition of the important role that electoral officers played in Namibia. The Government has agreed to that recommendation. I also refer to recommendation 15, where we mention greater regional cooperation. The Senate's finding greatly reinforces what we are already doing, and I am glad to see that the Minister has fully agreed with that.

Recommendation 16 calls for international peacekeeping to be explicitly included in the objectives of the Australian Defence Force. The Minister in his response agrees in part in that he argues that this is already explicitly in the Defence of Australia 1987 White Paper. He outlines the three particular objectives of the Defence Force.

I have no argument with the Minister's response but, unfortunately, I believe that this is interpreted too narrowly by many in the Defence Force and many in public discussion in Australia as being only the first of the three items set out in the White Paper which are in fact orthodoxy in Australia. I believe that we all still need to see that, while the priority for the Defence Force is the direct defence of this country, peacekeeping is included in the second and third points that are set out in the Minister's response.

Finally, I refer to recommendation 19, which I foreshadowed earlier. It is the only recommendation that the Minister has rejected. I support his reasons for rejection. Therefore, I wish to note that there has been a misinterpretation. When the recommendation is made that there be wide publicity of the kinds of criteria that ought to be observed by Australia in the commitment of a peacekeeping contingent, we are saying that this should be done before the commitment to Cambodia. The word `before' is meant to stress that we should undertake this matter urgently so that the public is well-informed on these matters and is able to discuss and maturely accept these matters by the time the Government has responsibly made a decision about Cambodia.

The Government and the Opposition are of the view—there are a few in this chamber among the Australian Democrats who take the contrary view—that defence decisions such as this are to be made by the responsible elected government of Australia. I believe that such decisions should be brought to this Parliament as soon as possible so that the Parliament is able to debate the matter and for that debate and any resolution of the Parliament that flows from it to be fully taken into account. I do not wish to detract from the sovereignty of the Government or to delay any decision by responsible government that should be made.

Finally, I wish to stress that Australia can make a real contribution to the current United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia, UNTAC. I very much welcome the decision by the United Nations to invite General John Sanderson of the Australia Defence Force to be commander of UNTAC. I have confidence in General Sanderson and wish him and all the Australians serving in the United Nations peacekeeping forces every success in their endeavours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I am pleased to see that the Government has accepted almost all of the Committee's recommendations relating to United Nations peacekeeping. Our report brought down a total of 19 recommendations. It is worth emphasising that the recommendations were unanimous; they had the support of all parties represented on the Committee—Government, Opposition and Australian Democrats. I welcome the systematic way in which the Government has addressed each of the Committee's recommendations. I would like to emphasise that the recommendations arose out of a very comprehensive exploration of the issues involved in Australia's participation in United Nations peacekeeping.

PARA.TAB: The report reflects the belief of the Committee that historically peacekeeping has played an important role in certain international circumstances. The recommendations also reflect the view that the need for such activities is likely to increase in future rather than decrease. That is a very important part of our assessment of the situation.

The Committee concluded, as the Government pointed out in its response, that in purely numerical terms Australia's contribution to United Nations peacekeeping operations has been modest. But we also share the Government's view that Australia's high standing internationally as a peacekeeper is in large part due to the professionalism and competence of the Australian personnel who have participated in United Nations peacekeeping operations.

I will not attempt to comment in detail on the Government's response to each of the Committee's 19 recommendations. I will, however, make a few general remarks and refer specifically to some of the recommendations. For example, I welcome the very positive response that the Government has given to the Committee's concerns about accurate financial costing of Australian contributions and the prospective Cabinet consideration of a framework for setting conditions of service for Australian Defence Force personnel serving on United Nations peacekeeping missions. I emphasise the word `prospective'. We are very much concerned to ensure that the conditions of service for Australian personnel serving abroad on peacekeeping missions are laid down clearly and concisely in black and white before those personnel leave Australia. That has not always been the case.

I note the Government's decision to use more extensively the inter-departmental committee process to address questions of coordination rather than establishing a small secretariat in the Public Service, as recommended by the Committee. The important aspect of the Committee's recommendation in my view is the need to ensure effective coordination of future peacekeeping activities, when both the level and complexity of Australian participation is likely to increase.

There was certainly no intention on the part of the Committee to isolate United Nations peacekeeping from other multilateral objectives, to duplicate functions or to create additional bureaucratic layers. They were not the objectives of the Committee in that recommendation. On the contrary, the purpose of a clearly identified central coordinating unit or secretariat was considered desirable by the Committee in order to carry out a number of important functions. These include integrating peacekeeping even more fully into Australia's overall foreign policy objectives; ensuring that there is no unnecessary duplication or overlap of functions; and systematically evaluating our participation in peacekeeping activities under the United Nations umbrella.

If the inter-departmental committee process can ensure these outcomes effectively, then I feel confident that it will be acceptable to members of the Committee. I am reassured that the responsibility for implementation of the recommendations in the report has been clearly designated, and in particular that the question of the most suitable administrative structures for Australian involvement in the Cambodia mission is being kept under active review.

I trust that the minor technical problems that have been identified as standing in the way of publication of an official history of Australian involvement in peacekeeping activities will be readily overcome and the project begun without delay, as recommended in the Committee's report.

Although there is a little literature available on the subject, it falls far short of giving adequate coverage to or acknowledgment of the services performed overseas by Australian peacekeepers. The recommendation by the Committee that such a history be written was very closely tied to the Committee's concern that the Australian community should be better informed about our contributions to United Nations peacekeeping.

In the Committee's view, press releases announcing Australian contributions are simply not enough to ensure the level of public understanding and support for the Government's contributions to peacekeeping in various theatres abroad. It was for this reason that the Committee urged the Government in recommendation No. 18, in effect, to engage in dialogue with the community and actively encourage debate on issues relating to peacekeeping, the objective being to raise the profile of peacekeeping in the Australian community.

There is no question that the final decision on participation in peacekeeping is one that the Government itself must take. We all agree with that. But the decision that the Government takes should be based on as full and comprehensive an understanding of community attitudes as is possible. Letting the community know as much in advance as possible of the reasons for Australia's participation, the likely costs and the likely benefits will, in the long term, be the only way to maintain continuing community support for Australian involvement in the United Nations peacekeeping operations.

The Government response confirms the impressions of the Committee that `links with other members of the region on peacekeeping issues, while increasing, are not as well developed' as they might be. The activities foreshadowed in the Government's response to recommendations Nos 1 and 15 go some way to meeting the Committee's view that there is scope for more productive cooperation in UN peacekeeping operations at the regional level.

I would like to point out that recommendation No. 1 urged that Australia coordinate its efforts to improve UN peacekeeping machinery with regional and other like minded countries. Recommendation No. 15, which I also referred to, urged the Australian Government to explore greater regional cooperation in peacekeeping.

I reiterate the recommendation that more emphasis be placed on introducing a peacekeeping component to the links which already exist under ongoing defence and foreign policy programs in our region. Whether this is done through joint peacekeeping exercises, regional seminars or personnel exchanges is a matter for further consideration in consultation with our regional partners.

The important thing is for Australia to actively initiate and pursue such an initiative. It is not only an important activity in itself, it is also a useful addition to the range of activities which our Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, advocated in his statement on regional security in 1989 as adding substance to our relations with our neighbours.

The Committee recommended that the Government seek to have an Australian appointed to head the UNTAC mission—the mission to Cambodia. It is very pleasing to see that the Government has had considerable success in promoting the appointment of an Australian, General John Sanderson, to command the military component of the UN Transitional Authority in Cambodia. I understand that the United Nations Secretary General has nominated General Sanderson, and that no Security Council member has raised any objection to his appointment.

The Committee felt that this was a very important recommendation, given the importance of the Cambodia peacekeeping operation and the likely level of Australian participation in it. I am sure I am speaking for all members of the Committee in expressing my full confidence in the Government's selection of a very capable and highly experienced officer to fulfil what is going to be an exceptionally difficult and demanding task. I seek leave to incorporate the balance of my remarks in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to take this opportunity to express my admiration for the dedication with which the leadership of the United Nations has tackled the enormous job of putting in place the machinery necessary to bring the Cambodian peace plan to life. I am more than conscious of the delicacy of the task and the very many pressures that the United Nations has been under.

As those who have read the Committee's Report will know, strong criticism by witnesses of some aspects of past United Nations peacekeeping activities surfaced during the course of the inquiry. The Committee felt it was its duty to acknowledge that there were aspects of the United Nations capacity to carry out its peacekeeping tasks that needed to be reviewed and improvements sought.

It is a tribute to the leadership of the United Nations that they not only paid close attention to the Report itself, but also continued to work in a most constructive way to find the best solutions to the myriad of organisational, political and resource problems that the Cambodia peace plan confronted them with. This achievement is all the more remarkable when you consider that the United Nations was simultaneously engaged in launching three other new peacekeeping operations, in Angola, El Salvador and in Western Sahara.

I am sure I speak for all the Committee members when I wish both the United Nations and the Australian personnel participating in the Cambodia peacekeeping operation well in their endeavours to bring a tragic episode in Cambodia's history to a close.

I cannot agree with the suggestion that the Report lacked balance in its treatment of the United Nations administration of peacekeeping operations. It is true that there was a selection of views critical of certain aspects. Some of these criticisms came from individual military officers with first-hand experience of peacekeeping operations. Some reflected organisational views (e.g. army presentation to the Committee, p. 39 of the Report).

Equally the Report gave a very full account of the difficulties that an international organisation such as the United Nations faces in mounting peacekeeping operations. Paragraphs 2.59—2.64 in particular give a faithful account of the testimony presented to the Committee by the representative of the Foreign Affairs and Trade Department, testimony which clearly acknowledged the difficulties inherent in administering peacekeeping operations by a multilateral body such as the United Nations and the role that Australia could realistically expect to play.

The question over which I, and I believe other members of the Committee were left in some doubt, was the extent to which past shortcomings in the United Nations administration had been clearly articulated and made known to those responsible in the United Nations Secretariat as they occurred. It seemed to the Committee that legitimate concerns amongst personnel in the field may well have been filtered and diplomatically watered down in the past to a point where they no longer served to bring about change for the better.

The very lack of resources for peacekeeping to which the Government refers may well reflect a false complacency amongst some members of the international community that the job of peacekeeping was being done well enough and therefore needed no attention or timely and adequate funding.

I think it important to reiterate the point made by those who made critical comments, that their main concern was to see a vital international function carried out in the best possible way. The Committee shared this objective.

The Report made it clear when testimony was being given in a private capacity (e.g. pp. 36-37). The Committee felt confident that the United Nations Administration was more than capable of differentiating between individual, personal opinions and the considered views of the Australian Government.

One of the most valuable aspects of the Senate Committee Reports such as this one is the opportunity it gives to various interest groups, individuals and organisations to air views and reveal perspectives that can, in the normal course of events, remain unarticulated and perhaps not sufficiently taken into account by decision-makers. It seems to me also valuable for international bodies, such as the United Nations, to be made aware of the community pressures and community values that play an important part in shaping the policies of democratic governments such as ours.

With regard to the suggestion that the Committee might have benefited from testimony from senior United Nations Secretariat officials, the Committee invited the United Nations, through their representative in Australia to make a submission to the inquiry. The invitation was declined on the grounds that the United Nations did not consider it appropriate to do so. Nevertheless, several reports relating to United Nations peacekeeping which were made available to the Committee by the United Nations were carefully studied in the preparation of the Committee Report.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on United Nations peacekeeping and Australia is a very significant and extremely important document. Most of the recommendations are designed to improve the performance of the peacekeeping task which is now becoming one of the high priority areas of the United Nations both within the United Nations and within Australia. I shall not rehearse the recommendations which are directed towards those, but there are a number of recommendations which have particular significance and which I would like to advert to briefly.

PARA.TAB: I certainly agree with the first recommendation that the Committee made—and I am pleased to be now a member of that Committee—that the Australian Government should give a high priority in its foreign policy objectives to seeking improvements of the United Nations machinery for peacekeeping. It is entirely reasonable for the Government to say that the permanent appointment of an Australian officer to the United Nations Secretary General's military planning staff can wait until our continued contribution to the force warrants such a step.

Recommendation No. 3 warrants comment. It suggests that a more comprehensive picture of the total financial cost of any Australian contributions to peacekeeping be readily available to government, the Parliament and the Australian people. Clearly, that is part of the accountability process and, indeed, is an essential component if we are to structure our continuing contribution to peacekeeping forces adequately and positively.

In that sense I strongly support recommendation No. 4 which the Government does not fully accept. The recommendation is that a small permanent secretariat or task force be established as a matter of priority to oversight the many and varied aspects of peacekeeping in the evolving international order. The Government suggests that the interdepartmental committee process is adequate to achieve that. One must express some doubt about whether it is. I do not think it is good enough. The interdepartmental committee process is essentially disjointed, not particularly focused and does not have the continuing and direct responsibility for the development of priorities in this function. We would certainly prefer the establishment of a permanent secretariat.

Recommendation No. 11 warrants a brief mention. It suggests that additional emphasis be given to imparting negotiation and conflict resolution skills in the pre-posting training period. Very clearly, that is a function at the heart of a United Nations peacekeeping operation. Regrettably in many ways but, quite naturally, this is foreign to the normal training that our defence forces receive. Clearly, it is an area which should now receive continuing and renewed emphasis.

Recommendation No. 15 has been referred to previously. It suggests that we explore with countries in the region the concept of greater regional cooperation at various levels. This is something that the Australian Democrats would welcome as we believe that our defence concerns should have a regional focus.

In recommendation No. 16 the Committee recommends that the Australian contribution to international peacekeeping be explicitly included in the objectives of the Australian Defence Force. I believe that would be extremely important not only to confirm that the Australian Government now considers that to be a high priority in its strategic defence concerns, but also because it would have some effect on the measures taken in developing our future defence strategies and capabilities.

As is well and truly on the record, the Australian Democrats favour a defence posture which is directed towards defending our shores rather than the often touted forward defence idea which would involve us in military adventures overseas. However, here we have a situation where we must provide capacity to contribute to United Nations peacekeeping forces. While this, on the face of it, shows a certain conflict with the stance we have taken, I believe it can be resolved by placing great care on our strategic considerations and selecting the sort of equipment for, and direction and development of, our armed forces which will enable them to join other forces in concert in overseas operations which are directed towards United Nations peacekeeping efforts.

We still emphasise that we should not aim for high expenditure in equipment and in general strategic provisions which are directed towards allowing us to have an independent capacity to deploy our forces overseas. Recommendation No. 19 is extremely important. I regret that the Government has seen fit to reject it. The recommendation suggests that a statement of the factors which lead to the decision, and which are listed in recommendation No. 18, should be publicised widely in the Australian community before a final decision on participation in that particular operation is taken. I prefer to apply a literal interpretation to that. I do not think there is a misunderstanding. I solidly support that.

The recommendation is in keeping with the view that we have held for a long time—that before Australian troops are deployed overseas a resolution of both Houses of Parliament is necessary. I do not share Senator Teague's suggestion that we should debate that after the decision has been made, after the troops have left our shores. That is closing the gate after the horse has bolted. It is a significant decision that is being made on behalf of the Australian people; it is a decision that places lives at risk. I believe that this Parliament has not only the right but also the responsibility to consider the reasons that the Executive Government puts forward for making such a weighty decision. I regret that the Government has rejected that suggestion.

I conclude my remarks by welcoming the report. It is a timely one. Very clearly, the Australian contribution to the United Nations peacekeeping force, while commensurate with our capacity, is extremely important. I trust that it will be given high priority in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a few words on the subject of the Government's response to the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on United Nations peacekeeping and Australia. The coalition parties have, of course, a fine record in supporting Australia's peacekeeping efforts, and we maintain that attitude. Those peacekeeping efforts have been both under UN auspices and otherwise. I can remember one force in particular, not under UN auspices, in the Sinai which I visited some years ago. That multinational force was playing its part in maintaining the one peace treaty that lasted in the Middle East between Egypt and Israel. I have seen Australian peacekeepers in many areas of the world doing fine work. I know that they are highly regarded and that their work is internationally appreciated.

PARA.TAB: I wish to refer in particular to the peacekeeping forces in Cambodia and the decisions of the Australian Government in that regard. I speak of the force that has recently been sent to join the United Nations Advance Mission in Cambodia, UNAMIC. It involves some 40 military personnel. The much larger group that is going to be sent will join the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia, UNTAC.

The Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade made mention in its report of the need to ensure security for Australian personnel. I would have thought that that was obvious. I raise the issue in the light of the very unfortunate events that have occurred in Phnom Penh in the last 24 hours, where two SNC Khmer Rouge representatives, Son Sen and Khieu Samthan, were almost lynched. We regret violence wherever and whenever it occurs, and we deplore that act. On the other hand, in many ways it is not surprising. They are senior representatives of the Khmer Rouge, which is responsible for the deaths of over one million Cambodians. Many in the lynch mob were children who had lost their parents and other relatives to the Khmer Rouge.

I have always said that it is beyond my comprehension that the Khmer Rouge would be allowed back into Phnom Penh. I think anyone who has visited the torture chambers in Phnom Penh and contemplated the return of those who committed such atrocities on other Cambodian people would be amazed to believe that it would be possible to find a peace solution that would embrace the Khmer Rouge. Yet the international community has sought to do that, and the Australian Government has been a key player in finding a solution that legitimises the future role of the Khmer Rouge in Cambodia.

As I have said, this has caused us concern. We are not surprised about the violent reaction that has occurred in Phnom Penh. We have questioned the sense, the realism, in incorporating the Khmer Rouge, the hated enemy of so many of the Cambodian people, within that peace formula. We have pressed alternatives that have excluded the Khmer Rouge. We have pressed them upon the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), and he has criticised us for doing so. We have argued that the Khmer Rouge leaders should be charged with genocide. At least until very recently, when we have done that we have been criticised by Senator Evans. When I was in Phnom Penh last year arguing that Hun Sen should move to unilateral democratic elections as a step towards peace that would perhaps force the non-communist factions to become involved in the peace process with him, we were criticised by Senator Evans for advocating that sort of solution.

Senator Evans, since putting down what he modestly refers to as `his plan', has argued that it is essential that the Khmer Rouge be part of that plan, that it be embraced within it. We have consistently questioned the realism of that solution. My colleague Senator Teague raised in this chamber the issue of Son Sen's record. He was the Interior Minister, actually responsible for the running of that torture chamber. We endorsed his presence as one of the representatives on the SNC, a body which we said was important to be constructed to take over the role of interim government of Cambodia. When we have put his record to Senator Evans in this chamber, he has avoided that issue. We have asked why Australia is embracing people with that type of record to play key roles in the future of Cambodia, and we still have unsatisfactory answers to that.

We have asked how we could depend on a settlement which depends so much upon the good faith of the Khmer Rouge. Looking at the record of the Khmer Rouge, how could one take for granted its good faith? It was demonstrated immediately before the settlement when the KR started to force refugees out of their camps in Thailand and back into Cambodia so that they would not come under the UN authority and be protected by it to be repatriated to where they wished to go. The KR wished to return them to where it wanted them for future purposes within Cambodia.

We have asked how, in the real world, we can accept that all of the forces of the Khmer Rouge would, under US auspices, assemble in these cantonments, and that 70 per cent of those forces would hand in their arms and be discharged from military action and returned to the villages as peasants. It seems to us that that is a totally unrealistic proposition, yet it is a key to the basis of this peace agreement. When I put that to UN officials recently in New York their answer was, `Of course we can have no guarantee. It depends upon their good faith'.

Looking at their good faith over the past 13 years, there is no realistic basis for assuming that such would occur. The Khmer Rouge is believed to have some three or four years of weapons and ammunitions stashed away in the jungle. Is it realistic to believe that all of a sudden this communist, horrendous organisation will convert itself into a democratic group, cast aside its armed struggle and join in free and open elections? We have raised the unreality of that and have been condemned by our Foreign Minister for raising it as an issue.

What does this now mean? It means that we have sent some 40 Australian officials to Cambodia under the first of the UN missions, UNAMIC. Their role is to communicate between the Khmer factions and between the Khmer factions and the SNC. The SNC can now not operate and, as was envisaged, hold meetings in Phnom Penh. Prince Sihanouk is now trying to cause a meeting to be held in Bangkok.

How are the Australian officials who have now left the city and gone out into the jungle going to carry out that communication task? How are they also going to carry out communication tasks between the factions and in particular between the Khmer Rouge and the other factions, especially after the atmosphere that we witnessed in Phnom Penh overnight? How safe will they be? We have very serious concern about that issue.

We said that for the Government to put Australian military personnel into a country where there are literally hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of unmarked mines; into a continuing conflict—I remind the Senate of that; there may be less now than there was but fighting is continuing—to deal between factions that have a hatred almost more intense than anything that can be imagined, and which was witnessed in Phnom Penh overnight, is to put Australian personnel into a very serious situation, our knowledge of which is made more acute by what has happened in the last 24 hours.

We said that the Australian Government, before doing that, should have put down a statement in both Houses explaining exactly what was to be the function of the Australian military personnel, how their security was to be guaranteed, how long they would be there—matters which the Australian representatives have a right and responsibility to debate.

We are not opposed to Australia contributing to a peacekeeping force in Cambodia in the same way as we have supported other peacekeeping forces. It can be a very useful contribution that Australia can make to maintaining peace in our region and elsewhere. But peacekeepers can effectively carry out their function only after peace has been achieved. We wanted the opportunity to debate a Government statement as to whether that peace had been achieved and whether it was premature to send those forces.

Madam Acting Deputy President, you might remember that, when the Department of Defence put out its statement on the first 40 personnel going to Cambodia, it said they would be unarmed in the same way as is the general practice in UN good offices missions. Upon reflection, the Australian Government changed its mind—probably sensibly—to allow them to take weapons for personal protection.

So the Australian Government, upon reflection, was obviously more worried about their safety than had been indicated in the first statement that was put out by the Department of Defence. But there was never a proper debate in this place either on why that change of policy occurred or on what sort of information the Government received upon which it decided to change its security assessment for these Australian military personnel. These are important matters that should be properly reported to the Australian Parliament, and we should have the opportunity to debate them.

Now the Government has made an offer to the UN to provide a much larger force to the United Nations to be part of UNTAC. The Australian Government has not disclosed to the Parliament the terms of that offer. We have not been told how many troops we have offered or what functions and roles they will carry out. I cannot see any reason why the Australian Government should not have informed the Parliament of those details.

We have been told that, when the UN makes a decision on whether to accept the Australian Government's offer in that regard, then the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) will put down a statement which can be debated. But the House of Representatives gets up today. So the Prime Minister will not be putting down any statement. These decisions are likely to be made—perhaps not on deployment—before the Parliament returns. There will not, therefore, be that opportunity to debate the issue put to us by this Government.

We may now be putting forces—the Prime Minister has mentioned up to 500 men—into considerable danger. We as parliamentarians have a responsibility in that regard—an issue that has been raised in general terms in the report put before the Parliament by the Parliamentary Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —And explicitly in recommendation No. 6.

—As my colleague Senator Teague said, explicitly in one of the recommendations. So we take this opportunity to raise these concerns. At a different level we are concerned by other aspects. We raise questions about the cost of Australia's commitment. The cost to UNTAC has been estimated to be anything between about $1 billion and $5 billion. It would be by far the largest and most comprehensive of any UN mission that has ever been put anywhere in the world.

PARA.TAB: Its functions will be beyond that of any previous mission. It will be responsible for removing the mines and making the country safe. It will be responsible for all the tasks I have talked about, of disarming the current forces of the four Khmer factions, or 70 per cent of them as in the agreement. According to the letter of the agreement, it will be responsible for interim functions of government in Phnom Penh—the functions of foreign affairs, defence, the interior, communications and one other function of government that I can not immediately remember.

This is the first time that the UN has assumed such functions of government. It will be responsible for resettling some 350,000 refugees that are presently in camps on the Thai border—resettling them to farms that no longer exist. These are people who have been in camps for many years, with all the social difficulties one can imagine that would be involved in that, apart from the security issues. It will also be responsible for laying all the plans for the reconstruction of Cambodia—an enormous task.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the election itself, of course.

—And the election itself. It will be responsible for every facet of the election: drawing election laws; educating the public; putting the election into effect; monitoring and recording it; and seeing that whoever wins takes government. This is a country which is not familiar with these practices.

PARA.TAB: Considering the enormous educational task alone, it is mind-boggling. The task of bringing to people who have had so many years of trauma participation in what we can so easily refer to as a democratic election process is an enormous task in itself. It is challenging. We want to see a real peace in Cambodia and we want to see that the Cambodian people have a chance to determine their own future through free and fair elections, but it will cost a lot of money. We have never had a satisfactory answer from this Government as to what will be Australia's contribution to that. For example, on reconstruction it is assumed that, because of the huge sums of money involved, the normal peacekeeping formula will not apply and that countries will be asked to make voluntary contributions.

Japan is expected to make a voluntary contribution of 30 per cent of the total cost. I cannot see how we can be expecting others whom we claim to have played prominent roles in the peace process to make large voluntary contributions if we are also not prepared to do so. I suspect that means that this Government has a much larger sum of money in mind than the $15m it has already committed. We should have the opportunity to debate these issues. The Government should have been prepared to come clean and put them before us in order that we might debate them.

I take this opportunity today to say that the issues of Australia's contribution to both UNAMIC and to UNTAC are important and should be debated before the Parliament. The Minister should be prepared to put down a statement stating exactly what the Australian Government intends to do in order to give us the basis of that debate. He should put to us what the Government intends to do in relation to our contribution to the refugees, disarmament and cease-fire monitoring and what part, if any, we are to play in the UN administration function that is to be carried out.

It is interesting than when Mr Hun Sen was in Canberra recently he suggested that perhaps the functions of government would not be passed to the United Nations as was envisaged in the agreement. One wonders if in fact that is not evidencing a further failure of the agreement. Those who are sceptical about the process now raise the issue of the agreement that Mr Hun Sen and Prince Sihanouk have reached in the last week or two to join together in a coalition which is outside the terms of the UN agreement. This,

SPEECH.PARA: of course, is going to put incredible pressure on the SNC. The SNC had the four functions coming together jointly to carry out governmental functions in the lead-up to the election.

PARA.TAB: Has that now broken down? How much of the UN agreement has now broken down by that process of the functions of government perhaps not being passed to the United Nations and by the violence that has now occurred in Phnom Penh? Is it safe, therefore, to continue looking to develop the peacekeeping function in the light of these developments. They are important issues that we want out before the Parliament so that we have the opportunity to debate them. We criticise the Government for not giving us that opportunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like briefly to discuss the Government's response to the report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade entitled United Nations Peacekeeping and Australia. I will probably be reiterating much of what Senator Maguire has said and incorporated in this debate.

PARA.TAB: There are two recommendations to which I specifically want to draw attention. The first is recommendation 12 which relates to the pioneering role of women in peacekeeping forces. I recognise that the Government response is that the practice of having women within contingents will be continued by future Australian contingents in accordance with operational requirements. The progressive introduction of women into new areas and occupations within the defence forces will ensure that opportunities to participate in peacekeeping operations will increase for female ADF members. That is to be highly commended.

We also need to recognise that women went to Namibia when the UNTAG contingent was there, and the Australian Electoral Commission sent female officers there. It is very important to make sure that women are able to exercise their rights and participate in these contingents. This is a very important part of their military work and training and it provides them with a very good basis for future progression up the scale of seniority within the Defence Force. We saw also women travelling to the Middle East in that contingent, and that is something I highly recommend.

The main recommendation of concern and interest to me is recommendation 10 which relates to families of defence personnel. There was a saying within the British Army last century: `If we wanted you to have a family, we would have issued you with one'. Fortunately, that attitude has changed. With each participation by Australia in a contingent of United Nations peacekeeping, we have seen improvements in how we have handled matters pertaining to the family and their concerns and problems. The Government has accepted our quite lengthy recommendation. The Government is correct when it says that it represents the bare minimum support desirable for any deployment and reflects standard procedures already in place.

I asked the Minister for Defence (Senator Ray) a question a couple of weeks ago as to what had been done for the families of the contingent that has gone to Cambodia. He was able to advise me that all of the things that we had put in our recommendations had in fact happened. It is very important that we continue to remember the families of the service personnel and provide them with the support that is so necessary while their spouses are overseas.

It is also important to remember that at least half or more of the service personnel families consist of their parents or brothers and sisters, many of our personnel being single people. It is important to remember to provide information to and care for and support the families of the members of the Defence Force—be they their spouses or their parents as next of kin. Each of the three services has to fulfil that responsibility, but the services are becoming very professional in caring for families.

I urge other organisations that participate in peacekeeping forces—we have had a number —to carry out this responsibility. The Australian Federal Police are in Cyprus. It was commented that the Army cared for families better than it did. The Australian Federal Police was certainly interested to see our recommendations in that regard. The Australian Electoral Commission may be sending personnel overseas in company with the Cambodian peacekeeping contingent. We also have a number of bodies, although not actually military bodies, such as AIDAB, which are supporting a number of people who are also going to Cambodia. We need to make sure that these other bodies involved in peacekeeping, not just the military people, are conscious of the need to provide information to and care and support for the families of the personnel that they send to these places as well. I thank the Government for its response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a supporter of Australia's involvement in United Nations peacekeeping efforts, I commend both the Joint Parliamentary Committee for Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade for its excellent report entitled United Nations Peacekeeping and Australia and the Government generally for its response which is mostly positive. I support the idea of Australian Defence Force personnel being used for the socially useful purpose of peacekeeping—which is an appropriate use of the skills of our Defence Force—along with disaster relief and emergency services rather than engaging in overseas war-making. I would say that is a very good use of taxpayers' money.

PARA.TAB: These positive roles of the Australian defence forces need to be given a higher priority instead of that which is traditionally promoted in ADF advertisements seeking recruits. These advertisements generally emphasise learning how to use weapons system and how to become `a man' out there in wild territory. If these weapons systems are used, of course, the end result is death. That is so often overlooked. I really welcome the whole emphasis of the other side of what the ADF can do and, as other speakers have said, do very well; that is, to engage in peacekeeping efforts.

I would like to refer to a couple of the recommendations.
