Senator Spindler has already referred to recommendation 11, which says that additional emphasis should be given to negotiation conflict resolution skills. I am pleased to say that the Government has agreed to that. The Government has organised the inclusion of a two-day module on negotiation conflict resolution skills during predeployment training for future Australian UN peacekeeping contingents. I do not think that is nearly enough, but I am very glad that is there. It is a start and I think it will prove to be very effective. I hope it will be enlarged upon. That is a most important aspect of their role, as is the cultural climatisation which overseas peacekeeping forces need.

The next recommendation on which I would like to briefly comment is recommendation 16. The Committee recommends that Australian contributions to international peacekeeping be explicitly included in the objectives of the ADF and, in particular, be recognised as one positive element in regional security. Unfortunately, the Government's response to that is only to agree in part. I think it is very important for this to be emphasised and promoted as one of the chief functions of the ADF. I am sorry that that has not been more enthusiastically adopted.
In the comment on recommendation 16, the Government says that in the White Paper entitled Defence of Australia 1987 it is explicitly mentioned that peacekeeping should be part of the ADF role:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Defence recently reaffirmed this view in his 30 May 1991 statement to Parliament on `Defence Into The Twenty First Century'.
I will continue the quote with this comment from the Minister for Defence:

As the Gulf War showed, from a self-reliant defence force structured for the defence of this nation, Australia can make a contribution to operations further afield in support of friends and allies, and activities sanctioned by the United Nations.

This is hardly a peacekeeping operation. I find it almost unbelievable that that quote is used to reinforce the notion of peacekeeping. It seems to be totally misplaced. That was not peacekeeping, that was helping the United States in war making; that is what that was about. There should be no illusions about that whatsoever. I find it almost incredible that the Government has included that quote to re-emphasise its commitment to peacekeeping. It is totally out of place.

PARA.TAB: The last recommendation I would like to mention is recommendation 19, which other people have also referred to. In this one the Committee recommends that the specific peacekeeping operation be publicised widely in the Australian community before a final decision on participation is taken. As other speakers have said, it is a shame that the Government has rejected that. We need to be very careful about peacekeeping operations in which we decide to engage. The community and the Parliament need to be involved in that consultation and discussion before a decision is made and not after the event.

Finally, I would like to congratulate General John Sanderson, who is commanding the UN forces in Cambodia. I wish him well in the very challenging task ahead, and I join others here in wishing the Australian peacekeepers in Cambodia a successful tour of duty and a safe return home. They have a very difficult task ahead.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray), I present a further Government response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on visits to Australia by nuclear powered or armed vessels—contingency planning for the accidental release of ionising radiation. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator the Hon. Robert Ray
Senator G R Maguire
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs,
Defence and Trade
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Maguire

I am writing to inform you of action by the Government on two recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee's report into safety aspects of visits by nuclear weapons capable warships. This was foreshadowed in the Government's response tabled on 13 December 1989. The recommendations concerned emergency dry docking arrangements and nuclear weapon accident planning.

The announcement by President Bush on 27 September 1991 of a new defence strategy involving the deployment of its nuclear weapons worldwide has had a large practical effect on the safety issues associated with port visits and emergency dry docking arrangements by allied warships. Of special relevance is the following extract from his speech:

". . . the United States will withdraw all tactical nuclear weapons from its surface ships, attack submarines, as well as those nuclear weapons associated with our land-based naval aircraft. This means removing all nuclear Tomahawk cruise missiles from US ships and submarines, as well as nuclear bombs aboard aircraft carriers. The bottom line is that under normal circumstances, our ships will not carry tactical nuclear weapons.

You might recall that the Government said in response to Recommendation 37 on dry docking arrangements that it was reviewing dry docking policy. The review has now been completed. As a result, the Government has modified the general conditions for dry docking to make it clear that allied warships needing to enter an Australian drydock for emergency repairs must meet the RAN's safety requirements for the drydock concerned and for the repairs to be undertaken. Australian safety requirements for dry docking are similar to the requirements of our allies.

As a result of this policy review, I can also confirm the advice in the Government's initial response to the Committee's report that the guidelines for the dry docking of nuclear weapons capable warships provide for at least the same level of safety as for vessels berthed alongside. This accords with the Committee's recommendation. Amongst other matters, the RAN safety requirements take into account the type of repairs involved, the likely duration of the docking, the location of the area in the ship under repair in relation to weapon magazines, and the firefighting facilities available to the dock.

At the same time, the Government will continue to consider requests case by case for US and UK warships to dry dock in Australia for emergency repairs, and will not endanger the safety of a ship or its crew in need of access to Australian facilities. Government policy also accepts the US and UK policy of neither confirming nor denying the presence of nuclear weapons on board warships while they continue to adhere to that policy.

Recommendation 38 concerned preparation of a document on procedures for responding in the unlikely event of a nuclear weapon accident in an Australian port. Even before the President's announcement, the Government had confirmed the Committee's assessment that the risk of a nuclear weapon accident in a visiting warship in port did not warrant contingency planning measures in addition to existing and well-established general port safety plans. The President's announcement means that the need for planning in addition to existing port safety plans is further diminished.

The Commonwealth, however, will continue to work closely with port planning authorities, which are responsible for port safety, on safety issues associated with visiting warships. Through the Visiting Ships Panel (Nuclear) we will continue to make expertise available to them and to the State and Territory emergency organisations involved in the development of those safety plans.

The Visiting Ships Panel (Nuclear) has prepared an information paper outlining the division of responsibilities, internationally as well as nationally, in the event of an accident involving nuclear weapons on board visiting warships. While largely of historical interest, I am enclosing a copy for your information. In view of the emphasis the Committee placed on public information about safety planning, a copy is also to be made available to the State and Territory Governments.
Yours sincerely
ROBERT RAY
VISITS BY FRIENDLY AND
ALLIED WARSHIPS
RESPONSIBILITIES IN THE EVENT OF A NUCLEAR WEAPON ACCIDENT
Introduction

1.The safety issues involved in visits to Australia by nuclear powered and nuclear armed warships have been the subject of an inquiry conducted by the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. The Committee tabled an exhaustive and objective report in August 1989.

2.In endorsing the judgements made by successive Australian Governments about the safety issues involved in visits by allied warships, this multi-party Committee made a number of recommendations on procedures to enhance existing arrangements. One of these—Recommendation 38—concerned a draft procedures statement being developed by the Department of Defence on arrangements that would apply in the event of a nuclear weapon accident. This paper is the result.

3.The aim of this paper is to outline the framework of international and national arrangements that would guide the reactions of the parties in responding to an accident involving a nuclear weapon on board a visiting warship.
4.In this paper, a nuclear weapon accident is defined as:
`An inadvertent or unauthorised occurrence involving a nuclear weapon resulting in, or having the potential to result in, the release of radioactive material.

5.The announcement by President Bush on 27 September 1991 of a new defence strategy involving the deployment of its nuclear weapons worldwide has had a large practical effect on the safety issues associated with port visits and emergency dry docking arrangements by allied warships. Of special relevance is the following extract from his speech:

".. the United States will withdraw all tactical nuclear weapons from its surface ships, attack submarines, as well as those nuclear weapons associated with our land-based naval aircraft. This means removing all nuclear Tomahawk cruise missiles from US ships and submarines, as well as nuclear bombs aboard aircraft carriers. The bottom line is that under normal circumstances, our ships will not carry tactical nuclear weapons.
Policy Framework

6.The visits made to Australian ports by the naval ships of our allies and friends are one of the most visible aspects of Australia's international defence relations. The policy of successive Australian Governments has been to welcome such visits.

7.The Australian Government permits conventionally powered warships of friendly and allied countries, whether or not they are nuclear capable, to visit any port in Australia subject to standard navigational safety requirements and the availability of berths. Between January 1988 and January 1991 some 133 ship visits have been made to 23 ports—in all Australian States and Territories—by warships of the United States and British navies.

8.Nuclear powered warships, however, are subject to special arrangements and are permitted to visit only those Australian ports which have been assessed and approved as suitable in terms of strict environmental and safety criteria.

9.The Government does not require its friends and allies to disclose whether nuclear weapons are on board their visiting warships; it respects the policy of these countries neither to confirm nor deny the presence or absence of nuclear weapons in visiting warships. However in the highly unlikely event of an accident involving a nuclear weapon, agreements are in place for both the United States and British authorities immediately to notify the Australian Government.

10.The Government is satisfied that the standards applied by NATO countries in respect of nuclear weapons safety, and with the safety precautions taken on board visiting warships, effectively preclude the possibility of an accidental nuclear detonation.

11.The US Navy has never had a nuclear weapon accident in any port, either in the US or elsewhere. Nor has it ever had an accident involving the release of fission products from a reactor core in the history of its nuclear propulsion program. The United Kingdom also has confirmed that it has never suffered a release of radioactive material due to an accident involving nuclear weapons. A wide range of foreign warships, including nuclear powered warships, have visited Australia but there has never been an accident involving the weapons or the nuclear propulsion systems on board these vessels while in an Australian port.
Safety Issues

12.The worst credible hazard for any nuclear weapons that might be in visiting ships in Australian ports is a fire in the magazine. The effects of a fire conceivably could include the detonation of the conventional explosives in the nuclear weapon. However the risk of this type of accident is very remote. And the general design features and crew training of modern warships are calculated to minimise the effect of any fire, to contain damage and to contain any radioactive material that might be released within the ship's hull.

13.Any nuclear weapons that might be carried in visiting allied warships are safely stowed according to detailed safety procedures. They would be under armed guard in their magazines. They would be in an unarmed condition, electrically disconnected, isolated from stray electrical currents and able to be sprayed, smothered and/or flooded in the event of a ship fire. They would not be handled or used in training.

14.In addition to these safeguards in ships' magazines, nuclear weapons have a number of special safety features; for example, US nuclear weapons must comply with four safety standards, requiring positive measures to:
a.prevent nuclear weapons involved in accidents, or jettisoned weapons, from producing a nuclear yield;
b.prevent deliberate prearming, arming, launching, firing, or releasing of nuclear weapons except upon execution of emergency war orders or when directed by competent authority;
c.prevent inadvertent prearming, arming, launching, firing or releasing of nuclear weapons in all normal and credible abnormal environments; and
d.ensure adequate security of nuclear weapons.
15.A positive measure is a design feature, safety device, or procedure that exists solely or principally to provide nuclear system safety.
16.The Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade in its report concluded that:

a.`. . . the known accident/incident records of the United States and British Navies do not demonstrate that a risk arises during port visits by vessels from these navies of sufficient magnitude to warrant contingency planning for a nuclear weapon accident.' (11.114); and

b.`While accidents of the kind noted in paragraphs 12.65 [collision resulting in loss of weapon overboard] and 12.66 [collision resulting in exposure of fissile material] may be more credible than those discussed earlier in the chapter [12], the consequences were they to occur are limited. Accidents of this kind are sufficiently similar to ordinary shipping accidents to be dealt with under the general port safety plans which currently exist.' (12.69).

17.Every port in Australia has a general emergency plan which would apply in the unlikely event of an accident involving a foreign warship. However, the risk of a major collision involving a foreign warship in an Australian port is very remote because of navigational practices and port restrictions on shipping movements.

18.These safety plans are the responsibility of the port authorities, naval or civil. The plans are developed in cooperation with States and Territory emergency services and include Federal support as necessary. The plans generally provide for a graduated response, relying in the first instance on the safety design features and crew expertise available in modern warships. Should this be insufficient, the resources of the port emergency services, including State, Territory and Federal support, are utilised. But all these arrangements address a remote contingency.
19.The remainder of this paper outlines the arrangements that would be involved in the unlikely event of an accident.
International Arrangements

20.The obligations of countries possessing nuclear weapons are defined in two international agreements. The United States and the United Kingdom are parties to the 1986 Convention on Early Notification of a Nuclear Accident (CENNA) and the 1986 Convention on Assistance in the Case of a Nuclear Accident or Radiological Emergency (CACNARE).

21.While the undertakings made in the CENNA concern early notification of reactor accidents, all five acknowledged nuclear weapon nations (USA, UK, France, USSR and China) have declared that in addition to their obligation to provide such notification, they will notify other countries of any nuclear weapon accident which has or might have significant radiological effects in another country.

22.The main provisions of the CACNARE that are relevant to visits by nuclear-armed warships are Articles 1 and 3. These provisions would enable Australia to request assistance from both the US and UK in meeting a nuclear or radiological emergency resulting from a nuclear weapons accident. The overall direction and control of assistance within Australian territory would be the responsibility of the Australian Government.

23.In addition, the Australian Defence Force is party to two agreements with the defence forces of the USA, United Kingdom, Canada and New Zealand—within the AUSCANUKUSNZ Air Standardisation Co-ordinating Committee (ASCC)—which also defines responsibilities in the event of an accident. The Air Standards which are relevant to nuclear weapon accidents are:
a.Air Standard 84/12—Peacetime Nuclear Accidents—

TAB.TAB: Division of Responsibilities; and

SPEECH.PARA: b.Air Standard 84/13—Peacetime Nuclear Accident Key

TAB.TAB: Control Areas.

SPEECH.PARA: 24.Under the aegis of these agreements—which apply to all the armed services of the participating countries—the specific obligations in the event of a nuclear weapon accident are identified. The significant and agreed issues are:

a.The custodial nation (ie, the weapon/s owner) is required to advise the host nation (the nation with sovereignty over the land or territorial waters in which an accident occurs) that an accident has taken place.
b.The overall command, control and coordination of the response to a nuclear weapon accident are the responsibility of the host nation.
c.The custodial nation is responsible for rendering safe, recovering, salvaging and disposing of its nuclear weapon/s and other associated equipment and materials.

d.If a weapon is lost in its territorial waters or economic zone, the host nation has overall responsibility for the maritime operations necessary to recover the weapon. During the recovery operation the custodial nation is to provide such assistance as might be requested and that it was able to provide.
e.Fire/crash rescue services and cordoning are the host nation's responsibility. The custodial nation is to provide support when requested for decontamination activities.
25.The practical applications of these agreements are:
a.Under CENNA and the two Air Standards, the custodial nation is obliged to advise the host nation (Australia) that an accident has occurred.
b.Under CACNARE and the Air Standards, the custodial nation is obliged to:

TAB.TAB: 1.co-operate with the Australian government to `facilitate prompt assistance in the event of a nuclear accident or radiological emergency to minimise its consequences' (CACNARE);
2.render safe, recover, salvage and dispose of the weapon and associated equipment and material;
3.provide such assistance as might be requested to effect the recovery of a weapon lost in the host nation's territorial waters or economic zone;
4.provide support, when requested, for decontamination activities; and
5.ensure that contamination remaining has been reduced to safe levels acceptable to and agreed with the host nation.

SPEECH.PARA: c.Under the Air Standards, the host nation (Australia) will:

TAB.TAB: 1.have responsibility for overall command and control of the response to an accident;
2.provide the necessary fire/crash rescue services; and
3.in the case of the loss of a weapon in its territorial waters or economic zone, have responsibility for the maritime operation mounted to recover the weapon.

SPEECH.PARA: Federal-State Arrangements
26.The Federal Government has primacy with respect to national capabilities in the nuclear science and engineering fields. In any post-accident scenario, it would have specific responsibility for:
a.all negotiations with the custodial nation;
b.overall coordination of Australian and the custodial nation's responses to an accident;
c.provision of a Federal Technical Advisor and equipment to assist the State or Territory during the accident response; and
d.provision of any assistance requested by the affected State or Territory.
27.The concerned State or Territory would be responsible for:
a.public safety to include;

TAB.TAB: 1.comprehensive education/media awareness programmes, designed to counter ill-informed statements on accidents and the results thereof;
2.pre-planned and exercised evacuation procedures for all relevant port areas; and
3.adequate emergency medical facilities.

SPEECH.PARA: b.provision of emergency services to include;

TAB.TAB: 1.provision of police, fire and ambulance;
2.provision of radiation monitoring teams and associated protective measures for all affected emergency services personnel; and
3.production and maintenance of comprehensive port emergency plans and procedures.

SPEECH.PARA: c.control of the on-site response operation with the ability to;

TAB.TAB: 1.define, implement and maintain a protective cordon around the accident site;
2.liaise with the affected warship and with Federal and custodial nation emergency personnel; and
3.provide all necessary assistance and/or direction to the public in the affected area.

SPEECH.PARA: Medical Aspects

28.Medical aspects of the Australian response remain a State and Territory matter. Advice, direction and support for Commonwealth and State and Territory authorities will be available from the Australian Radiation Laboratory and the Peter MacCallum hospital in Melbourne.

29.The Australian Radiation Laboratory and the Peter MacCallum Hospital were jointly designated as World Health Organisation collaborating centres for radiation emergency preparedness and assistance in 1989. Jointly these organisations conduct courses for medical personnel and health physicists in the care and handling of radiation accidents (including nuclear weapon accidents).
Administration

30.Visits by nuclear weapon capable and nuclear powered warships take place under the policies administered by the Visiting Ships Panel (Nuclear) (VSP[N]) which is a committee of Commonwealth officials. The Panel works closely with State and Territory officials responsible for the adequacy of port planning arrangements to confirm relevant information is available in general safety plans for ports which are visited by nuclear weapon capable warships.
Summary
31.In the unlikely event of a nuclear weapon accident on board a visiting USN or RN warship, the responsibilities of the parties would be determined in accordance with the following principles:

a.The custodial nation would be responsible for rendering safe, recovery, salvage and disposal of its nuclear weapon and all associated equipment and material and, ensuring that contamination remaining has been reduced to safe levels acceptable to, and agreed with the host nation (Australia). Additionally, it will seek to meet requests by the host nation (Australia) for any additional requests for decontamination assistance.
b.Australia, as the host nation, would be responsible for:

TAB.TAB: 1.development and maintenance of comprehensive response plans and procedures to cover its responsibilities in the event of a nuclear weapon accident;
2.clear delineation between Federal and State/Territory authorities with respect to on and off-site responsibilities; and
3.all necessary liaison with the custodial nation in the event of an accident.

SPEECH.PARA: c.The Federal Government would be responsible for overall coordination of the national response and for the provision of assistance to the States/Territory to permit the production and maintenance of the necessary plans and procedures.

d.The States and the Northern Territory would be responsible for the production, maintenance and exercising of comprehensive plans and procedures which will ensure their ability to react immediately in the event of a nuclear weapon accident. Such a reaction will include:

TAB.TAB: 1.establishment and maintenance of the accident cordon;
2.deployment of monitoring teams;
3.activation of evacuation plans as required;
4.activation of medical facilities and
5.liaison/coordination with both Federal and custodial nation personnel to effect recovery.

SPEECH.PARA: e.The Visiting Ships Panel (Nuclear) (VSP[N]) provides a mechanism for Commonwealth and State/Territory authorities with responsibilities for port safety to coordinate plans.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This response by the Government should be welcomed by everyone in the chamber. It addresses two of the matters foreshadowed in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade of more than two years ago to which the Government tabled a response four months later. We brought the report to the Parliament in August 1989 and the Government's response was tabled on 13 December that year. In that response it was foreshadowed that there would be a subsequent addressing of these two further matters—the emergency dry-docking arrangements and nuclear weapon accident planning.

PARA.TAB: Not only has there been some progress in the arrangements the Government has made to respond completely and satisfactorily to these matters, but there has also been a most important development in the announcement two months ago yesterday by President Bush of unilateral measures for the complete elimination of tactical nuclear weapons and the removal of tactical nuclear weapons from all United States ships. Some weeks later there was a response by President Gorbachev of the Soviet Union announcing a number of other decisions, including that the Soviet Union would also eliminate such weapons. The important point is that our ally, the United States—and it is this ally's ships that visit Australia—will be directly affected by the unilateral decision of the United States that the ships will no longer have these weapons. To quote the statement of President Bush that the Minister has cited:

SPEECH.PARA: The bottom line is that under normal circumstances, our ships will not carry tactical nuclear weapons.

Those who are sceptical of the United States living up to its declarations have in logical terms quite correctly said that we have never professed to be able to verify such an affirmation. To be realistic, that is something that both the Government and Opposition have long acknowledged, and I think the Australian Democrats also acknowledge that. That is why, when in recent years we have been urging these disarmament measures, we have said that there needs to be very careful verification. We need to be aware that, even with verification procedures in place, there could some evasion. However, no-one has seriously doubted the United States' intention to implement its own announcements.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to put any scepticism on the very welcome and very sound announcements that President Bush made two months ago, but I do note that the Minister for Defence included this sentence in the second page of his letter addressing this matter:

SPEECH.PARA: The President's announcement means that the need for planning in addition to existing port safety plans is further diminished.
It is realistic wording. He does not say that it is eliminated. I do not call into question the bona fides of the Government's response because it is realistic.

PARA.TAB: I note the paper on accident planning that has been included in this response put down today and which the Minister says is of some historical interest now. In particular, I note the responsibilities as they divide between this nation and the nation whose ships would be visiting our ports.

I believe that the response the Government has made today is in keeping with, and does positively respond to, those matters to which the Senate Committee alerted the Government some two years ago. As an Opposition senator who participated in that inquiry, I therefore welcome the Government's statement put down today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having recently submitted a question asking whether many of the recommendations of the original report have been implemented, I find this document of some interest as it deals with some of the questions I raised. I would like to make it clear that the peace movement will continue to oppose the deployment of US warships because, although we welcome President Bush's unilateral disarmament initiatives, the announcement of 27 September 1991 indicates that the nuclear weapons being withdrawn from US warships are not being destroyed but are simply being put into storage.

PARA.TAB: We also question the need for ship visits in the first place, since the alleged Soviet threat in the South Pacific and the Indian Ocean has now diminished. There never was any strategic need for these port calls and there is no need for them now. They are simply to show the flag and to give rest and recreation leave to the sailors, which many of us believe would be better spent at their own home ports and not in our ports.

The Minister's statement also perpetuates the myth that US nuclear warships have a great safety record. Recent reports have indicated quite clearly—I am referring here to the Arkin papers—that they have a terrible record, with 50 nuclear weapons at the bottom of the ocean after submarines sank and nine nuclear reactors also on the ocean floor. There has been a variety of other accidents involving nuclear weapons and nuclear powered warships. The only claim the US can make is that there has not been a significant accident in a port, and I would say that it has been very lucky up to now.

The record of other navies is equally deplorable, if not worse. One accident causing concern at the moment is the Soviet Kilo class submarine in the Bering Sea which Greenpeace asserts is now leaking radioactive contamination into that sea. It has always been very difficult to find out details of those accidents because nuclear navies are very reluctant to admit that accidents have happened at all or to release details. It is only by constant pressure that any details of accidents actually come out into the public arena.

This is largely due to the fact that nuclear navies are not monitored by anybody else. There is no independent assessment of their safety records. There is no equivalent of the International Atomic Energy Agency, for example, to monitor what the nuclear navies are doing at sea. The United States Government consistently refuses to allow naval arms control to be put onto any disarmament agenda. I saw it happen at the United Nations special session on disarmament in 1988. The United States has consistently refused to allow naval arms control to get onto the agenda. It does not want to be scrutinised for very obvious reasons.

I do question the assertion in the original report—and it has been reasserted in the Government's response here today—that the risk factor of nuclear accidents is so minimal. An accident is an accident. We do not really know when one will happen. As I said, the navies have been extremely lucky that none of these accidents has happened in a port. The testimony that accidents do happen for various reasons is lying on the ocean floor.

I want to make the point that the New Zealand Government's ban on nuclear ships covered both nuclear-powered and nuclear-armed ships. This is what we would like to see in Australia. Unfortunately, the National Government across the Tasman is seeking to review this policy now because it wants to get into bed with the Americans at very close quarters. The United States Government is just waiting for the New Zealand National Government to have the courage to try to revoke its anti-nuclear legislation. I do not think that it has a snowball's chance in hell of doing that, if it takes any notice of public opinion in New Zealand on that score. The people are as committed now as they ever were to New Zealand's nuclear free status. I commend them for that.

What has been interesting is that the New Zealand Government, in the form of the Prime Minister, Mr Bolger, is using this document, this 650-page report which took three years to complete and was totally inadequate—I would say erroneous—in its conclusions, to justify the reintroduction of nuclear-powered warships into New Zealand. I think he really needs to read the fine print and especially the dissenting report by former Senator Irina Dunn. There are so many unanswered questions. Over and over again that report showed that the United States Navy, which is the chief navy that we are concerned about because that is the one from which we receive most of these visits, consistently refused to supply information to the Committee. The Committee was hampered in its job over and over again by the United States Navy refusing to give any information. This is typical of nuclear navies. They are not the only ones which do that. As I said, the United States Navy is the one most relevant to us. The fact that the New Zealand Government is trying to revoke its nuclear-free legislation has raised some interesting questions about the `neither confirm nor deny' policy. As Senator Teague said, most people would expect that the Americans will do as they said they would do, which is to remove tactical weapons from their surface ships and submarines. It is another case of our having to trust them. Most people would. I think we have to be ever vigilant. This is why I would like independent monitoring of nuclear navies to be put in place. However, there is one significant rider to this claim that the United States has made:

SPEECH.PARA: The bottom line is that under normal circumstances, our ships will not carry tactical nuclear weapons.

That quote is taken from the documentation of President Bush's speech of 27 September. Now, `under normal circumstances' is the bit that we have to question. Who decides what are normal circumstances? Of course, it is the United States Government; it is just up to the United States Government to reintroduce these weapons at any time, if it sees fit. It will see fit if it feels that it needs to go into a particular region to protect its interests.

PARA.TAB: The global policing role is alive and well on the part of the United States foreign affairs department. It will make the decisions. We will have no say in them. There might be a situation of some tension internationally where these weapons, which we would hope have been removed from these ships, could be refitted very quickly to meet any contingency that the United States Government thinks it needs to meet in its own interests.

We would never be quite sure whether these ships actually had nuclear weapons on board. The `neither confirm nor deny' policy remains intact. I think that is the big flaw in this additional reply that the Government has now put out. It is not convincing at all. The peace movement will continue to oppose all port calls by United States nuclear warships, as it will continue to encourage our Government to work for naval arms control and other confidence building measures in the region.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to comment briefly on the letter from the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) to the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade dealing with a change in policy announced by President Bush on warships carrying nuclear weapons. Of course, the statement is welcome. In part, it states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the United States will withdraw all tactical nuclear weapons from its surface ships, attack submarines, as well as those nuclear weapons associated with our land-based naval aircraft.

It is part of the general de-escalation of the nuclear threat between the superpowers and as such, as I have said, it is extremely welcome. However, I echo the words of Senator Vallentine when she said that the critical flaw in that statement is:
The bottom line is that under normal circumstances, our ships will not carry tactical nuclear weapons.

Once again the question must be raised as to who decides, in what sort of circumstances and when we can be sure that ships visiting our ports do not carry such weapons. The answer is that we cannot be sure.

PARA.TAB: The second point is that these weapons have been taken from the ships, but have been placed in storage and can be put back at any time. The policy of the United States to neither confirm nor deny continues. In these circumstances, while the announcement in general terms is welcome, the Australian Democrats must put on record our concern that in basic facts nothing has really changed. We are still exposed to risks. The population in port cities is still very much at risk when United States navy and other navies which potentially carry nuclear weapons visit our shores.

We believe that at this point the Government, unless it can get an assurance that we will get specific confirmation or denial, should refuse entry to these ships. It is a natural consequence of a government's responsibility to have a concern for the safety of its citizens. We believe we should press the other governments which wish to have their ships visit our ports to give us individual assurances that tactical nuclear weapons—and other nuclear weapons for that matter—have been removed from those ships. Our concern also extends to nuclear-powered ships because accidents have not been confined to nuclear weapons.

The letter briefly states a range of measures which have been taken to reduce the adverse effects of an accident, should it happen, and these are welcome. The Australian Democrats continue to believe that it is the responsibility of government to exclude that risk as far as the Australian people are concerned.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Vanstone and on behalf of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, I present the Committee's report entitled, Who is to Guard the Guards?, an evaluation of the National Crime Authority, together with the transcript of evidence. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report is the culmination of over 12 months work by the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority. That Committee decided, I think in June or July last year, to undertake an evaluation of the Authority despite the fact that the previous Committee had suggested that that evaluation not take place for a further 12 months.

PARA.TAB: During the last 12 to 14 months, the Committee has taken a wide range of evidence from a wide range of people, including members of the police force, some of whom have worked in the Authority and some of whom have not; journalists from the Authority; civil liberties groups; and academics interested in this matter. The Committee wishes to express its gratitude to those people who did bother to put in submissions and make evidence available to the Committee. The Committee met on a number of occasions in a variety of States to take this evidence.

The report is unusual in that it deals with the Authority both when it was facing a difficult time and as it is now—a much calmer and steadier ship under the chairmanship of Justice Phillips. Justice Phillips is now going to leave the Authority and take up a position as Chief Justice of Victoria. I am sure that all coalition members very warmly congratulate him on having achieved that status in life where he will be undertaking the task that he has in some way been aspiring to over a period of time. It begs the question: who is going to take over the Authority?

This evaluation shows among a number of things that, in terms of efficiency, the Authority is very much a function of whoever happens to be chairman at the time. When Justice Stewart was Chairman, the Authority had one particular flavour or perception in the public arena. Then Mr Farris took over the chairmanship and the Authority had a different public perception altogether. Julian Leckie, currently a member of the Authority, had an interim chairmanship before Justice Phillips was appointed. This evaluation deals with the Authority across that time span and highlights how much it is a function of who happens to be the chairman. That, of course, begs the question: will the Government this time make as good an appointment as it did last time?

We would like to be able to say that, yes, of course it will. I very much hope that it does. I do not want at this time to go back into past appointments other than to say that it is abundantly clear to everyone who has come anywhere near the Authority that not all of its past appointments have been anywhere near up to scratch. One in particular caused some very serious problems in my State and in Senator Bolkus's State. There were very serious problems in the South Australian office of the National Crime Authority. Those problems were by and large the biggest problems that the Authority has had to face.

The report says that those problems were largely a function of this Government not listening to what it had been told and having a complete changeover in Authority membership all at the one time. The Chairman left and the two members of the Authority left on 30 June, and on 1 July a new Chairman and new members took the helm. To an extent that sudden changeover did play a role in those problems. So I think the Committee is right to draw attention to that.

Of course, that was not the beginning and the end of the matter. There were other causes for the problems in the Adelaide office. Not all of those causes have been addressed in this evaluation report by the majority members of the Committee. The dissenting report put in by the minority members, the coalition members, raises some of the issues which, as far as the coalition members are concerned, the majority has steadfastly refused to look at.

Some time ago, last year, the majority of the Committee put out a report on Operation Ark. That was an operation to investigate the manner in which the police have investigated themselves. Due to a police operation common to a number of States called Operation Noah, a number of members of the police force had been dobbed in, if you like, by members of the public as having some hand in drug dealings in the community. There was no certainty that those investigations had been properly carried out.

There was so much concern as to the conduct of those investigations by the police force into themselves that the Authority took on an operation, called Operation Ark, to investigate whether the police had investigated themselves properly. It was at the end of Justice Stewart's term that a report called Operation Ark was prepared. A letter of transmittal to the South Australian Government was signed by Justice Stewart with the expectation that that report would be delivered to the South Australian Government. We all know that events overtook the presentation of that report and that it was never intended to be presented by the Authority at that time.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robert Ray) adjourned.
Debate resumed from 14 November, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1991 contains some minor Budget measures and technical changes, most of which have a very minor financial impact. The first relates to the indexation of pensioners' earnings credits. At the moment it is possible for pensioners to earn up to $42 a week indexed before they start to reach the taxation threshold. This Bill allows for a degree of averaging of earnings so that pensioners are not unfairly disadvantaged by the pension income test if their earnings fluctuate. The scheme therefore encourages pensioners to earn amounts in addition to their pension. It is desirable that those limits be indexed from 2 July next year, and we therefore support that measure.

PARA.TAB: The second initiative relates to rent assistance. Currently, the maximum break in Jobsearch allowance and Newstart allowance entitlements before an individual is required to serve another waiting period for rent assistance is four weeks. For JSA recipients that will be increased to six weeks and for Newstart recipients to 13 weeks. Again, we think that is an important change which will accommodate those who quite often undertake irregular work in rural areas, such as itinerant casual labourers. It is desirable that they should not have to get back into the queue and wait simply because they have undertaken what was always going to be a short term period of employment.

The third change relates to a new limit on the amounts payable for new grants of income support to partnered persons. For claims granted after 12 March 1992, the maximum pension or benefit entitlement of a member of a couple living with a partner not receiving a social security pension, benefit or similar payment or who is receiving Abstudy will be the married rate of pension or half the married rate of benefit. Again, that change will not make any significant difference in terms of the current financial year because it operates only in the last quarter, but it will involve savings of the order of $11.29m over a full year. That is a streamlining of the system so that it will be possible at least to ensure that in some areas half the married rate is the appropriate level of payment. The proposal is necessary because currently some pensioners and beneficiaries have been able to claim more income support than is paid to each of the couple who are both receiving social security payments. We therefore support that initiative.

The fourth initiative is in relation to the Aboriginal employment incentive scheme. Under this change, persons receiving payments will have the equivalent amount deducted from the amount of social security income support they receive. In the interests of targeting welfare to those most in need, this is a desirable initiative and should be supported. It has a negligible financial impact.

The fifth initiative relates to the international social security agreements with the United Kingdom, Ireland and Portugal. The Bill inserts into the Social Security Act 1991 the agreements signed with Ireland and Portugal as schedules. This would seem to be one of the meagre returns we get from that infamous sum of $125,000-odd which the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) managed to chalk up in his odysseys overseas over the past 18 months or so. One of those trips was to the west coast of Ireland. We will really never know why. Certainly, there seems to be no good reason why the discussions could not have been held in Dublin. Nonetheless, Brian Burke and a few others thought that Galway would probably be a more attractive place to spend the night. As a result, we had extravagance on a grand scale. Senator Richardson would claim that the signing of the agreement is the benefit that flowed in due course.

The old reciprocal agreements between the United Kingdom and Australia are to be revived, given that in another respect that trip was spectacularly unsuccessful. The Government, despite much talk on the subject, failed to negotiate a new agreement with the United Kingdom which would ensure that Australia did not have to bear the brunt of topping up pensions. The UK has remained intransigent on this issue and has not agreed to the terms asked by Australia, in particular in relation to the indexation of pensions paid by the United Kingdom Government to its former citizens resident in Australia. The agreements do tend to limit the flexibility of our policies in relation to what can be paid to migrants once they have arrived, but in principle at least they are normally intended to result in net savings. In this instance the financial impact is estimated to be negligible, and on that basis we support the signing of those agreements.

The next change relates to an amendment to the data-matching program so that the date of birth of a living spouse will become one of the details that can be used in the data-matching process. It is an identifier that should have been in the legislation when the data-matching provisions were introduced last year. This would seem to be merely an amendment to rectify that oversight. Quite clearly, the date of birth of a living spouse is one of those unique characteristics that only a very limited number of people would be aware of in relation to themselves. Therefore it would seem to be a quite useful check in the system, and we would support that change as well.

That covers the ambit of the original Bill. There are now some amendments of substance which the Government is moving in relation to extending the Jobsearch allowance and the Newstart allowance to farmers. I will have something to say in the committee stage about the form of the amendments and, indeed, I will move several amendments on behalf of the Opposition at that time. In general principle, we support the desirability of recognising that there are farmers who are not able to earn a living from farming activities at the present time, who are viable in the longer term but need a degree of income support to tide them over. Currently, it is necessary for them to be looking actively for work away from the farm. That can serve as an almost automatic disqualification for most farmers.

These new provisions will at least introduce hardship provisions quite similar to those applicable to the family allowance and family allowance supplement, which we dealt with in the preceding social security Bill. We are in general sympathy with the thrust of the Government's amendments, but we think there is a need for several refinements in order to ensure that the same matters are taken into account in assessing hardship as operate now in relation to the family allowance and family allowance supplement. I will provide more detail in due course and, in particular, outline the approach we would take in government.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1991 contains a number of important measures affecting the social security portfolio and a series of Government amendments—which we have seen only fairly recently and which have not been through the House of Representatives—which give effect to the Government's recently announced rural hardship package for farmers, ostensibly to enable farming families greater access to income support under the social security system.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats have major problems with two areas of the legislation. These are the proposed treatment of compensation payments to sole parents and the inadequacy of the rural hardship package. I will deal with those two areas later. Firstly, however, there are a number of other measures in this Bill which are generally positive—they are certainly quite significant.

The Bill provides for the indexation of the earnings credit limit for pensioners. Basically, the earnings credit scheme allows full rate pensioners to accrue their weekly income test free limits up to $1,000 in a year in order that they offset the accrued amount against earnings that would otherwise reduce their pensions under the income test. Once the limit is reached, the normal income test provisions apply. This provision for earnings credit has certainly proved a very effective tool in encouraging some pensioners to take up part time and casual work, and the Democrats welcome this move.

In this Bill there are also some changes to rent assistance waiting periods. I would argue that these are long overdue. Previously, where Jobsearch allowance and Newstart beneficiaries were receiving rent assistance and then ceased to be entitled to JSA or Newstart for four weeks, they had to wait 26 weeks to requalify for rent assistance. The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3), which passed through here a few weeks ago, reduced that 26 week wait to 18 weeks. This Bill now extends the permissible break in income entitlements to six weeks for JSA and 13 weeks for Newstart recipients as from 1 March next year. This also means that, where a person is not entitled to benefits for no more than these periods, he or she will be able to count the weeks already served while receiving the benefit towards the 18-week waiting period.

Since I came into the Senate, I have consistently called for, and moved amendments to give effect to, reductions in social security waiting periods. It is quite clear that waiting periods cause considerable and unnecessary hardship and that the sole rationale behind them seems to be to cut costs rather than to address in any way the suffering that they cause. They certainly do nothing to relieve the problems of those people who are forced, through no fault of their own, to rely on government income support.

The Opposition seems determined to see these reductions as some sort of subsidy to the private rental market—I am relying on some comments about previous legislation. I have some difficulty reconciling this view with the Opposition's desire to reduce the public housing sector. Where exactly do those opposite think low income earners will live? As we see from the number of people on our streets, there is not enough public housing to go around. We can also look to the long waiting lists in every State for evidence of this.

Data collected by the national housing strategy clearly pinpoints the enormous stresses that housing costs place on many lower income families, particularly in times of recession when the breadwinners are unemployed. The strategy's data indicates that about 10 per cent of all households in this country are suffering very severe housing related stress and that many people are paying up to 50 per cent and more of their income in rent.

The current situation for private renters is that housing is often extremely expensive, especially in the inner urban areas of our large cities where it is frequently of poor quality, and the ability to access affordable private rental housing often forces people out to the extremities, out to areas where their employment prospects may be reduced or where there may be less infrastructure to support the needs of families, particularly young families. That does not make much sense in economic or labour market terms and improved access to rent assistance is one, admittedly limited, way of making some inroads into this problem.

This Bill also makes changes to the pharmaceutical allowance. This allowance was introduced to offset the charge for pharmaceuticals for people who had previously had their prescriptions filled free under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. In response to concerns about how the charge could affect chronically ill persons, the Government agreed that advances of the allowance could be claimed in certain circumstances and people were subject to a liquid assets test. This Bill extends the period in which advance payments are payable to 31 December 1993, removes the assets test, and aligns indexation of the allowance with other legislation. We welcome these moves and I want to remind the Senate that, at the time the prescription charge was introduced last year, the Australian Democrats stated that we felt the eligibility criteria for advance payments were far too narrow. I moved amendments in the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs to relax them. These amendments were defeated then, so I am now somewhat gratified to see the liquid assets test dumped altogether.

However, it remains the case that, in order to qualify for an advance payment, a person must still not have an ordinary income in excess of $20 per fortnight. These income levels are most ungenerous and they operate to ensure that only the poorest of the poor pensioners—and legislation which will be put through here later tonight will include veterans as well—have access to advance payments for the allowance.

I do not want to go over this ground in great detail now, but I want to make it clear that we really do not yet know the full impact of the prescription charge. We simply do not have the evidence to say with authority that there has been any effect on pensioners' consumption patterns, doctors' prescribing habits or, indeed, the health of pensioners. In fact, anecdotal evidence from pensioner organisations indicates that the limited income test for receiving advance payments may be disadvantaging those pensioners who have been unable to afford the $10 or $12 to fill multi-scripts and who are deciding, upon their own initiative, which two or three medications they will not bother having the script filled for—in other words, they put it off until the next pension cheque arrives. We do not plan to move any amendments to these provisions tonight, but I ask the Minister to give consideration to raising the limits of the income test for advance payments of the allowance.

There is also a provision in this Bill to bring the maximum penalties under the Social Security Act into line with the same level of penalties for fraud under the Crimes Act. This means that the maximum imprisonment period for social security fraud will increase from six months to two years. Essentially, the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions has been prosecuting social security fraud under the Crimes Act because of the higher penalties in that Act. However, I understand that a recent South Australian case has held that the self-incrimination provisions of the Crimes Act prevent DSS review forms being used as evidence by the prosecution. So it seems that DSS wants it both ways: it will push for the higher penalties available under the Crimes Act, but it does not want to be subject to the same rules against self-incrimination.

Again, we do not intend to move any amendments, as I accept the Government's point that fraud in these instances should be viewed very seriously. However, I wish to make the point that, regardless of which Act is used, there remain serious sentencing discrepancies between people who are convicted of taxation fraud and those who are convicted of social security fraud. Earlier this year we saw some remarkable sentencing discrepancies in Victoria.

We accept these changes, but I ask the Minister to monitor closely the sentences being handed out for social security fraud and, in particular, the prosecution practices of the DPP in relation to taxation and social security fraud. The Government should be very strongly committed to ensuring that both types of fraud are pursued with equal vigour and that we do not encourage the totally unacceptable double standard that somehow social security fraud is worse than taxation fraud.

The Bill also proposes cuts in income support to certain couples. This is a major concern. At present, where only one member of a couple receives income support, the maximum rate that that person can receive is the same as for a single person. From 1 March 1992 the maximum rate the person can receive will be reduced to half the married rate of benefit. This reduction will also apply to rates of pharmaceutical allowance and remote area allowance payable to a member of a couple with a non-pensioner/beneficiary partner. It will not apply to existing pensioners and beneficiaries as at 11 March 1991 and it will apply only to a person who is actually living with his or her non-pensioner/beneficiary partner.

The Government argues that there is no justification for paying the higher rate to a person simply because his or her partner does not receive any income. Certainly there are some instances where this would be true. However, there are a number of circumstances where this move will cause undue hardship. I refer to those cases where the person's partner is not actually receiving any income at all from any source. Welfare groups have provided me with examples of where this could easily occur—such as where the partner does not have permanent resident status.

There is a strong argument for targeting this proposal in a much better fashion to avoid reducing the income to those families who are already living off a single benefit. It really does not make much sense to foist even greater hardship on couples and indeed families in these circumstances. I understand that the Minister is prepared to take a closer look at this issue, and I will be following this up in Committee.

Other provisions in the Bill cover technical amendments incorporating recent changes to the Act—prepayments, improvements in access to child disability allowance, reciprocal agreements between Australia and Ireland and Australia and Portugal and so on. We have no objection to any of these proposals.

I now turn to the two areas which I mentioned earlier and which are of major concern to the Democrats. First, I turn to the issue of compensation payments to sole parents. Under this Bill persons receiving social security payments who are injured while doing part time or low income work while they are receiving the pension or benefit and who then receive periodic—usually weekly—compensation payments will have their compensation treated as ordinary income; that is, the ordinary income test will apply.

This is a change from the current situation where such payments are reduced dollar for dollar, creating a poverty trap which discourages people from returning to work. This is a step in the right direction. However, sole parent pension is to be included in the list of payments which are still subject to a dollar for dollar deduction when the person receives lump sum or periodic compensation, outside the particular circumstances I mentioned. I cannot see this measure as anything other than cost cutting and one that really overlooks some fundamental legal principles about the relationship between compensation and the social security system.

It should be noted that no similar measure is proposed for age pensions. I think that shows up this move very clearly for what it is. It is targeting a group of people that the Government believes cannot organise any opposition. But it is the disregard for the principle of compensation that concerns me most. There has always been a quite legitimate argument for preventing double dipping—that is, that a person should not be compensated twice for the same disability or injury. In other words, if a person is receiving, for example, sickness allowance because of an injury and subsequently receives a compensation payment for the same injury, he or she cannot take the benefit of both. That is a well-accepted principle and I have no dispute with it. But sole parent pension is not a payment that is related to a person's incapacity to work. It is a payment that is made to enable a sole parent to care properly for a child or children. Accordingly, as the pension and the compensation are not related, the ordinary income tests should still apply.

To look at the matter in another way, if a person is working in an ordinary job and receives compensation for, say, a car accident that occurred several years ago, we would not expect them to give up part of his or her salary simply because that person had received a benefit from some other source.

Now in relation to pensions and benefits an ordinary income test applies. There may be some disagreement about the levels of that test, but essentially an income from another source will affect the rate of pension. Again, nobody has any dispute with that general principle but, if a sole parent receives compensation for an injury, I cannot see why that should not be subject to the same ordinary income test. It is clearly not a case of double dipping, so why should sole parents be penalised dollar for dollar?

This proposal will lead to inconsistencies between sole parent pension recipients, depending upon when they receive their compensation and when they claim the pension. We will be moving a series of amendments which will prevent this measure from proceeding, and I urge Opposition senators to give them serious consideration. There is a principle involved here. We are not talking about a rort or any sort of unfair advantage being given to sole parents. We simply want them to be treated in the same way as are other pensioners.

Finally, I come to the rural hardship package. First, we welcome at least some acknowledgment by the Government that there really is a problem out there. We welcome the fact that the Government has now recognised that existing income support provisions for farm families are totally inadequate. That acknowledgment backs up what we have been saying in this place now for over well over a year. To expect potentially viable farmers who are in severe financial hardship to have to put their means of earning a living on the market before they become eligible for minimal income support is completely unreasonable. In fact, to expect people to have to make such a major and traumatic decision as to leave a lifetime's work because they have no income with which to buy food is barbaric and heartless.

It is very clear that the current arrangements have been for a long time totally unsatisfactory. However, honourable senators will recall that as recently as two weeks ago the Democrats tried to provide relief for farmers through an amendment to the Social Security Act which would have exempted farmers' tools of trade, that is, their work assets, from the assets tests for all social security pensions and benefits. That amendment did not receive support from either the Government or the Opposition.

Because I consider the hardship package that is before us tonight to be totally inadequate, I will be putting the same amendment again. I urge those people in this chamber with a genuine concern for the future of country families to give it very serious consideration. The Democrats believe that exempting the tools of trade from assets tests for all education and income support payments is the simplest, most equitable and most workable way to remove the discrimination against rural families which is contained in the existing system. Given the record of support so far, I will not hold my breath, but there is always some hope.

Let us look at the package that is now before us. What exactly is the Government offering? The aim is to make unemployment benefits—Jobsearch and Newstart allowances—available to some farmers. The publicity surrounding the announcement suggested that this was a wonderful and innovative measure, but then when one looked closely at the proposals one gathered that only 2,000 farmers would benefit. I was in northern South Australia and could not understand how it would be possible that only such a small number of farmers could benefit—having visited an area where probably that number would be eligible almost immediately. Having seen the package, I now understand what is happening. However, having looked at the package, I wonder how it will reach even that number.

The scheme will work by enabling a rural adjustment scheme authority to certify under section 26 that a farmer is a `financial hardship farmer' if the person is in severe financial hardship, if commercial credit cannot be obtained to finance continued farm operations on the farm, if part C assistance under RAS is not available, if the farm is likely to be profitable in the long term, and if the person is available for and is willing to do full time paid work.

In addition, the RAS authority must also be satisfied that under normal circumstances the person and his or her partner contributes a significant amount of his or her labour and capital to the farm and where the farm would normally provide the person's principal source of income. A further impediment, it goes on, to obtaining a certificate is that the farmer must actually apply for assistance under part C of the RAS scheme.

After obtaining this certificate—those who are able to do so—the RAS authority can then issue a second certificate under section 27 that an asset of a financial hardship farmer is unrealisable. Basically, the question is whether in the long term the farm is profitable. In other words, the rules are so difficult to get through that we are beginning to understand why on government estimates only 2,000 farmers would make it.

Assets that can be excluded as certified under section 27 are the farm itself, farm livestock and farm machinery. In addition, unrealisable assets are redefined in section 11 of the legislation to include an asset where a section 27 certificate is in force, and a life insurance policy on the life of a financial hardship farmer.

Persons who have jumped through all these hoops and climbed over all these hurdles and who have a certificate saying they are financial hardship farmers can then receive Jobsearch or Newstart allowances if they are at least 18 years of age, are Australian residents, are registered with the CES, have satisfied the activity test and, in the case of Newstart, are prepared to enter one of the Newstart agreements. Then, of course, they have to take reasonable steps to comply with them.

An assets test presently applies on other payments and these new measures enable farmers to have their assets declared unrealisable via the section 27 certification process. Under existing financial hardship rules there is provision to disregard the value of an unrealisable asset in working out the rate of a person's pension or benefit. Presumably, the new definition of an unrealisable asset will enable more farmers to access pensions and benefits via the hardship rules. A decision made by an RAS authority to refuse a section 26 or section 27 certificate is a non-reviewable decision under section 1250. This means that farmers cannot appeal to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal against a decision not to grant them a certificate. They have nowhere to go.

There is a sunset clause in the package which cuts off assistance under these provisions in November 1993. There are problems involved with this. For a start, it is absolutely ridiculous that farmers will be forced for apply for RAS part C in order even to get to first base. I remind honourable senators that part C exists to provide household assistance to farm families who are leaving the land.

Aside from the issue of whether it should be the Government that decides whether or not a farm property is viable, why should farmers have to apply for assistance to leave the land in order to get assistance to stay on the land? It is unfair, it is illogical and it is certainly the wrong way to go about it. It is simply the wrong way round. Surely it makes more sense for farmers to be assessed first and then advised which option is best for them and what exactly their options are.

I also remind honourable senators that, once a farmer has applied for and been granted part C assistance, he or she cannot receive a social security benefit. Farmers have three options in these circumstances. If they apply for and get part C assistance, they have to get off the land. If they accept the assistance and later decide they want to stay on the land, they have to pay it back. If they do not want to get off the land because they genuinely believe their farms are viable but the RAS authority disagrees, then they are stuck without any income support whatsoever. It is a woeful range of choices. This is why we argue that it makes far more sense to have the RAS assessment done first.

One can only speculate about whether the Government's agenda is really about providing income support for farm families or getting as many of them as possible off the land. We will be moving an amendment deleting the requirement that farmers must apply for RAS part C. It should be noted that they still need to be assessed; they simply do not have to go through the nonsense of applying for something that they will not be pursuing.

Another problem is that the certificate granted under section 26 will be available for only three months. Why? Obviously, there should be some time limit but three months seems extraordinarily short, especially given the somewhat convoluted process involved in getting a certificate in the first place. We think six months is a far more reasonable and realistic time period and we will be moving an amendment to this effect.

We also question why there is a two-year sunset clause. We see absolutely no reason why we need to limit this package to a two-year period. Perhaps the Government is expecting a miraculous recovery out there in the bush. There are certainly no indications from everything I have read that that will happen, unfortunately, as much as we would like it to.

Finally, why is the decision of an RAS authority to refuse to issue a certificate not reviewable by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal? It is clear from this package that the RAS authorities are being given an enormous amount of power in assessing the range of factors. Many of these factors are entirely subjective or rely upon an assessment of facts that may very well be disputed very strongly by the farmer and the farm family.

For example, what is severe financial hardship? What does `commercial credit' mean? Is it a loan offered at current market rates or within 3 per cent of market rates or 4 per cent of market rates? Does it include taking out a second mortgage or a stock mortgage? Does it mean that one can still get one's groceries on credit or does the local store have to have cut one off altogether?

These are judgments that should be reviewable if only because they take away some of the tin god power from RAS authorities. They should be reviewable within the framework of the Social Security Act not via some cosy administrative arrangement set up by the same body that is making the decisions.

The principal of independent review of bureaucratic decisions is an important one. Unfortunately, it is not a principle for which this Government has shown the greatest amount of respect. I urge Opposition senators to ensure that farmers have access to independent review. We are glad that the Government is doing something. It is better than nothing—only marginally, but at least it is better. Difficult and flawed as it is, it is a slight improvement.

We still believe that the approach that we have been pushing for some time is a better way of assisting farmers. I can only say this one more time to Liberal and National Party senators: if they are serious about getting real help for this country's farmers, they should support the Democrats' amendments which will have the effect of totally exempting farm assets from the assets test on social security pensions and benefits.

For the benefit of those honourable senators who have not listened to this debate before, this does not mean that all farmers are exempt from everything. It means that farmers are being placed on a level playing field with all other Australians when it comes to dealing with the social security system. They will be dealing with a social security system on the basis of need. The income test will still apply, as will every other assets test. All we are exempting is the work related assets. For the last time, I urge Opposition senators to give this their support. It is simple, it is equitable and it is certainly a far more workable way of assisting all farmers in need than is this Government package.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1991 where it refers to the rural adjustment package for farming families. Among other things, the Bill introduces a Jobsearch allowance for farmers. While I appreciate what the Government is doing with this Jobsearch allowance, I suggest that it would be more beneficial to farmers if it were a family allowance support.

PARA.TAB: On 29 October the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) issued a press release which said that the provisions will target farmers who fall between RAS part B, carry on assistance, and part C, which is re-establishment assistance—those who have prospects of longer term profitability but cannot carry extra debt even with interest subsidies.

That indicates to me that the farmers that this legislation is aiming at are viable farmers, yet the Bill introduces Jobsearch which, in effect, means that the farmers have to go out and search for jobs. If a farmer is viable and is going to stay on the land he will have to produce a crop for next year. If it rains, and if there is a market for his commodity, hopefully he will get back into a profitable situation, or he will have to look after his animals or his stock. But if he is forced to look for a job sometimes up to 150 kilometres away, by definition—and I hope the Minister is listening to this—he will not be viable because he will not be there to produce a crop or maintain his equipment and look after his animals.

The provisions are made when assets exceed the assets test of $157,000 but meet hardship provisions. The hardship provisions are defined as liquid assets of less than $10,000 and yearly income of less than $13,708, plus $624 per child. The Government has put a two-year hardship clause on the provisions. A statement put out by ABARE on 20 November said that broadacre farms are expected to record an average farm business loss of around $30,000, yet this package targets 2,000 farmers. I do not know where the other 40,000 farmers who are going to be in need of this assistance are going to look, but there will certainly be more than 2,000 farmers. In Queensland alone I believe there are 10,000 grain farmers who need assistance.

It is a time of high interest rates and very low commodity prices. On top of all that, we have had a drought. Our farmers are in an almost diabolical situation. I do not know how to paint a picture of what is happening out in the bush. Usually the farmers who are in danger are those at the lower end, the beginners, those who have just been given a farm by their family or gone through a drought or a death. The scale has now moved up to where probably 50 per cent of farmers are in danger. If the drought does not break or commodity prices do not rise, the scale will go even higher.
