It is an absolutely desperate situation out there. One would have to experience it to understand what is happening. There are suicides and family break-ups. People are so desperate that they are becoming introverted. They are not game to go down the street. They do not have the petrol to go out. They are looking to decide what they can put in the grocery trolley. I find myself inadequate to describe the desperation in the rural sector at the moment.

The industry has to be considered the backbone of the nation. We are going through times of desperation. If we do not look after these family farms, if we do not support them in the short term, we will not have any export income in the long term. That is going to hurt Australia now and far into the future. We have to stand behind the farmers now. While I appreciate this package that the Government has provided—this additional $20m to support 2,000 farmers—it is really like putting farmers on a drip and keeping them there, just surviving.

I said that I appreciate this package, and I certainly do. Any assistance should be appreciated. However, in 1983 there was a drought right across Australia—commodity prices were reasonable but there was a terrible drought—and the Government of the day put in $340m. In today's terms, that would probably be equivalent to $500m or $600m. The benefit of that assistance was that when the drought broke farmers had stock and equipment and they could get right back on the job. This Government has made some provision for assistance, and tonight I will not attack the Government about the adequacy of what it has provided. This is not a situation in which to score political points; it is time for the Senate to go through the amendments to see which ones can be carried and what provisions can be made for the thousands of farmers who are in terrible trouble.

The package that is offered here has to be looked at in the context that it is part of a rural adjustment scheme. Part A of that rural adjustment scheme is an interest subsidy for farmers for commercial loans or term loans. Assistance is up to 50 per cent of the annual interest. The limit of borrowings is $400,000. At a current rate of approximately 16 per cent per annum, on borrowings of $400,000 that is equivalent to 8 per cent interest subsidy. Assistance is for up to seven years, subject to annual review, when the subsidy may be reduced.

Part B is for carry-on or yearly working expenses. Assistance is up to 50 per cent of the annual interest rate. The limit on borrowings is around $100,000, at a current rate of 16 per cent per annum. There is maximum assistance of 8 per cent of $100,000, or about $8,000 a year, in interest subsidy. The assistance is reviewed annually and also includes drought aid. It comes down to a flat rate of 6 per cent for between two years and seven years. There is a maximum advance of $100,000 and it is to be used on restocking.

Part C is for people who have decided that they cannot stay on their farms any longer and it gives household support until they sell the farm. The farm must be listed. It is there to alleviate the personal hardship of farmers prior to adjusting out of farming. The payments are in line with unemployment benefits and are paid quarterly in advance. Those are the people to whom the Government is paying household support. It is ironic that the Government is paying household support to those people who have been declared non-viable when it is putting Jobsearch on farmers who are viable. I hope the Minister can see the inconsistency there. They also receive unemployment benefits. Married couples receive $503 per fortnight, plus $53 for each child under 13 and $77 for children aged between 13 and 16.

The package we are discussing tonight fits between part B and part C, which is for those people who have made the decision, or had it made for them, that they are no longer viable. Those people also get assistance of up to $34,000 to re-establish themselves in a home in the city. If they have received household support since July 1990, or for longer than six months, the amount of assistance provided in excess of six months shall be deducted from the amount of the re-establishment advance.

What we are discussing is access to the social security benefit for people who fit between part B and part C. These people have been subjected to a work test under this legislation, and the shadow Minister responsible for social security, Senator Richard Alston, will be moving an amendment to take care of this inconsistency. The Australian Democrats have not seen that amendment—it is being prepared at the moment—but I am confident that Senator Lees, with her consistent attitude towards these problems, will support that amendment when it is shown to her. I believe that there has been discussion with Senator Richardson, who is not in the chamber at the moment but I hope will be here when the Bill goes through the committee stage.

A number of questions have to be asked and put on the record. Will these payments be retrospective to December 1991? At the moment, the Department of Social Security and the other departments administering these rural adjustment schemes are having tremendous problems servicing the number of people who are coming in.

In Queensland, 974 farmers claimed some form of assistance in October. That is choking the Department that administers the rural adjustment scheme. We were told today that it is taking up to three months in Western Australia for a claim to be processed. The Minister must assure us that additional funds will be made available to the rural adjustment authorities for the purpose of putting on extra staff to process these claims and applications.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose Senator Lees makes a good point. But someone has to actually process these claims. As there is a three-month wait in Western Australia and 974 claims made in October in Queensland, one would have to concede that there is tremendous pressure on these departments that are trying to process these claims and get farmers some sort of assistance.

PARA.TAB: Both Senator Lees and I have mentioned that there is only enough money at the moment to cover 2,000 people. I estimate that there are 40,000 people in need of some form of rural adjustment. Certainly, there will be if the drought does not break or if it extends further. If people are not receiving sufficient money, it is probably because commodities are being subsidised, forcing the price of commodities down in Australia to under the cost of production, as was the case last year with wheat. Farmers received in their pocket something like $70 a tonne for their wheat, yet their actual cost of production would have been around $130 to $140 a tonne. The more wheat they grew, the quicker they went into receivership. This year, many of them decided that they would not grow wheat because they could not afford to sustain another loss. I think it costs something like $65 an acre to actually produce a crop. A conservative farm would grow around 15,000 acres of wheat, the cost for which would be in the vicinity of $50,000. This raises another point which Senator Alston has taken into consideration. Under this legislation, for every $250 that a farmer has, he loses $1 in returns from the benefits that he receives. If these farmers are deemed to be viable, they must have adequate funds to plant a crop, shear their sheep and fill their diesel tanks. We are talking now about farmers who have been declared viable under the rural adjustment scheme. Under the legislation that the Government proposes, for every $10,000 in cash that a farmer has, he loses $40; in today's terms, $10,000 is almost insignificant. I have said already that it costs a farmer who plants 15,000 acres of wheat at, say, $65 an acre around $50,000 to $60,000. If the farmer has $60,000 with which to plant his crop, he will almost inevitably lose the total assistance package.

Senator Alston, on behalf of the Opposition, will move an amendment that will disregard the assets for the purpose of this section, such as other essential and usual expenditure incurred in the operation of the farm. It is absolutely essential that that amendment be carried. If it were not to be carried in the Senate—I am confident that it will because I believe Senator Lees and her colleagues will support it; it will have the support of every person on this side of the House—the farmers we are trying to assist will be wiped out. We would find that very few viable farmers who rely on this part of the rural adjustment scheme which fits between C and B would get any assistance at all. They would then be forced to go into part C, which is for farmers who have been declared non-viable, and to move off the farm.

We also have to know whether the Government is prepared to give a total commitment to the family farm. It is essential that we make a decision as to whether we want the family farm to exist. We cannot dole out little bits of $20m. A total commitment from the Government has to be forthcoming. I urge the Government to make this commitment. I know that it has many other commitments that it has to meet and face with unemployment and various other things. But unless the Government and, for that matter, all people in both Houses of Parliament get firmly behind the family farm, we will destroy a viable institution that has provided this country with wealth, prosperity and jobs for the last 100 years.

I urge everyone in this Parliament to realise that. The things that we do well are mining and growing. If we lose half of that and the growing sector of our primary industries, it will take a long while for this nation to recover because we will have lost one of the best assets that Australia has.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1991. As with the Social Security Amendment Bill (No.3), which was debated earlier this month, this Bill provides the legislative framework for a number of changes to the social security system which were announced in the 1991 Budget.

PARA.TAB: By way of amendment, this Bill also includes the social security related special assistance provisions for farmers in severe financial hardship that were announced by the Government in its special package for farmers. I would like to concentrate on the provisions in this Bill which emanate from the 1991 Budget, as my colleagues have dealt with the special amendments to the Social Security Act that are proposed specifically to deal with the rural crisis.

First, this Bill provides that a person who temporarily ceases receiving either the Jobsearch allowance or the Newstart allowance will be able to count their most recent previous period on these benefits for rental assistance waiting period purposes. The maximum amount of time that a person may cease receiving these benefits to be eligible for this provision is six weeks for the Jobsearch allowance and 13 weeks for Newstart allowees.

In effect, this Budget announcement will mean that people previously receiving rental assistance who undertake temporary work for no longer than these specified periods will continue to receive rental assistance if they are forced back onto the benefit. The coalition supports this worthwhile initiative which will alleviate one of the disincentives for unemployed people taking up temporary or seasonal work opportunities.

Secondly, this Bill provides that the earnings credit limit for maximum rate pensioners, which currently stands at $1,000 per year for singles and $2,000 per year for married couples, will be indexed with inflation to maintain its real value from the first pension payday in July 1992. This earnings credit acts as an incentive for pensioners to maintain some degree of self-sufficiency and, as such, it is only right and sensible that it be indexed according to the CPI. Hence the coalition supports this initiative. However, in light of the considerable concerns being expressed by pensioners about the relevance of the CPI to their spending patterns, I would appreciate it if the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) could provide the Senate with an update of the analysis currently being undertaken by his Department in relation to this matter.

A further initiative which the coalition supports on the grounds of equity and fairness is the decision to restrict the level of benefit paid to a married new beneficiary after 11 March 1992 to half the married rate if the person-spouse with whom that person is living is not receiving a benefit. This will also apply to the rate of pharmaceutical allowance paid.

Given the financial advantage in terms of paying for life's necessities that people enjoy in situations of nuptial or de facto cohabitation, it is inequitable for a beneficiary with a working spouse to receive the single rate of benefit. For many years our social security system has recognised the existence of this comparative financial advantage, and married couples have been paid a married rate of benefit. This initiative will merely extend a long accepted precedent to couples where the partner is not receiving a benefit. The coalition believes that this proposal is necessary as some beneficiaries and pensioners have been able to claim more income support than is paid when each member of a couple is receiving social security payments.

When I read a Government paper outlining the initiatives contained in the 1991 Budget which would affect the social security portfolio, I was shocked to find that the Social Security Act would need amending to ensure that prepaid benefits which are paid to a person who is not entitled to them can be treated as a debt owing to the Commonwealth. I immediately thought, `Surely we are locking the door long after the horse has bolted?'. After all, the Department of Social Security has for many years been paying prepaid benefits and pensions when a public holiday falls on DSS payday. A very large amount of money is paid out in prepaid benefits every Easter and Christmas.

I ask the Minister: does this mean that, until this amendment comes into force on 1 December 1991, there is no legislative basis for the Department of Social Security raising overpayments resulting from the payment of prepaid benefits? I believe that the Minister should inform the Senate whether his Department has been collecting all such overpayments, as well as the amount of money that has been forgone as a result of lack of legislative backing.

A similar case of locking the door after the horse has bolted is the Government's belated decision to deduct the amount of benefits received under the Aboriginal employment incentive scheme from social security income. Like so many other examples, this is a classic case of a total lack of coordination between government agencies and, in particular, between Social Security and DEET. Thankfully, the coalition will alleviate this mountain of inefficiency and faulty communication by merging the Department of Social Security and the Commonwealth Employment Service.

The schedule to this Bill contains two new social security agreements with Ireland and Portugal which were signed earlier this year. The old agreement with the United Kingdom has also been reinserted in this Bill as the anticipated new agreement still has not been reached and is now not expected to commence before 1 July 1992. I remind the Senate that the Government's failure to reach such agreements is at the taxpayers' expense. For example, it is estimated that over $1 1/2m of anticipated savings will be forgone if the United Kingdom agreement commences only on 1 July 1992. I believe that the Minister should inform the Senate as to the reasons for this delay.

I also call on the Minister to inform the Senate as to the current state of affairs in relation to the negotiation of the reciprocal arrangement with Greece. I would like the Minister to confirm or deny whether negotiations are effectively stalled. Does the Minister agree with the reported claims of a Greek Government official that Australia is delaying these negotiations because it fears that such an agreement would add to our welfare bill? I find it difficult to believe such a claim and I eagerly await the Minister's answer to my questions about the annual cost to Australian taxpayers of the lack of a reciprocal arrangement with Greece.

This Bill also includes two essentially minor amendments to the data-matching legislation that will allow the matching agency to include the date of birth of a living spouse as a data item and will clarify the legislative effect of a breach of the data-matching guidelines. I find neither of these amendments particularly objectionable, but this Bill does give me the opportunity to expose what I consider to be the most rubbery figures that have accompanied any legislation since the last election.

During the debate on the Data-Matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Bill one year ago, the Government claimed that data matching would result in savings of $65m in 1991 and $290m in the first full year of operation in 1991-92. The Government based these claims on an assumption that there is a one to 2 per cent residual of total clients who are rorting the system, that this residual was not being identified using current monitoring procedures, and that they would all—I emphasise the word `all'—be picked up by data matching.

These assumptions were based solely on an unrepresentative sample of 10,000 family allowance recipients. During the committee stage of that Bill, we questioned the Department over and over about the adequacy of that 2 per cent and how it came to that figure. We got the idea that it was a guesstimate rather than any really firm figure. Our concerns about that have been confirmed. The $290m in annual savings would be derived from a combination of identity matching, income matching and double payment matching, although the Government refused to provide a breakdown of the savings derived from each of these three matching types. The savings derived from the compulsory provision of tax file numbers were quite rightly excluded from the estimates for the data-matching legislation because these savings had already been costed into the earlier legislation.

I well remember the reaction when the Opposition proposed to amend this legislation to tighten the circumstances in which Government agencies could investigate apparent discrepancies in either a person's income or identity. When the Opposition decided to replace the word `suggest' with the word `indicate' in the relevant clause of the legislation, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) saw fit to write to the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, claiming that such an amendment would threaten the Budget strategy and would result in loss of `at least $100m and possibly as high as $150m in a full year'. That is what the Prime Minister wrote to Dr Hewson: if we changed that word, there would be a loss of at least $100m and possibly as much as $150m in a full year. It was an hysterical reaction.
Later in the same letter, the Prime Minister claimed:

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments pose a threat to the Budget strategy and are completely at odds with the Opposition's call for increased savings. The Government will not accept amendments simply to achieve some of the savings announced in the Budget. I believe that the Opposition's amendments would make the Bill unworkable by significantly reducing savings and adding to administrative costs.

Concerned about the complete lack of a factual basis for the savings projected by the Department of Finance, the Opposition ensured that the matching source agencies would have to report the first six months operation of the data-matching legislation to the Parliament. These reports, which were tabled in the Senate earlier this month, cast very grave doubts on the savings estimates put forward by the Government.

PARA.TAB: The Government in its 1990 estimates claimed that 113,000 Department of Social Security clients would have their benefits or pensions either cancelled or decreased during 1990-91. This would result in estimated gross savings of $65m. In fact, the number of payment-matching cases identified by the Department of Social Security as requiring examination up to October 1991 was only 22,779. We know that there was a delay in the start-up date, but given a comparable period—in fact, it is a little conservative because there was a little more time—instead of 113,000 clients, we find that there were 22,779 clients. This resulted in savings of $12.7m. In terms of both the number of matches identified and the amount of savings derived, the actual result was a mere 20 per cent of the estimate for 1990-91.

We had this hysterical reaction from the Prime Minister that if we changed the word, we would be losing $100m to $150m. Another $4m was identified in previous overpayments. These cannot be included in any comparison with the original estimates because such overpayments were excluded from them. The Department of Veterans' Affairs, the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services and the Australian Taxation Office were not able to identify any savings during 1990-91, while the savings identified by Department of Employment, Education and Training were less than $1m.

To be fair, it might be possible to mount an argument—and I am sure that the Minister will attempt to mount such an argument—claiming that there have been teething problems with implementation of the data-matching legislation and that in the first full year of operation the estimated savings will be realised. It needs to be pointed out that the Department of Social Security has not yet collected the tax file numbers of the remaining pensioner population. No income matching has been successfully achieved because of computer problems.

These are two of the possible reasons for the massive shortfall in revenue from the first six months operation of the data-matching legislation. They are possible explanations for the fact that to this point over $50m of the estimated $65m in estimated savings has not been realised. Of the $65m that the Government estimated would be saved from the data-matching program, $50m has not been achieved. Yet the people on the other side came into this chamber and said, `We need to infringe people's rights even further, to have a tax file number, because we will make these massive savings'. Those savings have not been demonstrated in this first six months and I doubt whether they will be evidenced in the next two years.

However, the corollary is not necessarily true. In its six-month data-matching report the Department of Social Security claims that the estimated savings for a full year will be $115m. This represents a massive shortfall of $175m from the original estimate. Not only have we not achieved the savings in the first period but we now also have an adjustment. We will now have $115m in a full year; that is, a $175m shortfall from the original estimate. It should also not be forgotten that this latest full year estimate quite mischievously includes the savings that are derived from people voluntarily going off a benefit when they are invited or asked to provide a tax file number.

This additional item was quite rightly excluded from the original $290m estimate because it had been included in the costings for the earlier tax file number legislation. While this voluntary cessation element is discounted, the gaping hole is even larger.

It also needs to be brought to the Senate's attention that in this latest report the Department of Social Security has readjusted its matching success rate for sole parents and family allowance recipients downwards from 2 per cent to 0.8 per cent and for pensioners downwards from 1 per cent to 0.6 per cent. This is the 2 per cent that the officers who sat in the Committee said was an estimate, a correct estimate, a good estimate, of the Department's matching success rate. Now what are they saying? They are saying that we will only get 0.8 per cent of sole parents and only 0.6 per cent of pensioners. I would be interested to know how that will affect the costings and the predicted savings that we were to make at the expense of having everyone provide a tax file number.

We currently have a costing situation where the percentage success rate has been virtually halved. Erroneous costing items have been introduced and there have been massive teething problems during the first six months of operation. This is on top of a set of original costings that were both rubbery and unsubstantiated. What is the Department's reaction to the savings that are not what the officers said they would be when they were putting forward the idea of a tax file number? In one sentence in the data-matching report, the Department says:

SPEECH.PARA: Taking the above aspects into account, the results so far suggest that actual savings when the Program is fully implemented will be close to the savings estimated to be available from the initiative on an annual basis.

I believe that the Senate has every right to be concerned about the complete lack of evidence to support the accuracy of the original costings. Less than a year ago, the Prime Minister was writing to the Leader of the Opposition claiming that the proposed amendment to the data-matching legislation would put the whole Budget strategy at risk; the wheels were going to fall off totally. At the same time officers of the Department of Finance and the Department of Social Security were claiming that estimates were conservative and that the figures assumed that data-matching would pick up 100 per cent of the residual.

PARA.TAB: Now we find there is hardly a skerrick of information to indicate that the estimated benefits will be derived either this financial year or next financial year. In effect, the Prime Minister's claim of a year ago seems to have come back to haunt him. In his response to the speeches made in the second reading stage, I call on the Minister to provide an explanation of the latest estimates of the savings that will be derived from data-matching during the next two financial years. I also ask him to give very serious thought to calling for a full and comprehensive revision of these estimates, the results of which he should table in the Senate.

I suggest that instead of spending the taxpayers' money on hours and hours of work in looking at the package that we have put forward, he might address the issues facing him, the errors in his predictions and the estimates that have proved to be so wrong. I suppose that one could refer to the Sermon on the Mount: it is appropriate that while he is beholding the mote in his brother's eye, he ought to be considering the beam in his own eye. In this case, the beam is the gross inaccuracies of those predictions which have been demonstrated in this report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall eventually get to Senator Patterson's speech, but I think I should first go through the more important aspects of this evening's debate. The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) has been brought on to enable the Government to fulfil the announcement it made a couple of weeks ago that the special assistance plan for farmers could be presented by December. That is why it is being debated at this hour of the night. However, in doing so, I think it is my duty to place on record to the Senate that the Government has considered this special assistance package very carefully over quite a period of time and cannot accept some of the proposed amendments.

PARA.TAB: I think all honourable senators should understand that if some of those amendments which we will cover tonight are passed, they will be rejected in the House of Representatives and the package will not be ready for a couple of thousand farmers who want it to be available on Monday. I would like to make sure that they do have it on Monday. I hope that during this debate the Opposition and the Australian Democrats might consider that position and perhaps give some ground on it. When one looks at this package, one sees that the Government has given an enormous amount of ground. That is what we have been doing.

I think it would probably be best if I just went through an explanation of exactly what is occurring. I am not certain that everyone is fully aware of that. The Government has devised this package to try to assist those farmers who cannot benefit from part C of the rural adjustment scheme or the Jobsearch allowance. Obviously quite a few farmers—I think the number is about 4,000—are on the JSA. It is not as if no-one in the farming community is benefiting from it now. I think that about 4,000 farmers and their spouses are currently getting that benefit. Part C assistance—and it should be understood that that is not administered by the Department of Social Security—is not available to these farmers because their farms are considered to be profitable and viable in the long term. The JSA is not available to farmers because their commitment to work on the farm means that they are not unemployed under the definition that we have thus far adhered to. Even if they were to qualify for a benefit, the rate would be little or nothing because of the benefit's assets test. The Government is of the view that immediate financial assistance should be made available to those farmers who are in severe hardship, who are long term viable but who cannot handle any more debt. Hopefully, that is what today's package will provide.

The RAS authority in a State will receive applications from farmers who consider that they fall within the terms of these arrangements. The rural adjustment scheme authority will certify that a farmer qualifies as follows: where he or she or the farmer's spouse normally contributes a significant part of his or her capital and labour to the farm; the farm normally provides the person's principal source of income and the farmer is in severe financial hardship; commercial finance to support the farm is not available; part C assistance is not available; the farm is likely to be profitable in the long term; and the farmer is available for and willing to do full time work.

None of those assessments, with perhaps the exception of the last one, really comes within the ambit of Social Security. That is why I was always concerned in negotiating this package with my colleague, Simon Crean, to make sure that the Department of Social Security was making no judgment about the viability of farmers. My Department is not qualified to make such a judgment. So, we have tried to ensure that this is done only by those who have this specific job to do. Similarly, when one looks at appeals, agricultural economics would be at the top of the list of qualifications for those who sit on Social Security Appeals Tribunals.

When the RAS authority gives the kind of certificate that suggests a farmer qualifies under all of the conditions that I have just detailed, the farmer can be regarded as unemployed for the purpose of qualifying for Jobsearch allowance. In virtually all other respects, apart from those, the usual rules applicable to a person on JSA will apply to this farmer, even though he or she will not be subjected to a waiting period in respect of liquid assets.

The other major aspect of this assistance scheme is the modification of the benefit assets test hardship rules as they relate to farmers who have the kind of certificate about which I have just spoken. The RAS authority will certify which farm assets, including machinery, livestock and the farm itself, are essential to the farmer's long term profitability. These and a farmer's life insurance policies will be regarded as unrealisable assets. They will be ignored for the purposes of the assets test.

Additionally, in the great bulk of cases they will be regarded as generating no income. So they will not affect the farmer's rate of JSA either. The benefit assets test hardship concessions are generally available only where the value of a person's liquid or readily available assets test is less than $6,000 for a single person and $10,000 for a married couple.

In working out those amounts, notice will be taken of amounts held in business accounts as working capital where the funds are required for essential and usual farm operating costs. That concession was given in the rules for the family allowance and the family allowance supplement which we discussed in this chamber a couple of weeks ago.

I know that Opposition senators and the Australian Democrats in general are suggesting that this rule which applies in the hardship test should also be applied more generally to the assets test. This is one amendment in the category that I mentioned before—that is, it will not be acceptable to the Government if it is passed in that form in the Senate tonight. This will mean that a couple of thousand farmers who are waiting for this package are going to be delayed at least a month or maybe longer before they receive it. That is something that I want the Opposition to consider.

The Government debated this package over many months. In considering whether to make concessions on the definition of `unemployment', it was concerned about the precedents that might be set. The Government is very concerned about the kind of precedent that would be set if we walked totally away from assets testing. Given that at the present time there are more than 700,000 people on JSA and Newstart, if we start to make decisions that will create precedents that we will live to regret, we can undermine what the Government has always considered to be the proper basis of these benefits.

These amendments also provide for the conclusion of a protocol between Primary Industries and Energy and my Department to ensure the smooth running of the scheme. The SSAT will be able to review the farmers Jobsearch allowance rate, and that is fine. It will look at decisions and will be able to reject claims. That is fine. But, obviously, they will not be qualified to look at decisions about long term viability.

It has been suggested to me—and I do not think it ought to be a state secret—during the course of this second reading debate that we might look at the possibility of extending the appeal mechanism of the AAT rather than the SSAT. I think this is a reasonable suggestion. But greater minds than mine are being applied to it as we speak. While I cannot give honourable senators an answer to that right now, hopefully I will have something further to say on it during the course of the committee stage debate. I hope to be able to say something very soon.

In light of the comments that have been made about the working capital argument, I think we ought to look at how the hardship provisions will apply. The first hurdle that a person must jump is to demonstrate that funds are required for an essential and usual expenditure in operating a farm. It is at this point that I think the Government is treating working capital properly. But the suggestion that working capital then be included in the normal income and assets test which must then be faced as a second hurdle is where we part company. I think some examples of this may illustrate the Government's concern.

Take the example of a farmer with a dependent spouse and two children under 13 years of age, who has money in a business account and no other assets, apart from the farm, livestock and machinery, and has a negative income—and most or all of these people will be in that category. The maximum rate of Jobsearch allowance for a family of that kind is $609 a fortnight. But if that family were to have assessable assets—that is, assets excluding the farm, livestock, machinery and so on—of $20,000, the JSA rate would be $529 a fortnight. If it were $50,000, the rate would be $409; if it were $75,000, the rate would be $309; if it were $100,000, the rate would be $209; and if it were $125,000, the rate would be $109. In fact, JSA would not cut out until these assets, over and above the farm, the livestock, the machinery and so on hit $152,250.

The problem that the Government faces is that all of the 700,000 or more people who at present are on JSA and Newstart have to be subjected to assets tests. While we are certainly prepared, as is obvious from the Bill that is before the Senate tonight, to make special provisions for farmers, and in my view we have done so, we are not prepared to walk away from the concept of assets testing of farmers.

Once one has passed the threshold hardship provision test, all we are saying is one has to be able to be assessed under the assets test with all of the things that I have read out excluded. That is a very generous provision. The precedent that one sets by walking away from any assets testing of farmers is something that the Government cannot and will not accept. So what we have here is, in my view, a pretty fundamental difference.

Representatives of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy are obviously the experts in this matter. It is not my Department; this is a bit of a crossover argument and I am certainly not going to suddenly claim to be an expert on how to run a farm. Those representatives are the ones who are assessing and reviewing these things all the time—

TALK.START.PARA: —You could count the numbers on the animal farm.

—I conceded my limitations. This is not false modesty; it is genuine. The experts from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy are saying that very few of these farmers would have any money anyway. These farmers are at the end of the line. They are in constant touch with their banks. They have sold their extra surplus assets. They have sold a hell of a lot of things, and they are still in the position that they are in now. These are people who are in fairly desperate straits.

PARA.TAB: The principle involved in doing away with assets testing in this area is far too dangerous. In any event, where does it place these farmers compared with these other 700,000? Under this arrangement we are already giving the farmers a very special piece of assistance. The idea that we can take it further is something that the Government rejects. I really do hope that during this debate the Opposition might give that some serious consideration. I am not talking here about some major confrontation or some silly political point scoring. We have been working reasonably well on both sides of the chamber on this matter. I would regret greatly a delay of at least a month, possibly more, for a couple of thousand farmers who are, by definition, in severe hardship and in real need. I would much prefer to see assistance going to them straightaway.

Some of the things that Senator Lees said will be better addressed in the committee stage of this debate. Senator Boswell asked a couple of questions which require an answer. The first question was: will social security payments be retrospective to 1 December 1991? I would have said a couple of hours ago that there is no problem with that. If, however, we are to delay this scheme for a month or more, depending upon the decisions that are taken here this evening, I cannot promise that payments will be retrospective to 1 December 1991. If the legislation goes through as it is here, with an amendment that I will refer to in a moment, which I have agreed with Senator Alston, the answer to Senator Boswell's question is an unequivocal yes. If it does not, the answer is anyone's guess, because we will have to determine when farmers will be able to apply and to what date we will backdate the assistance.

The next question that Senator Boswell asked was whether there would be extra staff in RAS to handle the workload. The answer to that question is yes. In 1990-91, the administrative budget for RAS was $4m. This year it is $12m and a chunk of the extra $8m is being used to handle the questions that are inherent in what Senator Boswell has raised. What can one say to the issues that Senator Patterson has raised?

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a good speech —that is what you could say!
—One certainly could not say that.
—We found a hole.

—Senator Patterson has not found a hole. I wish I could comment on that, but there are limits on the sort of language I can use. The first matter I will deal with is the criticism of the failure to reach an agreement with the UK. As Senator Patterson would be aware, we have had numerous attempts to get those negotiations moving in the right direction. When I signed the most recent agreement with the Government of the UK in September 1990, we had for the first time some recognition of the question of indexation of British pensions, which is at the heart of the disagreement between the two governments.

PARA.TAB: I think I have said before in the chamber that the reason the British Government is reluctant to extend to us the provisions of an agreement which extends to countries all around the world is simply that South Africa, New Zealand, Australia and Canada have the most British migrants and therefore cost the most money. The British Government signed an agreement with the Philippines because there are something like twelve British pensions in the Philippines. But the British Government will not do that here because there are 130,000 pensioners, which would mean a cost to the budget of Great Britain of some hundreds of millions of pounds. I will have to get the figure, but #350m is the figure I have in my mind. In any event, it is a hell of a lot of money. That has always been the stumbling block.

However, I am pleased to report to Senator Patterson that the British Government is now considering a modification to the process. It would not give us a full indexation of all British pensioners immediately. It is worth noting that we are talking about pensioners who came here some 20 years ago with a pension of a few pounds a week, who are still on a few pounds a week and who therefore get either the whole or a very substantial part of an Australian pension. This is a matter of importance to the Australian Government, which is why I have been to London to discuss it a number of times with my British counterpart and why, no doubt, I will make sure I get there again next year to do the same thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did you stay? At the Ritz?

—No, I did not stay at the Ritz. I did not want to stay at the Ritz. I stayed at another hotel which—given that Senator Patterson has been kind enough to raise this issue with me—has since sent me something like a #1,000 rebate for charging me a wrong rate. That has been paid into the Department of Administrative Services. I am glad that Senator Patterson raised that matter.
—Did you heavy them?

—I cannot heavy hotels thousands of kilometres away. Even Senator Walters knows that I do not have that power. I can, however, manage when it comes to the protection of the dollars of the Australian taxpayer. I can put a case and I say with all the modesty I can muster that I can put a pretty good case. Justice has had its way and that repayment has been made into Australian Government coffers. So that is not such a great problem.

PARA.TAB: There will be talks between officials of Australia and Great Britain. I believe that those talks are scheduled for August or September. I am hopeful that they will lead to the first real breakthrough on this question, which will mean many, many millions of dollars to Australia.

Australia's unwillingness to enter into an agreement with Greece can best be explained by saying that what we are signing here with Greece—or with any country with which we negotiate—is a reciprocal agreement. Obviously, if we are to sign an agreement, it has to be capable of being reciprocal. The problem for the Greek Government is that as further and better particulars, as they say in the legal game, have been presented it has become apparent that the coverage of Greek workers by their pension scheme is very much lower than the estimates we were given previously. That makes a reciprocal agreement virtually impossible.

If we were to sign the kind of agreement that the Greek Government wants, we would be doing the Australian taxpayer a great disservice. However, that does not mean that we are taking away the benefits from anyone in Greece. Obviously, about 2 per cent of the invalid population is scheduled for medical reviews. I am not sure how many of them are in Greece—they are not guaranteed to receive their payment forever—but no-one else has any problem.

In the area of recovery of prepayments, Senator Patterson was shocked and appalled to see that legislation is now needed, and she asks why none was needed before. Pretty simply, we have been doing the same thing administratively, and all we are doing now is giving legislative force to it. I do not see that as a very big deal. Nonetheless, it is obviously the right way to go, so we are proceeding to do that.

Senator Patterson then got on to data matching; she always gets on to data matching. I understand that she has somewhat of an obsession on this point. Whether anyone would describe this as a magnificent obsession is probably another matter. I could think of many adjectives to describe this obsession, but I am not certain that it would be an edifying experience for anyone present.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have an obsession with finding the holes.

—There are no holes. This is very tempting for me and I have to resist this temptation. In respect of data matching, I admit that there was a delay for some time in the installation of the data equipment, and that held up the program. No-one can say with certainty that that kind of delay is not going to pop up from time to time. However, we remain confident that the estimates we have made will be adhered to. In the longer term, I am very confident that, with any luck with the system, we will be exceeding them.
—You have revised them downwards; that was weak.
—The attack is so weak that it is not worth spending any time knocking back. If Senator Patterson makes sure that she asks me a question during the next week I will happily—
—I've got another one to ask.
—I hope she has; I hope it is better than that one. In any event, to get down to the purpose of tonight's debate—
—Why don't you do it now?

—Senator Short would not be aware of the purpose of tonight's debate. I understand that because he has not been in here and he has not taken much interest. For those who have taken an interest, we have a fairly serious problem here in respect of the farmers' package which I would like to see ironed out. I hope the Opposition and the Democrats can see their way clear to have a rethink on this question.

PARA.TAB: I want to make this very valuable assistance available to a couple of thousand farmers, and I want to do it as soon as possible. Given that we are all acknowledging that these are farmers in severe hardship, why would it not be the case that all of us could combine to make sure they get the assistance that people in severe hardship need as soon as possible? The severity of the hardship will not go away if we delay this a month. The Government has gone a long way—it has made a very big movement in the course of the last few weeks—on family allowances, on family allowance supplement and now on this. We cannot move further. The Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) and the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) are quite adamant about this, and I do not blame them. I appeal to the Opposition and to the Democrats: it is not a matter of giving me a fair go; give these farmers a fair go and make sure they can get the money on Monday.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Clause 1.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) admitted while he was speaking during the debate on the second reading that he was not an expert farmer. I would like to tell him that he is not an expert psychologist in diagnosing my obsessions. I ask him to refrain from practising amateur psychology because he might be in breach of a psychological practices Act of some sort. He should keep his diagnoses to himself.

PARA.TAB: I asked him a question, which he did not answer, concerning indexation of the earnings credit limit for the maximum rate for pensioners. The Department of Social Security is currently doing an analysis of the relevance of the CPI to the spending patterns of pensioners, and I would like to know whether we could have that information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise; Senator Patterson did ask about that and I forgot to talk about it. I announced to interested pensioner groups, during the past couple of months and certainly since pensioners found out in September that they were not getting an increase, that the relevance to pensioners of the basket of goods in the CPI ought to be looked at. I asked the Department to review it. I said that I would circulate the contents of that review by Christmas. I still intend to do that.

PARA.TAB: It will go not just to honourable senators but to all the pensioner and welfare groups around the country. The sort of timetable I have in mind is that by the end of February I would like some consultations with the relevant groups to be concluded. If, as a result of whatever that review produces and whatever the consultations produce, there is a need for a change to the basket of goods in the CPI, I would intend to take that to the Government in March. But first I have to be convinced of the need. All I can say, without going into the matter in depth, is that there is conflicting evidence, and that is why I asked for a review. I did not think there was a clear case. It will be ready pretty soon, and Senator Patterson should be the second person to receive a copy.
Clause agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question to ask about Age Pension News—appropriately, since there is a spot here to ask it. Will the Minister give an undertaking to this Committee that the Age Pension News will not be used to discredit or to put out any information about the coalition's package and that the Government will not use Age Pension News as a vehicle to attack what is a most revolutionary and appropriate package for the future of this country.

—Again, if we are talking about adjectives, I could think of some different ones from `revolutionary' in referring to the package. `Revolting' would be a better one. I have been pretty scrupulous in ensuring that Age Pension News does not become a vehicle for Government propaganda. Senator Patterson has an unequivocal guarantee from me that the same diligence I have displayed in the past I will continue to display.

—It sends up my blood pressure, if that is the sort of circulation the Minister is referring to. Did the Minister give an unequivocal promise that Age Pension News would not be used to discuss the Opposition's tax reform policy?

—I forget the exact words I used, but I think I said that I would display the same diligence as I had done in the past to ensure that Age Pension News did not become a vehicle for Government propaganda, and I say it again.

—I am sure Senator Patterson would not be happy with it being framed in those words. Neither Senator Patterson nor I believe that the Government has not in the past used Age Pension News as a vehicle for Government propaganda. We believe it has been extremely blatant. I again ask the Minister, because Senator Patterson put it extremely clearly, to give an unequivocal promise that the coalition's tax reform policy will not be mentioned in the Age Pension News.
—I do not think I can add to the very strong words which I have already uttered several times.

PARA.TAB: Clauses agreed to.
Clause 9.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to state why the Australian Democrats will be opposing this clause and I also wish to ask some questions of the Minister. This clause is one of a series which we will be opposing to ensure that sole parents are treated the same as all other pensioners. I ask the Minister: what is the rationale behind making a differentiation between how aged pensioners will be treated when it comes to compensation payments and how sole parents pensions will be affected by any compensation payments?

—I think all we are doing in this proposal—while, as I said in the Senate a couple of days ago, maintaining the option of full time parenting for sole parents—is recognising that there is, and has been for some time, an increasing attachment of sole parents to the labour market. Currently, more than 58,000 sole parents are in full time, part time or casual work and about half of all other sole parents are actually looking for work. All we are trying to do is bring this into line with what applies to other benefits which are received—with the exception of the age pension where obviously people have retired from work and there cannot be considered to be a reasonable analogy between them and the labour market program. So we are just trying to bring it into line.

PARA.TAB: This is actually something which will affect only about 400 sole parent pensioners, so it is not something with broad application when there are something like 250,000 sole parents—I think those are the current numbers. One is looking at a measure which will affect some 400 people and these people will be getting quite considerable sums. We have already liberalised considerably the method of treating compensation payments, as Senator Lees would be aware. The kind of calculations that are made now about how long a benefit shall be suspended I think are a considerable improvement on how it was done in the past.

So I hold the view that this is a fair provision. When sole parents get these payments as a result of being in the work force—that is what they will be getting these compensation payments for—then I think it is only fair that they should have their pension assessed in exactly the same way as a recipient of JSA or Newstart would have that pension assessed. Honourable senators must remember that some disability support pensioners are sole pensioners and they are subjected to this. It is in fact an anomaly that sole parents were not subjected to it before. This will only affect entry into the sole parents pension for 400 people; and when 250,000 people are receiving the payment, I do not think it is unfair, harsh or unconscionable.
Clause agreed to.
Clause 10.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Clause 10, page 5, paragraph (a) proposed subparagraph 1168(1)(b)(ii), line 41, omit the subparagraph.
3.Clause 10, page 6 paragraph (b) proposed subparagraph 1168(2)(c)(ii), line 14, omit the subparagraph.
4.Clause 10, page 6, paragraph (c), lines 22 and 23, omit the paragraph.

These amendments go together, in terms of their intent, with the previous amendment. Therefore, I will not spend a lot of time on them. I simply ask the Minister: is he suggesting that sole parent pensioners are in fact double dipping? Is this why he is now treating them in this way?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I am suggesting that they would be placed in a position of some advantage, as against other beneficiaries, and even, as I said, disability pensioners who are in exactly the same circumstance. I had not been looking at it specifically as double dipping, rather as trying to make sure that there is—to use that often abused phrase—a level playing field in the way that we apply our pension rules.
