SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 6.Government Amendment No. 8, proposed clause 56D, paragraph 26(2)(b), omit "12 weeks", substitute "26 weeks".

I do not wish to move amendment No. 7 with this amendment, so I will speak to amendment No. 6. This amendment changes the period for which certificate 26 will last. At the moment it is 12 weeks and we believe it is unreasonable to expect farmers to go back and back again. We believe that 26 weeks is a far more reasonable time before we ask the farmers to go through all of these hurdles again. We believe it is unfair to expect them to keep returning and returning. I understand that the income test would still apply and, therefore, in the normal course of events, they would have to notify should their income go over the limit. Therefore, we cannot understand why they need to keep applying when in some States there is already a considerable wait for assessment. We understand that some extra staff were going to be appointed, but we still envisage long delays.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have checked the matter with an official from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, who informs me that the wait for new applicants will be four weeks but very short indeed for those who are in the circumstances covered by this amendment. It is not a matter of saying that some staff will be put on. There will be sufficient staff put on to ensure that there is no problem.

PARA.TAB: To get back to what I said earlier, we are still looking at the kinds of comparisons one makes with the requirements one is putting on more than 700,000 people on Jobsearch allowance and Newstart as against farmers. We have liberalised this very considerably, and are happy to do so, but if one is a Jobsearch allowance recipient in Hobart and has to go every two weeks, if we say that farmers only have to go every 12 weeks, we think that that will be very much a relaxation of the rules, and an important one.

I do not think that one can overlook the possibility that a farmer on Jobsearch allowance may make the decision—I hope that this will not happen too often—to leave the property. In such a case there is a greater risk of an overpayment occurring as the period is lengthened from 12 to 26 weeks and people will be put in greater rather than less difficulty. There will be some people in that position.

Although I understand what is behind this proposal, the Government is making a fundamental change to the rules for these benefits. The person in the city may well say, `I am in as bad a position as any farmer, because I am struggling too. My only income is benefit, but I have to trot up every two weeks and you are letting him have 12 weeks'. If one says that farmers will have 26 weeks, the disparity will become so great that problems will be caused. I do not want to be argumentative, but I think that 12 weeks is pretty fair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister outline what the difference will be between the initial test to get a certificate under section 26 and a re-test?

—I think Senator Lees must have misheard me. I was saying that the time would be shorter, not the arrangement. When people go in the first time they must provide some data. That data is then assessed. The data does not change fundamentally over time. So when the person comes back for the second, third or fourth time, the people administering the scheme are able to go through the matter very quickly indeed. That is all I was saying. I was not saying that the arrangement changes.

—I wanted to check that such people have to go through the process of applying for part C of RAS. Having been assessed under RAS, they then have to apply for part C and then have to go back through the Department of Social Security. Is that correct?

—I think we must be at cross purposes. I am trying to work out where this is leading. All that is happening is that at 12 weeks one is checking to see what has happened during the three months, unless something changes and there is some alteration to circumstances. That is not the same as a new application and having to jump through all the hoops. Perhaps I am not putting the matter clearly, but I do not know what else I can say.

—I had understood that that was the precise point of the exercise—namely, that every quarter one would check whether there had been a change in circumstances. Therefore, one would expect most of the subsequent applications or appearances to be pro forma. One certainly would not have to go through the same rigmarole because it would all be there on file. On that basis we take the view that it is not unreasonable to expect the person to submit himself to re-checking every 12 weeks.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 7.Government Amendment No. 8, proposed clause 56D, paragraph 26(4)(c), omit the paragraph.

This amendment removes the requirement that farmers must actually apply for part C. We acknowledge that they have to go in and be assessed, but if they are then assessed as not fulfilling the requirements, we think it is unnecessary for them to have to go through the rigmarole of applying. Basically, as this stands, it is saying that one has to apply for assistance to leave the land before one can get assistance to stay on the land. We see that as unnecessary. They simply need to go through the rural adjustment scheme and get assessed. If they are assessed, that is fine and those concerned do not have to go through the extra paperwork.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that this is the same argument that we have just been through and I do not have much to add. This is not a huge burden. We are talking about a simple and, in most cases, a quick process, unless there has been a change of circumstances. The whole purpose is to give the RAS people the opportunity to see whether there has been a change in circumstances. I do not think that effectively we can take that away from them. I think that this is a pretty efficient way of doing business and the Government can see no reason to change it.

—I would like to ask the Minister a couple of questions. I have no doubt as to the efficiency of the Minister's Department to a certain extent, but the rural adjustment scheme involves a lot of investigation and advice to farmers. Is the Minister happy that RAS is in a position to do all the things that he has mentioned? He said earlier that the first applications should be cleared in four weeks from 1 December. I would say that is a little hopeful considering that the Christmas break is almost upon us. Apart from that, although I am reasonably satisfied as to the Minister's Department, the most complaints I have received from rural people in Western Australia relate to the slowness of RAS, its inefficiency, and certainly some of the decisions it has made. Some of these decisions are quite arbitrary, especially if they come down on the wrong side. I am expressing my fear as to whether RAS can handle the situation as I see it from my end of the country.

—Minister Crean is well aware of that criticism and Senator Panizza is not the first person to utter remarks along those lines. That matter was taken into account in making the commitment of four weeks. Minister Crean has undertaken consultations with the States and has received their assurances that this can be done. This has to be a cooperative effort, as Senator Panizza would appreciate. I suppose that there is the same pressure on State governments as there is on the Commonwealth Government to undertake this exercise quickly and efficiently.

PARA.TAB: I understand that a further meeting between Minister Crean and the State agricultural Ministers is set for January or February. I am not certain of the date, but in any event it is very soon. The rural adjustment scheme is on the agenda for that meeting, again for the very purpose of making certain that what we are doing is working and that the scheme does not have difficulties. That was predicated on the basis that it was to start on Monday. We have yet to determine whether that is still the case. If it is the case, we will have had some time to assess how it has gone and we can put some more pressure on the States, or together come up with more money or do whatever is necessary to be done.

I can give an absolute commitment that the Government is determined to make this work. We do not wish unnecessarily to delay farmers who obviously are suffering a degree of hardship. It is in everybody's interests to get the job done, and we will.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Panizza. It is already a nightmare for many farmers trying to get through the whole procedure of RAS. I ask whether the Minister is aware that the average time a farmer takes, with the help of a rural councillor, to fill out the forms for unemployment benefits is three to 3 1/2 hours. I ask whether he has ever tackled the problem of duplicate forms. All I can see in this procedure is more and more forms and more and more paper warfare, and more and more bureaucrats needed to sift through it. I welcome the Minister's undertaking that he will monitor it, but I cannot see why he is setting up these additional hurdles in the first place.
—Job creation.

—I hope Senator Patterson does not mean that. What we are doing here in making a fundamental change to the system of unemployment benefits in Australia is, indeed, momentous. It is the first time we have done it. It is not done lightly. I do not think any responsible government would do it lightly. In those circumstances, there have to be rules. It cannot be done willy nilly. It cannot be done off the top of the head. There has to be a set of rules that are applied consistently. If there are not the same forms for each person to fill in, inevitably, rules will be applied differently across Australia and that is when we would get into all sorts of strife.

PARA.TAB: It is not a matter of creating jobs. Certainly, if we want to look at job creation we will look at how many public servants there will be in the Taxation Office if the Opposition's package gets through. That is a matter we will be taking up over the next few weeks, not tonight. I do not regard this as a matter of job creation. It is just a matter of having in place the necessary safeguards to administer a decent system, and that is all it will do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to wind up the point I was making. There is a big job ahead of the Minister, as Senator Lees has said. Okay, it takes 3 1/2 hours to fill in a form.
—I don't believe that.

—If it does, so what? It is certainly time well spent for anyone in that position. My worry is still with RAS in my State of Western Australia. People in that State are normally behind in dealing with part A, part B, part C or whatever, when they are leading up to seeding and looking for a part B contribution or part C carry on finance. I know they are generally two to three months behind. I accept the Minister's assurance that he will do it in four weeks, and I wish him luck, but it is a matter he has to look at.

PARA.TAB: On top of that there will be reviews at the end of harvest. Most of the crop is off by the end of December, the reviews will start and this, coming on top, will be an extra load. The Minister has already given me an assurance, I do not need another one, but I point out the danger of what might happen in my State. Maybe there is a lack of a work force, I do not know, but I think there may be a problem.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Government Amendment No. 8, proposed clause 56D, paragraph 26(5)(g), omit the paragraph.
2.Government Amendment No. 8, proposed clause 56E, paragraph 513(2)(c), omit the paragraph.
3.Government Amendment No. 8, proposed clause 56E, Note 2, omit the Note.
4.Government Amendment No. 8, proposed clause 56K, paragraph 593(2)(c), omit the paragraph.
5.Government Amendment No. 8, proposed clause 56K, Note 2, omit the Note.

In various ways these amendments all exempt farmers from having to look for work during the period of receipt of Jobsearch allowance. It is a recognition of the fact that obviously there will be instances where they will be required to be active on the farm even though they are not generating immediate income. In those circumstances, I think we all take the view that it is more trouble than it is worth to start subjecting farmers to inquiries about the extent to which they are actively looking for work, how far they have to travel to find it and how many days a week they ought to be exempted from doing other things. In all the circumstances, it seems to us that it is sensible simply to grant an exemption along those lines.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to see that at last Senator Alston has acknowledged how difficult the work test is and how many requirements there are for people who are trying to stay on either Jobsearch or Newstart. It has been a nightmare for many individuals. Indeed, many people without good literacy skills who do not look in their letterboxes regularly have found themselves in a rather large hole and having to rely on other forms of support, such as the Salvation Army and St Vincent de Paul. In this spirit I certainly welcome this new insight by the shadow spokesperson and we are very pleased to support it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Government as I believe it will be accepting these very important amendments. As Senator Richardson said in his joint press release with Mr Crean, this rural adjustment package is for those who are declared viable but who cannot take on any more debt. If a farmer is to be viable, he must work his farm and he must not be required to track around the country—I think the requirement was 150 kilometres. He must be on the farm to maintain his stock and equipment. It is a very sensible approach by all sides of the Parliament and I am very glad that it will go through.

—First of all, on behalf of the Government I indicate that these amendments will be accepted. Administratively, we were going to take this view anyway but I am happy to see it in legislation. We will not insist on the activity test here, given that we are talking about long term viable farms and if farms are going to be viable in the long term then people have to be around them. We accept that.

PARA.TAB: I would not want Senator Boswell or anyone else to have any misunderstanding about this. It is still a requirement that if a job is offered, farmers will be expected to take it provided, of course, it is within a reasonable distance and there is no hardship involved. Senator Boswell and others should understand that that is still the case.

In acknowledging that the activity test can be done away with, we are saying that in most rural areas, particularly in a severe rural recession, there will be very few jobs in any event for farmers to be chasing after—there will be hardly any employers. Rather than having them knock on the same door a couple of times every week I think we are better off with this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get some of those mining industry projects going.

—We are certainly working on that, too. If we acknowledge the difficulty involved in that, then we can agree with the amendments. Where there is work available—and in some areas that will be the case; if one looks at places like Senator Panizza's own State, there will be seasonal work and jobs available there from time to time—farmers will be expected to take it provided, obviously, the request is reasonable.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to put a hypothetical case to the Minister. I appreciate that he has accepted the amendments but let us agree that the planting is due to go in and this particular farmer is on the rural adjustment scheme. It has rained. He has to get his seeding in. Someone rings up and says, `Look, there's a job here'. He then has to make the decision—and he only has a matter of, maybe, a week to make that decision—of does he plant, does he take the job, or does he lose his benefit? These are the things that we must have cleared up. I think the Minister has the gist of what I am saying. I do not think any further explanation is required, but maybe he could answer.

—Yes, I do have the gist of what Senator Boswell is asking. The best way around that situation is to give an undertaking—commonsense will be involved in this—that we will not be insisting that farmers who are in the midst of putting in a crop, or about to put in a crop, have to get a job. There is no way we would seek to do that. However, the whole direction of this proposal is that, if a crop has been put in, the farmer would accept a job if it was offered. I do not think we should get carried away with this. There will not be many farmers in this category. I suspect that this will be a pretty rare event over the course of the next two years.

—I ask the Minister for clarification of what he has just said. If a job comes up within a reasonable distance at planting time—I think they are expected to travel up to 40 kilometres—is the farmer expected to take it if he is declared viable?
—No.

—If it is the farmer's planting time and his next door neighbour who is viable—it can happen—advertises for a tractor driver for seeding, would he be expected to take the job? Can the Minister clarify that, if he has not already?
—I thought I had. I gave an undertaking that that would not occur.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.
Progress reported.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:
That the Committee have leave to sit again at a later hour.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that the Government is prepared to proceed until we complete all stages of the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4).
—Yes, we are.
—Is that only in relation to this Bill?
—Not only in relation to this Bill but including it.

—I indicate that the Opposition does not favour proceeding beyond this Bill tonight. We understand the exigencies of completing the passage of this Bill so that it can go back to the House of Representatives. We do not support any other Bills being considered tonight.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the pathology Bills also have to return to the House of Representatives because they too have amendments. I accept that the start-up date is some way off. If the legislation does not get through tonight, the other bits and pieces cannot begin to be put in place. I understand that there is also some urgency with respect to that legislation.

—By 19 December, we will have been sitting for six weeks out of seven weeks; we will have been required to sit four weeks straight. Only this morning we were told that we would be sitting until 19 December, the previous date having been 13 December. We sat late earlier in this session to meet our commitment of finishing the Government's legislation, without the political advertising Bill, by 13 December. We are now being asked to sit beyond 10.30 tonight. That is unreasonable. We will not agree to do it. We have agreed to finish the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) tonight. That is as far as the Opposition will go.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I understand that honourable senators are using this motion to have this debate, but it is actually a subsequent motion on which we ought to be having this discussion. It is the same debate, so let us have the discussion now.

PARA.TAB: It is important to the Government, and to the proper management of the legislative program, that both the package of health insurance Bills and the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) be dealt with tonight. We would prefer also to deal with the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), but if there is concern about that we are prepared to drop it to try to get some sort of agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you organise the program properly this morning instead of coming in here at 10.25 p.m. and talking about this? You have had a ministerial statement. There was no requirement whatsoever for the Minister for Defence to bring that in this afternoon.

—We get plenty of complaints when we delay bringing in such statements. It has not fundamentally been Government Business which has taken up an undue amount of time today. We spent all morning on a debate about the political advertising Bill; it will be rehashed when we come back to the second reading. At this stage, I am not seeking to be provocative. I believe that there are two pieces of legislation which any responsible legislature would take the time to deal with. There is a third Bill which we would like to deal with, about which I will not enter into an argument, and that is the veterans' affairs Bill.

—Did the Manager of Government Business (Senator McMullan) inform the Whips of this decision? Did the Whips come to an arrangement regarding this decision about the health Bills? Was there any negotiation between the Government Whips and the Opposition Whips? Was there any negotiation between the Government and the shadow Minister in charge of the health Bill? What action has the Government taken, considering that it is now 10.27 p.m.? Why do we need the package of health Bills so urgently? The House of Representatives is coming back in December. The House of Representatives should be able to deal with the amendments then.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I will get some advice in a moment on the pathology Bills. My understanding was that there were discussions between the Whips before the suspension of the sitting for dinner which indicated that there was to be agreement to the passage of these three Bills.
—Social security.

—I was not there. Senator Reid and I share agreements so often that, if she says that, I am sure that was her understanding. I do not think we have ever misled each other. The understanding of the Government Whips was that the agreement was for these three Bills. That is what we are seeking. I suggest a compromise might be only two Bills. It is important that we have those two.

PARA.TAB: I am advised that there are some subsidiary regulation drafting requirements to get a licensing scheme in place before the operation of the pathology scheme which starts early in the new year. Therefore, that legislation is needed today.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I say to the Manager of Government Business (Senator McMullan) that the legislation is not necessary before those determinations and regulations are in place. The Department of Health, Housing and Community Services has emphasised to us in the briefings that the passage of this legislation cannot be implemented without those regulations and determinations. The drafts are already in place or about to be put in place. The Department has given us copies of the drafts; I have seen them. If that is the information that was given to Senator McMullan by the departmental officers, it is totally inaccurate. I suggest that he get some of the officers who gave us the briefing because they will have more accurate information.

—I take the opportunity to ask the Manager of Government Business (Senator McMullan) why this was not put in the program for the day? Why is there a need for these critical Bills? Why was it not taken to the Whips' meeting this morning in order that a program could be devised that could be met?

PARA.TAB: Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:
That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the negative.
Debate resumed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—In response to the question of the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) that would, in normal circumstances, have been reasonable, I say that these were the first three items that we listed. We did not slip anything else in ahead. They were the first three items of Government Business from the start of the day. There was some delay in dealing with them. I understand—and I am not saying this pejoratively—that the Opposition was not ready to deal with the health insurance legislation, so we had to change the sequence a little. The day was blown out by discussion this morning about political advertising rather than being blown out by anything that we have done.
—I am compelled to rise to my feet. The reason the coalition was not ready to deal with them—
—I am not criticising them.

—No, I am just telling Senator McMullan why the coalition is not ready to deal with them. The reason is that this is an amendment Bill. Late yesterday afternoon we received a number of pages of amendments to that. We received a briefing from the Department for which we thank the Minister. But it took time. Given the fact that the briefing did not finish until something like 6.00 p.m. and that Senator Walters and I, who were interested in this Bill, had a committee meeting that went from 8.00 p.m. to 12.20 a.m., we did not have much time to actually consider those. We began doing that this morning. We asked for a copy of the draft determinations so that we could decide—and the Democrats were considering this too—whether we would consider this Bill until we saw those.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tate was very cooperative. That cooperation had not been forthcoming prior to Senator Tate being involved. We saw the instructions for the draftsman and—in consultation with the shadow Minister; Senator Walters, who is the Chairman of the back bench committee; and the Democrats—we negotiated with Senator Tate to reach an undertaking that those determinations would be in place. The reason for that delay was we got those amendments at a time when it was impossible for us to consider them—we needed time this morning—and we did not have any idea of what was going to be in those determinations or the structure of those determinations. That was the delay.

If the Government had organised itself to get the amendments to us in due time and, in fact, had given, as had been asked for by the shadow Minister, Dr Robert Woods, the details about what was going to be the determinations, we would have been able to discuss the Bill in the correct order.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave —The Manager of Government Business (Senator McMullan) must understand that the Opposition, to date, has been quite cooperative and, I believe, bending over backwards in assisting the Government getting its business. Our leader and our Whip have stressed upon us that we will abide by the agreement to keep the agenda going so that we can rise on 13 December. The Government has now broken that promise and made it 19 December. Apart from that, the Government has broken an agreement among the Whips that we get up at 10.30 p.m. and that we do not negate the adjournment, which was the agreement among the Whips earlier in the day.

PARA.TAB: If Senator McMullan insists upon taking this action tonight and going on beyond getting the legislation on social security, it will not be worth his while to save the couple of hours that he may save by sitting on tonight. We will make sure that there will not be the cooperation that he has had up to date. He can try all the lurks that he likes but, in the end, the Standing Orders in this place give the Opposition the power to take as much time as it requires or as it chooses. The Government does not have the numbers in this place to make sure that it can gag us through.

Unless the Government abides by its promises, then I can assure it that we will be very disruptive. It is time that the Government understood that there must be some integrity amongst the Whips. Senator McMullan has acknowledged that Senator Reid has always expressed things in an honest and correct fashion, so he may well rest clear that that was the decision taken amongst the Whips at the meeting this morning. He tells us that tonight the Whips met. Could he tell me at what time?

TALK.START.PARA: —We have already told you.

—I am not talking to the Whip. I am asking the Manager of Government Business whether he can tell me what time the Whips were supposed to have changed that arrangement tonight. Senator Reid is particularly interested in that particular hour that that was meant to take place. I ask the Minister to rethink. Last time he tried to use his bully tactics in this place, it cost him dearly. I am asking him to rethink because if he wants the place the run smoothly until 19 December, he should not start at this early date, before the month of Christmas begins, trying to bully the Opposition. It just does not work.

—I will be very brief. As I understood the situation, we were to negate the adjournment for a short period of time, as I thought, to try to get this particular measure. But now I believe that there is another measure that the Government wants to get through. I certainly have not heard any valid arguments which would convince me that we need to get the pathology Bills through tonight. I note that Senator Tate is now in the chamber and perhaps he can elucidate on that. There is no disrespect to the Manager of Government Business (Senator McMullan) at all.

PARA.TAB: I make my remarks now through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, to the Manager of Government Business. I am a bit concerned that we are going down the track of having fairly regular negations of the adjournment. When I first came in here that, in fact, happened; it happened with a party that is not in power now. There was a great deal of strain at that particular time. People were working long hours. I do not suggest that this necessarily was the cause of Senator Greenwood's death, but certainly he was one of the first to suffer as a result, I believe, of the long hours. I do not necessarily say that it was because of the long hours that the chamber was sitting. Certainly, it was the long hours that he, as a Minister, was working that affected his health.

I was looking today at one or two of the Ministers in this chamber and thinking how aged they look now—present company excluded—compared with how they looked when they first became Ministers. None of us is as young as we used to be. Through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, I ask the Manager of Government Business to take into consideration this question of honourable senators' health. Senator Walters was on a committee last night. She was here until 12.15 or whatever time it was this morning. The morning before we did not get up until 1.30 or so.

These sorts of hours have a cumulative effect. But they do not have a cumulative effect just on us; they have a cumulative effect on all the people who support us here—the Clerks in the chamber, the attendants, all the people in the Table Office and elsewhere. I know that the Manager will think of this in future, but as of today I am yet to be convinced and yet to hear an argument as to why we need the pathology Bills tonight. We need the social security Bills, but why do we need the pathology Bills tonight? Is it absolutely necessary?
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Senator Tate, are you in a position to answer Senator Harradine and help solve this argument?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will hazard an attempt, Madam Acting Deputy President. When I had discussions earlier this morning with Senator Kay Patterson, we were concerned to give the chamber an opportunity to disallow the determination to be made by virtue of the exercise of a power by the Minister under the Act, if the Bill is passed into law. So we are really trying to get to a situation where I am able to give a guarantee to the Senate during the debate on the pathology Bill, and these are the terms I would have been using: I undertake that the ministerial determinations for the allocation of licences for specimen collection centres required by proposed new sections 23DNB and 23DNC will be tabled by 11 December 1991. That was in order to assist the chamber to have an opportunity to exercise its power of disallowance if it was not happy with the determinations.

PARA.TAB: To get to that stage, I am advised that it is necessary to get the Bill through the chamber and into the House of Representatives tonight so that it can then be prepared for the Executive Council and get the royal assent, and the Act can be an Act rather than a Bill. Under that Act, the Minister will make the determination, and the determination will be tabled, as I have promised Senator Patterson, no later than 11 December to allow this chamber to exercise its powers.

That is the timetable we have in mind. We are trying to assist the Senate eventually to exercise the powers it wants to exercise. That is why this timetable was arrived at. I am sorry if honourable senators find that it will require them to stay longer in the chamber—I would think no more than three-quarters of an hour, if we got under way. It is a very simple proposition. The Bill is largely agreed around the chamber, though I have not had a chance to discuss it in detail with Senator Harradine. Undertakings will be given to enable the confidence of the Senate to be maintained in the process. That is what we are trying to achieve.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to comment briefly on this matter because what happened this morning in the chamber created a quite dangerous precedent and attention needs to be drawn to it. This morning we had tabled a report from a committee on a Bill that had not yet entered the second reading stage. To my knowledge, we have never allowed one of those reports to become the subject of a debate. When leave was sought to debate that report, I fully expected the Government to refuse. I was disappointed when that did not happen because it seemed to me that, provided the second reading stage had not been proceeded with, there was a perfectly good opportunity to debate that report within the second reading stage.

PARA.TAB: I make the observation that one of the reasons the program today has blown out is the long debate we had on that report. It was a debate which I believe was unnecessary. I appeal to other senators that, when this situation arises again, if they have a perfectly good opportunity within a second reading debate later we not allow a debate on that report but proceed with the debate within the consideration of the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave —We do not need to get the legislation before regulations and determinations can be attached to the legislation. So many times in the Senate we have had legislation with regulations already given to us in the legislation. The Minister knows very well that we do not need to have the legislation with royal assent before regulations and determinations are made on that legislation.

PARA.TAB: The Minister can still give us the regulations and the determinations by 11 December—the legislation will be well through by then. He can still give us the regulations and determinations at the time he promised Senator Patterson and they could still be disallowed because the legislation will be through this place. There is no need for the legislation to have gone through, been amended and been returned for the regulations and determinations to be put to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—In the main, I want to respond to the points made prior to the last comments from Senator Walters. In response to that, I indicate my understanding of the situation and my advice, which is consistent with an interjection I heard from Senator Tate. It is true that the physical document—that is, the regulations—can exist before the legislation is passed. It is also true that it can be made available for consultation, consideration and discussion before the legislation is passed, but there is no way that the Senate can exercise its power of disallowance until the Act is passed and the regulations can exist as a matter of law. There is then a legal entity about which the disallowance power can be exercised.

PARA.TAB: So it is to protect the interests of the Senate that Senator Tate came to this agreement with Senator Patterson, and properly so. The only way that can be implemented is by the passage of this legislation tonight. That is my advice. It seems to me to be clear. That is my understanding, in response to Senator Harradine's question, and to supplement that perfectly adequate explanation from Senator Tate previously.

I want to deal with another of Senator Harradine's points. I will not go on at length; it would be very wrong to make a long speech while talking about the problem of adjournments. I am very conscious of the point he makes. I know that the adjournment has been negatived often. Frankly, I must acknowledge that it has happened because of the very cooperative attitude of all senators, which I have appreciated.

I have to say that this will not be the last late night, but I will try to keep them to a minimum. One of the advantages—if I can use that word somewhat generously—of sitting through to 19 December is that it will put less pressure on us to do that as often. I will be conscious of that, as I have been in the past. For example, we do not negative the adjournment on Wednesdays, however busy we might be, for the reasons Senator Harradine correctly outlined.

I want to say for the record that, although there may be misunderstandings as to what was the agreement at the Whips meeting about negativing the adjournment and what might have been the agreement at the Whips meeting about what legislation we would pass after the negation, I am assured initially by our Whips and reassured that what we are doing is exactly what we thought was the agreement at that time. It is exactly what we have always thought was the agreement at all times.

We have always thought the agreement was with regard to three Bills. However, if there is a misunderstanding or some concern, as I have said twice before, I am seeking to offer some form of compromise to drop one piece of legislation off, which is the veterans' affairs legislation. I understand in consultation with the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys), although it does not exactly fill him with joy, that that is a matter that can be accommodated. For the reasons outlined by Senator Tate and which I have reinforced, we do regard the health insurance Bills as important.

I have not and will not breach any agreement which I reached with the Opposition or other senators. Sometimes we might have to come back to say, `I am sorry; can we do it again?', but I have not and I will not breach agreements reached with the Opposition. I accept Senator Reid's bona fides in the matter, that there is a genuine misunderstanding between the Whips as to what the agreement is, but I have sought reassurance that what we are doing is exactly in accordance with what we thought was the agreement on the understanding upon which we have always operated.

As I say, I pose no challenge to the bona fides of Senator Reid when she says that what she is doing is what she thought to be the agreement, but it is a misunderstanding; it is not the breach of an agreement. The assurance which we have operated under until now is reiterated: we are not breaching and we will not breach agreements which we have reached with the Opposition. But I still seek and pursue what we understood to be the agreement with that compromise offer. We do insist upon the importance of two of the pieces of legislation but we are prepared to give way on the third.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I just want to correct Senator McMullan on one point. He said that we were following the program that was put to the Whips meeting this morning. If we were following the order of business as set down for the day we would not be doing Bills at all now; we would be doing General Business. This is the Opposition's time, and I have colleagues who are particularly interested in important reports that were to be put down today which they wanted to debate. The one about the Army Reserve comes to mind. That is what we ought to be doing now.

PARA.TAB: As I said a minute ago, to facilitate the Government we understood that we were asked whether a Bill which was of particular urgency and which the Government wanted to be taken back to the House of Representatives tonight could intervene in the proceedings. We cooperated with that and intended to go back to General Business so that in our time our senators would be able to raise and deal with the matters that are of importance to them. I just correct that one point. We are out of order in that way as well.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That standing order 64 be suspended to enable new business to be commenced after the question for the adjournment of the Senate is first put this day.

SPEECH.PARA: I reiterate that I will put this motion into effect only in so far as it relates to the health insurance Bills and not the veterans' affairs Bills.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator McMullan's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that Government amendment No. 8, as amended, be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 8.Government Amendment No. 8, proposed clause 56D, subsection 26(6), omit the subsection.

This amendment seeks to amend Government amendment No. 8. Briefly, the Democrat amendment seeks to take out the sunset provision. It would be nice to think that everything out there in rural Australia will be magically improved in 18 months to two years time. Unfortunately, we cannot guarantee that.

PARA.TAB: We supported an Opposition amendment to remove a sunset provision in respect of the assets test on the family allowance. Therefore, I look forward tonight to the Opposition agreeing with us that there is no point in having a sunset provision in this legislation. Farmers are either in need of assistance or they are not in need of assistance. We simply should not put this sort of a time limit on that assistance. We can always review it by way of legislation at a later date.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Opposition will not be supporting this amendment. I have some sympathy in so far as we are not particularly satisfied with the whole nature of this package. For that reason, we really do want it to be thoroughly reviewed in due course. Indeed, in government we will no doubt have a somewhat different approach to the one which is currently proposed. But, in the meantime, the most effective way of ensuring that we are not saddled with unsatisfactory legislation indefinitely is to support the sunset clause.

—The Government cannot accept this amendment. As Senator Lees will recall, in the end the Government did back down a couple of weeks ago on a sunset provision that related to family allowance. I think JSA and Newstart, bearing mind the fundamental nature of this change, are in a different class altogether.

PARA.TAB: I am delighted that Senator Alston would take this attitude and I thank him for it because it removes one of the impediments to delivering this package on Monday. This is in the category of an amendment which, if passed, would delay delivery because the House of Representatives would undoubtedly reject the amendment. So the Government also rejects this Democrat amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am most disappointed that Senator Panizza has left the chamber because those very arguments that he regaled us with in regard to a sunset clause in previous legislation would apply to this legislation. It is not time that determines whether a farming community is in hardship; it is in fact the geography and the climate—things that farming communities have to fight day after day, month after month. Those things do not change just because a date is written into legislation. If a farming family is in hardship, it is in hardship.

PARA.TAB: It is callous beyond belief and ignores reality to determine that hardship finishes at the date set by a sunset clause in legislation. That is the argument that was put to us by Senator Panizza. It is an argument that I support entirely and I wish the honourable senator was in the chamber to support us now.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 6.Government Amendment No. 8, proposed clause 56P, paragraph 1132(3A)(e) after "disregarded assets" insert "and for the purposes of this section such other essential and usual expenditure incurred in the operation of the farm".

The purpose of this amendment is effectively to exempt working capital from the hardship provisions. We have had a fair degree of cooperation from the Government in proceeding as far as we have. I certainly acknowledge that Senator Richardson has done his very best to accommodate a number of concerns, both in relation to this legislation and the earlier package of legislation in relation to family allowance and family allowance supplement. But it seems to me that, having gone down the path we did on that occasion in relation to exempting both tools of trade and working capital from the hardship provisions, there is, stated at its lowest, no harm done in being consistent in this instance.

PARA.TAB: I note that in the midst of a lot of bluster about how terribly important it is to the Government that no precedents be set, in the same breath we are told that it is the overwhelming expectation that there will be very few farmers in any position to have many liquid assets, let alone a swag of other assets. In those circumstances, it would seem that we are having almost an academic debate.

I also noted that in the course of purporting to spell out why he felt that somehow this was going too far, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) said that he was not prepared to walk away from the concept of any assets test. That is purely and simply a gross overstatement of the circumstances. By excluding working capital, we are still nonetheless leaving in place a provision that would catch a whole range of other assets. One does not have to get into the exotic to imagine that there can be a range of other readily realisable assets which could be caught by that provision and that would then reduce the JSA payment on a graduated basis.

It seems to us that we really ought to be consistent in the circumstances. As the Minister says, we are probably talking about only a couple of thousand farmers. It is unlikely that the great bulk of them will be in any way affected by whichever version of the hardship test we have. Therefore, we think that it is important to establish a principle. If that is not done, we are in a sense being asked to take the Government on trust.

There may well be very few people who would be caught by the tighter form that the Minister proposes. However, if some people are caught, it will just be bad luck. I would have thought that we would all prefer to give the farmers the benefit of the doubt in that sense by having a consistent principle that would ensure that, if the occasion arose, they still got the benefit of having working capital excluded rather than being simply caught short on the basis that they believed what the Minister said and it did not quite work out that way.

So extending as much goodwill as we can to the Government in view of the concessions it has made in this and other areas, I simply cannot see that this would set the precedent that is claimed by the Minister. The mere fact that this entire package of amendments is very much an exception, that they are targeting relief to a particular group in the community, seems to me to provide an answer to any suggestion that somehow this is a broad based precedent. It clearly is not. I would not pretend to argue that it is and I do not think the Minister would have any trouble in defending the position.

The concessions that have been made to date are nothing more or less than a recognition of the particular circumstances of those in rural communities, just as the amendments that brought in a hardship test in the first instance were a reaction to the ill-considered proposals in the Budget before last to simply bring in an assets test at $300,000 and then $500,000 and pretend that somehow farmers were in the same situation as everyone else. We knew they were not; the Government knew they were not. The Government blustered and lost. It went away and thought about it and 12 months later it came back with a completely different package of proposals which involved the introduction of a hardship test on two specific payments purely and simply to cater for those in situations of hardship in rural areas.

If we go down that path and accept that there are unique circumstances prevailing in country areas, I fail to see that anyone on either side of the House could find themselves embarrassed in defending the proposition that this is simply another unique exception to the general principle. I do not regard it as compromising the Government's ability in other areas. Therefore, we do not see that there is any harm done and there may well be a significant benefit in terms of reassurance, if nothing else. For those reasons, we will be pursuing this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly support the amendments that Senator Alston has brought forward tonight. We are looking at the matter in terms of hardship caused by high interest rates, drought and very low commodity prices. When farmers have to put up with one or even two of those things, they may have some way to survive, but when they are hit with this unholy trinity of the three together, then special measures are required to get them out of trouble.

PARA.TAB: As I said earlier, to plant 1,500 acres of grain, which I suppose is the average planting in Australia, costs about $50,000 to $60,000. If it rains and if the farmer gets a good commodity price, he will hopefully get a profit. Where is the benefit of giving a rural adjustment package and then making the conditions so hard to meet that many people are excluded from it?

Under Senator Richardson's own interpretation, this package is for all viable farmers that cannot handle any more debt. So any farmer who has the capacity to plant a crop would need $40,000 to $50,000 for the average size farm. That means that something like $120 would be taken off his package. If he needs $30,000 to shear sheep, then he loses $120 from the package every fortnight.

If this amendment is not carried, the package will be rendered almost useless because very few farmers will be able to get any benefit from it. So the Government is defeating its own purpose. It is bringing in legislation to support viable farmers, to keep them viable, and then it is removing those benefits from any viable farmer that has the capacity to plant, harvest, shear or fill his diesel tanks. Senator Richardson has gone a long way. I think everyone on this side of the Parliament would concede that he has done his best, but he is defeating what he set out to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not.

—I do not think Senator Richardson has the numbers in this case, so I can only put my arguments to the Committee to see whether it will carry our amendments. I am sure that Senator Lees, in her consistency on these matters, will support Senator Alston's amendments.

—I indicated at the end of the debate on the second reading where the Government stood on this question. I am committed, as I hope everyone here understands, to delivering this package to some 2,000 to 3,000 farmers, starting on Monday. That estimate of 2,000 to 3,000 farmers is with the assets test intact. It is not a matter of defeating the purpose. If this amendment is defeated, the people that we have said will benefit from this package will indeed get the benefit. That is what will happen.

PARA.TAB: We have already excluded farm equipment and the farm itself from the assets test, and these are major concessions. Those opposite are saying that there is no assets test. The Government cannot agree with that. We regard this as a threshold question. By insisting on it, those opposite will prevent those 2,000 to 3,000 farmers from getting what they deserve on Monday.

I appeal to the Opposition and the Australian Democrats to think again on this matter. The Government has moved a long way on a whole series of things. There are a couple of threshold questions for us. We cannot step back beyond those. This is one of them. I really do hope that those opposite will reconsider. Having been through this exercise in many debates in Cabinet as well as here, I really do want to see these farmers get the package, and if those opposite insist on this they will not. So please think again.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to be clear on this matter. I hear the Minister repeatedly saying that there will be effectively no assets test if this amendment is carried. Is the Minister suggesting that somehow any other assets would also be exempt, that everything would be regarded as working capital? I would have thought there is a whole range of items that we could readily identify that would not be working capital, by any stretch of the imagination, and that those things would still be caught by this legislation.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me to be a classic case of hyperbole to pretend that somehow this would mean no assets test in the same way that we all recognise that there would still be assets that would be caught. Indeed, in this and in the previous package of legislation, the Democrats have been moving to water down the primary assets because they took the view that there was a whole range of things, from beach houses to spare cars and other items. I do not see why they are not still caught by these provisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with this problem on a couple of levels. The first point is that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, not my Department, has been doing the analysis in the first instance of the kinds of people likely to be affected by these measures. It is developing a profile of the sorts of people we are dealing with. Far from trying to involve myself in hyperbole, the likelihood is that, if the farmers do have assets, these are most likely to be the very assets the Opposition is now talking about. That is what I am saying.

PARA.TAB: If we exclude farmers from this, I believe the kind of disparity we are creating between farmers and the other 700,000 we were taking about before is far too great. It goes back to the same argument on the second level I put to the Opposition earlier on; that is, that the Government regards the precedents set here as very dangerous indeed. We cannot agree to it for those reasons.

When it comes to a comparison with family allowances, we are actually suggesting the same treatment here as we did two weeks ago. We are not actually suggesting anything different; we are suggesting the same thing. It is just that here there is a second jump. What the Opposition is saying is it does not have to go over the second hurdle and we are saying it does. We still have no difficulty about the hardship provisions; they are being excluded under this. What we are saying is that in the second part of the test, in the assets test, we cannot exclude them. That is the difference we have.

TALK.START.PARA: —But under hardship.

—Under hardship with both we are exempting them. There is a second jump here. We are saying that we do not exclude them in the second jump and the Opposition is saying that we should. I am saying that we cannot.

—Of course we agree with the concept that has been expressed by the coalition and of course we agree with the need to remove as much of the assets testing as possible, as we have done previously with other legislation in other areas of farming. It is not the concern of the Government to establish a precedent that worries us here. Having fought for such removals in so many different areas of legislation, I was surprised to find this proposed amendment presented to us. I had not seen it and I had not known that the Opposition was heading in this direction.

PARA.TAB: I want to consider this amendment very carefully. We have here wording which to me is imprecise and open to different interpretations; for instance, what is `usual' and what is `essential'? This should have had attached to it some time ago the sort of spiel we heard from Senator Alston, which was a speech that more properly belonged in the second reading debate. I am tempted to wonder why, if it was as well thought out as the speech suggests, such options had not been presented to us and to the Minister much earlier. We could have determined our position on it and perhaps suggested even further amendments. It is a question not so much of the direction being offered here but, rather, of the method that is being proposed and the place it is being proposed. It does present us with the difficulty of having to deal with it at this time because of the way it has been added.

The Minister's intention is to deliver this package on Monday to those who desperately need the sort of assistance we have been able to provide from extending and stretching the package as much as we have already. Those farmers who are in desperate straits and who have the capacity to look forward to something would be greeted with an amendment that is imprecise, that requires further delays, that requires further passage through another House, then to be returned here, without knowing what the result will be, simply because the coalition has chosen to introduce it at this time rather than to sort out the fine details earlier. I cannot turn my back on those people who are expecting something on Monday. I think we have to take what we have stretched and extended so far, rather than the vagaries of this amendment and what it might promise.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am disappointed that Senator Bell has obviously accepted blackmail. Why do we not go down this track? I make the suggestion through you, Mr Chairman, that we stick to the amendment, that we push the amendment and let it go down to the other House and see what happens to it then. I have never subscribed to having a gun held at my head. If we do not stick with this amendment, then the whole package is virtually not going to be worth anything.

PARA.TAB: If the viable farmers whom it is supposed to sustain have any capacity to plant, to grow, to harvest, to shear or to do anything that requires money—and Senator Bell knows this because he has a rural background—then $30,000 or $40,000 is required. Every $10,000 in assets is $40 a fortnight coming off the benefit, so $30,000 is $120 off the benefits. That $30,000 would not plant a crop; it might shear 10,000 sheep, which is an under-average size flock. To plant 1,500 acres of wheat, and $50 an acre is the absolute minimum cost—it should be $70 but let us use the figure of $50—$50,000 to $60,000 would be required as working capital. That means the farmer's benefits would be reduced by $240 a fortnight, which makes the benefit hardly worth while.

The farmers I know are strong men, people who will withstand a bit of pressure, and I am not sure that they would want the Democrats to buckle at the knees. I am sure that they would say, `Get up there. Push for us. Fight for it, and we will wear the consequences'. That is the type of people they are. They are gutsy people. They will fight on, and I think they expect the Democrats to fight for them too. They will wear the consequences. They will stand up and say, `At least the Democrats tried. They put it to the test and they didn't go down'. I ask the Democrats to reconsider, to back the farmers and to give it their best.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Alston's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that Government amendment No. 8, as amended, be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 9.Government Amendment No. 8, proposed clause 56Q, omit the clause.

This amendment relates to the ability to review decisions made by the RAS authority with regard to granting section 26 and section 27 certificates. I welcome the support of the Opposition on this amendment. Basically, it will mean that farmers will be able to appeal and restate their case. In view of the hour, I will say no more.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is rather breathtaking to find that, immediately after having thrown in the towel on the last amendment, Senator Lees gets to her feet and speaks as though there had been no consideration of this matter in other terms. Indeed, the Minister said that there had been discussions during the evening about a number of alternative approaches. I am staggered. Either Senator Lees has forgotten what it is all about or she is somehow pretending that there is nothing wrong with the proposal in relation to going to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal.

PARA.TAB: As I understand what the Minister told us both, the Social Security Appeals Tribunal is not qualified to deal with these matters. We then explored the possibility of the AAT. I do not know quite where that has got to, but it struck me as a sensible suggestion. I have indicated to the Minister's advisers that if that is not acceptable on a temporary basis pending the legislation which will be introduced in the new year to establish a proper appeals mechanism, one could build in a sunset clause to ensure that one does not get ratted on next time round by people who promise that they will support the amendments now and do not do so later.

If that is not an appropriate path to go down, then I would be interested in hearing alternative suggestions. For example, the Government could give an undertaking to backdate payments once the new system was in place. In other words, if people do not have any appeal mechanism for three months, let us say, one could give them access at a later time, or one could give them special benefits in the interim. I am happy to accommodate either approach. It seems to me that those are the sorts of things Senator Lees ought to be exploring rather than getting to her feet and, quite dishonestly, pretending that somehow the Social Security Appeals Tribunal is the way to go and completely ignoring what has been brought to her attention earlier this evening.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I realise that there was some discussion as to what would be appropriate. The AAT was the later suggestion. But my understanding was that we were to leave that for Senator Richardson to discuss and debate and to answer our questions. As I understood it—correct me if I am wrong—the Opposition had given us an undertaking that it would indeed support this amendment. Therefore, I make no apology whatsoever for saying that when I got to my feet.

PARA.TAB: It was our one amendment that the Opposition was interested in, despite the fact that the Opposition had moved the sunset provision previously. It seems that as soon as the Democrats move an amendment those opposite are automatically obliged to reject it—notwithstanding it was something that they had previously given an undertaking to do.

With regard to the decision on the last amendment and the one upon which I did seek support and advice from my colleagues, I was advised that, as this amendment had not had the chance to go to our Party room, it was most unwise for me to continue with an amendment that was likely to put a Bill at risk.

Time after time the Liberals come into this place with amendments which have been drawn up during the dinner break, or perhaps later. We really would like an opportunity to have some time to be able to examine the major amendments. I am quite happy to run with some of the smaller amendments as we go. But when we have amendments as beneficial and in fact as attractive as that particular amendment was, but which put a Bill at risk, I am not prepared to continue with it without consulting my colleagues. If Senator Alston thinks that is unwise, that is fine; it may be the way in which he operates.

To return to the amendment in hand, I was given an undertaking. I understood that the Minister was looking at other mechanisms, but I do not think that farmers can sit around and wait for three months.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quarrelling with the Australian Democrats' last decision. That decision was taken by the Democrats presumably on advice and on reflection. I am quarrelling with the fact that Senator Lees got to her feet and put the matter as though she was expecting us to support her amendment and sat down. She put clearly to the Committee that she saw nothing wrong with the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and expected us to take the same view. Therefore, Senator Lees, quite wrongly but maybe inadvertently, misrepresented the entire situation.

PARA.TAB: Senator Lees had previously acknowledged that there were deficiencies as identified by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) in the proposal to take the matter to the SSAT. We both shared that reservation and explored other alternatives. What I am objecting to is Senator Lees standing up and pretending that somehow we are doing the wrong thing by not supporting an amendment which the Democrats themselves conceded was invalid. I do not want to get into a quarrel. I am simply saying that rationality should prevail and that we should all be looking at the most appropriate appeals mechanism.

The only reason that I am provoked to rise again is to set the record straight. I have no quarrel with Senator Lees putting forward propositions and explaining them, but I do not want her to suggest that we are reneging on a proposition which the Democrats themselves have conceded is flawed.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the score of appeals to the SSAT, the Government has two reasons for opposing the proposal. As the person who is responsible for appointing people to that Tribunal, I know the expertise it has. We have doctors, lawyers, and people with all sorts of qualifications, but agricultural economics has never been one of them. The people on the SSAT around Australia are simply not qualified in that respect and it is not the place to go.

PARA.TAB: I undertook to Senator Lees, Senator Boswell and Senator Alston earlier to look at the idea of this being sent to the AAT. There are a few problems there as well. The main problem, as the Attorney-General's Department rightly points out—I had not thought it through, as Senator Lees will recall; it was a request made on the spur of the moment—is that the State governments are very unlikely to agree to it. The difficulty is that, because we are involving RAS, we need the cooperation of the States. Whatever arguments we have among ourselves about consultation, if we go into this matter without talking to the States, inevitably we will get an argument. We are talking about a non-Commonwealth agency being reviewed by a Commonwealth agency. That will be difficult without the complete cooperation of the States.

However, I want to give a number of undertakings. I am not certain that this is the exact time, but with the indulgence of the Chair I will do so now. The Government can certainly undertake that, as a matter of urgency and priority, very early in the autumn session we will introduce legislation for an appeals mechanism. We will further undertake that anyone who is aggrieved by a decision from Monday on will be able to appeal to whatever tribunal is set out under the legislation. The decision can be effective in respect of payments back to the first day of the scheme. I can give an absolute undertaking that that will be done. We will not attempt to exclude people from the appeals mechanism because we do not happen to have one up and running right now.

In regard to Senator Alston's request about special benefit, I think that there are difficulties. Therefore, I cannot give that undertaking because of the qualifications involved, which are a quite different set from those we are talking about now. Certainly I can give an undertaking that on the first day of the scheme whoever applies from that date will have the right of appeal to this tribunal, even if it is not set up for another few months.

TALK.START.PARA: —With a right to backdate.
—With a right to a backdating of the payment to the first day.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.
Government amendment No. 8, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 10.Part 2, page 32, at end of Part, add the following Division:
calculating the value of a person's assets

PARA.TAB: "56A. The Principal Act is amended by inserting after section 1118 the following section:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Primary Production assets to be disregarded in calculating the value of a person's assets

PARA.TAB: `1118A. In calculating the value of a person's assets for the purposes of this Act (other than under subparagraph 263(1)(iv) and sections 1125 and 1126), where:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)the person has his or her principal home on a farm that is owned by the person, the person's partner or the person and his or her partner; and
(b)the person ordinarily works in a full-time capacity as a primary producer on the farm; and

(c)the value of the whole or part of the land comprising the farm (including the value of any improvements to or on the land) would but for this subsection, be included in the value of the assets of the person; and

(d)the value of items of plant or articles owned by the person, the person's partner or the person and his or her partner and used wholly and exclusively for the purposes of primary production would, but for this subsection, be included in the value of the assets of the person;
the value of the assets of the person does not include the value of the land referred to in paragraph (c) or the value of items of plant or articles referred to in paragraph (d).'.".

This amendment adds the provision that the tools of trade are not included. We have been through this debate time and again, and I suggest to Senator Alston that if he is really interested in making this an easy and accessible scheme he should support our amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has made its position clear on this matter in other debates. We are opposed to this proposal and I can only repeat our opposition.

I wish to say briefly that we have been through this debate before. This is another part of the series of amendments that would have put sole parents in the same boat as all other pensioners.

TALK.START.PARA: —We debated this question earlier and I do not see any need to repeat the debate. The Government rejects the Democrat amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to speak to this amendment, but I would like to speak to schedule 5. During the second reading debate I pointed out that the first stage of the data matching failed to achieve the savings that were estimated in the 1990 Estimates. The Government claimed that it would make $65m savings in the first six-month period of the data matching and have 113,000 matches—people who have been identified through that data matching process. As I said, that would result in a $65m saving.

PARA.TAB: I know that the Minister said in reply to me during the second reading debate that the data matching was delayed, but the savings that were given for the six-month period—or slightly longer—showed in the first period of the data matching for social security that 22,779 matches occurred with a saving of $12.7m.

There is a shortfall. The Minister might say that there were problems and hiccups with the data matching and that only two data matches have occurred, but they were the estimates that he gave us. Surely the Department should have taken into account the problems in setting this up. The Government has not achieved the savings that the Minister said it was going to achieve, and it is appropriate that he explain to the Senate why, given the hysteria that surrounded some of the discussions that took place in the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs—saying that the world would cave in if we did not get this, and that we were going to have all these savings—now we see only $12.7m in that first six-month period. It does not match with the $65m that was estimated. Can the Minister explain that to the Senate?

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Patterson knows, I did that earlier on. If she does not like the explanation I regret that quite sincerely, nonetheless it is the explanation. I have already said that there will be substantial savings. I have already said that there was a hold up in setting up the system. A regrettable one, but these things happen. Nonetheless, we will see very substantial savings achieved. I am very happy to give Senator Patterson an undertaking to have a further look at the question and give her an answer in the next week or so as to where we think this is, as we speak. I will do that. When she says there was hysteria at the Committee hearing, there certainly was not any on my part. I am not a very hysterical person. I cannot necessarily deny that there was any, but there certainly was not any from me.

—I thank the Minister. While he is at it, maybe he could also tell us whether there has been a revision of the $290m estimate for a full year down to a lower figure, and whether he will indicate that the savings are not going to be at the level that was anticipated or predicted when the system was set up.

—As I said, there was a delay in setting up the system so there is not the immediate savings that we wanted. We have gone around this point a few times. I cannot elaborate. It is just a fact. We have given estimates of what we are going to get. I have not been advised of any reason why we should not achieve them.
—So the Minister is saying that he is going to achieve the estimates that were set out in the 1990 Estimates papers?
—We will not achieve the estimated savings necessarily in the time that we said because we have had a delay, but we will achieve the savings.
—In a one-year full period of data matching you will achieve $290m, which was the estimate for a full data matching year.

—I can only say again that I have not been advised at any time by the Department that the full year saving cannot be achieved. It is just that we cannot achieve it necessarily in the first year because we have had a delay. I will get for Senator Patterson confirmation of that hopefully on Monday or Tuesday. That is as soon as I can do it.

—While he is doing that, could the Minister clarify something? There is the possibility of a misinterpretation of page 31 of the progress report on data matching. Under the summary of estimated full year savings the total is given as $115.4m. It says it should be noted that only two data matching cycles have been undertaken. It says that up to nine cycles can be undertaken each year. It does not tell us whether that $115.4m is what is estimated for data matching for the year or whether that is what is estimated, given that there were only two done a year. If nine are done would it be 4.9 times more? It is not clear from that document and I would appreciate if the Minister could clarify that.
—I will certainly have the matter clarified.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Schedule, as amended, agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Under the Standing Orders, only a Minister can move the adjournment. No-one can move the adjournment now because we are in the middle of considering these Bills.

INTERJECT.PARA: As I understand it, you can move to adjourn the debate on the Bills if you want to.
