That the debate be now adjourned.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning we are debating a package of four pathology Bills: the Health Insurance (Pathology) Amendment Bill 1991; the Health Insurance (Pathology) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991; the Health Insurance (Pathology) (Licence Fee) Bill 1991; and the Health Insurance (Pathology) (Fees) Bill 1991. These Bills implement the pathology restructuring measures announced in the 1990-91 Budget. The changes arise from matters raised by the National Health Strategy in its background paper No. 6 entitled `Directions for Pathology' by John Deeble and Peter Lewis-Hughes.

PARA.TAB: The National Health Strategy background paper provided some very interesting statistics showing the increased use of pathology services and the impact that this is having on the Budget. The number of pathology services performed increased from 22.3 million to 34.4 million between 1984-85 and 1989-90. This was an increase of 54.3 per cent. I think in anyone's terms that would be considered a large increase. However, in the same time period, the number of other medical services rose by 28.8 per cent. One can see a noticeable difference between those two increases. The total fees charged for pathology services increased by 67.8 per cent. Figures provided in the paper show that this increase has been largely due to an increase in the number of services performed. It is interesting to read that the average services per capita increased by 41.7 per cent over this period.

It does not take a genius to come to the conclusion that there is a level of overservicing in pathology services that must be addressed. In fact, the National Health Strategy group concluded that `some pathology testing is clearly unnecessary and wasteful, even on criteria which go beyond their contribution to narrowly defined clinical outcomes, although not all of the non-clinical reasons are unacceptable'.

As I have said, there is clearly a problem with the increasing costs of pathology services. As is typically the case with this Government, the problem has not been tackled comprehensively because the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) has been too gutless—I hope that is not an unparliamentary word, Madam Acting Deputy President, but with your experience I am sure that you would know—to implement the reforms that are necessary. The Minister continues to tinker at the edges of our health system instead of introducing the fundamental reforms that are so vitally needed.

There are a number of changes that the Government might have made. It could have addressed the problem of the absence of a price signal. If a service is free, it will be overused. I want to take the time of the Senate to share something that I was reading the other night in preparation for a speech that I was making. The founder of the first medical school in America in the mid-1700s indicated in a speech that it was important that people had a price signal and that they differentiate between the cost of pharmaceuticals and the cost of medicine so that they knew how much that service cost. That is something that somebody was saying in the mid-1700s; it is not new. People need a price signal to know how much that service is costing. If a service is free, there is a tendency for it to be overused.

Not only is there a problem on the demand side but also the provider of that service, realising that it is free, will oversupply or may be tempted to oversupply. This may not necessarily happen, but the temptation is there to oversupply. This is one of the problems facing pathology and, of course, the wider Medicare system. When bulkbilling is available and the service is provided free of charge, that service is likely to be overused. This is exactly what is happening with pathology.

I now turn to some of the specific aspects of the Bills before the Senate. The Health Insurance (Pathology) Amendment Bill 1991 amends existing provisions in the parent Act to allow for the payment of fees after the Minister has accepted undertakings from approved pathology authorities and practitioners, and has approved premises in principle as accredited pathology laboratories. In order to be eligible to participate in Medicare benefit arrangements for pathology services, practitioners are required to sign an undertaking to the Minister that the practitioner will comply with the requirements of the legislation and certain administrative arrangements. The proprietor of a laboratory must sign an undertaking to become an approved pathology authority and a pathologist must sign an undertaking to become an approved pathology practitioner.

I turn my attention to the Health Insurance (Pathology) Amendment (No. 2) Bill 1991. One of the provisions will introduce a licensing scheme for pathology specimen collection centres which will require collection centres to apply for and meet a number of conditions before they could be granted a licence. One of the other Bills in the package provides for a $1,000 licence fee to be charged for each collection centre.

The Opposition is concerned about the restrictions on the number of licensed collection centres that will be allowed to operate. We are extremely doubtful whether in fact the reduction in specimen collection centres will result in a reduction in the use of services. It concerns us that the only result might be inconvenience to the patients, who may have to travel further to have their specimens taken. I believe that the Department has admitted that it only has guesstimates on the possible reduction in centres. It has also conceded that the imposition of fees is little more than a revenue raising initiative. I do not believe that the Department has given due consideration to the effect that the rationalisation of collection centres will have on rural areas.

I ask the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) to seek assurances from the Minister responsible that that will be closely monitored to ensure that rural people are not affected, as we have seen in pharmacy restructuring. In some small towns, because of a failure to address the issues in the implementation stage, it has meant that some people are without a pharmacy service and we do not want to burden those people with undue effort to have specimens collected.

Another aspect of the reduction in collection centres that has concerned us is that the Minister will, by determination, decide the maximum number of licensed collection centres that may be operated by approved pathology laboratories. We have not, as I said, seen a draft of those determinations. But, as I mentioned earlier when Senator Tate was absent from the chamber, Senator Tate has agreed to organise for us to see the directions that were given to the draftsman. In fact, I have been advised that the shadow Minister's office asked for information of this nature so we could know the formula that was to be used to determine the number of collection centres. That was not forthcoming. We received that finally this morning, but we have not had a large amount of time to consider it. We agreed with the thrust of those directions, and in the discussions that we had with Senator Tate he indicated that he would be undertaking in the chamber tonight to table those determinations on 11 November so that we would have time to disallow them if necessary. I may be losing my senses at this time of night, but if for some reason we rise before 12 December I presume that the Minister will ensure that those determinations are here the day before we rise so that we would have time to disallow them. I do not ever imagine that in fact we will be up before 12 December.

Another measure in the Bill provides that a Medicare benefit for a pathology service is not payable where there is found to be some form of inappropriate agreement, arrangement or incentive for ordering the service between the approved pathology practitioner providing this service and the treating practitioner requesting the service.

The Opposition supports this measure. There is quite a good deal of anecdotal evidence of inappropriate arrangements between pathologists and the treating practitioner: for example, TAB accounts perhaps, nursing staff, rents paid or other kickbacks provided or paid for by unethical pathologists. We are not inferring that pathologists are basically unethical. In the majority of cases, pathologists carry out their practices scrupulously and ethically, but the small minority who do not behave in an ethical way give the rest a bad name and in fact contribute to the overservicing and the blow-out in the cost. The Opposition supports this measure of preventing Medicare benefits being payable where there is found to be some illegal and inappropriate activities taking place. As I said, we would not cast aspersions on the profession, and the peak body is in agreement with this sort of action.

The other significant measure included in the Government's reforms is changes in the fee structure. I understand that the Government is to introduce a two-tiered transaction fee as a trade-off for a 30 per cent cut. It will cover the costs of transporting specimens to the laboratory and other overheads. This transaction fee will be paid for each episode of tests. In other words, if all tests are ordered on the one day for the same patient by the same general practitioner, this measure will not affect the referring pattern of doctors but will reduce the benefit to pathologists and reduce Commonwealth outlays.

The Opposition does not believe that this two-tiered structure will have a major impact on the quality of service offered or the appropriateness of the service offered. However, it will have some impact on overuse, and for that reason we will not be opposing these measures.

One matter I wish to raise relates to the amendment to clause 4 that was moved in the House of Representatives. This amendment closed a loophole that was picked up by the shadow Minister for health, Dr Woods. The loophole related to collection centres in private hospitals. The amendment Dr Woods moved illustrates the poor drafting and the speed at which legislation is presented to Parliament.

As I said before, yesterday afternoon we were presented with six pages of Government amendments to two of the Bills currently before the Senate. I appreciated the briefing that was provided by the Minister's office and the explanation but, as I said, we had little time to examine them. It is not good enough to have amendments to amendments and loopholes where there would have been the possibility of some pathologists abusing the system. It had not been thought through, and that seems to be the case with a lot of the legislation that comes into this chamber. Not enough `what if' questions have been asked, and loopholes have to be detected.

I indicate that the Opposition will be supporting the amendments to be moved by the Government. These amendments basically amend oversights in the amending legislation before us. The impression I have is that some of the amendments relate to points raised by the Health Insurance Commission when it finally saw legislation or began to think about working through the legislation. It is obvious that either it was not consulted in the drafting of these changes or it had not thought through the implications of these changes adequately.

It seems that the Government often does not consult with industry. But it appears either not to have consulted with the Health Insurance Commission or the Health Insurance Commission has not adequately thought through the implications of those changes. It is a disgraceful situation and it is unacceptable. We should not have legislation coming to this chamber in that state. It should come thought through, without the need to have an amending Bill and amendments to that amending Bill.

As I have already stated, the Opposition is very concerned that the regulations and determinations accompanying the Government's pathology restructuring package have not been presented. Because those determinations are an integral part of the package, it would have behoved the Department to have those determinations here so that we would not have had the fuss we had this morning and the inconvenience to the Minister, to me and to my colleagues in having to rush around trying to discuss it.

The Opposition will be supporting this package of four pathology Bills. As I stated earlier, the Opposition does not believe that they will make the fundamental structural changes to the pathology aspects of Medicare that are needed. However, some minor improvements will be made, so we will not be opposing them. On behalf of the Opposition, I move the following second reading amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ", and the Senate congratulates the Coalition parties for turning their backs on the band-aid solutions offered by the Australian Labor Party to overcome a Medicare system which is in crisis and having the vision to develop a revolutionary health care policy which will maintain universal coverage, restore the balance between public and private hospitals, contain costs, reduce waiting lists in public hospitals and free up the health insurance system".

Last week, as part of the Opposition's Fightback policy package, the coalition released a comprehensive health policy that will restore equity, fairness and practicality to our ailing health system, in contrast to this Government, which only tinkers at the edges of the problems in the system—and we have an example of that tinkering tonight—providing only bandaid measures.

PARA.TAB: The coalition's policy addresses the fundamental problems plaguing our health system. As part of our policy, Medicare will be retained and improved. Up to 65 per cent of the public will receive up to $800 in tax credits for private health cover, bulkbilling will be retained for pensioners, and aged non-pensioners will receive a pharmaceutical concession card. The coalition health policy provides a sensible, equitable and fair means both to address the immediate problems of Australia's health care system and to achieve long term reform.

I need to quote only two of many organisations heralding the benefits of the coalition's policy. Firstly, the Voluntary Health Insurance Association of Australia described the policy as the best health policy either political party has produced in at least the last decade. Secondly, the National Association of Nursing Homes and Private Hospitals said:

SPEECH.PARA: At last—surgery which will cure Medicare.
It went on to say:
It is a rare experience in Australia to hear expounded the scope, depth and vision of a new set of policies by any political party at the Federal level.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take up a lot of the Senate's time this morning. The Australian Democrats will be supporting these health insurance Bills and the amendments that are amending the amending Bills. These four health insurance Bills represent part of the Government's restructuring of the pathology industry announced in this year's Budget and amended after it had further consulted with the industry. They come in response to evidence and widespread recognition that pathology services have been increasing for many years at more than twice the rate of other medical services.

PARA.TAB: Data collected by the National Health Strategy indicates quite clearly that more people are now receiving pathology services—some 34.5 per cent in 1989-90 compared with 25.6 per cent in 1984-85. Furthermore, over the period of Medicare's existence, pathology use has risen by 54.3 per cent compared with 28.8 per cent for other medical services. Increasing use of pathology appears to have coincided with it moving away from being largely a hospital based service and into a community based service—a move which has provided the scope for escalating costs and, I might add, escalating incomes for many private pathologists.

Aside from the measures in these Bills, it is high time we began looking seriously at an expansion of the public provision of pathology services. As the National Health Strategy's exploration of pathology services pointed out, many people believe that pathology is the medical service least suited to fee for service and that as it is not a personal doctor-patient service, it should be structured and financed along the same lines as other public health facilities. This is a view that I believe we really need to give some further consideration.

These four Bills comprise a package that covers structural reform, cost saving measures, and reforms of fees. According to the Minister, they lay the ground for further reform and restructuring of the pathology industry. Essentially, these Bills address three problems, and I will be brief. Firstly, there is the problem of kickbacks or inducements offered by some pathology practices—I stress that it is only some. This is for treating doctors in order to encourage them—entice them—to use particular pathology services. For example, it is well known that this sometimes takes the form of pathology practices offering staff, particularly nurses, to doctors. These staff are paid for by the pathologist. Such arrangements obviously limit the doctor's capacity to exercise freedom of choice as to what pathology services he or she will use. Further, as the nurse is generally used for collecting specimens, this is really a fairly blatant attempt to make the doctor some sort of outreach service for the pathology practice.

Unfortunately, there have also been reports of other sorts of incentives, including free travel and equipment, although such practices are, for very obvious reasons, extremely difficult to document. However, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, in its two hundred and thirty-sixth report in 1985, looked at medical fraud and overservicing and expressed considerable disquiet about the likelihood and consequences of such practices. The Government has moved to stop this sort of activity, and the Democrats welcome this move.

Secondly, there are too many collection centres operating. I think that is pretty clearly recognised. It is also recognised that the expansion of collection centres and courier services is a major issue on the supply side of pathology. Data from the national health strategy indicates that in 1989-90 there were 10.2 million non-hospital pathology episodes in Australia and that about 60 per cent of these collection centres were used. The additional cost of the use of private collection and courier services was in the vicinity of $60m to $70m. That is about 10 per cent of Medicare pathology costs. As the national health strategy Background Paper No. 6 observed, these costs `arose entirely from the underuse and inefficient use of people and facilities'. On page 70, the paper goes on to state:

SPEECH.PARA: This is one activity in which competition serves only to raise costs and whose reduction would free some valuable resources. It is an area where savings would be real and result in neither a shifting of costs to patients nor, necessarily, a reduction in provider profitability.

The fact is that there are too many collection centres, and this is generally accepted by the pathology industry. It is not an issue of reducing the number of pathology episodes—unfortunately some people have read it this way—but, rather, an issue of reducing inefficiency and unnecessary additional expense.

PARA.TAB: To call it interfering in a free market, as unfortunately has been done in the other place, simply demonstrates yet again the inability of some politicians and members of the medical profession to acknowledge that there is no such thing as a free market in the delivery of health services.

As I said before—I do not intend to go through it in detail tonight—the evidence from here and overseas is clear: market signals are undermined by the distinctive nature of the health system. There are a number of features of the health system that make free market logic unconvincing in this context, and that analysis includes a supply of pathology services. Indeed, some of these features are even more apparent in the area of pathology, because it is not the patient who is responsible for assessing the need or otherwise for a pathology service and then going to a doctor to request it. This is one area where the patient is virtually wholly reliant on the judgment and skill of his or her doctor. It is even more of a nonsense to argue for price signals in this area than it is in the provision of health services generally.

In addition, unlike the so-called genuine free market—if, indeed, there is such an animal—the taxpayer pays for inefficiencies in this area via the Medicare levy. I fail to see why the taxpayer should be obliged to protect these sorts of inefficiencies. As I said, this is not a free market, and it would be grossly irresponsible of the Government to permit the number of collection centres to grow with no regard to the consequences for public expenditure. Accordingly, we support the Government's move in this direction.

Thirdly, there is the issue of fees. A number of amendments are proposed to the pathology services table resulting in a reduction in the schedule fee which will be offset by the introduction of a new transaction fee. These fees have been the subject of considerable negotiation with the entire pathology industry and, in fact, the package was modified, as I have mentioned, after the Budget as a consequence of those negotiations. The new fee will cover those costs not directly involved in the test procedures, costs such as collecting the samples and transporting them.

These fees will be two-tiered with a higher fee being set for licence collection centres, private hospitals, the patient's residence or licence day hospital facilities. The lower fee will cover specimens collected in licensed temporary collection centres or in the treating doctor's surgery. Medicare benefits will not be payable where specimens are collected in an unlicensed collection centre or where an inappropriate agreement, arrangement or incentive for requesting the services is present between the pathology provider and the treating practitioner.

These changes will certainly result in savings to the taxpayer and, undoubtedly, will have some effect on the delivery of pathology services. However, it really is only playing about the edges of a significant problem in Australia's health system. It is not an easy problem to solve, and it is certainly not helped by the lack of adequate data about the actual cost structures of pathology service providers. As has been frequently pointed out, pathology fees are not based on an accurate costing. I hope that the Government is looking to undertake such an exercise.

I turn now to the Opposition's concern about the unavailability of ministerial determinations to be made under the second Bill, the Health Insurance (Pathology) (Fees) Bill. This does concern us. It certainly has resulted in a flurry of activity in the later stages of today. It would have helped had this been signalled earlier. We do have some sympathy with the point of view that it is preferable to see all the regulations, determinations, et cetera, at the time when the Bill is presented to us. Unfortunately, this is not always possible. I accept the Minister's explanation and, indeed, the reality is that it often does not occur. We do accept the Minister's undertaking that we will have the required determination at a date that will give us an opportunity to disallow if necessary.

We are pleased to have had a copy of the agreed formula for determining the number of licensed collection centres. We have, and I believe the Opposition has, a pretty clear idea of exactly what to expect. I am also quite satisfied that the Parliament has, in this instance, conducted lengthy negotiations with the pathology industry. This is certainly not the case in radiology, given the difficulties that we are having in that area. It would be nice to see the same practice applied to radiology where all players are involved and not just some.

In conclusion, I accept the argument that it is desirable to see the entire package of legislation at the time of the presentation of the principal Bill. It would certainly make life much easier all around. In this case I do not believe the circumstances actually warrant holding up the passage of this package of Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The package of health insurance Bills, as Senator Lees has said, is a Budget measure and their purpose is to reduce the number of collection services in the pathology area. We are told the reason for the large number of collection services having to be reduced is that, if there are a large number of collection services, there will be an equally large number of pathology services ordered by the general practitioners.

PARA.TAB: The Department of Health, Housing and Community Services says that if there is a collection service just around the corner the general practitioner is more likely to say to a patient, `Oh well, we may as well have a blood test done', and then send the patient around to have a blood test. The Department has said that, because the collection centre is so close, the general practitioner will feel that he may as well use it.

I have never heard anything quite so stupid in all my life. I think that general practitioners are, indeed, far more responsible than just ordering the odd test because a collection centre is close by. We certainly do not have that situation in our State.I would say that the general practitioners whose practices are located near the collection centres would not use those services any more than the general practitioners whose practices are not situated close by.

We are also told that there is anecdotal evidence—I would like to stress that it is anecdotal—that some general practitioners are getting kickbacks. How many general practitioners are getting kickbacks: one or two, 50, 500, or 1,000? I ask the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) whether there is any evidence—when I say evidence I do not want anecdotal evidence—that this is occurring. We have asked for the number of prosecutions that have taken place, as it is illegal to indulge in that practice. We have been told none.

I say again that we really need more than anecdotal evidence. The Minister will not remember because he was not here at the time—looking around the chamber I cannot see anybody here who would remember, but I do—that a previous President of the Australian Medical Association, Lionel Wilson, was convinced by the Department of Health that there was considerable overservicing and fraud primarily by general practitioners. Some of the departmental officers present tonight may have been around at that time. Lionel Wilson was told that Dr Blewett, based on the Department's figures, was really going to attack the doctors. The Department, in its wisdom, had come up with an assertion that doctors in Australia were involved in overservicing and fraud to the extent of $100m. An overservicing and fraud detection service was set up in the Department.

At the time, Lionel Wilson, the President of the AMA, went public and said that he was ashamed to say this figure had indeed been proved by the Department, and he acknowledged it. Dr Blewett, in his typical fashion, went in for a tremendous amount of doctor bashing on the basis of those figures from the Department. Finally, Dr Blewett had to acknowledge that the figures that the Department had used were fatally flawed. Dr Blewett took the fraud and overservicing detention service away from the Department because it could not be trusted and gave it to the HIC. The Department had used figures that were totally wrong. The President of the AMA was then left saying to his colleagues, `Well, I am very sorry. I was fooled by accepting the Department's figures'.

All this rhetoric of anecdotal evidence was rife in 1983 when this Government came to power. That is what the Government is again doing. It is not bringing to this chamber any substantial evidence, just rhetoric. We have once again anecdotal evidence, nothing substantial, from the same Department of Health as we had when those fatally flawed figures were produced way back then. As I say, an apology was eventually given, but it was a little late as the damage was done. I just do not accept this anecdotal evidence and I hope the Minister will not accept it either.

Let me get back to the Bill. The Government intends to cut the number of collection services to the pathology laboratories. What amazes me is that the number of collection services each laboratory should have will be reviewed annually. I suppose it depends whether the laboratory has increased or reduced its services in the last 12 months. I am not surprised that that comes from the Department because the bureaucrats have to build their castles and, if they do not have continuous annual checks, those departments cannot increase in number.

The pathologists have been consulted very widely on this issue. Madam Acting Deputy President, I remind you that this is a Budget Bill. The Minister will remember because he answered my question earlier on another Bill in one of the Committees. I asked him why the College of General Practitioners and the AMA were not consulted about the reduction of the $3.50 in the medical schedule rebate, and where the bulkbilled patients will have to make an up-front payment.

We all remember the fiasco when the rebate was reduced from $3.50 to $2.50 and all the high jinks that went on in Caucus. The Government had originally decided that there had to be an up-front payment to make patients realise that the levy did not cover their health services and there was a cost to them visiting the general practitioner and it had chosen $3.50. A Caucus committee was set up which came up with the brilliant idea that we would cut the figure back to $2.50. But to make sure that the general practitioners were encouraged to bulkbill, the Government decided it would give them an extra dollar to bulkbill.

The Minister will also remember when I asked him why there was not consultation on this issue, because the doctors had been promised that, if there were going to be large changes, they would be consulted. I asked him about the additional Caucus committee decision to bring forward $12m to `reform the funding of general practices'. There were to be large, sweeping changes to general practice in this country in the areas of the use of practice grants, trialing the use of practice budgets, accreditation of general practices, supply and distribution of medical practitioners, and information technology. The Minister said, `We could not consult. It was a Budget Bill'. That was the answer the Minister gave me at that committee.

Now, of course, we are debating another Budget Bill, with all the consultation in the world. The College of Pathologists has consulted widely with the Government and has agreed with the Government and has put up suggestions to the Government that have been implemented. The College agrees with the determinations that have been put up because the Government consulted it. It does not matter now that it was a Budget Bill. It mattered for the general practitioners and the AMA. It did not matter for the College of Pathologists. We may well ask why. What is the difference?

The difference is that the pathologists took the Government to the High Court and they won. So, of course, the Government does not want that sort of egg on its face again. It has respect for the College of Pathologists and so it will not take it on. Even though it is a Budget Bill, for some magical reason the Government is able to consult with the pathologists, but not with the general practitioners and the AMA. It said, `We could not do that because it was a Budget Bill', but it could consult with the pathologists. So I am not quite sure what the Minister's answer will be on this matter. Maybe he will just ignore it. He is getting some advice, but what use will that be to him?

I would like to add in the final part of my speech a warning to the pathologists. I have already made this warning to the College when I spoke to someone there this morning. I said, `Are you aware of what this Government has done to the pharmacists?'. The pharmacists are now nationalised; they cannot open up a pharmacy wherever they like, whenever they like. They cannot enter into a free market situation. They have to be licensed. The Government says that they cannot open up a pharmacy in a country area if it does not think they should, if the restructuring authority does not believe there should be a pharmacy there.

In other words, if the Government thinks there should be a pharmacy there it will let the pharmacists open one but not if it does not agree with it. The pharmacists may think that they can make it go; they may think they can make a profit; they may think that it is a very good business venture, but if the Government does not want them to open then it will not let them. Up until now we have not even had an appeal mechanism for it. It has just come in now, and the restructuring authority has been going since 9 August 1990 with no appeal mechanism.

What else has the Government done to the pharmacists? It told the pharmacists how much they would get paid—not how much they could charge but how much they would get paid—by the Government and how much they could charge as the result. But what the Government did not tell the pharmacists—we should remember that that agreement was done on volume of prescriptions and I am sure it was because it is a Budget Bill—is that there was going to be a payment up-front by pensioners of $2.50 which would cut the pharmacists' prescription numbers considerably.

The original agreement that was done on prescription volume is now scuttled because the prescription volume has altered so remarkably. This morning I said to the College of Pathologists, `Just bear in mind how familiar it all is. What you're agreeing to now is what the pharmacists agreed to a little while ago when they had that notorious agreement between Jim Matthews and the Government. They have lost the right to open where they want to and under this legislation you are losing the right to open a collection service where you want to. This is just the first step. In time you will be equally nationalised as the pharmacists have been. So don't come crying to us when it is all too late because you've agreed with the Government; you've negotiated with this socialist government; and you've watched the pharmacists being nationalised but you've done nothing about it yourself'.

This is exactly the same warning that I am giving the College of General Practitioners and the AMA. If they go along with this agreement and with these wonderful reforms of general practice where the Government tells them they can have a budget for their pathology and where the Government tells them they can have a budget for their pharmaceuticals and radiology—whereas to me a budget means that one sticks by it—what happens when one's budget is spent and one has 50 more patients lined up? What sort of service is one going to give then? The Government is driving the general practitioners so broke that it expects them to gratefully accept the grants to complement their fee for service reimbursements because they will be ripe for the picking, will they not? That is what the Government is relying on in its negotiations.

What does the accreditation of general practices mean? When I asked the Minister, he said that he had no idea. He told me in our committee, `I don't know. How do you expect me to know? That's all to be negotiated'. But when I asked why were the negotiations not done earlier, he said, `We couldn't. It was a Budget Bill.' After asking the Minister what information technology meant, I read this out to him:

SPEECH.PARA: Information technology could substantially enhance diagnostic and patient education roles of GPs as well as improving the business management of practices.
And he said, `I don't know what that means'—

TALK.START.PARA: —I gave you examples.
—Just a minute, we are coming to that bit because the Minister then said, `I understood it would help business management'. I read on:

SPEECH.PARA: However, as with other equipment, the current structure of general practice means few practices have sufficient capital base to provide these facilities.

I then asked, `What does it mean?' and the Minister replied, `It is all English'. I said, `Well, you explain it me' and he replied, `How do you expect me to know? It is all going to be negotiated with the AMA and the College, but we couldn't do it before because it is a Budget Bill. Anyway, it is all being amicably done by the College and by the AMA because they had agreed to set up committees'. But while the Minister was saying that, behind him the AMA and the College were shaking their heads vigorously. The Minister had been given misinformation by his Department because both the AMA and the College said, `No, we have not agreed to any of that. We have not even agreed to the setting up of these committees'. That paper he was reading from was a departmental paper that it had put up for discussion.

PARA.TAB: I am not going to be in this place for very much longer but I will be in government for a few months after the next election because I will be here until 30 June 1993. When we are in government, even for that short time, I will be able to remind the pathologists not to come back crying to us—if they are nationalised by then—because this is what they agreed to with this socialist Government. I warned them but it has all been too late for them because that is what they are doing and that is what the Minister is party to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Health Insurance (Pathology) Bill is addressing the rising use of pathology. Medibank was brought in 18 years ago and what we are witnessing with this Bill is an attempt to control the dying throes of Medibank nee Medicare. What the Government is doing is saying, `Okay, we're going to cut pathology costs by limiting the number of collection centres' and that is the answer. But what has happened in the last 18 years? I do not think that the Government has woken up to the fact that there have been a few advances in science in the last 18 years. There are such things as cholesterol testing, which was not heard of 18 years ago in terms of availability, and also Papanicolaou smears for the testing of cervical cancer.

PARA.TAB: The death rate from carcinoma of the cervix is rapidly decreasing because of the introduction of a scientific advance in pathology. The Minister would be aware that AIDS has developed in the last 10 years. Thousands of people are being tested and retested for AIDS; pathology tests are being done. Cytology for breast cancer has been introduced in the last 18 years. We have in-vitro fertilisation. I could go on for the next half an hour introducing the Minister and his Department to new tests that have been developed over the last 18 years. And one wonders why pathology is increasing.

Allied to that, the population has increased in the last 18 years. It increases at 1.2 per cent per annum. In addition to that, we have an ageing population; two-thirds of the health care dollar is spent on people aged over 60 years and they get pathology tests. So the Department is trying to cut down on the number of pathology tests being done by cutting down on the number of collection centres. It is trying to stop the waves like King Canute. It will occur, whether the Minister, the Department or anybody else in Australia likes it. Science is advancing all the time; diseases are being conquered and new diseases are developing. That will continue, and yet the Minister seeks to cut the number of collection centres.

I have waited until 1 o'clock in the morning to give the Minister this bit of knowledge. The departmental officers can put their pens to paper and write as hard as they like, but they will not stop the ageing of the population, the increasing number of people in the population who will have pathology tests, or the scientific advances.

The Government, with its sinking stinking corrupting Medicare, is trying to keep the sinking ship together by saying to the pathologists, `The cake is small and we will not get it any larger, despite these obvious demographic and scientific changes. The amount of money spent on pathology will not increase'. In the last five years we have seen the Medicare levy proportion of health care decrease from 25 per cent of government expenditure to 18 per cent. That is why the Government is trying to cut the pathology costs. Because the amount of money coming in is decreasing, it is trying to find the money out of revenue. We have the greatest recession that we have had in 60 years—a depression—because the taxation revenue is not coming in and the cake is getting smaller. So the Government is trying to control it by controlling things like pathology. That is what is occurring at the moment.

But the Minister should wake up to the fact that socialism has failed. It took 80 years for socialism to be proven to have failed in eastern Europe and Russia. That is what Medicare was based upon. It has taken 18 years for socialism to fail in relation to Medicare. The Government is trying to patch it together, stick it up with bandaids and stick it up other things too. It is trying to do that to the pathologists and other people within the community as well.

There are four great strands in society at the moment. There is the breakdown of socialism and the breakdown of governmental control which has been demonstrated in eastern Europe. The other strand that is emerging is the influence of the individual and the individual taking responsibility for his or her own health care. In our lifetimes we have seen the development of the naturopaths, herbalists, acupuncturists and whatever. People are wanting to go into those avenues. They are getting away from governmental control.

The third great strand which is occurring is the ageing of the population, as I have already mentioned; and the fourth is technology. Those strands are occurring throughout society and they are influencing health care as well. We have this demonstrated in the area of pathology, but there are many other examples as well. Yesterday in the other place the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, Mr Howe, said that 78 per cent of all GP attendances are billed at or below the schedule and 2.9 per cent of all GP attendances are billed at or above the AMA level. Therefore, Medicare is working and bulkbilling has nothing to do with it.

He did not say that there are more than four million pensioners, health care benefit cardholders, sickness benefit cardholders, health care cardholders and dependants in the community—nearly one quarter of the population. It has been traditional for the medical profession to bulkbill, or to charge them nothing above the rebate. It has always occurred; it has occurred since Hippocrates's days and it will occur in the future. That, of course, is part of our policy. Minister Howe did not say that two-thirds of health care expenditure is spent on people over the age of 60 years. They represent over 15 per cent of the population. He did not say that older people require more health care, and he did not say that more than 70 per cent of non-bulkbilled fees are already charged at close to AMA levels. It is the story of the big lie to patch up the stinking sinking ship of Medicare. It has to be paid for and, whether the Minister likes it or not, he will not do it via the direction in which he is heading with the changes he is trying to bring about.

It will be another patch-up next week. After pathology it will be radiology. The Government will get the radiologists; it will stick it up the radiologists next time. It has done the GPs, it is doing the pathologists and it has done the pharmacists. It just will not work because people will not accept it. They will throw the Government out at the next election because we have a policy which will cope with all of those things. It is all so simple, if those opposite could only see it. But they are stuck with their ideology and they cannot get away from it. I am delighted, because those opposite will be hung with their ideology.

Four things need to be done: we need to encourage private insurance with a rebate system and subsidies to lower income earners and increase the Medicare levy for those people who do not insure—something which the Government was not game to do even though it fits with its ideology. We should allow comprehensive medical and hospital insurance because it will cost people whether we like it or not. They should be allowed to insure. But the Government has made it illegal under Medicare. It will not let people insure themselves for medical expenses—socialism at its worst. The Government says, `We'll control it; the Government will do it for you. Lie back and enjoy it, because you will get it whether you like it or not'.

TALK.START.PARA: —You might have to wait in a long queue.

—But people might have to wait a long time. The third thing we will do is limit bulkbilling to health care and health benefit cardholders because they deserve it: the pensioners who do not have the ability to insure themselves, even though we will assist them. Finally, we will introduce co-payments for medical services because we do need a restriction and people will have to pay out of their pockets.

PARA.TAB: The principles are simple. They have been there all the time, but the Government was stuck with its ideology for 18 years. Good luck to it, because it will get stuck up the Government next time. In conclusion, I come to something which really summarises what the Minister is doing with this Bill. I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: We trained hard. . . but it seemed that every time we were beginning to form up into teams we would be reorganized. . . I was to learn later in life that we tend to meet any new situation by reorganizing; and a wonderful method it can be for creating the illusion of progress whilst producing confusion, inefficiency and demoralization.

That was written and said by Petronius in 65 AD. Those opposite have not learnt anything since that time. I support the amendment that has been proposed because only with that amendment is there an answer to the dilemma which the Government has got itself into. I am delighted to support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been provoked into speaking on this package of health insurance Bills because it involves a matter of clear policy difference between the Government and the Opposition. There is a clear policy difference between what is in the best interests of the Australian people and what this Government has proposed. As my Senate colleagues have said tonight, we again have a situation where this Government is not seeking to nationalise—it has given up the idea of maintaining the ownership and control of the private sector—but it has realised that it can control things better by basically imposing this sort of legislation. It has done it in terms of a taxation and regulation system on private business, whereby the manufacturing sector in Australia now only has control over between 25 per cent and 28 per cent of its input costs. The Government has been doing it to medicine through Medicare for many years now, it has done it to the pharmacists, and now it is seeking to do it to the pathologists.

PARA.TAB: It is important for the Senate to turn its mind to what would be the ideal system of pathology in an ideal world—the sort of world we will probably start moving towards after 1993, in Senator Walters's valedictory year, and a very successful year it will be. The ideal system is certainly not the sort of system that we are lurching towards at the moment; it is not a system that would limit the number of collection points for pathology. Individuals can now in a scientific way have easy access to pathology services. Because of the progress we have made, we can move to a system where the old adage of prevention being better than cure can be achieved. As a prerequisite to that we want a pathology system that is readily available to all people across Australia. That means wherever possible having pathology services in all the suburbs and towns.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you proposing a pathology-led recovery?

—There are a number of people around Australia who would agree with that, Senator Schacht. The second thing that we need if we are to have a sensible pathology services regime is a fair pricing system. Senator Patterson covered that topic very well. She said that if there are no price signals in the system, one will get overuse and overservicing. There is no doubt that there is some evidence of that in the system at the moment.

PARA.TAB: Bearing in mind what Senator Herron said, we know that some 10 years ago we did not have cholesterol testing. I know from my own family history that if we had had those sorts of services that number of years ago, probably many people would not have had heart disease or found it necessary to have bypass operations involving very expensive surgery. I think that most parliamentarians here in this building tonight will know that we have regular testing for cholesterol.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right. They have free testing here in this building.

—Yes, with that sort of testing it allows parliamentarians as a specific group of people to be screened. It refers back to the point made by Senator Harradine relating to the late Senator Greenwood. With that sort of pathology service readily available, sending signals to patients at a fair price, we can ensure that medical service costs generally can be reduced because prevention is better than cure. The essence of a good pathology services system is to ensure that in the long term the benefits of early detection can reduce wasteful expenditure on other medical services and hospitals. What has this Government done? Its solution is to cut the number of collection centres. This is a Government that talks about providing medical services to the masses, to whoever needs them, but here they are seeking to restrict the access in a physical and practical way to those who need them.

PARA.TAB: The other point about this Government's progress with Medicare, pathology, pharmaceuticals and medicine generally is the fact that this Government wishes to have more control over these things. We heard the Democrats via Senator Lees tonight say that the solution is not to go towards more private insurance, which will send price signals to the market in a very fair way so that our policy will allow people to insure for all these medical costs. Senator Lees would like to see us go towards more public provision of pathology services, with of course more control. It is clear from the Democrats' policies and from Senator Spindler's alternative budget—God help Australia!—that they believe in more public provision. It is quite clear from evidence around the world in the provision of any sort of service that if there is a difference between a public provision and a private provision, when the private sector does this in a competitive environment there are cost savings of between 10 to 25 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't exist in health care and you know it. If you don't, you should sit down.

—Senator Crowley, with a fair pricing mechanism there will always be those savings. I would like Senator Lees to take back to Senator Spindler when he is preparing his next alternative budget that increased public provision is certainly not the way to go. It will increase the number of inefficiencies in the system. It will ensure that in health terms limited resources are not directed to where they are most needed. I put it to both the Government and to the Democrats that increasing public control over this industry is not the way to go.

PARA.TAB: I wish to give two important examples to the Australian community of where pricing systems are so important. Two simple examples are the provision of water and the provision of air. People always thought that air and water could be provided for free. We have seen only today what happens when something is given away, where there is no pricing system. The water system in this country has been raped through stupid irrigation schemes and pollution from non-point sources by increasing the nutrients going into rivers. We saw on television tonight and have read about it in the papers the algal bloom which has broken out in Australia's once great rivers. It is only in recent times that we have seen the abuse of air—and I know that Senator Vallentine will be interested in this—because there is no pricing system. Air has been abused by the Western nations through pollution, and only now are we are realising the true cost of air pollution and the abuse of this other commodity where there is no pricing system.

I have used that important example of pricing systems to point to what is involved in this debate. In Australia in the past eight years we have seen a massive change involving people who provided for their own health needs moving to public provision. It has resulted in a decrease in the number of people who are privately insured. Fightback! and the coalition's health policy, which Senator Herron and a number of other Liberal senators helped put together, clearly moves health provision towards private provision. As Senator Herron said, we give incentives to low income earners through rebates to provide for their own insurance. We ensure that all people will be able to insure for their own medical costs—they are not banned from doing so as they are by this current socialist government. We will ensure that high income earners who bludge off the current system and who do not take out private insurance are given a stick to go out and get that insurance.

With those few words I encourage the Senate, and particularly the Australian Democrats, to consider our amendment embracing the coalition's sensible policy on health provisions. I ask them to support Senator Patterson's sensible amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under the Health Insurance (Pathology) Amendment (No. 2) Bill the Government intends to reduce the number of pathology collection centres. This is an interesting concept coming from a Government which has had much difficulty with its health policy, as we have seen in the past. It has come from a Government that has generated enormous queues and long waiting lists in public hospitals. We now see this Government's great exercise in fiscal restraint. How does it intend to exercise such restraint? How will it exercise good management in the health system? The answer is very simple. It will do so by cutting the number of pathology collection centres. It is quite extraordinary.
—If you don't like the message, shoot the messenger.

—Exactly, as Senator Herron says, if we don't like the message let us shoot the messenger. Instead of coming up with a solution to this country's health dilemma this Government finally, at the end of its dogmatic tenure, has decided that the only way it can exercise any restraint, any decent management or pretend to exercise any management of the health system is to cut the number of pathology collection centres.

PARA.TAB: I would like to address this Government and its problem. I recently received in the mail a copy of a letter sent by the Health Insurance Commission to a doctor in Townsville. We all know that members of this Government have often had the belief in their heads that there has been—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do they have any beliefs?

—Members of this Government do not get many beliefs in their heads and I suppose we have to give them credit for any that they have. They have long had the belief that their supposed extension of pathology services is a grave threat to the country. What are they going to do? They are going to send their thought police out. Coming from a Government with no brains, the idea of it sending out thought police is quite incredible. Based on the returns from those medical practitioners the Government is going to send them threatening letters. I would like to take the opportunity to read from this letter because this one is great.
—Who signed it?
—I will get on to who signed it in a minute. The letter says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Health Insurance Commission has been criticised for its lack of feedback to practitioners on benefit claiming patterns.
In Medicare Forum (September 1990) an article "Pathology Under the Microscope" revealed that $335m of $510m in pathology costs were initiated by general practitioners

The total cost of pathology tests continues to attract the attention of government and it is hoped that the data such as that shown below will provide the profession with an opportunity to consider cost effectiveness and clinical necessity in pathology ordering. This information strategy is directed towards all GPs who ordered more than a nominal amount of pathology and who were active in practice in the last quarter of the financial year 1990/91.

During the year, 1783 patients claimed Medicare benefits for services provided by you. In the same period, 807 of these patients claimed for a total of 2140 pathology services. The cost of these services to Medicare was $55,450. Most GPs in your State order between $18,152 and $49,495 (modal range).
The five tests generating the greatest Medicare benefit from your practice during the year were . . . PAP smear $6,797.

Here we have the Government with outspoken senators—and Senator Crowley certainly was outspoken tonight—who say that not enough is being done for women's health care and, at the same time, we have the Health Insurance Commission carrying out the directives of this Government that sets its thought police onto doctors to try to ensure that there is a decrease in PAP smear tests.

PARA.TAB: This is the same Government that gave its equal opportunity and equity and access strategies millions of taxpayers' dollars encouraging women to have PAP smear tests and what does it do? As soon as the doctors send off PAP smear tests it sends around its thought police. The letter goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: FBE $5,727 . . . Thyroid Function $5,528 . . . Histopath $5,324.

TALK.START.PARA: —They say all specimens need to be examined.

—I note that interjection because this is the same Government which, a few years ago, said that all specimens should go under the microscope. Here are the doctors trying to carry out the direction from this centralist government and as soon as they do, the thought police are set on them.

PARA.TAB: That is the way this Government will work. All I can say is that here we have a Government which is in total disarray. It has no health care policy, no strategy, no vision for the future. Instead, it goes round and round. I will get to the point of Senator Kemp's earlier interjection. Where does the Senate think this letter came from? Who do honourable senators think signed this letter?

TALK.START.PARA: —Was it signed by Senator Crowley?

—No, it was not, but it was signed by someone almost as far away from Townsville as Senator Crowley. It was signed by somebody here in Canberra. This is a typical centralist, socialist policy of this Government, and it has failed.
—Tired.

—It is a tired government. It is a socialist government. What has happened to other socialist governments around the world? They have failed miserably. Just as the Russians were told that the shortages would be divided equally amongst the peasants, so too, in this country under this Government's health policy the shortage of decent health care will be divided equally amongst the patients. All I say in conclusion is that I hope I am not one of the patients under this Government's health policy.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am just a casual observer who has learned that the Opposition and Democrats support this piece of legislation. I wish to express my gratitude to those who have spoken in support of this particular piece of legislation this evening.
—I raise a point of order. The Minister has indicated that we are supporting this legislation. We have an amendment, which he has ignored.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! I do not think this is a point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage of the evening I am not going to try to deal with those tempting asides from Senator Herron. According to Senator Patterson, the people who provide our health and medical services in this country should go back to the mid-eighteenth century in the United States, I think it was.

PARA.TAB: I simply note that the Government has no intention of creating a situation where the provision of pathology services to those who require them is in any way impeded or reduced in the community. It is very important that that sort of technological and scientific advance and supplement be available to a general practitioner in trying to diagnose what might be wrong with a patient who presents at the surgery with those sorts of tests which ought to be carried out.

So far as disease prevention diagnosis is concerned, it is quite right for Senator Herron to point to the necessity for those sorts of tests and the increasing need for them. With the growing sophistication and availability of those tests there will be a great number of them required. There is no doubt that there are inefficiencies in the provision of pathology services. There is evidence which was acknowledged by Senator Patterson and Senator Lees in their contributions where they indicated that they agreed with observations of, I think, a parliamentary accounts committee which pointed in the direction of over provision of pathology services.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't qualify it. I said `may'.

—But it was sufficient to allow Senator Patterson to support the general thrust of this particular Bill. The general principles underlying this Bill were made clear to the chamber in the second reading speech. It is the undertaking I gave to Senator Patterson earlier today to generate for the benefit of the Senate the formula for determination of the number of licence collection centres. This formula was agreed by the pathology advisory committee at its meeting on 26 November 1991 as a basis for the Minister's determination under clauses 23D and B6 and 23D and B5 of the Pathology Amendment (No. 2) Bill.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators will be aware that the Pathology Advisory Committee consists of representatives from the Royal Australasian College of Pathologists, the Australian Association of Pathology Practice, the Health Insurance Commission and the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. I table that document.

The ministerial determinations for the allocation of licences for specimen collection centres required by proposed new sections 23D, 23B and 23C will be tabled by 11 December 1991. Honourable senators will recall that those determinations will be disallowable. I thank those senators who have indicated their support for the Bill. The Government will not be accepting the second reading amendment moved by the Opposition.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Patterson's) be agreed to
Question so resolved in the negative.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that there is general agreement concerning these amendments. I will briefly outline the scope of the amendments.

PARA.TAB: The two amendments to the Bill and two to the principal Act are necessary to allow the Health Insurance Commission to more efficiently administer the issuing of undertakings for approved pathology authorities and approved pathology practitioners. The amendments will prevent the possibility of medical benefits not being payable in the period between an undertaking being approved and receipt of the fee. They will also allow for the continuation of the previous undertaking when a new undertaking is accepted. The further two amendments relate to the correction of minor translations of the amendments into the principal Act in relation to accredited pathology laboratories. They are the amendments to the Health Insurance (Pathology) Amendment Bill 1991.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are supporting the amendments, but it should be on record that the unit cost of pathology has actually decreased. That has not been recorded within this Bill. In other words, the cost of performing each individual pathology item has decreased in the last 10 years because of technology.

PARA.TAB: The other point I wish to bring to the attention of the House is that I asked in Question Time: do doctors who bulkbill order more pathology tests than those who do not? I have not yet got a satisfactory answer. I know that I got an answer; I have had all sorts of devious answers. The Minister knows and the Department knows that doctors who bulkbill order more pathology tests, but will they admit it? They will not admit it. They skid around and say that it cannot be done because it is done on postcodes; it is not done on individual doctors. They know; I know; the computer people know. It is about time that Government members got up and admitted the truth, because it is reality.

One of the other reasons I did not mention previously in relation to the increase in the number of pathology services is bulkbilling. Until that is eliminated, it is another item that is going to cause it to increase. Again, the Government is not prepared to do anything about that because it is another article of faith of Senator Schacht's socialism. It is another article of faith that belongs to the Medicare system. Senator Faulkner is another who subscribes. Proud socialists all, may they rest in peace after 1993. Because Government members are stuck with that, they are hoist on their own petard. It is not going to change, and I think that point should be noted too. The combination of bulkbilling, technology, ageing population, increasing science and the fact that unit pathology costs are going down is further evidence that these Bills will not achieve their objective. It is a pious hope of the Government and the Department.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: The first amendment removes the restriction of no Medicare benefits being payable where a specimen is collected from an in-patient of a private hospital or day hospital facility by an employee, that is, a nurse or doctor of the hospital. As this occurs in most small to medium sized private hospitals, it is necessary for the legislation to allow Medicare benefits to be payable under these circumstances.

PARA.TAB: The second amendment relates to the referral of specimens from one pathologist to another. This occurs when a laboratory has been requested to do a specialised test that it does not perform and sends the specimen to another laboratory to be tested. The amendment allows Medicare benefits to be paid to the referred laboratory where the requesting laboratory collects the specimen.

The third amendment relates to the collection of specimens by a GP. The legislation needs to provide for the collection of a specimen by a GP or on his or her behalf where the patient does not come to the surgery. This is particularly relevant in rural and remote areas or where a GP attends an accident and several specimens may need to be collected urgently.

A fourth amendment further strengthens the legislation in relation to eligibility for collection centre licences. The intent is to restrict eligibility for collection centre licences to the private sector. If the public sector is allowed to establish licensed collection centres, Medicare benefits will be payable for specimens collected in those centres. This will result in the public sector being reimbursed for services for which Commonwealth funding is already provided by hospital funding grants.

The amendments will not vary the financial impact of the reforms. However, if the amendments are not incorporated into the legislation, there is the possibility of savings being eroded as a result of the loopholes being exploited. I commend the amendments to the Committee.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 23 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Why are 196 departmental staff from the Strategic and Intelligence Program of the Program Performance Statements paid from trust accounts and what is the total amount paid.
(2) Why are 139 departmental staff from the Acquisition and Logistics Program of the Program Performance Statements paid from trust accounts and what is the total amount paid.
(3) How are the trust accounts funded.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The staff from the Strategy and Intelligence Program paid from trust accounts comprise the staff of the Defence Support Centre Woomera (DSCW). The DSCW exists to provide residential, municipal, financial and other support to the Joint Defence Facility Nurrungar and the Woomera Range.

Under agreements between the Government of Australia and the Government of the United States of America, the costs of DSCW are shared between the Australian Department of Defence and the United States Air Force. The estimated salary expenditure for 1991-92 for these personnel is $6.056m. Australia's share of this is about 60 per cent.

(2) The staff from the Acquisition and Logistics Program paid from trust accounts comprise persons employed at the Albion Explosives Factory (AEF), Explosives Factory Maribyrnong (EFM), Longlea Explosives Depot and the Point Wilson Explosives Area. Payment is made through the EFM Trust Account which was established to provide for the management of these establishments.

When Australian Defence Industries (ADI) was established in May 1989, AEF and EFM were not transferred from the Defence Organisation to ADI because a decision had already been made by the Government to close them. The EFM Trust Account has remained open as production at EFM has only just been completed.

Both AEF and EFM will remain under the control of the Acquisition and Logistics Program until they are disposed of. The Trust Account is planned to close at the end of 1991-92. Responsibility for the Point Wilson and Longlea establishments, which have been administered from EFM for many years, are planned to be transferred elsewhere in the Department during 1991-92.
The estimated salary expenditure in 1991-92 for the personnel at these four facilities is $4.800m.

(3) The Department of Defence and the United States Air Force both contribute to the DSCW Trust Account. Australia's share is paid from the Parliamentary Appropriations under Item 230/02/05 entitled 'Australian Contributions to the DSCW'.

When the EFM Trust Account was opened, it was provided with a working capital advance from Parliamentary Appropriations. The main source, of income, however, has been receipts from the sale of products to the Australian Defence Force and commercial customers from which all operational expenditure was paid. With the planned closure of EFM, working capital advances have been repaid.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 11 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) In respect of the field strength safety guidelines adopted for the Jindalee over-the-horizon radar project, what is the quantitative difference between the levels mandated by AS 2772.1-1990 and the European IRPA guidelines.
(2) What was the reason for Professor Huey, in his final report, recommending an additional six decibel margin in field strength over that contained in AS 2772.1-1990.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) In general, the IRPA guidelines are more stringent than the Australian standards, as can be seen by the following non-occupational exposure level chart. The quantitative differences between the maximum non-occupational exposure levels mandated by AS 2772.1-1990 and the IRPA European guidelines are shown for a cross section of frequencies from within the Jindalee operating frequency band. The units are Volts per Metre (V/M), Amps per Metre (A/M) and milliwatts per square centimetre (mW/cm2):

TAB.TAB: AS 2772.l IRPA

PARA.TAB: In all cases the Department of Defence has used the more stringent standard in relation to non-ionising field strengths.

(2) The effect of reflections from electrically conductive objects, such as buildings, fences, power lines and towers near the transmitting station can have a local effect upon the field strength. Under worst case conditions (very near the reflecting object) the field strength may be doubled, and under other quite different conditions, the field strength may be reduced to a very small value.

ANSWER.PARA: Because reinforcement of signals by reflections occurs only very close to the reflecting object, the likelihood of an increase of more than 6 dB is extremely remote. Nevertheless, to accommodate this effect and to be conservative, Professor Huey recommended the additional 6 decibel margin. As the Department of Defence has adopted the more stringent IRPA guidelines and there were no substantial reflecting structures within three kilometres of the transmitting site Professor Huey agreed that the additional margin was not necessary.
